Title: Wild Karnataka to be screened at the UN headquarters on World Wildlife Day
Content: One of the films that got everyone to sit up and take notice of Karnataka’s bio-diversity last year was Wild Karnataka . The film will now be screened at the United National headquarters on World Wildlife Day , which is on March 3. Directed by Amoghavarsha JS and Kalyan Varma, Ricky Kej has worked on the music. Sir David Attenborough ’s commentary is one of the highlights of this film which also saw a one-of-its-kind theatrical release.“The UN Environment Programme is being kind enough to host this event, where they will screen our film and also have a panel discussion with Amoghavarsha and me,” says Ricky, who is an ambassador for various UN organisations working for the environment.Ricky adds that the show will not just have some of the big delegates from the UN, but there will be space for a few lucky members of the public who will get to experience being in the headquarters.Wild Karnataka captures the rich bio-diversity of Karnataka, especially in the Western Ghats , wherein a bunch of wildlife lensmen led by Amoghavarsha and Kalyan Varma have recorded rare animal behaviours. From otters chasing tigers and dancing frogs to drone footage of elephants and tigers, it provides an educational and entertaining experience.

Title: Upendra's dance inspires name for a species of dancing frogs
Content: We often hear of fans idolising film stars so much that they tend to name their children after them. Illustrator Rohan Chakravarty and researcher and scholar Madhushri Mudke, have named a rare species of dancing frogs Kappendra — after Kannada’s Real star Upendra . Find out why…The endangered species of dancing frogs — commonly known as the Kottigehar Dancing Frogs are also referred to as the true Kannadigas, owing to the fact that they are found only along the Western Ghats within Karnataka . “The species is endemic to the Western Ghats in our state and is found in primary streams and Myristica swamps (a type of freshwater swamp forest which are only found along the Western Ghats),” explains Madhushri. Since the species is now on the brink of extinction, Madhushri and her team have been studying the species and their habitats for over a year to understand how they can be protected.When illustrator Rohan, who was roped in to create posters to spread awareness of this species, spent time observing the species, he was reminded of a song from one of Upendra’s films — MTV Subbalakshmi ge. “These are a species of frogs that grow and live exclusively in Karnataka. They are also dancing frogs — and the only star that one can think of as far as great dance moves are concerned, is Upendra. The name Kappendra was therefore inspired by Upendra’s moves in that song. Though, he is not aware that we were inspired by him at all,” explains Rohan.This particular species of frogs live in areas with high background music (created from flowing water). They use visual signalling which involves alternate movements of their hind limbs to attract mates and show their presence in a particular territory, and in doing so, they look like they are dancing.EDGE species refers to animals that are Evolutionarily Distinct and Globally Endangered (hence EDGE). And, sadly this beautiful amphibian is now an edge species. "They do require a special habitat for breeding. And, One of the requirements for this amphibian is that it requires canopy cover and if there is no canopy cover, then with direct sunlight falling on the swamps might disturb their habitat. And, not just that temperature rise, polluted water streams, human disturbance affect their habitats and you cannot find them in such places. These are the reasons why we can't see them along the Ghats that much as they prefer less disturbed habitats." On being asked whether global warming is one of the reasons for the shrinking numbers, she adds, "To understand the impact of global warming on any species, we need years of study and data which we do not have in this case. But, yes globally, there is a decline in the amphibian population because of Global Warming."Name of the species: Micrixalus KottigeharensisWhere they are found: Along the Western GhatsUnique trait: Their croak is rather feeble, so they depend on visual signalling which is also calledfoot-flagging— Inputs from Madhushri MudkeIn 2014, a team of researchers studied the diversity of frogs that belonged to the Micrixalidae family. They found 24 species of dancing frogs along the Western Ghats alone. The size of these dancing frogs (males) ranged from 1.46 to 2.88cm; with the Sali’s Dancing Frog being the smallest and the Kalakkad Dancing Frog being the largest. The Kottigehar Dancing Frog is among the larger members of this family, with the male measuring around 2.29cm.— Study done by Biju et al

Title: Yogaraj Bhat pens a special song on exam tension for Gaalipata sequel
Content: Trust director-writer Yogaraj Bhat to write a song that really strikes a chord. In the recent past, Yogaraj has taken a detour from the standard song-writing practices to come up with numbers about the elections and GST, among others. This time around, he has chosen a subject that most parents and students can relate to — exam tension. Ramesh Reddy, who is backing Gaalipata 2, that stars Ganesh, Diganth and Pawan Kumar , reveals that Arjun Janya and Yogaraj will work together for the first time for this song that has been titled Pareekshe Na Badiya. “For everyone, right from an average student or a rank holder or even a 55-year-old who has long finished writing his exams, there is always this anxiety surrounding exams. I really don’t know who was the person who first came up with the concept of examinations, but that word evokes similar emotions in almost all people. This song will explore this exact feeling and I’m sure it is going to be popular with both youngsters and elders alike,” explains Yogaraj.

Title: Viraat and Sanjana Anand to star in Adhuri Lover
Content: After their first outing with Kiss, director AP Arjun and actor Viraat are teaming up for yet another film. However, this time around, it is newbie Bharath Raghavendra who will direct Viraat in this film that is being backed by Arjun. Arjun had recently released a poster with a silhouette of a person to announce the title — Adhuri Lover . Confirming that Viraat is, in fact, playing the lead role, he says, “This is a fun film that will cater to the youth. We are looking at kickstarting the project by the end of this month.”For this role, Viraat is apparently working on a makeover of sorts. “I’ve been sporting a lean frame until now. But for this film, I am required to bulk up. I play an interesting character , who will do anything for love. It is one that youngsters will connect with. In a way, it adds to the image that people have of me after my last film. It offers me the opportunity to explore and work on the mass appeal that comes with playing such a character,” he says.Meanwhile, Arjun also adds that he has chosen Sanjana Anand to be the leading lady for the film, as she fits into the girl-next-door character to the T. “She fits the bill for the character we have and we believe in her acting abilities. Virat and Sanjana will be an interesting pair to watch out for,” he adds.

Title: When Bengaluru was treated to an evening of Indo-Korean music
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

In a day and age when Gen Now is lapping up all things Korean, be it pop music, beauty products and trends, TV dramas, cinema, etc., it comes as no surprise that the city played host to a performance that was a mix of Indian classical music, traditional Korean music and contemporary dance. Called Same Same But Different , the event was organised by the InKo Centre, as part of their annual Indo-Korean performance series that attempts to put the spotlight on their cultural diversity. The title of the performance, for instance, was meant to denote the similarities between Indian and Korean cultures, especially in music.

This time around, they had Korean new wave music group Noreum Machi, Indian classical ensemble Trayam (consisting of vocalist and flautist Varijashree Venugopal , percussionists Manjunath and Praveen D Rao) and Padma Shri awardee and dancer-choreographer Astad Deboo.

“When the idea of this collaboration was pitched to me, I found the combination of music very interesting. The amalgamation of the beats is so unique and different that I knew that I wanted to contribute to this collaboration,” says Astad.

When asked about her experience of working with such a diverse group of artistes, Varijashree says, “The process was enriching and educational. We had performed together last year as well. We got to learn a lot about Korean culture and music through this performance and I was very impressed with the way we brought our music together. Korean music includes a wide range of instruments, some being slightly similar to ours, my personal favourite being piri, which sounds a little like the shenai. Teaching each other the little intricacies of our music was what made this performance really special.”

Title: TV show Jothe Jotheyalli inspires viewers to segregate waste
Content: The makers of the Kannada TV show Jothe Jotheyalli are setting an example of sorts. A twist in the tale, which is based on the love story of a 20-year-old girl Anu ( Megha Shetty ) and 45-year-old businessman Aryavardhan (Aniruddha Jatkar), touched upon the relevance of segregating waste at source to tackle the growing garbage menace in urban areas. What’s interesting to note is that watching this on air has had its impact on its viewers — as people across Karnataka have apparently adopted the practice. Confirming the same was a message from Mythri, an environmental engineer at the Mysuru City Corporation , to the lead actor of the show – Aniruddha . The corporation informed that the number of people who were mixing dry and wet waste has reduced by 20% ever since the show created awareness on waste segregation and management. Jagadish Arooru, the director of the TV show, tells us, “Every day, a huge quantum of waste is being generated, but there is no place to dump this. It is carried to landfills, where they segregate the waste, and that is a herculean task. Despite waste segregation at source being made mandatory, very few have actually been doing it. So we thought we should do our bit by including the idea of waste segregation as part of our show, which has proved fruitful.”The director adds that the TV show will also shed more light on the ways of making money from waste. “In the coming episodes, we will show how waste can be treated as manure, and, therefore, does not have to be disposed outside,” says the director.Buoyed by the response from the people, lead actor Aniruddha says, “We are glad that our show is changing the way people think about throwing garbage. TV shows are not just about entertainment alone, they can also be used as a tool to bring in change.”

Title: Rajinikanth's Annaatthe heads to Pune and Kolkata next
Content: Siva’s #Thalaivar168 now has a name! The family entertainer, which stars Rajinikanth in the lead, has been titled Annaatthe , and the makers announced the same by releasing a motion teaser on Monday.“Annaatthe is a Madras slang, and it means ‘brother’. Rajini has used the word in some of his earlier films,” a source says, “The team is presently shooting in Hyderabad and will be back in Chennai after March 1. And then, they will commence the next schedule either from mid-March or April. Though the shooting location is yet to be finalised, they are looking at Pune and Kolkata.”The film also stars Meena, Khushbu, Nayanthara, Keerthy Suresh, Prakash Raj, Soori and Sathish, and has music by Imman. This is the first time that both Siva and Imman are teaming up with Superstar.

Title: Team Aranmanai 3 shoots in a real aranmanai in Rajkot
Content: Not one to bow out of a social media battle, Kangana Ranaut claimed that she was the first "in the history of Hindi cinema" to bring “Maratha Pride”. She went on to claim that she put her life and career on the line in an “Islam dominate industry” to make a film on Shivaji Maharaj and Rani Laxmibai.

Title: Did 'Bigg Boss 13's Mahira Sharma lie about winning an award or was it a miscommunication?
Content: It’s not even a fortnight since 'Bigg Boss 13' came to an end and one of the contestants, TV actress Mahira Sharma already finds herself in the middle of a controversy. The organisers of Dadasaheb Phalke International Film Festival (DPIFF) have refuted her claims on her Instagram story that she received a certificate of appreciation for being the ‘Most Fashionable Contestant’ on the recently concluded reality show. They also issued an official statement on their Instagram stating that though she attended the ceremony, no such award was given to her. The organisers had sent the actress a notice asking her to take down all the misleading posts and demanded a written apology.Mahira issued a statement on Monday which read: “This is with regards to the statement issued by the social media team of Dadasaheb Phalke International Film Festival 2020. I would like to inform that the charges made against me for receiving and forging the award is untrue and totally uncalled for. In my defence, I would like to clarify with exact details on what happened that day.On Thursday, Feb 20, 2020, I was invited for the reputed Dadasaheb Phalke International Film Festival by Premal Mehta of Purple Fox Media along with Yash Naik, who is an artiste manager for the said award show. They informed us that they have been associated with Dadasaheb Awards for the past two years. My manager Abhinav Tanwar was informed by Mr Mehta that we will be gratified at the event with the title of ‘Most Fashionable Bigg Boss 13 contestant’. At the event, the team of Bigg Boss 13 was called on stage and gratified with a token of appreciation. On questioning about my solo award by my manager to Mr Mehta, he handed over the award to my manager stating that I cannot be called on stage owing to the huge hue and rush on stage. I did my media bytes at the event and later had put a social media story (on my personal Instagram account) to express my love and gratitude. Little did I know that this would turn against me within two days. Since Sunday night I was told that there has been some miscommunication and will be rectified as soon as possible.I would like to inform that I did not forge any award and would never intend to do so. The managing team of Premal Mehta and Yash Naik have taken the onus of this fiasco completely and have stated that I had nothing to do with it. For everyone’s clarity, I am attaching the mail signed by them which was sent to Dadasaheb Phalke International Film Festival 2020 management today morning. Also to add, I have all the required proofs and chats on me to prove myself not guilty. Post an amazing stint with Bigg Boss and having made it to the top seven list, I surely am not intending to look for any PR gimmick of this sort. In the wake of this scenario I would request the managing team of Dadasaheb Phalke International Film Festival 2020, to please look into the matter.”Following Mahira’s post, the authorities of DPIFF responded with an open letter saying, “To address Ms Mahira Sharma’s latest response on the forged DPIFF certification, it is really unappreciated that she still claims that the award has not been forged and is unapologetic about the same.We believe that being the only official authority of DPIFF award functions, we are in charge of confirming the authority of our awards and certificates. This, however, is unfortunately still unclear to Ms Mahira Sharma. Even now we are looking for an amicable resolution in this regard through an apology which we have asked for Ms Mahira Sharma to post. Even though she has called this incident to be ‘untrue’ we still stand by our claims in this matter and expect her to to share an apology. We shall be patiently waiting for the same.”So will Mahira issue an apology? Let’s wait and see...

Title: Germany Accident: Around 60 people were injured when car drove into German carnival
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

BERLIN: Around 60 people were injured when a car ploughed into a carnival parade in the German town of Volkmarsen , a police spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

Local news programme Hessenschau had first cited that number from police .

The police spokeswoman could not say how many of the victims were seriously injured. She said there had been no deaths due to the incident.

Thanks so much bade bhaiya I promise to improve. Much love. Kabir. https://t.co/kIkGwI0kEz — Shahid Kapoor (@shahidkapoor) 1582654231000

Title: Harvey Weinstein Case: Harvey Weinstein stays at hospital for 'chest pain' a day after his sexual assault conviction
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

NEW YORK: Former movie producer Harvey Weinstein was receiving medical attention for chest pain at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan on Tuesday, his spokesman said, a day after a New York jury convicted him of sexual assault and rape in a stunning victory for the #MeToo movement.

Once one of Hollywood's most influential producers, Weinstein , 67, was found guilty on Monday of sexually assaulting former production assistant Mimi Haleyi in 2006 and raping Jessica Mann , a onetime aspiring actress, in 2013.

More than 80 women have accused Weinstein of sexual assault, and Weinstein has denied all of the accusations and said any sexual encounters were consensual. The allegations helped fuel the #MeToo movement on social media in 2017, which inspired more women to publicly accuse powerful men of misconduct.

Juda Engelmayer , a spokesman for Weinstein , said on Monday that the onetime movie mogul was taken to Bellevue Hospital, which has a unit that provides medical care for jail inmates, after he was led away from court in handcuffs. If not for his medical concerns, the former producer would have gone to New York City's Rikers Island jail complex.

Weinstein remained in the hospital on Tuesday as a "precautionary measure" because he had complained of chest pain, and he was expecting a visit from his legal team later in the day, Engelmayer said on Tuesday.

After the verdict on Monday Arthur Aidala, one of Weinstein 's lawyers, quoted his client as saying, "I’m innocent. I’m innocent. How can this happen in America ?"

His sentencing hearing was set for March 11. The attorney vowed to appeal.

Weinstein , who produced acclaimed films like "The English Patient" and "Shakespeare in Love," faces up to 25 years in prison on the sexual assault conviction. He was also convicted of third degree rape - sexual intercourse without consent - which carries a prison sentence of up to four years.

The jury of seven men and five women acquitted Weinstein on the most serious charges, which carried a potential life sentence.

A statement from the leaders of the #MeToo movement said: "The jury worked with an incredibly narrow and unjust set of laws governing sexual assault, and though he was not convicted on all counts, Harvey Weinstein will have to answer for his crimes."

A long legal battle in the appeals courts is likely to ensue. At the start of the trial, defense lawyers accused the judge of bias, the prosecutors of withholding evidence, and the media of turning the trial into a circus.

Weinstein still faces sexual assault charges in California, which were announced just hours after his New York trial began on Jan. 6. Dozens of women have also filed civil lawsuits against him.

"Just seeing someone so powerful taken down and being held accountable for his action - is a huge moment," Dawn Dunning , an actress-turned-costume designer who testified against Weinstein , told CNN on Tuesday. "I don't look at this as the end of a trial, it's the beginning of something bigger."

Title: New-age sat Gisat-1 that can constantly watch India to be launched on March 5
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Isro is set to launch a new-age geo-imaging satellite Gisat-1 from Sriharikota on March 5.

NEW DELHI: Indian Space Research Organisation ( Isro ) is set to launch a new-age geo-imaging satellite Gisat-1 from Sriharikota on March 5 with the capability to perform real-time and constant watch of the Indian subcontinent.

GSLV-F10 rocket will launch Gisat-1 from the second launchpad at 5.43 pm, subject to weather conditions.

Weighing 2,275 kg, Gisat-1 is a state-of-the-art agile earth observation satellite that will be placed in a geosynchronous transfer orbit at 36,000km altitude. Operating from the geostationary orbit, Gisat-1 will facilitate near real-time observation of the Indian subcontinent, under cloud-free condition, at frequent intervals. Gisat-1 will apparently be in a fixed spot looking over the Indian continent at all times.

“Gisat-1 will do a full rotation of the Earth and come to the same point after every 2 hours. It is really good for fast imaging of the Earth and can perform constant and rapid surveillance. If needed, the satellite can observe a point for a longer duration,” says a source in Isro. This will be the first satellite launch of this year from Indian soil.

A 4-metre diameter Ogive-shaped payload fairing is being flown for the first time in this GSLV flight. This is the 14th flight of the GSLV.

In all, Isro will launch an unprecedented 10 earth observation satellites with space surveillance feature during 2020-21 in order to boost the country’s space surveillance power in order to strengthen border security and check terrorist infiltration.

Title: Placido Domingo apologizes after union finds he sexually harassed women
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

NEW YORK: Opera singer Placido Domingo apologized to the women who have accused him of sexual harassment on Tuesday after an investigation by the American Guild of Musical Artists concluded he had behaved inappropriately with female performers.

One of the most feted and powerful opera stars of the modern era, Domingo said in a statement he had spent several months reflecting on the allegations made by his musical colleagues.

"I respect that these women finally felt comfortable enough to speak out, and I want them to know that I am truly sorry for the hurt that I caused them," he said.

More than three dozen singers, dancers, musicians, voice teachers and backstage staff have said they witnessed or experienced inappropriate behaviour by the 79-year-old Spanish singer towards women at different opera houses over the last three decades.

A former prosecutor was hired to investigate the complaints last September by the American Guild of Musical Artists (AGMA), the labor union that represents performers and producers in opera houses and concert halls across the United States.

The union , of which Domingo is a member, announced its findings on Tuesday.

"The investigation concluded that Mr. Domingo had, in fact, engaged in ?inappropriate activity, ranging from flirtation to sexual advances, in and outside of the workplace," the statement said. "Many of the witnesses expressed fear of retaliation in the industry as their reason for not coming forward sooner."

Domingo said in his statement he now understood the women 's fear.

"While that was never my intention, no one should ever be made to feel that way," he said. "I am committed to affecting positive change in the opera industry so that no one else has to have that same experience."

The union declined to make public its full report. Its board of governors will take "appropriate action," the union statement said. Union spokeswoman Alicia Cook declined to discuss what action it would take regarding Domingo.

Domingo had disputed the allegations when they were first reported by the Associated Press (AP) last year, forcing him to sever ties with some of the foremost musical institutions in the United States.

Women told the AP that Domingo, who is married, forced wet kisses on them, groped them and sought to pressure them into meeting him privately outside work for sex. They described it as a pattern of behavior stretching back to the 1980s that had long been an open secret in the opera world.

Following the report, Domingo resigned as general manager of the Los Angeles Opera and pulled out of performing the title role in Verdi's "Macbeth" at the Metropolitan Opera in New York .

LA Opera said it would comment once officials there had finished reviewing the union 's findings. The Met did not respond to a request for comment.

The allegations had less of an impact on his career in Europe, and he was still due to sing and conduct at performances in Vienna, Madrid, London, Moscow and Hamburg in the coming months, according to his website.

The Teatro Real in Madrid and the Royal Opera House in London confirmed that Domingo would still appear on their stages for "La Traviata" and "Don Carlo" this year. Milan's Teatro alla Scala, where Domingo is scheduled to sing in "La Traviata" in November, declined to comment.

The Hamburg State Opera , where Domingo is booked to sing in March, said it took the complaints about Domingo "very seriously." Michael Bellgardt, a spokesman for the opera house, said his colleagues "will also exchange information with the other institutions in Europe and then go public."

As one of the Three Tenors singing group, Domingo, Jose Carreras and the late Luciano Pavarotti helped bring opera to a wider audience with concerts around the world in the 1990s. Domingo took to singing baritone roles later in his career.

The union will announce plans in the coming weeks to prevent sexual harassment in the future, Leonard Egert, national executive director of AGMA, said in a statement.

"AGMA's efforts to protect its members will not end with this investigation," Egert said. "AGMA is calling upon all companies in Opera , Dance, and Choral concert fields to join an industry-wide initiative to positively change the culture."

Title: After years of struggle, Goa’s blind cricketers see a brighter future
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PANAJI: Having won a trophy for the first time, Yeshwant Nageshkar was putting together a list of people he should thank for making this possible. There was the Goa Cricket Association (GCA) who funds the team’s travel, a senior official who contributes towards their boarding and one well-wisher who transferred money into the account, sent an email and asked to let him know – through email – if they needed more.

“I don’t know his identity. I want to thank him personally,” said Yeshwant, coach-cum-captain of Goa’s blind cricket team and secretary of the Blind Cricket Association of Goa .

Yeshwant has had to wait for a really long time to see the trophy in his boys’ hands.

For four years, he has been dreaming about this. For four years, he has been coaching, playing and finding support for the blind cricketers. As coach-cum-captain and secretary, nobody has had a bigger role to play. But when Goa eventually won a trophy, he wasn’t around.

“I have to undergo an eye operation so couldn’t be part of the team. But I’m delighted that we have managed to win a trophy. This is definitely the start of something good,” he told TOI after personally handing a bouquet of flowers to all players who alighted at the Karmali railway station on Tuesday.

The Konkan Kanya Express train from Mumbai was delayed by more than two hours, so the wait was even longer for Yeshwant, the only official waiting for his boys at the station.

“This trophy could have so easily been a bigger and better one. We should have emerged champions but even a runners-up trophy is good for a start. We defeated teams who were better prepared than us and enjoyed better facilities,” said captain Tukaram Gaonkar.

Goa lost to Gujarat in the final of the Paras Mal Champions Trophy, an inter-state cricket tournament for the visually impaired that had Gujarat, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh also taking part in Ajmer.

Goa secured two victories against Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh in the league stage and qualified for the final where they succumbed to the might of Gujarat, a team they had so easily defeated earlier in the tournament.

In the final, Goa were bundled out for 185 while chasing Gujarat’s score of 235 in 20 overs.

“We had restricted Gujarat to 177 in the league game but in the final they struck form and scored 235. We weren’t overawed by the score since 12 (runs) an over is achievable but our main players were unlucky to get out. It became a stiff chase,” said vice-captain Aftab Patel.

Despite the final defeat, Goa had so much to cheer. The two victories in the league stage was their first this season, particularly after tough outings against top-ranked teams in the Nagesh Trophy. There were individual success stories too, none more impressive than Asutosh Maraskar (B3, partially sighted) who walked away with the Man-of-the-Match and Man-of-the-Series awards.

Asutosh was the highest scorer all along with scores of 48, 66 and 88 in the league games, while he managed 70 runs in the final. No other player could match his consistency and he is now touted to find a place in the Indian team for a two-match series against South Africa on April 2 and April 3 in Goa.

Akshay Borikar (B1, totally blind) and Sandeep Ghudge (B3, partially sighted) were among the notable performers too, while captain Tukaram also had allround success, particularly with the ball in his hand.

“We now have to train harder than ever before. We know we can defeat the top teams, only if our preparations are thorough. Our training camps at Marcel, Kavlem and St Cruz helped us a great deal,” said Yeshwant.

Goa’s next challenge is another four-state tournament at home with Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Telangana among the invitees. Having made it to their first final, they’ll want to do even better on home soil.

Title: Julian Assange: WikiLeaks did not put lives at risk;Julian Assange in UK court
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

LONDON: WikiLeaks did not put lives at risk by leaking people’s names when publishing classified US diplomatic cables, a lawyer for Julian Assange told a court in London on Tuesday during a hearing on Assange’s extradition to the US.

The US is seeking Assange’s extradition from London for publishing classified US documents in 2011. During the trial, James Lewis , an attorney for the US, claimed Assange had put lives at risk by leaking unredacted files. Mark Summers , who represents Assange, however said WikiLeaks had redacted all names from the files and that the US government was even involved in the redaction process.

Summers said a retired Guardian journalist was responsible for the leak. “Someone published a book which enabled the world to publish the unredacted materials,” he said, naming David Leigh ’s book “WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange’s War on Secrecy” as the direct source of the “unredacted leak”. Another defence attorney claimed Assange was handcuffed 11 times and stripped naked coming and going from court.

Title: Ankit Tiwari: I have not done as much work as Arijit Singh; you can’t compare us
Content: The trend of recreating retro songs in Bollywood seems to be at its peak at present. While playback singer and music composer Ankit Tiwari isn’t averse to the idea, he has his own priorities straight – he wants to stick to the originals. This, however, has not often yielded results, Ankit says.He tells us that as he always stuck to the original compositions and stayed away from singing rehashed versions of old songs, a lot of his contemporaries went ahead in the race. He was in Jaipur to perform at a campus fest. Ankit Tiwari in Jaipur (Shalini Maheshwari/BCCL)“I am not against remakes. They help in selling a film or creating a buzz around it. But it’s my personal choice to stick to original music. After Aashiqui 2, I sang Galliyan. Then I sang Tu Hai Ke Nahi and a number of other songs in films, including Airlift, Rustom, Baaghi etc. Yahaan tak sab sahi chal raha tha,” he says.“Then suddenly, this trend of remaking old songs made its way into Bollywood and everybody went gaga over it. Almost every second film today has a rehashed version of an old song. In fact, even non-filmi songs are now being rehashed and used in Bollywood films, which is a good thing. But I don’t want to be a part of that trend, not as a composer or as a singer. I have always loved originality. I am trying my best, but maybe because of that, meri speed thodi kam ho gayi hai. But that’s how it is and I am at peace with it,” he adds.Ankit Tiwari and Arijit Singh There was a time when Ankit and Arijit Singh were sailing in the same boat. But now, Arijit has completely swept over the industry, overshadowing the likes of Shaan, Mohit Chauhan and Atif Aslam . Opening up about the comparisons with Arijit, Ankit replies, “I have not done as much work as Arijit. So, you can’t compare us. I might have been in the industry for a longer period of time than him but he has done a lot more work. In fact, if you look at our work, you will see that Arijit has sung for a lot of big stars; I am yet to do that.”“And then, I am also a composer. I understand that this comparison started after Aashiqui 2. It used to affect me initially. But over the years, I have realised that we are simply drops in this ocean and everybody is doing his or her work and trying to give their best shot. I have a long way to go,” he adds.While Ankit has performed in the Pink City before, this was the first time he was performing at a college fest. “Jaipur is a city with a lot of genuine people. They appreciate your work. I think Jaipur ka ek andaz hai milne ka. It pulls you towards the city,” he says.

Title: Richa Chadha: Ali Fazal proposed to Richa Chadha in Maldives, the two to tie the knot in April
Content: You will not see this couple indulging in too much PDA or featuring regularly on each other’s Instagram posts, but that hasn’t kept our attention away from Ali Fazal and Richa Chadha . Putting speculation to rest, our sources have confirmed that the couple will tie the knot in the third week of April. We hear it was a romantic proposal. Ali proposed to Richa in the Maldives a few months back, and it was an instant “yes” from his lady love. The wedding dates will be locked in the next few days, and April 15 is one of the options for the big day.A source revealed, “The question was never ‘would they’ but ‘when would they’ get married? The two first met on the set of Fukrey in 2012 and have been friends ever since. They started dating in 2015, made their relationship public in 2017 and now, they are all set to take the big leap. The wedding will happen in Delhi among close family and friends. The festivities will go on for two days. There will also be a party for their Bollywood friends in Mumbai after that.”Apparently, the couple has opted for an unconventional venue for their shaadi festivities. “Ali and Richa are going to go quirky with their wedding, owing to their personalities. The duo is working round the clock with their teams for interesting, unconventional venues and celebration ideas. The party in Mumbai will most likely be at a venue by the sea or in an experiential venue, something like a performing centre, which is a break from the usual venues.”While the two have been vocal about their relationship, the wedding news has been kept under wraps. Speaking of Ali, Richa had told us, “Ali is extremely supportive, and I couldn’t have asked for a better man in my life.Our relationship is a great creative partnership. No one that sees us together feels like it’s a mismatch. it’s rare to find like-minded people who share certain core values and have similar interests like poetry, music, films and literature. Ali is also progressive and liberal. To find someone like that in your industry is rare. Also, we never expected to end up together. It happened organically.”Ali had told us, “I believe in the sanctity of marriage. I think it’s beautiful. Somewhere, we all stumble upon it, I guess. And maybe, I have thought about marriage, but I won’t speak about it yet."

Title: #MentalHealthAwareness: Celebs open up about struggles with depression
Content: The immense pressure to perform, not be bashed online and still score at the box-office takes a toll on celebrities in the entire showbiz circuit. For every success story, there seems to be a counterpoint in the number of suicide attempts being reported. The recent deaths of Kushal Punjabi and Sejal Sharma put the much-needed spotlight on depression and mental health again. The conversation around these issues, however, are no longer muted as over the years, actresses like Deepika Padukone and Anushka Sharma have opened up about their own struggles. This has helped others to talk about their struggle with depression, anxiety and bipolar disorder. We spoke to some celebs in recent times, who shared their breakdown stories and how they overcame it.“It took me over a year to realise that I was in depression,” says Shama Sikander, adding, “I’d cry for hours for no reason. I’d have no desire to go anywhere or do anything. All I wanted to do was sleep, but I couldn’t. It’s when a friend told me that I might be suffering from depression that I got myself checked. This was some seven years ago.” Shama says that she also attempted suicide around that time. “I can’t pinpoint what got me into that state. I thought the world was extremely selfish. It took me almost five years to come out of that state of mind. Having said that, I don’t think it ever goes away. The only difference is that I’m not threatened by it anymore. It has become my friend,” she says, adding, “The awareness towards depression and towards your own truth is the most important. I had to be friends with my darkness. I had to accept myself fully, I had to learn to love myself fully. It’s the only way to fight it.”Anjana Sukhani chose to take a two-year sabbatical from films when she found that she was clinically depressed. “I decided to open up about my depression, but I was warned against doing that. I was told that if I do that, I won’t get work. But I thought mere bolne se agar ek zindagi bach jaati hai ya ek zindagi badal jaati hai, then my job is done,” recalls the actress.” She continues, “The cost of counselling and treatment is another aspect that gets ignored. Counsellors and therapists are expensive and beyond the reach of a certain strata of society; everyone should be able to afford treatment.”For someone who saw immense popularity with TV, Sharad Malhotra found it hard to come to terms with the failure of his debut film. “There seemed to be no balance at what I was experiencing – my first TV show, Banu Main Teri Dulhann was super successful, but my debut in films with From Sydney With Love was just the opposite of it,” he looks back, adding, “I went through a low phase after the film didn’t work out. It even affected my personal life. I didn’t know where to look for help. Finally I took to spiritualism, which calmed me as a person.” He adds, “One must be vocal about one’s issues and emotions. Suppressing them can lead to depression.”She’s all bubbly and vivacious in her television shows, but Jasmin Bhasin admits to having been through a dark phase. “I had come to Mumbai and had no friends and family,” says the actress who made her acting debut in a Tamil film, Vaanam. “Things were not in my favour initially. I was so low that I started finding flaws in my own body and even, stopped going for auditions for some days. I felt hopeless. Over time, I made a few friends, who cheered me up and motivated me. Having the right people and environment is necessary to maintain your mental health,” she adds.Sahil Khattar is known for his funny streak, but he’s been through a meltdown, too. “I had everything going for me, but it all changed when my longtime girlfriend broke up with me,” recalls the actor, host and radio jockey. “Within a week my father fell ill and was diagnosed with acute pancreatitis. I just took a flight to Chandigarh and left Mumbai without informing the radio station where I worked. I had crashed-out mentally.” However, that was just a beginning. “It’s when my dad returned home that my depression set in. I’d just sit on the couch at home, watch TV all day and eat only noodles and cereals. Finally, a friend, who was a psychologist, pulled me out of the house and took me to play snooker, which gave me the needed zest to come back to my life.” Sahil also says, “When you know that things are not going good, you have to occupy yourself doing what you love the most. That is how the happy hormones are generated.”is among the few from Bollywood who has openly spoken about her battle with depression, without mincing words. In an interview with Filmfare, she had shared, “My family and friends never let me feel as if something was wrong with me. They made me feel that what I was going through was okay. They supported my decision to take medication for depression.”has also been upfront about her issues with anxiety. In an interview with a magazine, she says,“I have anxiety. And I’m on medication for it. Why am I saying this? Because it’s a completely normal thing. I want to make this my mission, to take any shame out of this, to educate people about this.”spoke about his bipolar disorder in an interview with us last year. “It went on for 18 months, during which I changed four doctors. I didn’t care about losing my stardom, I was scared about losing myself.” He also added, “I belong to my fans who have made me. They needed to know, and this was the best time to talk about it.”

Title: Sonali Naik: The entertainment field is a superstitious field: Actress Sonali Naik
Content: Sonali Naik, who impressed the audience with her performances in shows like Pyaar Ka Dard Hai Meetha Meetha Pyaara Pyaara , Yahan Mein Ghar Ghar Kheli and Gathbandhan, among others, was in Lucknow to shoot her latest serial. “I tried the chai at Sharma’s here, I think it was incredible. I loved having it and I also had the mouth-watering Tundey kebabs. Lucknow has such great hospitality and food to offer, its terrific.” “I feel along with hard work, you also need your lucky stars to be on your side. I feel, I have been quite lucky in this sense because normally people come to Mumbai in search of work, I however, came to Mumbai after I was offered work,” said the actress from Satara Sonali Naik (extreme left) shooting in old Lucknow with other actors from the serial (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Sonali further adds, “I used to perform in a local theatre group when my work was noticed in the year 1991, and I came to Mumbai after that in the year 1995 to perform in a commercial play. There has been no turning back since and have been getting work by God’s grace.”The actress says, “Although luck plays a huge role, your work is extremely important. The entertainment field is a superstitious field as well. So if your show is a hit, you’ll be tagged as successful in the sense that they’ll say things like she works well, she’s particular about her work and the show is also running successfully.”Confirming that theatre is her first love Sonali says, “Not just Satara, Maharashtra , in general, has a rich culture in theatre. Recently I had acted in a play for which we had even gone overseas and received much appreciation. I have noticed immense love for arts and theatre internationally, its beautiful.” She further adds, “Time and again, I take small breaks from serials and do theatre. I feel theatre is a great way of refreshing your acting skills.” — With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

Title: Aditya Roy Kapur: I would like to direct a film one day
Content: In his last release, Malang Aditya Roy Kapur went all out to look his best on the screen. While talking about the efforts he took to look his beefiest best in the film, Aditya mentioned that as much as he loves to be on the screen, he would also like to try his hand at an off-screen job. The actor, who’s now busy working on the sequel of Ek Villain , says that he would like to give filmmaking a shot someday. However, unlike his brother, Siddharth Roy Kapur, who produces movies, he would like to direct a film. He says, “I don’t think I am fit to get into production, but I want to direct. The more I act, the more I realise how much effort goes into directing a film. It is a pretty tough job. But until I find a story that I am eager to tell, I won’t get into direction.”

Title: Pullela Gopichand: There’s lots of dramatisation in films on sports, but I am okay with that
Content:
Pullela Gopichand

Sonu Sood

will be playing Pullela Gopichand in PV

Sindhu

biopic

There has been a flurry of sports biopics in the last few years.

When you go and watch them, what are you looking at – accuracy or entertainment?

Do you feel that there is so much inherent natural drama in sports that one doesn’t need to add too much to it to bring it to the big screen?

Talking of sports biopics, there are at least two coming up, where we will see you being portrayed on screen – one of yours and one on PV Sindhu. Then there is the Saina biopic where reports say the coach’s character will be an amalgamation of all her coaches, which includes you, too. When these actors come and meet you or talk to you, apart from the mannerisms, what do you try and tell them so that they can understand your psyche and portray you better?

And you are ok with that dramatisation?

(laughs)

Coaching isn’t a straightforward thing. How a coach deals with a 12-year-old kid cannot be the same way you are with a senior

athlete

, particularly because senior athletes are more prone to rebelling or having their own viewpoints that may be divergent from those of the coach. How do you tackle that?

Oye choohe idhar aa

sahab

How much of coaching an elite athlete – a senior athlete – is a management of their egos as well?

gurukul

guru

These days, people get quick recognition in sports. An 18-year-old playing in a professional league today is no less than a film star. Not letting it get to your head – is that something you have developed over the years or is it something that has always been ingrained?

Manav Kaul will play Parineeti's coach in Saina Nehwal biopic

Pullela Gopichand doesn’t watch many films. He admits that the last film he watched was over a year ago, and it’s ironic that the celebrated coach will be portrayed in three mainstream movies over the next two years. In a freewheeling chat with us, the national badminton coach talks about the utility of sports biopics for sportspersons, how he would want to see himself on screen, and on his philosophies on coaching. Excerpts:I have two views on this. The first is that storytelling in sports is very important, as is creating those role models. That’s when people get inspired and take up a sport. Inspiration is important. When I see a sports movie, unfortunately, I say ‘this is not real’. When I see a regular movie and say, a fight takes place, I don’t say ‘this is unrealistic’ but in a sports story, I am thinking, ‘She is not playing the way she should’ or ‘This is not the way it happens on the field’. Yes, there will be instances where you see things that can happen but the dramatisation is probably what is too much. But I’m still okay with that.Yes, I agree. There are parts of a sportsperson’s life which would be dramatic but you just have to compress it to get it on screen. But yes, there are instances which will connect with people. Things like injuries, poverty, and pushing through family’s support, the wins and defeats, the last-minute thrills are all there. You just have to compress them.I have met Sonu Sood a few times (who portrays him in Sindhu’s biopic). But really it’s more about mannerisms. I think the movies that are being made are more about the athletes and the coach may not be the central figure. I’m sure there is a lot of dramatisation because of the way I am, I don’t think it’s going to make a very good script for an on-screen hero. I’m not so noisy or dramatic to portray something great. I don’t think there would be any interest in portraying me the way I am.Do I have a choice?My first coach was Hamid Hussain. He made me fall in love with the sport. I would want to go to the courts because he was there. He was a big Pathan and would address me as, ‘!’ But we’d love to be in the stadium. My next coach was Arif(Dronacharya awardee SM Arif) and he was a disciplinarian. Later I was at the Prakash Padukone Academy with Prakash sir. At each stage, I look back and see that when a kid starts, he should have a coach that makes him love the sport. When he loves it, you need to be disciplined and structured. Then once you are disciplined, you need to be someone who sets a goal and has an aspiration. That’s how Prakash sir was. And then in the later stages of your career, you need someone who is a co-pilot in your car, who sits next to you and you both navigate the vehicle together. That’s how the relationship between a senior athlete and a coach is. At every stage the situation is different. The coach who is able to mould himself and get to that stage is the most productive.I think we are living in a society that is changing. You can’t really equate all elite athletes. You have to take into account culture and upbringing, too. But yes, you have different challenges today. You have athlete managers coming into the picture as well as cultural norms at play. There is a culture in the society that asks you to question. We are moving in a zone that is changing. We are also not a country that has a specific culture. We have some roots in thesystem where theas the final authority is one thought. But on the other hand, we have a questioning mentality that has come from the west, where you feel this is my job. The athlete thinks you do your job and I’ll do mine. You are looking at a very mixed society so it is a challenging space to be in.I think it’s the upbringing. It’s the number of times you have fallen down in life and remembering that the ups and downs are not permanent. You kind of stay in the middle. As a coach, it’s about where you focus on. You want to look at the top two wins and think ‘I’m super successful’ or look at the entire scenario and try to reduce the percentage of the times you’ve been unsuccessful. It’s tricky, because you need to see the wins to stay positive but look at the failures to not get complacent. I go back to the Olympic finals (where Sindhu won the silver) and I think ‘superb!’, but I also think why my sub-junior players lost here. That night, I thought ‘This is over but what about the rest of them, whom I had left for six months’. As a coach, it is tough because you are constantly thinking about the next batch.In Video: Pullela Gopichand: I am not loud or dramatic

There is a culture in the society that asks you to question. We are moving in a zone that is changing. We are also not a country that has a specific culture. We have some roots in thesystem where theas the final authority is one thought. But on the other hand, we have a questioning mentality that has come from the west, where you feel this is my job. The athlete thinks you do your job and I’ll do mine. You are looking at a very mixed society so it is a challenging space to be in.I think it’s the upbringing. It’s the number of times you have fallen down in life and remembering that the ups and downs are not permanent. You kind of stay in the middle. As a coach, it’s about where you focus on. You want to look at the top two wins and think ‘I’m super successful’ or look at the entire scenario and try to reduce the percentage of the times you’ve been unsuccessful. It’s tricky, because you need to see the wins to stay positive but look at the failures to not get complacent. I go back to the Olympic finals (where Sindhu won the silver) and I think ‘superb!’, but I also think why my sub-junior players lost here. That night, I thought ‘This is over but what about the rest of them, whom I had left for six months’. As a coach, it is tough because you are constantly thinking about the next batch.In Video: Pullela Gopichand: I am not loud or dramatic

Title: Bihar becomes first NDA state to adopt anti-NRC resolution
Content:
File pic: Bihar assembly

PATNA: Bihar on Tuesday became the first state with an NDA government to unanimously adopt a resolution to stick to the old National Population Register (NPR) pro forma, adopting only the transgender column from the new format recommended by the Union home ministry. The resolution, virtually a copy of CM Nitish Kumar ’s response to the Centre’s letter seeking feedback on NPR , also states that “the National Register of Citizens (NRC) is not needed in Bihar”.None of the BJP members present in the assembly — the party has 54 MLAs — opposed the resolution when Speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary sought to know if it had the consent of the ruling and opposition benches. “For the smooth functioning of the House, it was essential for this resolution to be unanimously adopted,” Choudhary later told TOI.Nitish clarified in the assembly that the Centre had sought feedback from all states on NPR, but he took the opportunity to also communicate his government’s stand on the NRC. “The Bihar government has communicated to the Centre that the NPR format should be the same as it was in 2010, and only the transgender column should be added to it. We have also communicated that the NRC is not needed in Bihar,” he said.Earlier in the day, there was a commotion in the assembly after RJD functionary Tejashwi Prasad Yadav moved an adjournment notice on NPR and CPI-ML legislator Mehboob Alam a separate one on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, NPR and NRC. Some BJP and RJD members almost came to blows when Tejashwi dubbed CAA a “black law”.Defending his party’s support to CAA in Parliament, Nitish cited previous statements of former PM Manmohan Singh and other Congress members demanding Indian citizenship for persecuted minorities from some neighbouring countries.Tejashwi claimed that the state government moved the resolution on NPR and NRC under pressure from RJD, a statement that was immediately contested by JD(U)’s ally BJP.State BJP vice-president and Baikunthpur MLA Mithilesh Tiwari told TOI: “The PM has clarified that there has been no discussion on NRC. So, discussing NRC is like celebrating the ‘mundan’ of a baby before birth. Tejashwi should not feel elated as BJP never deviates from its principles. It is the party that has forced a country like Pakistan to kneel down.”Many see the resolution as a Nitish masterstroke to blunt the RJD-led opposition and the likes of CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar , who is on a statewide yatra against the NRC.

Title: No provision for relief in riot-related deaths: Yogi Adityanath
Content: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath submitted in a written reply in the state assembly on Tuesday that the state government has no provision to compensate families of people who die in “riot-related incidents”.According to Yogi’s submission, 21 people died in “riot-related incidents” in the last six months. He said 400 police personnel were injured in stone-pelting by protesters while 61 cops suffered gunshot injuries.At least 21 people were killed in violence during anti-CAA protests across UP on December 19 and 20. The UP government has claimed that none of them died of police bullets. While referring to these incidents of violence in his speech in the assembly last week, the CM had claimed that “rioters were killed by rioters”.On Tuesday, the CM was replying to a query by SP MLA Rakesh Pratap Singh who asked for the death toll of the people dying in riot-related incidents in the past six months and whether the state government would make any provision to compensate the families of the victims.Yogi’s statement has come at a time when the opposition has been criticising his government on the law and order situation and the handling of anti-CAA protests. Yogi had earlier ordered issuance of recovery notices to the protesters who damaged public property during violence. The CM also submitted that crime against women rose between 2017 and 2018 but these cases were brought down in 2019. In a written reply to SP MLA Ujjwal Raman Singh , the CM said that 51,582 cases of crime against women were registered in 2017. This figure rose to 53,608 in 2018 but came down to 49,867 in 2019.

Title: This adorable childhood picture of Janhvi Kapoor, Khushi Kapoor and Shanaya Kapoor deserves all your attention!
Content: We all are aware of Janhvi Kapoor , her sister Khushi Kapoor and Shanaya Kapoor share a close bond. And the latest picture shared by Sanjay Kapoor is proof that they share such equation since they were kids.Sanjay took a trip down the memory lane and posted a photo featuring Janhvi, Khushi and Shanaya cutting the cake along with him. While Janhvi's sweet smile will make you go aww, Khushi's adorable braids will melt your hearts. Without sharing any details about the celebration, Sanjay uploaded the picture on his Instagram. He tagged all the girls in his caption!Shanaya was quick to comment on the post and wrote, "@Khushi05k you are ready to dive into the cake"Check out the post here:For the unversed, Janhvi and Khushi are daughters of Boney Kapoor while Shanaya Kapoor is the daughter of Sanjay Kapoor.On the work front, Janhvi will next be seen in ‘Dostana 2’. She will also feature in ‘Gunjan Saxena: The Kargil Girl’, Karan Johar ’s period drama, ‘Takht’ and ‘RoohiAfza’ with Rajkummar Rao . On the other hand, Shanaya is yet to make her debut in Bollywood. She has worked as an assistant for Janhvi's Gunjan Saxena biopic.

Title: Swine Flu in Delhi: Five Supreme Court judges catch H1N1, right to religion hearing gets derailed
Content:
Justice D Y Chandrachud told lawyers in the morning that six judges were affected by H1N1 virus: File photo

DELHI: In the past 10 days, Supreme Court judges and thousands of lawyers practising there have been spooked by H1N1 with five judges kept in isolation on being found infected with the virus. This derailed day-to-day hearing by a nine-judge bench to outline the ambit and scope of right to religion.The first to be struck down by H1N1 was a judge who is part of the nine-judge bench which on February 10 heard arguments for just two hours. The judge’s illness has derailed the hearing since then. He has almost recovered, brightening the chances of early resumption of hearing. After him, the flu spread quickly, catching four others.Of the four, three had a milder attack of H1N1. Though infected much later than the first judge, they have fully recovered and resumed court work on Tuesday.The sitting of many courts had to be cancelled as apart from these five, another judge slipped in the bathroom at his residence a fortnight ago and injured his spinal cord. He has been advised rest and will take weeks to recover. A woman judge had an attack of nausea on Monday and is expected to resume work on Wednesday.The health ministry said, “All the judges were provided treatment as per the protocol. Prophylactic treatment was also given to all who have come in contact with them including their family members. All five judges were kept in home isolation. Of these, three judges have already resumed their duty and two continue to be under home isolation/observation and are recovering.”Given the unprecedented situation, CJI S A Bobde met his colleagues Tuesday morning and discussed a plan of action to contain spread of the virus. The health ministry was also contacted. After a detailed discussion, the CJI asked the health department to take urgent measures — equipping the first aid post of CGHS in the SC complex and sanitising courtrooms and judges’ residences.According to SC sources, the health department has agreed to open a temporary medical dispensary that will help identify lawyers and court staff infected with H1N1 and inoculate on a chargeable basis.The effect of this unprecedented virus attack was evident on the judges. Justice D Y Chandrachud told lawyers in the morning that six judges were affected by H1N1 virus and that the SC was taking steps to make inoculation available to lawyers. Justice Arun Mishra was seen advising lawyers who were feeling unwell to stay home and rest. “It is a request to everyone. If you do not feel well, do not come to court,” he said.

Title: US President Donald Trump says Harvey Weinstein conviction is a "great victory" for women and 'sends a very strong message'
Content: Harvey Weinstein's conviction of rape and sexual assault was a "great victory" for women and sends a "very strong message", US President Donald Trump said on Tuesday. "I think that from the standpoint of women, I think it was a great thing," Trump said at a news conference in India, a day after Weinstein was convicted."It was a great victory. And sends a very strong message, very, very strong message."The conviction of the once-powerful Hollywood producer was hailed as a historic victory by the #MeToo movement against sexual misconduct.A jury which included seven men and five women came to a verdict against the disgraced Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein who was facing charges in his New York County trial.According to the reports, Weinstein has been convicted of criminal sexual assault in the first degree, based on the testimony of Miriam Haley and rape in the third degree, based on the testimony of one-time aspiring actress Jessica Mann

Title: Kunal Kamra: HC pulls up DGCA over Kunal Kamra flying ban
Content:
Kunal Kamra ( File Photo )

NEW DELHI: The Delhi high court questioned aviation regulator DGCA Tuesday for “endorsing” the decision of three airlines other than IndiGo to ban comedian Kunal Kamra for allegedly heckling a journalist on board.The court asked the DGCA to clarify by Thursday why it “certified” the action of other airlines to penalise Kamra without any inquiry by the authorities. “Why did you (DGCA) give a certification on Twitter,” Justice Navin Chawla asked the counsel for the regulator while hearing a plea by Kamra challenging IndiGo’s decision to ban him from its flights for six months.Chawla asked DGCA’s lawyer to come prepared on the next date to explain how the action by these airlines was in tune with civil aviation requirements (CAR) rules.The HC also remarked that once Kamra had informed the DGCA of the violation of CAR by the airlines which had banned him, the regulator could not say it would not examine or look into it.Appearing for Kamra, senior advocates Vivek Tankha , Gopal Sankaranarayanan and Mohit Mathur underlined that for perhaps the first time in the history of Indian civil aviation, all airlines imposed a flying ban on him without there being a complaint as required under CAR.“Even more shocking is the fact that other airlines — Air India , GoAir and SpiceJet — on which the petitioner was not even travelling (and in respect of which there was never any allegation against the petitioner), also followed suit and banned him for an indefinite period,” the plea says, noting that even IndiGo handed down a six-month ban before it received a complaint.Tankha apprised the court that CAR lays down that it is the pilot of the flight who must receive a complaint, but no such complaint was made. Even then the airline set up an internal committee which has scheduled a final hearing of the matter on February 26.His plea argues that the other airlines — Air India, SpiceJet and GoAir — banned him for an indefinite period without even setting up an internal committee to enquire into the issue, prompting Justice Chawla to demand an explanation from the airlines on why they acted without a committee and put him on a no-fly list.The comedian has sought directions to the DGCA to direct the airlines to revoke the ban and also action against them for alleged violation of CAR.The DGCA said in its defence that it was only a regulator and the airlines had the freedom under CAR to take action against passengers for unruly or disruptive behaviour. “As per CAR, it is an internal decision of the airlines,” the DGCA told the court and added that the other carriers be also made a party in the matter as the regulator cannot answer for them.IndiGo said its internal committee was already looking into the matter and would give its decision soon.

Title: Donald Trump: CAA is up to India. I hope it’ll take the right decision for its people
Content:
President Trump and PM Modi arrive for their joint news conference at Hyderabad House in New Delhi. (Reuters p... Read More

NEW DELHI: Even as violence over the Citizenship Amendment Act wracked the capital, US President Donald Trump said, “I want to leave that to India, hopefully they will make the right decision for the country.”Responding to questions at a press conference here on Tuesday, Trump refused to get drawn into a discussion over CAA as he wrapped up a high-octane two-day state visit, even as he said he had discussed the issue of religious freedom with Prime Minister Narendra Modi during their official talks at Hyderabad House .The outcome of the Modi-Trump talks contained in the joint statement unequivocally reflected Indian concerns over Pakistan’s role as a terror sponsor. “Prime Minister Modi and President Trump denounced any use of terrorist proxies and strongly condemned cross-border terrorism in all its forms,” the statement said and asked Pakistan to ensure no territory under its control is used to launch terrorist attacks.The statement further called on Pakistan to expeditiously bring to justice perpetrators of such attacks, including 26/11 and Pathankot. “They called for concerted action against all terrorist groups including Al-Qaida, IS, Jaish-e-Mohammad, Lashkar-e-Taiba, Hizb-ul Mujahideen, the Haqqani Network , TTP, D-Company and all their affiliates,” it said.In his media interaction, asked about incidents of violence in the national capital during his visit, Trump said he hadn’t discussed “individual attacks” with Modi. “That’s up to India. I hope it will take the right decision for its people,” he added.Replying to another question, Trump, who in his opening remarks had made it plain that he was not going to say anything “controversial” that might cast a shadow on the trip, said he was satisfied with what he’d heard from Modi about religious freedom in India.“We did talk about religious freedom. I will say that the PM was incredible and he told me that he wants people to have religious freedom. He told me that in India they have worked very hard to have great and open religious freedom,” he said.Asked about alleged discrimination against Muslims and rise in hate crimes against them under Modi, the president said, “Well, we discussed that and specifically Muslims and we also discussed Christians, I had a very powerful answer from the PM. We talked about religious liberty for a long period of time in front of a lot of people and I had a very, very powerful answer. And the PM said we have 200 million Muslims in India and a fairly short while ago they had 14 million and he said they have been working very closely with the community.”Trump’s disinclination to speak on CAA must come as a relief for the government, which had billed the visit as a big leap in India-US ties aimed at cementing and advancing a crucial strategic partnership spanning anti-terrorism cooperation to trade and commerce.On another tricky terrain, that of Kashmir, Trump repeated his favourite formulation that he could help or mediate and referred to there being “two sides to every story” but did so without any particular vehemence.“We talked a lot about Pakistan. I have very good relations with PM Imran Khan. We talked about it at length actually. No question that it’s a problem. But it’s a problem they have been working on. India is a brave nation and I have said I will do whatever I can do because my relations with both gentlemen (Modi and Khan) is so good. But there have been difficulties in Pakistan and we are seeing what we can do about it. Anything I can do to mediate, anything I can do to help, I will do,” Trump said.He also emphasised the convergence between the two countries as well as between him and Modi on terrorism. “We discussed terrorism and I think we have some very good ideas. I feel very strongly against terrorism. PM Modi is a very religious man as you know, he is a very calm man but actually he is a very very strong person. Very tough actually, I have seen him in action and he has got that foremost in his mind-terrorism,” he said.The tenor of Trump’s remarks reflected the Indian side’s view that India and the US are increasingly moving together on critical areas of national security, energy and technology with ties rebadged as a “comprehensive global strategic partnership” as the two leaders announced earlier in remarks to media.The president’s remarks were punctuated with strong praise for Modi and an implicit acknowledgement that he found the PM’s response to issues of religious freedom in India and on terrorism sourced from Pakistan convincing.In his briefing, foreign secretary Harsh Shringla said Trump did not specifically bring up CAA. “You would have heard President Trump in his speech yesterday in Ahmedabad referring to religious diversity and harmony that is evident in India; discussions really to the extent possible were on these lines on this issue,'' he said. "The issue of CAA did not come up; there was appreciation from both sides that pluralism and diversity are a common binding factor of both countries," he added.

Title: Unnao rape convict Kuldeep Singh Sengar disqualified from UP House
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Lucknow: Expelled BJP MLA Kuldeep Singh Sengar has been disqualified from the membership of the UP assembly, following his conviction in a rape case . The development has necessitated a byelection in Bangarmau assembly seat in Unnao, represented by Senger.

According to a notification issued by the Vidhan Sabha on February 20, Sengar has been disqualified as per the rules following his conviction by a Delhi court which had awarded the life imprisonment to the MLA on December 20 last year. With this the Bangarmau seat has fallen vacant from that date itself, the notification said. A senior official in Vidhan Sabha secretariat said that it would soon be informing about the Sengar’s disqualification to the Election Commission of India which will decide on the date for bypoll.

Sengar is the second BJP MLA to be disqualified after getting convicted in a criminal case. Last year in June, BJP Hamirpur MLA Ashok Singh Chandel was convicted by Allahabad HC in a 22-year old murder case. He, too, had been sentenced to life imprisonment, necessitating a byelection, which was won by BJP candidate Yuvraj Singh in September last year.

A four-term MLA, Sengar was expelled by BJP in August 2019 following a furore over his alleged involvement in rape of a minor at his Makhi village in Unnao in June 2017. The case came to the limelight after the survivor attempted self-immolation outside the CM’s residence in April 2018 when the police did not take action on her complaint. A few days later, her father died in police custody.

The case was later handed over to the CBI, which said it had evidence against Sengar. It filed four FIRs against Sengar and his aides and he was arrested, along with his brother Atul .

Title: No clarity on Wuhan evacuation yet
Content:
First batch of people who were airlifted from Wuhan at the ITBP quarantine facility (file photo)

With inputs from Rohan Dua

NEW DELHI: Several Indians stuck in China's Wuhan are waiting with bags packed for their evacuation by India from the coronavirus-hit city, but said there was still no clarity on when they would be able to leave.A day after the Union health ministry said Indians stranded in Wuhan would likely to be brought home on February 26, many Indians told TOI that the anxiety is playing havoc with their minds. A majority of them have remained confined to their homes for a month now as the city has remained under complete lockdown.“Every morning I wake up hoping that this will be the day we are told we are being taken to India, but by evening I lose hope again,” said a senior scientist in Wuhan who hails from Saharanpur (UP).On Tuesday, a message from the Indian embassy in Beijing on a Wechat group — which has 100 members waiting to be evacuated — asked members to “prepare for departure tomorrow morning (Wednesday)” but added that the arrangements were “still subject to change”. Earlier, official sources had said China was delaying clearance to the military transport aircraft which was to fly to Wuhan on February 20.Meanwhile, the Indians in Wuhan had signed consent forms for evacuation on February 19 itself and have been waiting since then. Ready with their luggage, they had then informed their families they were coming home.“It’s been a week since then,” the scientist at an R&D firm who’s been in Wuhan for six years now said, adding that he is surviving on ready-to-eat soup sachets he brought from India when he last visited in October. “Until February 16, supermarkets were open but now gates of the apartment complex are closed. Only those with a special permit can enter or exit. I had run out of food two weeks ago but my Chinese neighbours contacted authorities who gave me rations free of charge. But now the stock is over. How many times can I bother my neighbours? I don'y have much left.”In another apartment, an Indian from Himachal Pradesh employed with a biopharma company, said he hasn’t seen a soul in over 30 days. “When we need something, we contact community leaders (similar to RWA presidents). Items are delivered to the doorstep and we receive a text alert. There is no human contact,” he said.At the Wuhan Textile University , associate professor Ashish Yadav and wife, Neha, have been stocking up masks, sanitisers and disinfectant sprays. The couple was not evacuated earlier as Neha was on bed rest following a surgery but their worries have grown since three hostel buildings in the varsity, a few metres away, have been turned into medical wards to keep suspected coronavirus patients in isolation.The coronavirus scare has prompted at least two Indians to hand in their resignations. Akshay Vats, who works with a two-wheeler manufacturing firm in Hubei , said the company has told him that quitting would be in violation of his contract. “I won’t get dues of 80,000 yuan (Rs 8 lakh approx) and I’m also being asked to forfeit my salary in lieu of notice period.” Vats, however, added that he was facing pressure from his concerned family to return.A sales agent with a Hong Kong-headquartered casino operator has also been told to pay back the money for medical insurance and housing loan that his company had offered as part of his salary component. “I can’t arrange so much money at a moment’s notice. Companies need to show more compassion in such cases.”The hardships have mounted. While the scientist is surviving on soup, another has been living in a hotel. At least two Indian professionals who decided to quit their jobs and leave China permanently now face penalties for violation of contracts.With evacuation delayed, other issues have cropped up. Several Chinese companies are slated to open on the second week of March and expat workers have been told that if they are not back when offices open, it will be counted as leave without pay.Many have even offered to pay for their tickets, if that helps speed things up. Like one 33-year-old chef at a five-star hotel who had to abandon his apartment after he ran out of food and necessities. “My company was quick to offer me a guest room at the hotel, otherwise I don’t know what would have happened. I just want to go home even if that means buying my own ticket,” he said.

Title: Riteish Deshmukh: Hope to make a biopic on my father's life
Content: Actor Riteish Deshmukh hopes to someday make a film on the life of his father, the late former Chief Minister of Maharashtra Vilasrao Deshmukh . He said he is waiting for the right script that will entertain the audience as well as do justice to his father's journey."It is one of those miraculous journeys of a human being. He started off as a sarpanch (head of Gram Sabha) and went on to become Chief Minister of a state. Many a time, people have written scripts about his life and asked me to make a film but it is not easy," said Riteish.He added, "When a subject is so close to your heart then you forget objectivity. Just suppose, I make a film on his life and people say I have shown only the good things about him and not shown the other side of his life. If somebody else makes it, then I will say, 'he wasn't like this, he never used to talk like this and certain things never happened in his life'. So, there will always be a difference in opinions when you make films on such subjects."All the same, he hoped to make a film on his father's life someday. "When you write a book on someone's life, you can write 500 or 600 pages. But it is very difficult to show all aspects of a person's life in a two-hour film. If you don't succeed, the biopic gets boring. So, one need to take care. Hopefully, if something comes up, then why not? But it's not in the agenda in the near future," the actor explained.Riteish was interacting with the media at a promotional event of 'Baaghi 3'. The film stars Tiger Shroff with Shraddha Kapoor and is directed by Ahmed Khan . The third film of the 'Baaghi' franchise is an official remake of the 2012 Tamil blockbuster 'Vettai'. It is scheduled to be theatrically released in India on 6 March 2020.
