Title: Mixed reaction from trade, industry bodies
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PATNA: Trade, commerce and industry bodies gave a mixed response to the Rs 2,11,761 crore state budget for the 2020-21 fiscal presented by deputy CM-cum-finance minister Sushil Kumar Modi in the assembly on Tuesday.

Abhishek Kumar, secretary general of Bihar Entrepreneurs’ Association, said the state government should have focused more on small and micro enterprises as it contributes to the growth of the state.

“In a bid to encourage small industries and startups, the government should have created better marketing, funding and business ecosystem. Creation of incubation centres backed by experts of industries associations and entrepreneurs was the need of the hour. The state government should also have focused on establishment of food parks and jute clusters,” Abhishek said.

Sanjay Bhartiya, vice-president of Bihar Industries Association (BIA), said the allocation for industries sector slightly increased from previous year. “Last year, the industries department got Rs 585 crore under the scheme head. The allocation has increased to Rs 810 crore this time,” he said.

Bhartiya added, “It is only through industries that sustainable employment is created and the state government receives revenue in the form of tax.”

Bihar Industries Association president Ram Lal Khetan congratulated the state government for achieving 15.01% growth rate. “A large sum has been proposed for various schemes to strengthen the state’s economy,” he said.

Bihar Chamber of Commerce and Industries chairperson P K Agarwal also hailed the budget. “The budget is good if we consider the larger perspective. However, we were expecting allocation of Rs 2,000 crore for industries sector,” he added.

Title: Truck runs over leopard in Bareilly, 8th death this yr
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Bareilly: An adult leopard was killed on Monday night in Fatehganj West area of Bareilly after it was run over by a truck. The leopard which sustained head injuries died on the spot. The carcass was spotted by locals who alerted the forest department. It is suspected that big cat was the same leopard which had been living in defunct rubber factory and adjoining villages for the past two years.

This is the third case of leopard death in an accident in West UP in a month. Earlier this month, two big cats were killed in road and rail accidents, respectively, in Bijnor.

This is also the eighth case of leopard death in west UP this year. Three of them were killed by villagers in Bijnor, Moradabad and Badaun, respectively. While the fourth died of age–related issues in Bulandshahr’s Bawanpur village. These deaths took place in January. Another three-year-old succumbed to some disease in Bijnor earlier this month.

Divisional forest officer Bharat Lal said, “When the leopard was crossing the road around 10.30 pm on Monday, it was run over by an unidentified vehicle. The leopard sustained severe head injury as its skull was broken and its blood spilled all over the road. Some villagers who were passing by spotted the carcass of the big cat and moved it to roadside.”

Forest officials on Tuesday sent the leopard carcass to the Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) for post-mortem and the report is expected to arrive in a couple of days. “Forest range officer will give a police complaint against unidentified driver of the vehicle,” said Lal.

Forest officials suspect that the leopard which was killed on Monday was the same big cat which had been living in and round the defunct rubber factory for almost two years. “As the road accident happened in Fatehganj West, it is suspected that it was same leopard which has been spotted moving about in the area for almost two years. The leopard of the rubber factory often strayed into villages situated on the banks of Sanka river but never harmed any human,” said Lal.

Title: Rain to continue for two more days in Bihar: Met
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

A view of suddenly rain in Patna on Tuesday.

PATNA: Light to moderate rainfall with hailstorm and gusty winds in Patna and some other parts of the state brought down mercury by a few notches on Tuesday. Thick cloud overshadowed the state capital throughout the day.

Patna received 13.5mm of rainfall till 5pm on Tuesday, Banka 44.6mm, Dehri 15.2mm, Jehanabad 14.4mm, Jamui 12.8mm and Biharsharif and Gaya 12.6mm each.

Minimum temperature in Patna was recorded at 18.3 degrees Celsius and maximum at 23.4 degrees Celsius. The chill in air was augmented by northeasterly winds due to western disturbance, which lies over south Bihar and extending up to 1.5km above the mean sea level.

According to daily bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre, widespread rainfall was witnessed in several parts of the state on Tuesday. “The system will continue for next two days,” it said.

The Skymet bulletin stated that light to moderate rain may occur in parts of Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal during the next 24 hours.

Title: Kolkata: Hi-tech link plan for New Town’s Action Area III
Content:
Image used for representational purpose

KOLKATA: The Housing Infrastructure Development Corporation (Hidco) is engaging a consultant to prepare a project proposal for either a ropeway system or a personalized rapid transit or a light rail transit (LRT) system from New Town ’s Action Area III to the Biswa Bangla Gate on the Narkeldanga intersection of the main arterial road in Action Area I. Officials said the objective was to have better connectivity between Action Area I and III, and a synchronized transport system with the new Metro alignment.At present, the three Action Areas are connected to each other by four arterial roads. Hidco has introduced electric buses and the Metro construction is on parallel to the main arterial road. However, with the Metro alignment passing only through Action Areas I and II, Action Area III is yet to connected with the Metro and other public transport.“Action Area III is a huge place with several important institutions. There will be a huge surge of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in this area in the near future and keeping this in mind, we must have a plan in hand for an advanced urban public transport system which will be able to synchronize this traffic with the Metro alignment. This will ensure better and faster transportation from Action Area I and II to Action Area III,” said a Hidco official.“The new transport system will likely be in the form of a ropeway or a personalized transit system like podcars. It could also be a light rail transit system. The selected consultant will have to carry out detailed survey to decide on the most feasible transport,” said a Hidco official.The bidders competing for the job must have at least two years’ experience in setting up transportation infrastructure projects in the country or abroad.

Title: Coronavirus Update: Not just drugs, medical devices may go out of market
Content: MUMBAI: It’s not just critical medicines that could witness potential shortages due to the coronavirus outbreak. Commonly used medical devices like digital thermometers, infrared thermometers, nebulizers, blood pressure monitors and glucometers could face the same risk soon.Manufacturers of med devices have started pressing the panic button as they are running out of key raw materials — mainly the electronic parts for these items, imported from regions like Hangzhou and Dongguan in China. With no sign of supplies being replenished anytime soon, their assembly lines could face closure from March-end or April onwards.At present, a majority of the demand for infrared thermometers (temperature gun) is from China itself, which is facing the worst-ever outbreak with cases still rising. There have been hundreds of enquiries, particularly for infrared & digital thermometers, from neighbouring countries too like South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong, and even African countries.As a result, a section of the industry wants the government to restrict exports of such critical items as infrared & digital thermometers, and three-layer surgical masks to build a stockpile to tackle the pandemic.Further, with the disruption in supply chain, increase in prices of raw materials & components and higher cost of shipments, margins for companies are getting squeezed, which could impact profitability. Worst hit are companies that import finished devices (from China) and market them in India, and those that assemble items after importing the raw materials/components from China.The $15-billion medical devices market is heavily import-dependent — at around 80%, with imaging equipment ( CT MRI scanners), cardiac stents, orthopaedic implants, syringes, glucometers, and critical care equipment cornering a large share (see graphic). For consumables and disposables like gloves, crepe bandages, IV sets, blood transfusion sets and syringes, there are several small to medium players, largely in the unorganised sector. Only 10-20% medical devices are manufactured in India, and even for these there’s a high dependence on input raw materials and components from China now.“The small to medium players will get impacted due to coronavirus as they are dependent on China for raw materials, components and packaging materials. Most companies have one-two months of stock. We may see some disruption in the coming weeks. Already domestic raw material suppliers have started increasing prices,” said Himanshu Baid , MD of Poly Medicure. The company is engaged in IV catheters, blood bags and dialyzers. Baid added the company is not impacted as it has minimal imports from China.The problem is acute for both infrared & digital thermometers with companies and wholesale distributors fast running out of stock. Infrared or non-contact forehead thermometers used at public places and airports are fully imported (with no indigenous manufacture). For digital thermometers, a few companies import electronic components from China, and assembly is done here.With the number of coronavirus cases rising, China is scrambling to import infrared thermometers from India, at even three-four times the earlier rate of Rs 800-900, according to a market player. For digital thermometers, wholesale rates have doubled to Rs 70. Earlier, rates of masks had skyrocketed amid the surge in demand following the outbreak.“We have 20,000 pieces of Infi digital thermometer which will end in a month, after which there are no stocks of electronic components,” said Tarun Arora, director of Infinity Mediquip. As for nebulizers, where the company is a significant player, he says the assembly line will have to be shut in April if shipments do not move from China soon. H C Gupta of Hicks Thermometers (India), a company which has a major share in digital thermometers and imports the finished product, said it is on the verge of zero stocks of both thermometers and BP instruments, due to supplies being indefinitely delayed.Companies assembling blood pressure monitors and glucometers are facing a glitch too. “We are facing problems in supply of raw materials for pregnancy kits, thermometers and nebulizers, and have stocks till April,” J S Kohli, who has an assembly unit in Delhi, said.Association of Indian Manufacturers of Medical Devices ( AiMeD ) forum coordinator Rajiv Nath says India needs to urgently create a stockpile of essential drugs and critical medical devices for disaster management. Dr G S K Velu of Trivitron Healthcare summed it up by saying that the real impact on industry will be visible only after April. The local manufacturers should become a reliable source in global shortages — whether it’s thermometers, water bottles or adhesive bandages.

Title: Companies’ purchase of liability insurance goes up by average 50%
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

(Representative image)

CHENNAI: Rising strife and damages caused is forcing companies to purchase liability insurance , which covers loss and damage caused due to natural disasters, burglary and riots. Some insurers are witnessing a 50% increase in policies sold.

“We have seen about 20% increase on yearly basis in the sales of our product — Public Liability Insurance (Industrial Risks) Policy — which provides coverage to accidental death, body injury or disease, loss or damage to property. It also covers legal costs and expenses incurred which is within the limit of indemnity. The loss claim ration is around 50%-60%,” says Sanjay Dutta, chief, Underwriting and Claims, ICICI Lombard General Insurance.

SBI General has seen an increase in both policies sold and premium earned. “Higher conversion rate of liability, from queries turning into sales, seen under directors and officers (D&O) liability policy, with 80% rise in sales. With the amendment of Companies Act, 2013, more companies are keen on insuring their officers, directors and independent directors. Even premium charged has increased up to Rs 2.5-Rs 2.8 crore, from Rs 1.4-Rs 1.5 crore for sum assured value in the range of Rs 5-Rs 25 crore in the past one year,” Vaidyanath Balasubramanian, Underwriting Manager, SBI General Insurance said.

Shreeraj Deshpande, COO, Future Generali India Insurance , said they have seen 30%-40% higher sales in public liability covers were driven by educational institutions, as compared to 50%-60% higher sales among product liability covers due to export requirements.

The insurance company said it does record more claims to cover damages from policyholders running businesses in the auto industry and pharmaceutical business. Deshpande said, “The overall loss claims ratio stands at 40%-50%, which is much better as litigations are lower in India. However, we so see higher awareness on liability insurance. Even the overall premium for this cover gone up by 10%-20% compared to previous year.”

Title: Beed MP Pritam Munde attacks state over loan waiver
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Beed MP Pritam Munde on Tuesday took part in the state-wide stir called by the BJP against the Maha Vikas Aghadi government.

Munde, along with her supporters, staged a sit-in agitation outside the Beed district collectorate and criticised the state government on issues like women’s safety, farm loan waiver , among others.

With the ongoing budget session of the state assembly, the BJP, which is in the opposition, has launched the BJP Elgar campaign under which agitations will be held across the state against the coalition government of Shiv Sena, NCP and Congress.

A similar agitation was held in Aurangabad district and it was led by BJP city chief Sanjay Kenekar.

In Beed, the protestors held placards and raised slogans against the MVA government. Raising the recent incidents of violence against a woman in Hinganghat and rape of minors, Munde said that the instead of addressing the failure of the administration in ensuring women safety, the ministers of the Maha Vikas Aghadhi government are busy being felicitated in their constituencies.

In a memorandum submitted to the district collectorate, the agitators called for implementation of complete loan waiver for farmers and assistance of Rs 25,000 per hectare for crop loss and Rs 50,000 per hectare for fruit farms damaged due to unseasonal rains in October 2019, among other demands.

It was also stated in the memorandum that none of the insurance companies have signed an agreement with the state government for crop insurance for the current rabi season in Beed district and demanded help for loss of rabi crop.

“Cases of eve-teasing and crimes against women have increased so the government should contain such crimes by efficient police administration,” Munde said.

Title: Bihar: Koilwar bridge to remain shut twice a week
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

ARA: The northern lane of the Abdul Bari bridge, popularly known as the Koilwar bridge , which connects Ara and Buxar to Patna, will be shut from 7am to 5 pm for road traffic every Wednesday and Sunday from February 26 to May 24.

This was informed by the Bhojpur district public relations officer (DPRO) Pramod Kumar.

The DPRO said that Bhojpur DM Roshan Kushwaha has passed this order on the request of deputy chief engineer, East Central Railway, Hajipur, for the repair work to be carried out on the northern lane. The DM has asked the district transport officer (DTO), SDO (sadar) and SDPO to establish coordination among themselves and take the help of Koilwar SHO and traffic in charge for regulating traffic and maintaining law and order during this period.

The SDO and the SDPO have been asked to deploy adequate number of magistrates and police personnel every Wednesday and Sunday for maintaining law and order during the repair work . They been also directed to coordinate with their counterparts in Danapur for taking appropriate steps for the smooth flow of traffic under their jurisdiction so that no inconvenience is caused to commuters.

SDO (sadar) Arun Prakash said that during the repair work, heavy vehicles will not be allowed even on the southern lane. Only passenger buses and four-wheelers will be allowed to ply on the southern lane during the repair work . To avoid traffic jam during the period , vehicles will be allowed to depart after every half-an-hour from Bhojpur side for going towards Patna.

The Bhojpur DM has also asked the officials to put up big banners and bill boards on both ends of the Koilwar bridge informing the public about the timings of the repair work on the northern lane. He has also asked to use loud speakers for informing the commuters.

Title: KYC fraudsters on the loose; don’t fall for fake SMS, calls
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Beware, Indore residents are being duped of lakhs by fraudsters , who ask them to download remote access applications by offering to update their ‘e-KYC’ for e-wallet applications. The company has also warned users recently by sending out alert texts against fake KYC update messages.

According to SP Jitendra Singh, over half-a-dozen similar cases have been reported in the city in past one week. “There is no age or education bar in such scams. They randomly send messages and whoever responds by calling is duped,” he said.

While explaining modus operandi, Singh said that customer gets a message for KYC verification and a warning that e-wallet account would be blocked if verification is not done.

The customer calls the number provided in message and is directed to a fraudulent customer care.

“A man, who has got extensive training in duping people over calls, asks the victim to download an app like Team viewer or quicksupport, which actually is a remote access application granting complete control to a device located elsewhere,” he said.

The ‘online KYC’ team makes the customer log on to the app to get the password details for their account.

The customer is then asked to make a token payment from their debit or credit card so that the e-wallet can get access to account details for transaction.

“Fraudsters can get full access to bank information through this so even if the victim clicks on the message, they can read the OTP and get information,” said investigating officer Pooja Muvel.

She said, “One of the elderly victims had called the number to update the KYC. The call went on for over three hours before the accused duped over Rs 1.5 lakh in different transactions. The accused also asked him for another number and he called on that such that he could direct the elderly man how to download the application on his phone.”

The complainant told TOI that the message looked real and by the time he could understand what was happening, he had already lost over Rs 1 lakh.

Title: Education deparment gets the highest allocation of Rs 35,191 crore in Bihar budget
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Bihar deputy CM and finance minister Sushil Kumar Modi talking to newsmen at Bihar Legislative Council annexe ... Read More

PATNA: The five works departments, along with the education department, have taken the hefty share of the budgetary allocations made for expenditure during the 2020-21 fiscal, as part of the state budget that deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi presented in the state assembly on Tuesday.

Later, outside the House, Modi said the Madhepura Medical College would start works related to academic session in a month, and the piped drinking water supply would be made available to each household by the end of March this year. “Bihar would become the first state in the country, where every household would have piped drinking water supply,” Modi added.

Otherwise, the budgetary allotment for the education department has been the highest at Rs35,191 crore among all the departments, hogging 16.62% share of the estimated state budget worth Rs2.11 lakh crore for the 2020-21 fiscal. Of the sum allocated for the education department, Rs21,264 crore would utilized as scheme or plan expenditure.

The government would also be spending a no mean sum on the payment of interest, pension and repayment of loan amounts during the 2020-21 fiscal. Separately, the payment of pension amount accounts for Rs20,468 crore, interest payment for Rs12,924 crore and repayment of loans Rs7,035 crore.

However, the four major works departments together — rural development department, road construction, rural works and building construction — would be spending Rs38,796 crore during 2020-21, including Rs25,272 crore on various projects and schemes.

Separately, the budgetary allocation for rural development department is Rs15,955 crore, including Rs15,529 crore for scheme expenditure, while Rs10,638 crore has been earmarked for the rural works department, including Rs9,619 crore for scheme expenditure.

The share of the road construction department is Rs6,706 crore, including Rs5,581 crore to be spent on various projects. Similarly, the allocation for the building construction department is Rs5,395 crore, including Rs4,543 crore to be spent on the projects.

Other than them, the other major allocations have been made for health (Rs10,937 crore), panchayati raj (Rs10,651 crore), energy (Rs5,560 crore) and public health engineering department (Rs5,856 crore), while the allotment for the social welfare department that handles social security schemes is Rs7,994 crore.

While the government would be spending Rs24,500 crore on implementing the ambitious Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali campaign over the five years, the budgetary allotment is Rs500 crore for the 2020-21 fiscal. Further, the urban development and housing department would be spending another chunk of Rs10 crore on the related schemes during the same period.

Title: Maharashtra: 2 booked for death of duo while cleaning drainage line
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Around six years after two workers died while cleaning a drainage line in Nanded city, two people from the management of a Hyderabad-based firm — contracted by the Nanded Municipal Corporation — have been booked by the police for causing death due to negligence.

The duo has also been slapped with sections of Prohibition of Employment as Manual Scavengers and their Rehabilitation Act, 2013. An offence was registered with Itwara police station in Nanded after father of one of the deceased workers lodged a complaint on Monday.

The deceased — Shaikh Yusuf (24) and Mohammed Yasin (26) — were hired by the Hyderabad-based firm for carrying out the cleaning work. As per the complaint lodged by Yusuf’s father Shaikh Khajamiya (68), on May 22, 2014, the two workers drowned after inhaling the poisonous gas in the drainage line.

The work was being carried out in front of Eidgah Kaman at Deglur Naka. The complainant has stated that the contractor did not provide any safety gear to the workers before making them enter the drainage.

Investigation officer Arun Nagare said, “Records show that soon after the incident, a case of accidental death was registered, but as no one had come forward to lodge a complaint no offence was registered then.”

When contacted, complainant’s family claimed that they were not allowed to lodge a complaint by the representatives of the company. “We finally lodged a complaint in a hope of getting justice. We want the people at fault to be punished,” Tamiza Bi, Yusuf’s mother, said.

Police said they are not aware if the contractor is still catering to the civic body.

Title: SBI Card IPO values co at Rs 71,000 crore, offer from March 2
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: The Rs 10,300-crore IPO of SBI Card will open for retail investors on March 2 and close on March 5. The company has fixed a price band of Rs 750-755 per share with a minimum bid size of 19 shares.

The listing comprises fresh issue of equity shares worth Rs 500 crore coupled with an offer for sale of 13 crore equity shares. This includes 3.7% shares offloaded by SBI and 9.3% being sold by the Carlyle Group, which currently holds 24% stake in the company. Going by the price band and equity dilution, the post-issue valuation of the company ranges between Rs 70,425 crore and Rs 70,891 crore. This is the second SBI subsidiary to be listed after SBI Life, which is currently valued at Rs 90,095 crore.

The issue will have reservation of 1.3 crore shares for SBI shareholders and 18.6 lakh shares for employees. Eligible employees are entitled to a discount of Rs 75 per share.

According to SBI Card MD Hardayal Prasad , the company has a market share of 18% in terms of number of cards and spend. “We are the only card issuer that is not part of a bank. This gives us a tremendous advantage in issuing white-label cards on behalf of other banks,” said Prasad. He said there was a threefold growth opportunity with customers making more payments on the e-platform, increasing propensity to avail credit for consumption and low penetration of cards in India.

According to Dinesh Khara , MD, SBI while technically it was possible for the company to become the largest issuer in three months given SBI’s Card base, the focus was on ensuring that the base was profitable. He said that the bank did not charge the card company for issue of cards to its customers. “We are doing it as a mutually complementary exercise as we get to enlarge our product bouquet. We endeavour to do this by running algorithms on our customer database,” said Khara.

Title: Kolkata Rain: Mercury plunges 5°C, Met says light rain likely till afternoon
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Kolkatans take refuge under umbrellas and in raincoats on Tuesday

KOLKATA: A thick cloud cover and intermittent drizzles brought the mercury down by five degrees in Kolkata on Tuesday. The maximum temperature plunged to 22.6°C, eight notches below normal. With a cyclonic circulation that triggered the rain still looming, the rain could continue till late Wednesday afternoon, predicted weathermen at the Met office.

However, the showers will never be intense since the circulation, which reached Bihar on Tuesday afternoon, is set to move towards north Bengal. On Tuesday, Kolkata recorded a minimum temperature of 18.8°C and received 1mm rain.

“The drizzles and the cloud brought the day temperature down. Since the cloud cover will persist, along with the occasional drizzle, the minimum temperature will not rise significantly. It could be around 20°C on Wednesday,” said Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC) director G K Das, adding, “Till another system forms and leads to a cloud cover and rain, the mercury will keep rising.”

The north Bengal districts of Malda, South and North Dinajpur, Jalpaiguri, Siliguri and Darjeeling received moderate rain. With the circulation moving towards the region, the rain could intensify early on Wednesday. “But it will gradually lose intensity as the circulation moves away. The mercury will start rising on Thursday and will steadily climb towards the 30°C-mark,” added Das.

Last week, the city had turned warm with the maximum temperature crossing 30°C for the first time this season. It was attributed to the disappearance of the chilly northwesterly wind. The Met office had predicted the drop in temperature after it spotted the cyclonic circulation over Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.

Title: After 10 years, Jawahar Marg may get the flyover it needs
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Better late than never. Decade-old plan to streamline traffic at Jawahar Marg may soon make its way from shelved files of IMC storeroom to reality.

The project of building a flyover that could not see the light of day at that time due to objections by local traders and politicians has been taken up by Indore divisional commissioner Akash Tripathi, who exercising his power delegated as IMC administrator, ordered a survey for constructing flyover on Jawahar Marg connecting Bhagat Singh Square at Rajmohalla to Sardar Patel Bridge via Sanjay Setu.

Tripathi’s instruction is said to be very important to deal with congested traffic problems on this road by sidelining objections raised by senior BJP leaders including then education minister Laxman Singh Gaud. The divisional commissioner gave the instructions in a meeting held on Tuesday to review progress of ongoing development works and planning new projects.

To meet deadline of ongoing works, Tripathi appointed in charge official for each projects like completing a bridge at Kulkarni Ka Bhatta by June 15, Sarwate bus stand and Gandhi Hall restoration works by end of June. He also emphasized on restoration of Nehru Park and completing ongoing works of Vishram Bagh and Chhota Nehru Stadium as soon as possible. The commissioner set a deadline of completing ongoing cleaning and beautification of Kanh and Saraswati by March-end.

The commissioner also reviewed ongoing road widening works between Gangwal and Sarwate bus stands, MG Road and Subhash Marg and issued required instructions to complete them.

During the meet, he asked officials to explore possibilities to legalize illegal colonies and take appropriate actions on colonizers, who failed to deliver basic amenities to residents as per standard. He reiterated to start construction of a four-lane road between Bhawarkuan Square and Tejaji Nagar Square soon along with developing service road alongside bypass.

Title: Bihar: Budget speech sets tone for government’s poll campaign
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: The Budget speech by deputy CM and finance minister Sushil Kumar Modi in the state assembly on Tuesday set the NDA agenda of campaign for the assembly election scheduled in October-November this year.

Modi harped on 15 years of Lalu Prasad-Rabri Devi rule versus 15 years of Nitish Kumar-led NDA’s governance in the state. He highlighted the atrocities on Dalits with a special mention of mass massacres since 1990, before Nitish took the reins in 2005.

Reacting to the budget, the former principal of Patna College and retired professor of economics, Nawal Kishore Chaudhary, said, “It was a propaganda budget with little branding as green budget talking about environment and water resources.”

He told TOI: “The budget speech was like the government’s campaign manifesto. The state’s budget should be about the government’s vision and plans for the next fiscal. What is the purpose of enumerating the number of medical and polytechnic colleges when there are no teachers? The focus on Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali Mission is a welcome move, but it also reflects the government’s failure on water resources front. The budget lacks vision.”

Modi, in his speech dwelt at length on the NDA government’s achievements such as 35% reservation for women in state jobs, 15 medical colleges in 15 years and revival of dying boards and corporations as opposed to the lack of development during the Lalu-Rabri rule.

Former state finance minister and senior RJD leader Abdul Bari Siddiqui termed it as a “copy and paste budget”. He said the Nitish government has been trumpeting the increased budget allocations every year and compares that to pre-2005 state budgets, but the finance minister never reveals how much funds lapse every year.

“They don’t mention the budget of other developed states of the country in the pre-2005 period. They also don’t tell that the budget size has been increased due to more central assistance over the years, as has been the case with other states as well. The present budget has neither vision nor road map or even proper homework,” he told TOI.

While presenting the Rs2,11,761.49 crore budget, SuMo said it has increased eight times compared to Rs 23,885 crore in 2004- 05.

Title: Suresh Khanna, Leader of Opposition lock horns over crime figures in UP
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Suresh Khanna

LUCKNOW: Parliamentary affairs minister Suresh Khanna locked horns with Leader of Opposition Ram Govind Chaudhary in assembly on Tuesday and questioned authenticity of the crime figures in last three years being mentioned by him.

Earlier, Samajwadi Party’s Ujjwal Raman Singh started reeling out figures to claim that crime against women had spiraled under Yogi government, and the data he was quoting was from a state government website.

He said crime cases against women, mainly dowry deaths, rapes and molestation, had gone up while they were much less in SP regime. Khanna presented figures saying crime against women was highest under SP government, and strict measures by Yogi government had brought a sharp decline.

Chaudhary challenged Khanna and said he had NCRB figures. Khanna countered saying he too had figures of same agency. “Your figures are not true and the Central government’s are correct,” Chaudhary responded, but Khanna replied saying, “Yours are photocopies while mine are original,” leaving the House in splits. He said, “We should submit our papers to the chair to verify whose claim is right,” and handed him papers to be given to Speaker Hriday Narayan Dikshit. Chaudhary also handed the papers to speaker.

Earlier, SP alleged that fake encounters were increasing and staged a boycott demanding a judicial inquiry.

Title: Kolkata East-West Metro work: BB Ganguly-Sealdah stretch to stay shut for 2 years
Content:
The stretch of BB Ganguly street, between Sealdah station and Sealdah court, will be shut for around two years

Times View There will be some amount of dislocation because of this unavoidable work. Good planning — and cooperation from motorists and pedestrians — will be essential to maintain a semblance of order in this zone, which tends to be chaotic even at the best of times.

KOLKATA: Pedestrians bound for BB Ganguly Street will get a new pathway out of Sealdah station soon while vehicles — especially those carrying goods — will have to take the longer route via BR Singh Hospital. The new traffic plan has been formed since the BB Ganguly Street stretch between Sealdah flyover and Sealdah court will remain shut for around two years to facilitate East-West Metro tunnelling.KMRCL has sought cops’ help to manage traffic here since the tunnel boring machine (TBM) is set to arrive within three-five months.The Sealdah traffic guard and KMRCL carried out a survey of the area after tunnelling restarted at Bowbazar. “For now, we have taken three important decisions. No vehicle or pedestrian will be allowed under the Sealdah flyover from the station and vice versa. From the station, cars will have to go via BR Singh Hospital and get on the flyover to approach BB Ganguly Street. The only exception will be the KMC conservancy trucks that enter the station complex early in the morning to clear garbage. “Given the importance of this operation, KMRCL will marshal these vehicles,” said a police source.The new pedestrian walkway is being created on the northern part of the station complex, close to the VIP parking. From there, the people can move towards Santosh Mitra Square and Muchipara police station,” said an officer.The traffic police are also worried about the dispersal of vehicles from the station. “There is a possibility that the Metro workers might need a deck span of around 45m to complete work near BR Singh Hospital. However, with KMRCL agreeing to complete work in two phases, cops are certain that traffic flow will not be affected too much.But there may be snarls near Sealdah flyover towards the approach to BR Singh Hospital. “With movement to Koley Market affected, it will be a logistical challenge. We are hoping none of the agencies decide to shut any part of the flyover at that point of time,” said an officer.“We will depute a dedicated team near Sealdah court to guide pedestrians and regulate vehicles entering the station premises. A new traffic signal is being put in place along with a temporary boom barrier,” said an officer from Sealdah traffic guard.Sources on the ground, though, said managing thousands of pedestrians will be a tough task. “We have already had people challenging the diversion. Several have claimed they will continue using BB Ganguly Street. Unless we can channel everyone on to dedicated lanes, our plan will not see success,” said an officer when TOI visited the spot on Tuesday.

Title: Yarn exports down by 20% due to corona virus impact
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Chennai: Coronavirus has brought down the yarn exports to China to almost nil. The country, which imports over a quarter (27%) of India’s cotton yarn appears shut for yarn business.

Exporters said that February so far has seen a 20%-30% drop in overall exports because of the inactivity in China.

“Compared to January, there is a 40% drop in overall exports and almost nil exports to China. However, there is demand from Bangladesh and Vietnam who usually import yarn from China. So the situation has been salvaged a bit,” said Arun Jhajaria, director of Salona Cotspin.

As a result of low demand, cotton yarn prices have fallen by 3%- 4% to Rs 185 to Rs 200 per kilogram, for export quality in the past 10 days. After the lunar new year, Chinese come forward to purchase the yarn but exporters add that business has not yet picked up.

In FY 2020, yarn exports were already down by 9% for the period April to Jan. The industry saw an improvement in exports from November after seeing a drop of upto 39%. “We saw a revival of exports in November and December and now, with the factories shut, we expect to see a drop in exports again,” said KV Srinivasan, chairman of industry body TEXPROCIL.

Title: Poonawalla’s son Adar takes bite of cookie business
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Adar Poonawalla (File photo)

MUMBAI: Billionaire vaccine maker Cyrus Poonawalla’s son Adar has made his maiden investment in India’s food service sector by acquiring a stake in Sweetish House Mafia , a cookie speciality cafe, founded by former investment banker Neha Sethi and her brother-in-law.

A few years ago, Adar, CEO of Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine manufacturer, had acquired a stake in Pune’s Ritz-Carlton hotel. He has invested about Rs 12 crore in Sweetish House Mafia, which was started in 2013 with Neha, a self-trained baker, selling cookies in a Tata Nano at pop-up locations in Mumbai.

A year-and-a-half later, the partners set up the first brick-and-mortar store in Lower Parel , a business district in Mumbai. Currently, there are 12 outlets across big cities.

“The funds will be used to strengthen our presence in existing geographies as well as to enter new cities,” said co-founder Akash Sethi . “Some part of the money will be also deployed to expand our range of gourmet cookies.” The cookie business in India, worth Rs 14,500 crore, is growing at a compounded annual growth rate of 10%.

The Sethis are also planning to launch an e-commerce platform. “The coming decade will be dominated by direct-to-consumer brands. And investors are looking for models that stay relevant to consumers,” said an industry observer.

The food service sector has attracted over $3 billion of venture capital (VC) and private equity money in 12 years, according to a 2019 report by National Restaurant Association of India. Recent months saw VC firm RB investing in homegrown QSR chain Burger Singh and Tiger Global in Wow! Momo Foods. In 2017, ICICI Ventures invested Rs 100 crore in Theobroma Foods, a patisserie chain and a competitor of Sweetish House Mafia.

Title: Katihar couple commits suicide after killing son
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A debt-ridden couple committed suicide by hanging themselves from ceiling after killing their minor son at their rented accommodation in Katihar town on Tuesday.

The victims were identified as Manish Kumar (42), his wife Mona Kumari (35) and their three-year-old son Samrat.

Katihar SP (incharge) Aditya Kumar said Manish was a businessman and Mona a social worker. “The two have left a four-page suicide note stating that they took the extreme step after failing to repay a loan of Rs 30 lakh,” the SP said, adding the incident probably took place on the intervening night of Monday and Tuesday.

The SP said preliminary investigations suggested that the couple poisoned their son and hanged themselves to death. “Manish and Mona were found hanging from a rope tied to a hook fixed in the ceiling,” he said, adding Manish had tried his luck in different businesses, including television and mobile sales. “He had taken loan from several people,” the SP said.

Title: Traffic jam: Vehicle numbers vroomed from 5 million to 303 million in 40 years
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CHENNAI: There’s a reason for the bumper-to-bumper traffic on Indian roads. The number of registered vehicles in the country has risen from a mere 5.4 million units in 1981 to a staggering nearly 303 million units in 2019, a rise of 5500%.

This includes cars, SUVs, taxies, tractors, buses, two and three-wheelers, trucks and people carriers. Just cars, SUVs and taxis on Indian roads has gone up by almost 40 times in nearly 40 years. Based on SIAM stats, estimates put the total number of registered passenger vehicles in 1981 at 1.2 million units. This went up to just over 10 million in 2005 and 40 million in 2019. The exponential increase in cars shows the impact a scrappage policy might have both on the environment as well as on the health of the auto industry, say auto consultants.

India’s two-wheeler population has gone from 2.6 million units to 228 million units in just under 40 years. Most of this spurt has happened in the last 15 years or so. The two wheeler park went from almost 59 million in 2005 to 169 million in 2016. In contrast, the number of buses plying on Indian roads have gone up from 0.2 million units to 1.5 million units in the last nearly 40 years. The number of goods vehicles have gone up too but not as much as personal vehicles — in 39 years the population has gone from 0.6 million units to 11.4 million units. Other categories which include tractors, trailers, three-wheelers etc have also gone up — from 0.9 million units to nearly 22 million units in the same period.

Currently, there are about 3 million registered commercial vehicles (buses and good vehicles) on the roads which are more than 15-years-old. According to a report by equity research firm Dart , the total registered vehicles between 1991 to 2005 include 7.37 million passenger vehicles, 45 million two wheelers, 0.56 million buses and 2.68 million trucks/goods vehicles. “While the government has been talking only of commercial vehicle scrappage, industry has been asking for scrappage of all older vehicles including cars and two wheelers. The extent to which the older vehicles will be weeded out will depend upon whether the scrappage will be mandatory or voluntary. If it is voluntary, the impact may not be that big.,” said Ashish Modani , VP, ICRA.

Title: Baby girl saved from dog’s jaws
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Rajkot: A four-day-old infant girl was rescued from the jaws of a dog on the outskirts of Mahika village near Rajkot on Wednesday. People spotted the stray dog carrying the newborn in its jaws and managed to save her.

“We have booked an offence against the unidentified mother of the baby girl for allegedly abandoning the child. The child has been admitted to the paediatrics ward of Rajkot Civil Hospital,” said C H Asodara, sub-inspector with Aji Dam police station.

Title: ‘Insufficient’ allocation draws flak from some
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PATNA: Even as the state government has given priority to education in its annual budget this year with the highest allocation of Rs 35,000 crore, the budget presented by finance minister Sushil Kumar Modi on Monday evoked mixed reactions from academics.

While some appreciated the government’s initiative for improving the academic scenario of the state, others criticized the budget, saying it “failed to meet the people’s aspirations”.

Patna University economics department former head Nawal Kishore Chaudhary said, “The budgetary allocation for higher education is not sufficient to ensure its proper growth and development. Although there is emphasis on ‘Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan’, schoolteachers are not getting adequate salaries. Lakhs of them are already on strike to press their demand for better salaries in the state.”

Chaudhary further observed that there was no concrete proposal for developing the higher education system in the state. “The universities are suffering from acute scarcity of teachers and other ministerial staff, but the budget does not speak a word about their appointment. There is no talk of opening any new university or research centre. The government has not announced any new development proposal for 103-year-old Patna University even when the Centre has already turned down its request for its take over,” he added.

Federation of University Teachers’ Associations of Bihar working president Kanhaiya Bahadur Sinha told this newspaper, “If the state’s GDP has increased to 15%, there should have been a corresponding increase in the budgetary allocation for higher education. How will the government fulfil its own commitment of enhancing the gross enrolment ratio (GER) in higher education to 30% by 2030, if it does not provide for any new college or university in the state in the coming fiscal.”

Sinha also pointed out that more than three lakh students of the state, who had passed Intermediate examinations from the state last year could not get admission to graduation courses due to lack of colleges. “This year, even a greater number of youths will be deprived of higher education opportunities as the number of Inter examinees has increased. Neither has the government announced any new scheme for improving the system of higher education nor has it initiated any step for strengthening the state council for higher education,” he added.

However, Patna College sociology department head and Patna University Teachers’ Association president Randhir Kumar Singh hailed the state budget, which “aims at greater infrastructural development in the education sector”. “The government decision to set up at least one polytechnic for women in each district is praiseworthy as it will enhance job potential for them,” he said.

Patna Science College geology (honours) student Saurabh also welcomed the budget and hoped that with the strengthening of various student-centric measures initiated by the Nitish Kumar-government the higher education scenario would improve.

Title: Promotion of organic farming hailed
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

BHAGALPUR: People of Bhagalpur region have evoked mixed response to the state budget presented by finance minister and deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi in the assembly on Tuesday for the financial year 20020-21.

Residents, however, hailed the announcement of free certification to promote ‘organic farming’ which may lend support to farmers opting for organic farming in the region. Teachers and students of the Bihar Agricultural University (BAU), Sabour, besides farmers expressed satisfaction over the announcement of ‘Pratibha Samman’ to promote quality researches in agriculture universities and institutions in the state.

The netizens also hailed the announcement for constructing new hostels in state-run engineering colleges, polytechniques etc besides announcement of free dialysis for patients suffering from kidney-related diseases under PM’s Free National Dialysis Programme at all the district hospitals and others.

General secretary of the Eastern Bihar Industries Association (EBIA) Alok Agarwal said that except for earlier announced Khadi Park, Handloom & Silk Bhavan, Software Park, Migratory Birds’ Ringing and Monitoring Station in Bhagalpur, which has been reiterated again, nothing specific for Bhagalpur region has been announced.

“Long-pending issues concerning Central University at Bhagalpur, archaeological excavations at Vikramshila and Karnagarh etc. do not find any mention in this budget,” lamented Agarwal adding, “Nothing much has been done to give an impetus to business of building construction and real estate. Allocation of 0.43% to industries speaks volumes about the state government’s apathy towards industrialization.”

“There are no schemes in the budget for industries related to maize, banana, sugarcane, tassar silk etc of Bhagalpur region. The state government should make region specific industrial planning and promote agro-industries besides others,” a trader associated with the silk industry said.

Title: 19 hurt as speeding bus turns turtle near Fatuha
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PATNA: At least 19 passengers were injured after a speeding bus, in which they were travelling, turned turtle on NH-30 near Morera village under the Fatuha police station area in eastern Patna on Tuesday.

Of the 19, three were critically injured. They were identified as Dinesh Kumar (47), Rohit Kumar (35), and Vikas Kumar (32). There were at least 70 passengers travelling in the bus when the accident took place between 10.30am to 11am. On getting information, police and the district administration officers rushed to the spot.

Fatuha police station SHO Manish Kumar said, “Out of the 19, three were critically injured, who were referred to Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) for better treatment. The bus, belonging to a private travel agency, was on way from Biharsharif in Nalanda to Patna,” he said.

“Few of the locals told police that a woman suddenly started crossing the highway from the middle and the bus veered off the road while trying to save her. However, according to the passengers, the driver failed to control the speed of the bus which resulted in the accident,” he said adding, “The bus driver fled from the scene after the accident.”

Daniwayan block development officer (BDO) Sanjay Kumar said that all the injured were rushed to the primary health centre (PHC) on ambulances which were brought from other neighbouring block PHCs.

Daniyawan PHC medical officer incharge Dr Sneha Tripti said that there were 16 male and three female passengers among the injured. “Except three males, who were critically injured, all were discharged from the local PHC after giving primary medical attention,” she said.

Title: AI can pick candidates even before they apply for a job
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

By Chaitanya Sreenivas

Ever since ‘personnel administration’ came into being in the 1900s, it has continuously evolved, more so in the last decade. Now human resources (HR) no longer pertains to merely hiring, assessing & compensating employees, but is intrinsic in achieving the business goals of an organisation.

Emerging technologies that disrupted traditional business models have permeated HR too. Technology is becoming vital to HR as it moves closer to business and HR leaders expect it to play a strategic role. Among the emerging technologies, artificial intelligence (AI) signals an HR technology step change, as it can create an impact across the entire talent management life cycle.

AI across talent management life cycle

An organisation can apply AI in almost any area of HR, be it to attract & hire candidates or to engage, retain & develop skills of current employees.

AI tools can pinpoint high-potential candidates even before they apply for a job. With specialised chatbots, AI — powered by natural language processing — can help attract talent by enabling prospective candidates to learn more about the organisation and answer any other queries they have. Thus, enhancing the candidate’s experience during the ‘attract’ phase.

AI can enable efficient and effective recruitment by predicting the time taken to fill a vacancy by analysing historical data. So, recruiters can prioritise the open positions they need to fill and do not hastily hire the wrong candidates.

It can also predict the future performance of a candidate by analysing the data submitted in the job application, resume and job requisition. Moreover, AI can assist in putting together more inclusive job descriptions and filter candidates minimising unintended bias in the recruitment process.

During the ‘engage’ phase, AI offers two important use cases — talent alerts and engagement analysis. AI talent alerts are essentially notifications for first-line managers that provide insights about their team members by sifting through employee data available within the organisation. AI engagement analysis is a technology that analyses unstructured data from employee surveys and social media chatter within a corporate firewall. At the ‘retain’ phase, AI can aid in smarter compensation planning. HR teams need to consider several factors like market rate for different skill sets, the demand for these skills and the approach to reward performance in base pay or bonus.

Above all, AI can accelerate skill development at individual employee-level while optimising learning at the organisation-level. The most promising aspect of AI deployment is in the real-time inference of skills. AI-based skills inference can support organisations in spotting high-potential employees.

Today, most of the innovation-led organisations are using AI to mitigate biases and enhance diversity & inclusion (D&I).

AI as a tool to alleviate bias and bolster D&I

In any organisation, several types of biases tend to creep in due to a variety of reasons, whether consciously or subconsciously.

Cognitive biases happen when employees allow systematic irrational judgments into their thinking and reasoning. In such cases, they may indulge in stereotyping, confirmation bias (tendency to search or interpret information in a way that confirms one’s preconceptions) or self-serving bias (propensity to blame external factors for failure and claim credit for success).

Bias in everyday work life could manifest into micro-aggression where employees resort to verbal or non-verbal slights and hostile communication due to bias against gender, ethnicity or disability. Whatever be the reasons, biases prevent an organisation from building a truly diverse and inclusive workplace. Mitigating these biases is crucial for organisations to ensure compliance and foster an environment of innovation and healthy competition wherein employees can grow.

This is where AI plays a role. Unlike human beings, machines do not suffer from inherent biases, but are subject to the choices of data and algorithmic features chosen by the people building them.

AI can remove the attributes that lead to biases. It can also learn how to detect potential biases, particularly those unconscious ones that are unintentional and hard to uncover in the decision-making processes. AI can ensure the right-fit candidates have equal access to job opportunities and support HR in making fair hiring decisions.

Road map to imbue AI in HR

Before an organisation introduces AI into its HR system, it can start with identifying the business case. What are the business problems they intend to solve? Who are the people who need this problem solved, and will they commit to it in their profit & loss reporting? Then the business case should spell out the minimum viable product (MVP).

The next step is for the organisation to decide if it can build its own AI applications or procure them off-the-shelf. Irrespective of whether it decides to buy or build, deploying AI capability in the cloud is the best way forward. An organisation should remember that the faster it deploys the MVP, the sooner it can deliver the next improved iteration.

Finally, if the MVP rollout is successful, it should contemplate enterprise-wide adoption by leveraging design thinking and agile working models.

If an organisation wants to test the waters and not commit to using AI, chatbots can be a starting point. HR can choose a process that generates many questions from employees and deploy a chatbot based on a list of frequently asked questions (FAQs). Chatbots are inexpensive and non-technical HR staff can manage them.

The bottom line is that ‘strategic HR’ has to come into the play wherein the focus moves from administrative practices to high-performance HR practices concentrated on key jobs and groups of workers. AI has a substantial role to play in making HR strategic and, fortunately for CHROs, it has become more accessible.

The writer is the HR head, IBM India/South Asia

Title: Binny Bansal backs online gold loan co Rupeek
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Bengaluru: Rupeek , a five-year-old startup that helps consumers get loans against gold, has raised another $35 million in funding from Flipkart co-founder Binny Bansal , US and China-based venture capital firm GGV Capital, Korea’s KB Investments and Flipkart CEO Kalyan Krishnamurthy-backed Tanglin Venture Partners.

The investment will take the valuation of Rupeek, which operates through a branchless model of home pick-up and drop-off, to over $300 million. The latest round will take the total capital raised by Rupeek to about $70-75 million, with early backers including Sequoia Capital India and Accel India .

The startup is expected to disburse loans of about $28 million this month and plans to further accelerate this in 2020. The startup will use the capital to expand from 10 cities to 30, brand building, setting up data science team and invest in its hardware product which assesses the quality of gold. The startup was set up in 2015 by Sumit Maniyar, an IIT-Bombay alumnus, who had earlier co-founded ed-tech startup Function Space besides working at JP Morgan and Religare.

“Gold loans serve as overdraft or credit card for self-employed borrowers or even the salaried class, who can’t either get the quantum of loans or have the right credit score,” said Maniyar. The startup works with banks and NBFCs that are not active or don’t have the capabilities in the gold loan segment, leveraging their balance sheet to lend. This gives these financial institutes ability to expand into a market without opening own branches and network, while also allowing Rupeek to lend at a rate which is “25-40% lower as compared to NBFCs”, said Maniyar.

Rupeek also has its own NBFC, which it primarily uses to try new products or launch in new markets, while about 95% of the loan book is through its partners. India’s gold loan market is expected to reach Rs 4.6 lakh crore by 2022, growing at a compounded rate of 13.4%, according to a recent KPMG report.

The sector has seen several NBFCs like Muthoot and Manappuram Finance, which have built a loan book of billions of dollars. “I am excited about how Rupeek is opening up access to formal credit for a large base of users. Their strong customer proposition and approach of partnering with banks is truly a game-changer for the unorganised gold loans space in India,” said Bansal, who is also setting up a $300-400 million venture capital fund to invest in startups. Bansals other fintech investments include general insurance player Acko.

Title: Patna drenched in untimely downpour
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Passengers of e-rickshaw try to protects themselves from rainfall in Patna on Tuesday.

PATNA: An untimely downpour led to waterlogging and traffic jam in several localities of the city on Tuesday. Commuters were stuck in traffic jam for hours at several places.

Since several roads were dug up for laying underground water pipelines, electric and phone wires as well as construction of drains, it added to the woes of people. Rainwater inundated roads in several low-lying areas of the city, such as Rajendra Nagar, Kadamkuan, Patliputra, Patna Junction and Thakurbari.

Mukesh Kumar, a motorist, said parts of Ashok Rajpath and its approach roads were dug up for laying gas pipeline. “The rain complicated the situation. The traffic police personnel were nowhere to be seen when the motorists were trying to negotiate the waterlogged roads,” he added.

Ashwini Kunwer, a resident of Bank Road, said some motorists nearly met accident near Gandhi Market and Judges Court Road.

Surabhi, a resident of Rajendra Nagar road number 12, said the agencies concerned did not repair roads at several places after completing civic work.

Patna mayor Sita Sahu said the agencies concerned did not take permission from the municipal body before digging up the roads in the city. “The Patna commissioner had instructed the companies to take permission from Patna Municipal Corporation and road construction department before digging up roads. They, however, dug the roads at their will and filled the wholes with debris. Action will be taken against these agencies for causing inconvenience to people,” she added.

The mayor said the civic body was trying to pump out rainwater from the affected areas.

Title: 40,000 high school, higher secondary teachers go on indefinite strike in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Around 40,000 contractual teachers of government-run secondary and higher secondary schools in the state went on indefinite strike on Tuesday in support of their three-point charter of demands, including creation of service condition for them.

The strike, organised by Bihar State Secondary Teachers’ Association (BSSTA), means the teachers will boycott evaluation of Intermediate answer sheets. The Intermediate exams were conducted by the Bihar School Examination Board (BSEB) between February 3 and 13 and the answer sheets are to be evaluated from Wednesday.

BSSTA president Kedarnath Pandey said the teachers selected for evaluation duty were supposed to collect the joining letter from their respective schools. “The contractual teachers, however, did not collect the letters. They also did not conduct academic activities on Tuesday,” he said.

Pandey said the BSSTA’s three key demands are sparing teachers from non-academic activities, removal of discrepancies in disbursement of salary and creation of service condition for contractual teachers. “The teachers will continue the strike till the government accepts their three demands,” he added.

Pandey said academic activities were not carried out at 6,200 secondary and higher secondary schools in state on Tuesday. At many schools, the teachers locked the gates.

Ashutosh, mathematics teacher at Patna-based Raghunath Balika High School, said he did not collect joining letter for evaluation work from Patna Collegiate.

Raghuvendra Kumar, a contractual teacher at B P High School in Begusarai, none joined work at four evaluation centres in the district. “Academic activities remained virtually suspended at 84 high schools in the district,” he claimed.

Mukesh Kumar, a teacher at K B Sahay School, Patna, said some regular teachers were trying to conduct regular activities in schools.

Education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma said the government would initiate action against agitating teachers if they boycott evaluation duty.

Title: Over 2 lakh JD(U) workers to attend ‘Karyakarta Sammelan’ on March 1
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PATNA: More than two lakh booth-level active workers are expected to gather at the JD(U)’s state-level ‘Karyakarta Sammelan’ at Gandhi Maidan here on March 1. JD(U) chief and CM Nitish Kumar will deliver a pep talk to the party workers on how to win the heart of people at polling booths during the assembly elections, expected to be held in October-November this year.

Earlier, the JD(U)’s lowest rung organizational unit was at the panchayat level. But from this year, the party has constituted its lowest rung unit at the polling booth-level. If the JD(U)’s national general secretary (organization) RCP Singh is to be believed, the party has this year constituted its committee at more than 72,500 polling booths across the state.

“The president and secretary of each polling booths have been invited for the March 1 ‘Karyakarta Sammelan.’ Thus, 1.45 lakh party’s lowest rung office-bearers will arrive at the Gandhi Maidan. Besides, two to three active workers from each village are also coming. The party expects a footfall of more than two lakh grassroots workers at the Gandhi Maidan,” JD(U) state general secretary Anil Kumar told TOI on Wednesday.

Besides the booth president and secretary, the panchayat to district-level office-bearers of JD(U) and all its 30 cells have also been invited. “If office-bearers of all 30 cells turn up in a large number, the footfall may go up to near three lakh,” said a senior JD(U) leader.

Since majority of workers hailing from the remote areas will reach the state capital on February 29, the party has started preparations at massive-level to provide facilities of night stay and food to the visiting workers. Huge pandals are being erected at the official residences of the JD(U) ministers and legislators.

The party’s Tekari MLA and Yuva JD(U) president Abhay Kushwaha has planned to host around 25,000 workers at the sprawling ground of the Miller School on Beer Chand Patel Path here. A series of big pandals is being erected at the ground.

“At the Miller School ground, we have made arrangements to host 25,000 workers of Yuva JD(U) and around 700 booth-level office-bearers of my assembly constituency (Tekari),” Kushwaha told TOI on Wednesday.

“As around 15,000 Yuva JD(U) workers are expected to reach by the evening of February 29, we have planned to provide them light and plain food comprising rice-pulse and vegetables in the night. In the next morning, there would be food arrangements for 30,000 people. In the morning of March 1, workers will be provided a packet of ‘puri, bundia and sabzi’ before their departure for the Gandhi Maidan,” Kushwaha said.

Similarly, the Chhatra JD(U) has planned to host its around 20,000 workers at the camp residence of party state president Bashishtha Narain Singh at 36, Hardinge Road. “As Feb 29 being Saturday, we have planned to serve a combination of khichri, chokha, papad and pickles. On March 1, the visitors will be served ‘chura-poha’, ‘chana-ghughni’ and ‘kheer’ before their departure to Gandhi Maidan,” Chhatra JD(U) in-charge and MLC Ranbir Nandan told TOI.

Sources said, the JD(U) has asked all its MLAs to provide means of transportation and facility of night stay in Patna to all booth-level workers coming from their respective constituency. Party’s other influential leaders or former MLAs have been given the task to make arrangements in those constituencies where JD(U) do not has its MLAs. In some cases, one JD(U) MLA has been given responsibility of two to three neighbouring constituencies.

Title: Adalats on registration of undervalued docus
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The registrations department has launched mega adalat scheme wherein all the undervalued documents will be excluded from further legal action after giving an opportunity for a one-time settlement .

In the adalats, such documents will be excluded after remitting 30% of the undervalued sum. The adalats will be held at all the sub-registrar offices till March 5. Those who have not received the notice, can identify whether their documents have been categorized under undervalued documents from the website of the registrations department. The details are available from the link “online Application/know your document undervalued or not” in the website www.keralaregistration.gov.in.

The details are available at all the sub-registrar offices as well. The provision for remitting 30% of the undervalued sum and getting the documents regularized will be available only till March 31. According to sources in the registration department, the undervaluation of apartments while registering them, mostly of those in which bank loans are not involved, have been taking a heavy toll on the state exchequer.

The government had, in 2016, widened the pool of engineers who can undertake mandatory evaluation of new apartments on the basis of central public works department norms to check undervaluation while registering them.

The government had included all engineers equivalent or above the rank of assistant engineers of PWD, Kerala Water Authority and irrigation department, chartered engineers, approved valuers, registered valuers and registered architects or engineers who can evaluate the apartments and issue certificates.

Title: Min: Fin dept has delayed NREGA funds
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Lucknow: Rural development minister Moti Singh on Tuesday admitted that a delay by the finance department in sanctioning funds for MNREGA was the reason behind the agitation by ‘rozgar sewaks’ or MNREGA volunteers.

Leader of Congress legislature party Aradhana Mishra raised the issue of alleged suicides by MNRGEA volunteers in the state as they had not been getting wages for the past two years. The arrears had risen to Rs 200 crore, she said.

“In many places, MNREGA volunteers have ended their lives and many more are facing starvation. I want to know what the state government is doing for the harried lot. If no steps are taken, the Congress party will launch an agitation,” said Mishra.

Title: CAT relief for IRS officer in AP govt crosshair
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jasti Krishna Kishore

HYDERABAD: Senior Indian Revenue Service (IRS) officer Jasti Krishna Kishore got a relief on Tuesday when the Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT), Hyderabad, set aside his suspension and sent him back to his parent wing of income-tax department.

The AP government suspended Kishore in December last year over allegations of irregularities during his tenure as CEO of the Andhra Pradesh Economic Development Board (APEDB).

A bench comprising tribunal chairman Justice L Narasimha Reddy and member BV Sudhakar gave this verdict after hearing a plea filed by Kishore. The bench, however, made it clear that the AP government was free to pursue the criminal cases it had filed against the IRS officer in accordance with law.

The bench said the suspension was illegal and set aside the order of Kishore’s suspension. The bench also agreed with the argument of senior counsel Neeraj Malhotra who said his client may not get any relief even if the tribunal directs the state government to repatriate Krishna to the Centre since the state may not implement such an order. The tribunal directed Kishore to join his parent wing and a direction was issued to the Centre to take him back.Kishore was an I-T commissioner and part of a team that assessed the accounts of Jagathi Publications, a firm owned by AP chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy. It was based on the findings of this team, CBI officials concluded that the share value of Jagathi was artificially inflated during 2008-09.

Kishore was made APEDB CEO in September 2015 by the then Chandrababu Naidu-led TDP government. Though his deputation from the Centre ended in 2018, it was extended for three more years.

In May 2019 when Jagan came to power, Kishore urged both the Centre and the state government to send him back to his parent wing. However, citing financial irregularities, the AP government refused to repatriate him and transferred him to the secretariat. It attached him to the general administration department (GAD) without giving him any posting. Apart from suspending Kishore, it ordered ACB and CID probes against him to enquire into the alleged deeds of financial misappropriation committed by him. It also asked him to not leave Amaravati without its permission. Following a plea, the tribunal had stayed the suspension order some time back and even found fault with the government’s decision to transfer him to GAD. “By making him an ex-officio secretary, you (government) brought him under your administrative control. Can you do this? Do you possess such powers? You did this only to suspend him,” the bench had fumed at the state counsel in one of the hearings.

Title: MSEDCL restores supply to Latur purification plants
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Not scarcity, but power bill dues deprived Latur residents of water supply for the past 18 days.

Latur residents usually get water supply once in 10 days from the Manjara dam. The water levels in the dam have already hit dead storage, because of which the civic body is pumping water for supply. The Latur Municipal Corporation has not paid the electricity bills totalling Rs 1.8 crore to the irrigation department since September 2019.

Around 10 days back, the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Corporation Ltd ( MSEDCL ) disconnected the power supply to the water purification plants at Harangul, Nagzari, Sai and Varvanti in Latur city in a bid to recover the dues.

MSEDCL superintending engineer N Mane said the Latur municipal corporation has not paid its power bills since September 2019. The disconnection of power was aimed at recovery of dues, he said.

On Tuesday, the Latur municipal corporation made partial payment to the power utility and the supply is expected to be restored.

Latur mayor Vikrant Gojamgunde said the power bills for two months (September and October 2019) have been paid to the MSEDCL. “The corporation has paid Rs 67 lakh to the power distribution company. The power connection to the water purification plants has resumed. We have started pumping water from Tuesday afternoon,” he said.

Gojamgunde added that the dam receives water only in October. So, in order to ensure that current stock lasts till October 2020, the water is being supplied to the city in a 10-day cycle, he said.

He added that the MSEDCL also has dues payable to the Latur civic body worth crores. “They had conducted underground cabling work in 2018 for which they have to pay us Rs 1 crore and they have outstanding property tax dues of Rs 30 lakh. They should avoid disconnecting power to essential services like water supply system,” he said.

The power supply disconnection took a political turn on Monday when BJP corporators and workers held a protest at the municipal corporation office. While the BJP is in the majority in the civic body, the mayor is from Congress. Gojamgunde said that he was elected as mayor only two months back, while the power bills are pending for the last six months. “The dues will be cleared soon,” he told TOI.
