Title: Chief priest found dead at Pilibhit temple
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Pilibhit: The 50-year-old chief priest of Balaji temple in Bisalpur city was found murdered in a room of the temple premises on Tuesday morning.

According to Bisalpur kotwali police, the priest, identified as Vishnu Sahai, was hacked to death. The body was first spotted by a milkman on Tuesday morning.

Circle officer Dharm Singh Marchhal visited the spot, along with a police team and a dog squad, and the body was sent for autopsy.

The priest, hailing from Ajmer in Rajashtan, was living alone in a room on the temple premises.

The CO said, “Police suspect that another priest Ramesh Chandra Mishra, who also used to live on the temple premises, was behind the murder. Mishra, a resident of Sarkhaula village under Bilsanda police station, has been absconding since Tuesday morning along with his wife and children.”

The CO added, “The temple is run by Balaji Trust, which also runs an intermediate college adjacent to the temple.”

Bisalpur kotwali SHO KK Tiwari said following a written complaint by Ravi Sharan Chauhan, principal, SVM Inter College, an FIR was registered against unidentified accused under IPC section 302 (murder). IPC section 34 (acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) will be added to the FIR if it was established that Mishra was involved in the murder.”

Title: Kangana Ranaut's team celebrates 9 years of 'Tanu Weds Manu' and it has a Hrithik Roshan's reference!
Content: Not one to bow out of a social media battle, Kangana Ranaut claimed that she was the first "in the history of Hindi cinema" to bring “Maratha Pride”. She went on to claim that she put her life and career on the line in an “Islam dominate industry” to make a film on Shivaji Maharaj and Rani Laxmibai.

Title: CAA Protest in Kolkata: Kolkata cops on high alert after Delhi riots
Content:
Anti- CAA protesters hit the street near Moulali on Tuesday

KOLKATA: The Lalbazar brass has issued a slew of instructions to its men on the ground in the wake of clashes and violence in Delhi. Nabanna, too, has asked all districts to be vigilant to avoid any skirmish between anti- and pro-CAA protesters.“In the backdrop of clashes reported from Delhi since Monday, all DCs, ACs and OCs are requested to stay alert. Regular patrolling in respective areas, gathering of intelligence and remaining in touch with the community leaders is required. Please take necessary action accordingly,” one such message from the administration and police brass read.The social media cell, though, has been categorically asked to stay in touch with local police and nip all rumours in the bud. Residents have been asked to call up the control room to share any relevant information linked with the any manifestation of anger. “While protests are taking place in the city as well as several districts, none has disrupted everyday life even for a day,” said an IPS officer.Earlier, police commissioner Anuj Sharma had expressed satisfaction to his officers saying not even one major incident was reported in the city after the Citizenship Amendment Act protests broke out across the country. Lalbazar thanked its officers who kept in constant touch with the community, managed the scheduled political marches with confidence and ensured there was enough police mobilisation on the ground. However, Sharma has asked his men not to be complacent but carry on with the good work.Sources said that the vigil will be continued till Holi. Community meetings, like the one arranged for residents of Entally and Beniapukur a couple of months ago, will also continue. “Let us assure all Kolkata citizens that no incident of violence has been reported in the city so far. We are maintaining strict vigil and the citizens are coming forward and helping us,” said an IPS officer.Police said they have made special arrangements for smooth traffic flow despite several protests lined up against the Delhi violence.

Title: Polls for four Rajya Sabha seats on March 26
Content:
Election Commission of India

GANDHINAGAR: The election commission has announced dates for elections to four Rajya Sabha (RS) seats of Gujarat along with those of other states. The election for the four seats in Gujarat will be held on March 26.The term of office of four members of the Rajya Sabha elected from Gujarat — Chunibhai Gohel, Madhusudan Mistry, Lalsinh Vadodiya and Shambhuprasad Tundiya — ends on April 9. While Mistry represents the Congress, the other three represent the BJP.With the budget session of the state assembly starting on Wednesday, and RS elections scheduled for March 26, both BJP and Congress are in election mode. A candidate will need 37 first preference votes to get elected as a Rajya Sabha MP.Meanwhile, both BJP and Congress are facing pressure in finalizing candidates for the election. While sitting MPs are seeking re-nomination, a number of hopefuls are also demanding the nomination.If there is no cross voting or abstentions, the BJP will lose one seat to the Congress, as it does not have adequate numbers to get three candidates re-elected. On the other hand, assuming independent MLA Jignesh Mevani votes for Congress candidates, the Congress has enough MLAs to get two candidates elected.In the run-up to the 2017 Gujarat assembly election, more than a dozen Congress MLAs switched sides, while five more MLAs resigned after the 2017 election. If the BJP has to retain the three RS seats, it will have to get Congress MLAs to either cross-vote or abstain from voting.

Title: Couple killed as police vehicle rams motorcycle
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Warangal: A couple was killed after a speeding police vehicle hit the motorcycle they were travelling in at Thirumalayapally village of Rayaparthy mandal in Telangana on Tuesday.

The deceased were identified as Bommakanti Raju (40) and Rani (33) of Nandanam village, both toddy tappers. Raju’s sister-in-law Kavitha sustained serious head injuries in the accident. She was shifted to MGM hospital in Warangal . Police said that the accident took place when Palakurthy circle inspector Banoth Ramesh Naik’s vehicle hit the couple’s motorcycle when they were returning home after attending a religious ritual at Shakuntala village of Rayaparthy mandal.

They added that the accident was a result of triple riding and speeding. “A triple rider lost control of his vehicle while trying to overtake a truck and hit the police car, which in turn rammed into the couple’s motorcycle,” said Wardhannapet ACP G Ramesh.

Angry villagers who gathered at the accident spot left after an assurance from the police that the case would be properly probed. Police have shifted the bodies to Wardhannapet mortuary for post-mortem.

The Wardhannapet ACP registered a case and investigation is underway.

The couple is survived by two children Rakshitha (12) and Shashank (10).

Title: Hundreds join ‘occupy Raj Bhavan’ protest
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The city saw one of the biggest protests in recent history when anti-CAA protesters laid siege to Raj Bhavan under the aegis of Welfare Party of India.

The 30-hour protest titled ‘Occupy Raj Bhavan’ was inaugurated by Asma Khatun (90) of Shaheen Bagh, one of the oldest women leading the protest there. She handed over a copy of the preamble of the Constitution to Aysha Renna of Jamia Millia Islamia University, who is one of the young faces of the protest.

Khatun said it was the brutality on their children at Jamia Millia Islamia that prompted mothers of Shaheen Bagh to launch the protest.

Congress leaders Adoor Prakash and MM Hassan, IUML general secretary KPA Majeed spoke at the event. Welfare Party of India state president Hameed Vaniyambalam delivered the keynote address.

On Wednesday, Bilkis (82) and Sarvari (75) of Shaheen Bagh will turn up at the protest venue to address the agitators.

Agitators have taken position in front of the main gate of Raj Bhavan, blocking the Vellayambalam–Kowdiar road.

Though the police started regulating vehicle movement by diverting traffic at Vellayambalam and Kowdiar junctions, it led to chaos on the road during peak hours. Many residents even vented their anguish on social media as the main road was blocked on a working day.

Traffic regulation will continue on Wednesday till the protest ends and traffic won’t be allowed from Vellayambalam-Kowdiar road. Police advised motorists coming from Nedumangad side to use alternative routes via Pippinmoodu-Sasthamangalam and Kuravankonam-Nanthancode.

Meanwhile, Sainuddeen (69) from Pathanapuram, who turned up to take part in the agitation, died after he collapsed under the scorching sun at 2pm. Though he was rushed to hospital, doctors declared him dead on arrival. His body was moved to medical college hospital’s mortuary. It will be handed over to the family after conducting autopsy.

Title: Pro-Pakistan slogans: Kolkata student branded traitor for supporting Amulya Leona on Facebook
Content:
Amulya Leona as profile pic draws Ire on Facebook

KOLKATA: In a show of solidarity, Bangabasi College student and Habra resident Souvik had on Saturday put up Amulya Leona’s photo as his Facebook profile picture. The 19-year old girl was charged with sedition for raising ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ slogan at an anti-CAA protest in Bengaluru. Over the last 72 hours, Souvik has been labelled a traitor, jihadi and a Pakistan sympathiser by right-wing supporters.Souvik said he was trolled and warned by ABVP supporters SD Shan Das and Atanu Barai. “The trolling started from Monday and I was called a jihadi, a traitor, a Pakistan sympathizer by the right-wing supporters and groups. They threatened to visit my home and bash me up. They have even reported my Facebook profile to Kolkata Police’s Facebook page,” said the political science student.Souvik felt as a student and a sensible citizen, it was his responsibility to show support to the 19-year old girl who was not given a chance to complete her speech and explain her stand. “She has been booked with sedition for saying ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ but she also said ‘Hindustan Zindabad’. If someone sees her Facebook post, it will be clear what she meant to say. She wanted to hail every country and its people. At a time, when people all over the world, mostly minorities, are being deprived of their rights, it is our duty to work for the people,” said SouvikIn spite of facing wrath from several quarters, Souvik said he completely supported Amulya’s statement: “I don’t become a part of a different nation just because I say zindabad to that nation. As per law, I am an Indian citizen and it is my duty to respect my nation.” He wondered why saying ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ can be seditious but not ‘Long Live America’. “It is unfortunate that my post ‘Long Live America’ was not trolled but my act of putting Amulya’s picture didn’t go down well with a section. This makes the narrative of the right-wing groups clear. I will visit Lalbazar on Wednesday to make my stand clear and register a complaint, “ said Souvik.SFI leader Suvajit Sarkar felt: “Democracy is threatened when someone is trolled just for putting up a picture. Everyone has the right to express their views and should not be put on a trial using social media. But one should not make such comments on a public forum that eventually strengthen the hands of BJP-RSS.”Teerna Bhattacharya, chairperson of JU’s AFSU, added that there should be space for constructive criticism instead of labelling people, which is not our culture.

Title: GSHSEB app to check paper leaks
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Board has developed a special app to check malpractices or incidents of paper leak during class X and XII examinations.

From now the invigilating teacher will not certify if seal has been intact instead will have to upload eight photographs of the sealed examination papers along with location of the mobile phone . One of the pictures should have the signature of the teacher. The GSHSEB officials said teacher will also mark attendance on the app.

Explaining the functioning of the app a GSHEB officer said, as soon as the teachers opens the app, they will have to enter the name of the examination of which he or she is an invigilator and will have to enter the examination centre code along with the building code for the same.

The officials said that the user name and password for the application will change daily and the same will be communicated to the teacher before the commencement of the examination. The officials said that the app was tested successfully in one of the Talent Search test conducted for class IX students.

Title: Ravi Pujari: Man who lived with Ravi Pujari was first to snitch on him
Content:
On his arrest, Pujari denied he was the gangster and showed his Burkina Faso passport to identify himself as A... Read More

ADGP Amar Kumar Pandey displays the passport of gangster Ravi Pujari who was nabbed in South Africa

ADGP Amar Kumar Pandey

displays the passport of

gangster Ravi Pujari

who was nabbed in South Africa

MANGALURU: The first lead on Udupi-born gangster Ravi Pujari was provided to Karnataka police by a man who lived with him in Burkina Faso but finked on him in return for money. The man provided details and pictures of the hotel run by Pujari in the African country and its outlets, a source privy to the gangster’s hunt revealed.This was the first piece of credible information that ADGP (law and order) Amar Kumar Pandey and ACP Venkatesh Prasanna , the two-man team hunting for Pujari since June 2018, got.Handpicked for the job, Pandey had summoned Prasanna asking him to join him in the probe. Only three years earlier, Prasanna had been part of the team that got back another fugitive don, Bannanje Raja, extradited to India from Morocco.The two officers had no lead on Pujari though he’d been booked in several cases of murder, attempt to murder and extortion. No agency in the country had a clue about his whereabouts, the source said.The first thing the officers got to know about the gangster was his refrain in every extortion call he made: “I am Ravi Pujari speaking from Australia,” the extortionist would say. The two officers knew Pujari was bluffing as no criminal would give such accurate details.Sifting through his dossiers, they came to know Pujari was first arrested for robbery in Mumbai in 1992. “They finally managed to get an informant, who agreed to help after a lot of persuasion. He connected police with a person living with Pujari, who allegedly agreed to give information in exchange for money. He told police the man they were looking for was in Burkina Faso and ran a hotel. He gave details about the hotel’s outlets. The informant even shared photos of the hotels from different angles. Police, by then, managed to find another ‘khabri’ (informant) who said there was no Ravi Pujari in Burkina Faso but a man by the name Fernandes,” the source said.The officers spent at least one month checking passports looking for Fernandes. They called the first informant every day. They got a tip off that his house was located near Cambodian English School and through another informant, got the location and a route map. At this point, they received information that he’d left the country by road.It took another 2-3 months for police to get back on track. One of the informants provided them a picture where Ravi Pujari was seen distributing a prize to a winner at a cricket match. Experts found out from the photograph that one of the men in it wore a T-shirt with the word, Cricketers Club, Senegal. Pandey and Prasanna were now sure that Pujari was holed up in Senegal and got in touch with central agencies about their findings.Soon, he was arrested in Senegal. But he claimed he was not Ravi Pujari and showed his Burkina Faso passport to identify himself as Anthony Fernandes from Mysuru. But Prasanna had a copy of his fingerprints collected by Mumbai police when he was arrested in 1992 .

Title: Govt suspends deputy collector
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana government on Tuesday suspended D Srinivas Reddy, deputy collector and tahsildar of Rangareddy district on the charges of irregularities in mutating land in Survey No. 127 of Gopanpally village of Serilingampally mandal during his tenure three years ago. The six-acre land in Gopanpally was mutated in favour of Kondal Reddy, brother of Congress MP A Revanth Reddy.

Chief secretary Somesh Kumar issued the suspension orders saying that the deputy collector did not follow due procedure prescribed under ROR Act and guidelines. Srinivas Reddy was directed not to leave the headquarters without permission of the government. TNN

Title: Gujarat: ‘Machadas’ to help check man-beast conflict
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: To monitor human-wildlife conflict, the Gujarat forest department has started building high towers called ‘machadas’ in Gir and Greater Gir landscape, the last habitat of Asiatic lions.

The towers are equipped with solar-powered mobile charger, and financial assistance of Rs 17,300 is given to farmers for the foundation work for the machadas, officials said.

“The scheme has been rolled out recently and 8,000 farmers have so far enlisted. With big cats increasingly moving out of protected areas, we aim to implement this scheme aggressively and cover new areas like Chotila,” said a forest official.

The scheme aims to protect people from being attacked by lions and the farmers can seek refuge on these machadas, where they can rest or even sleep to escape attacks from wild animals.

“Issues for conservation are changing, the lion is regaining its territory and moving out of the core area, hence it is important for the forest department to gear up for the new challenges, not just for lion but all species,” said D K Sharma, principal chief conservator of forests (PCCF) and head of forest force (HoFF), Gujarat.

He was speaking at a session on the conservation efforts by Gujarat forest department at the 13th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS-COP13) held in Gandhinagar recently.

There are 523 lions in a 22,000 sq km area across eight districts of Gujarat, including the Gir sanctuary, according to the census carried out in 2015. Asiatic lions in Gujarat have seen a considerable rise in their numbers due to key management practices such as habitat management, wildlife monitoring, mitigating human-wildlife conflict, rescue operations, wildlife crime control, eco-tourism, people’s participation, awareness programs and research and training, he said.

Mohan Ram, deputy conservator of forests, Sasan, ascribed significance to research and training as they are the basis of all other practices. The Gir National Park area has camera traps for monitoring, radio-collaring of lions (world’s largest project), GPS monitoring, a wireless communication system, foot patrols and state of the art facilities with the wildlife rescue service.

Title: Kolkata: Disabled take ramp route to protest
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The participants walk the ramp at Tuesday’s show

KOLKATA: A group of visually impaired youths on Tuesday chose the platform of a fashion show and cultural event to voice their concerns over the countrywide protests against the CAA/NRC. They said that their physical inabilities prevented them from going to rallies but they felt the need to speak up against the “coercive” manner in which the citizenship issue was being handled by the Centre.

Most of the participants held posters decrying CAA/NRC, calling it an unnecessary evil. They stood on the stage of the Rabindra Okakura Bhawan, Salt Lake, that had been prepared for a fashion walk. “Unless all of us unite to take a stand against the issue, the message will never reach the Centre,” said Ilyas Molla, a visually impaired RBU student.

Bachchu Bera, who will be representing India as part of the visually impaired football team against Bangladesh on March 9, took part in Tuesday’s event. “Today, even students are not being spared. Though we are visually impaired, we are aware of the bloodshed,” added classical singer Arjun Sarkar.

The programme was jointly organised by Rotary Club of Kolkata South East, Lions Club of Kolkata Sunshine, Sapne and Indian Human Rights & Crime Control Organisation. “We hope other NGOs wil start giving them such protest spaces,” said Ashish Basak, spokesperson for the initiative.

Title: Pongala on March 9, green protocol to be in force
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Attukal Bhagavathy Temple will witness congregation of lakhs of women to offer pongala on March 9. Attukal Pongala is held on the ninth day of festival which will begin on March 1.

The pongala, which has entered the Guinness World of Records as largest gathering of women in 1997 and 2009, will begin at 10.20am with the lighting of pongala hearths and ends by around 2.10pm with the sanctification. The festival will conclude with the ceremonial removal of ‘Kappu’ (kappu azhippu) and the ‘kuruthi tharppanam’ on March 10.

Film actor Anu Sithara will inaugurate stage programmes at 6.30pm on March 1. Lyricist, poet and film director Sreekumaran Thampi will be awarded Attukal Amba Puraskaram 2020.

Around 800 children, aged between 6 and 12, have registered for the ‘Kuthiyottam’ ritual. Temple authorities said that registration for Kuthiyottam will conclude on February 20.

In a news conference on Tuesday, the temple trust authorities said that there are taking all steps to ensure strict implementation of green protocol. “Use of plastic covers and disposable paper/plastic cups are strictly banned. Considering the exam time, we have also directed all to ensure that the loudspeakers don’t pose any diffuculties,” they said.

The temple administration has directed devotees to use non-fired bricks for pongala and ensure that they won’t obstruct traffic. The temple trust has constituted a 115-member committee for the smooth functioning of the festival. Review meetings were conducted by devaswom minister Kadakampally Surendran, mayor K Sreekumar, MLAs and district collector. The event will be live streamed through trust’s official website www.attukal.org.

Title: Soon, a library for bookworms at Technopark
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A reading space for book worms among the techies will soon become a reality at Technopark . Prathidhwani, a socio-cultural organization of techies, has proposed to start a branch of State Central Library at the IT hub.

Prathidhwani has launched a survey to understand the needs of the readers. The plan is to start a library along the lines of the one functioning at Infopark in Kochi.

Dipin Varghese, who was among the people behind the initiative at Infopark and now works at Technopark, said that a meeting was held with Technopark officials and State Central Library authorities and they received positive response from them.

“A library in Technopark has been a long-time demand. We had sent a request in this regard to the higher education department and the State Central Library. The library at Kochi was started in association with Ernakulam Public Library a few years ago. The library is open on one day each week. People can select their books of choice online and library staff brings the books to Infopark. Here, we have planned a library with all infrastructure facilities,” said Dipin.

As a first step towards the initiative the survey was launched. A space near Technopark Club is proposed for the library. A library operating committee has been formed and techies Sabari and Kavitha were selected as its representatives.

“We received around 200 responses within two days of the survey. The survey will be completed in two weeks. Also, considering the demand we will have a separate section for children’s books,” said Dipin.

As of now they have also planned to start a small library by collecting books from the IT community, till the State Central Library branch starts functioning here. It will be open for one or two days in a week and will be managed by techies.

Title: India US Trade Deal: Big trade deal elusive, India & US eye Free Trade Agreement
Content:
PM Modi (R) shakes hands with US President Donald Trump before a meeting at Hyderabad House in New Delhi. (AFP... Read More

NEW DELHI: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday signalled immediate launch of negotiations for a free trade agreement with India with his administration expected to kick off the process through the mandated 90-day notice to the US Congress over the next few days.The move will come along with legal vetting of what is expected to be a $10 billion “limited trade deal” expected to see a restoration of generalised system of preferences (GSP) scheme for India in return for dismantling of “retaliatory tariffs” on American almonds, walnuts and pulses, apart from lowering import duties on high-end motorbikes like Harley Davidson and several farm and food products like cherries.The US too is expected to ease access of Indian food products such as pomegranates. Some of the products on the list may spill over into the free trade agreement, whose details will be thrashed out once negotiations start. Though different from trade issues under discussion, the FTA should signal closer cooperation on trade and commerce in keeping with the overall forward momentum in bilateral ties.“We will hopefully close the first end of the limited engagement that we have already discussed and nearly finalised, ambassador Robert Lighthizer (the US Trade Representative) and I. We’ll get into legal vetting and close that quickly,” commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal said at an event.An announcement on finalising the ‘limited’ trade deal, which many believed was off the table for the moment due to divergent positions, came after bilateral talks at Hyderabad House in the capital. “As far as bilateral trade is concerned, our commerce ministers have had a positive dialogue. President Trump agreed the understanding between our commerce ministers should be given legal shape. We have agreed to launch negotiations for a large trade deal,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in remarks to the media along with Trump.India has also flagged the need for a ‘Totalisation Agreement’ which will allow Indian software professionals to get a refund of the social security contribution that they make while in the US.Once the US completes its internal domestic formalities, the Trade Policy Forum will set up a joint study group to work out the contours of the proposed FTA before actual negotiations kick off. India has focused its trade agreements on reducing import duties of goods in return for getting more visas for its software professionals, chartered accountants and nurses, apart from investment.The US, however, typically seeks a broader agreement, which also seeks to tackle what have been contentious issues such as intellectual property rights dealing with patents as well as regulation of state-owned enterprises. Besides, the US may also seek that its concerns on data flow and opening up FDI for retail and insurance are also addressed.The Indian government appears hopeful of clinching a deal quickly, while assuring interests of Indian industry are protected with Goyal promising comprehensive stakeholder consultations. “We can do a much larger trade deal much faster for two-three reasons... We are both transparent economies. We can trust each other, we can talk with openness and fairness and in the spirit the two nations have decided to engage on a fast-track basis. So, I certainly do not see that this will be like one of those free trade agreement negotiations going for decades and years,” he said.

Title: In a first, city parks to have chess areas & selfie points
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In case you are a chess buff, it won’t be long before you can enjoy a round of chess in the park with your friends or family.

For the first time in the city, open chess areas, selfie points and roller skating yards will come up in two parks. Roller skating yard and open chess areas will be the major attractions at Children’s Park at LMS-Vellayambalam Road, opposite the Kanakakkunnu Palace which will be developed under the Smart City project. Selfie point is one of the key components included under the redevelopment of the Sree Chithira Park.

The project will focus on revamping the parks into more active zones with craft stalls, open air theatre, selfie points, sculptural & landscape elements. SCTL issued tenders for both projects on Tuesday. Sree Chithira Park will be revamped at a cost of Rs 1.78 crore and the Children’s Park at Palayam will be revamped at a cost of Rs 1.72 crore.

Children’s Park, Palayam, will be revamped within nine months. Open chess and food kiosk have been envisaged. Entry ramps will be constructed which will lead to the activity hub. The entrance gate will be re-done and a plaza point will be made which will double up as an interactive space for pedestrians along footpath. A barrier-free pathway will also be constructed linking all the facilities of the park, starting from the entry point.

The open chess area shall have facilities both for children and adults. A roller skating yard will be constructed for children below 10 years of age. Two food kiosks will function near the open chess area. There will be three different seating provisions in the park. The park will also have an open gym. It will be fitted with equipment such as chest press, twist stepper, rider and arm/pedal bikes.

Development of a craft stall, an open seating gallery and landscape improvement are the major components under the project to revamp Sree Chithira Park. As many as 12 craft stalls and two storage spaces will come up as part of the project. Landscape features will include buffalo grass, trees and shrubs. Lamp posts will be installed in the park. As per the scope of the work issued by SCTL, ‘the project for redevelopment of Sree Chithira Park would envision to develop it as a landmark for the city, which will represent and celebrate the culture, art, tradition, heritage, cuisine and handicrafts of the state or more specifically the region’.

Title: In a first, ASI team explores Masol for fossils, stone tools
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

SAAR president Mukesh Singh and ASI deputy superintending archaeologist (pre-history) Dr Manoj Kumar Kurmi in ... Read More

Chandigarh: In a first, a team from the Archaeological Survey of India ( ASI ) is carrying out an “exploration” of fossils around Masol to build on an Indo-French research team’s theory that the first intelligent ancestors of Homo sapiens roamed the hilly village in Mohali district nearly 2.8 million years ago.

An official of ASI confirmed that a four-member team from the central body’s pre-history branch was working at the site. “Our team is working in collaboration with researchers from ASI’s Chandigarh circle, in continuation of the study earlier conducted by the French team,” said Dr Manoj Kumar Kurmi, deputy superintending archaeologist of ASI’s pre-history branch and who is overseeing the entire exercise.

If ASI is able to find more evidence to back the Indo-French team’s study, which concluded that findings in Masol could change the way human evolution is looked at, it would deepen research into the prehistoric site. Dr Kurmi’s team has been issued an exploration and excavation licence from the ASI for carrying out the work till September 2020.

The team, according to a source, arrived for exploring the prehistoric site earlier this month. The source said area around Masol was large and they would be looking for a “suitable” site to carry out a detailed investigation. “If a suitable site is found, we will go for an excavation to establish a stratigraphic sequence,” said Dr Kurmi.

A stratigraphic sequence is a chronologic succession of sedimentary rocks from older below to younger above. Dr Kurmi said stratigraphic sequence, if they are right, would help strengthen claims made by the Indo-French team. “There are positive signs. We have found some tools. We are looking for a possible place where excavation could be carried out,” said another source in the ASI.

When contacted, Mukesh Singh, a member of the Indo-French team and president of Society for Archaeological and Anthropological Research, welcomed the development. Be it the Centre or the Punjab government, the protection of fossils in Masol has been poor. No steps have been taken so far to stop people from taking away fossils and stone tools found there.

Title: Convicted of wife’s brutal murder, Retd Army doctor gets life term
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The Khurda district and sessions judge, Loknath Mohapatra, on Tuesday awarded life imprisonment to retired Army doctor Somnath Parida (78) after convicting him of killing his wife Ushashree and chopping her body into pieces in his bungalow in upscale Nayapalli here in June 2013.

Nayapalli Police had arrested Parida on June 22, 2013, after finding the body parts of Ushashree (62 at the time of death) stashed in 22 boxes in the couple’s house on June 21. They said he had killed her on June 3 and kept the body parts in the house, where the couple lived on their own, as he was confident they would not be discovered.

His crime would have gone unnoticed had Ushashree’s brother not visited the house on the evening of June 21. His suspicions were aroused by Parida’s furtive actions and the foul smell emanating from the house, and he informed police.

Police had conducted a polygraph test on Parida on June 29, 2013, and filed a charge-sheet in court on October 17, 2013. Since his arrest, Parida has been kept in the Jharpada Special Jail here.

Public prosecutor Sarad Chandra Samant said the sensational murder had been the result of prolonged bitterness between the couple. Parida was not on talking terms with his daughter, who then lived in the UAE. Ushashree, who would talk to their daughter on the phone regularly, had angered Parida by insisting on letting her visit the Bhubaneswar house. Matters between the couple soured further and he is believed to have killed her in a fit of rage.

“Ushashree died after being hit on the head with a blunt object,” the public prosecutor said. “I had sought capital punishment for Parida as the nature of the offence is barbaric,” he added.

Police sources said the couple’s daughter and son had both given statements against their father. They had also said Parida had planned to dispose of Ushashree’s mutilated corpse in Shirdi.

On Tuesday, Parida broke down in court after the pronouncement of the verdict. “I am innocent. I was an honest officer in the Army. I never took bribes,” he told reporters outside the court.

Parida had joined the Army as Second Lieutenant in 1970 and retired as Lieutenant Colonel in1992.

Title: Kolkata: Patuli woman files murder-threat plaint, pro-CAA group counters
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

KOLKATA: A day after Kasturi Basu, who was campaigning in her Patuli neighbourhood against the amended citizenship law, claimed that she had received death threats and the pro-CAA camp retorted that she had allegedly misbehaved and even slapped one of them, the cops said they were investigating the conflicting versions.

A few of those cops have spoken to so far are “trying to mislead the probe”. “We are trying to develop on a few CCTV footage leads in this respect,” said an officer from the south suburban division.

Police said the neighbours of the woman, Basu, who is an independent documentary filmmaker, will be approached soon. “As for our prima facie investigation, the pro-CAA camp was unhappy that their posters were being taken down. They were trying to identify the person who did it when Basu came out and stated those posters were hurting sentiments of some people. She dared them and an argument ensued. The pro-CAA camp said it was then that she had slapped one of them,” said an investigating officer.

The men who confronted Basu were led by Tulshi Gharami, the district president of the BJP-affiliated Bharatiya Janata Mazdoor Trade Union . Basu has denied slapping Gharami. Gharami and Basu both lodged complaints with Patuli police station after the face-off. “We have slapped IPC charges on both sides based on specific complaints. We have warned them against any further escalation,” said an officer.

Title: Passengers rue as audio ads drown announcements at rly stations
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Passengers travelling from major railway stations in the city – Secunderabad, Mancherial, Kacheguda, Hyderabad and Nampally – are complaining about not being able to hear train announcements due to loud audio advertisements being played at the stations.

“The advertisements continuously run at the stations. They are very loud. As I am a regular passenger, I know my train timings. But those travelling occasionally may find it hard to navigate amid the loud chaos,” Keerthi Kalyanam, who was at Secunderabad railway station , told TOI.

Passengers say that they are missing their trains as the unregulated advertisements are drowning out important announcements.

“Due to unregulated non-stop ads at Mancherial railway station by Kartikeya advertisements, we can't even hear the train announcements. People playing with government property as they want because no one is checking," tweeted a passenger on Monday tagging the rail ministry, South Central Railway (SCR) and the respective divisional railway managers on Twitter.

Staffers at the railway stations say that there has been no marked change in the advertisements or announcements, however passengers say the frequency of public service announcements have lowered in the past few months and advertisements have increased.

"Necessary railway announcements are being made regularly at all stations, and very few advertisements run throughout the day but we will definitely look into the matter raised by the passengers," said an official from SCR.

Railway union members have come in support of the passengers saying that the commercialisation of the railway station space is a major reason behind may issues.

"Most of the railway stations in the city, especially Secunderabad, Kacheguda and Nampally have become increasingly commercialised. Number of private stores in and around the station have increased and the authorities are thereby running their ads continuously to earn more revenue," said a member of South Central Railway Mazdur Union (SCRMU).

Title: Road problem hanging fire for decades solved in days
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The dirt road at New Colony, Miyapur X Road, is getting a cement concrete layer, and the area is also getting an underground drainage line after residents living in that area highlighted their plight on TOI Citizen Reporter app.

Residents said they had reported the grievance several times to authorities, but in vain. Half of the road has already been laid by Tuesday. The grievance was published on February 11 in TOI Citizen Reporter section.

The first representation to fix the road was given in 2012, after which the budget was sanctioned, but the works did not take off.

“I took up the problem with MLA, corporators and GHMC officials too, but the issue was not fixed for years,” said Anwar Akhtar, the citizen reporter. “I reported the complaint so many times that I even remember the names of GHMC engineers. I thank TOI for publishing the issue.”

P Chinna Reddy, GHMC executive engineer of the area, said: “We are also laying underground drainage line in that area.”

Another resident said that the bad stretch had turned into a parking lot for autos. Residents also lodged a police complain about the illegal parking previous year.

“The autos, with seating capacity of seven, used to be parked on this kachha road. Now, after the GHMC started laying the new road, auto drivers are not parking their vehicles. Our security concerns have also come to an end along with commuting woes,” said Srinivas Murty a resident of New Colony. “People living in Laxminivasam and Srinivasam along and Narayandri Building will be benefited the most,” he added.

The road, which is being restored, is close to NH-65. Even a brief spell of rain brings stagnant water, and mosquitoes. This besides the piled up garbage.

Title: Senior citizen dies after fall from tree at Bantwal
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: A senior citizen died after accidentally falling from a tree at Ajikala in Bantwal taluk on Tuesday. Police said the victim is Koragappa , 65, a resident of Kanakapade .

When Koragappa was trimming tree branches, he accidentally slipped and fell down. He was immediately rushed to a nearby hospital, but succumbed to his injuries on the way.

A case has been registered at the Bantwal town police station in this regard.

Title: Urs: Pak team to reach Ajmer on February 28
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Ajmer: The delegation from Pakistan will come to attend the 808th Urs of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishty and will reach Ajmer on February 28. The 260-member delegation will reach Ajmer by a special train from Atari border.

A meeting was held on Tuesday for arrangements and security measures for the team, which is coming to Ajmer after a gap of two years. After the meeting, district collector Vishwa Mohan Sharma told media that they have received information that a delegation of 260 devotees from Pakistan is coming to attend the annual Urs by train. Till now, visas have been given to 200 devotees and the administration is making further arrangements.

Title: Spot a pothole in Kochi, send a WhatsApp alert
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

A pothole-filled road in Kochi city (File Photo)

KOCHI: Now, if residents come across potholes or bad stretches of road in the city they can bring them to the attention of the amici curiae appointed by the high court.

The public can click pictures of potholes and post them on the WhatsApp numbers of advocates S Krishna, Vinod Bhatt, and P Deepak who were appointed amici curiae in the case seeking repair and maintenance of bad roads in the city.

The three have been entrusted with the task of going around and identifying places within Kochi corporation limits with potholes. They have been doing the activity since the last three months. Speaking to TOI, advocate P Deepak said, “Initially, the WhatsApp numbers were circulated among advocates. Later, we discussed the matter with the Kerala high court advocates association. They took it up and posted them on their website. As a result, responses have started to trickle in. The whole process has just started.”

The amici curiae want to diversify the activity by taking this activity to the municipalities adjoining Kochi corporation, particularly Maradu, Tripunithura and Kalamasserry. As it is difficult for the three to go around in all these areas, they publicized the WhatsApp numbers. As of now, these municipalities are not a party to the case. They requested the HC to implead the local bodies in the adjoining areas. The intention is to spread the message to a larger region.

Meanwhile, the Edappally-Tripunithura Road, SRM Road, entry point to Ponnurunni ROB from Vyttila Junction, the exit and entry roads to Subhas Chandra Bose Road from Vyttila Junction, Santo Gopalan Road and Pandikudy Road are in bad shape with maintenance work being carried out by Kerala water authority (KWA) and Kerala state electricity board (KSEB).

“Residents are forced to rely on these roads, even in case of emergencies, and this is frustrating. The dust that is generated on bad stretches blows into houses and shops, casuing health issues and other inconveniences,” said Sreedharan Nair, whose resides along the Edappally-Tripunithrua Road. He said people are clueless on when the road owners would complete the work.

Moreover, people will stand to benefit only if the WhatsApp system really works.

Title: Maharashtra: Man gets life term for rape and murder of 4-year-old girl
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

Title: Pvt schools disregard govt bar, make a killing in fees
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Even as the state government tries to introduce reforms in the education department to check the collection of exorbitant amounts of fees in private schools, many corporate institutions in the city expedited the 2020-21 admission process without permission in a bid to rake in large amounts in fees.

Chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy, who promised to create a stress-free pocket-friendly education system in the state, constituted Andhra Pradesh School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission (APSERMC) to implement education reforms.

The state government conducted inspections in private and corporate schools collecting unreasonably high fees and barred them from conducting admissions till they were given grades fixing the fee pattern.

But the majority of corporate schools in the city are conducting admissions ignoring the directions. Parents were busy gathering reference letters of ministers and other VIPs to get admissions for their kids in corporate schools. “Marketing teams of corporate school managements were repeatedly contacting us for the admission of my son in high school. They are offering huge discounts if we take admission before the completion of the academic year,” said J Lakshmi Narasimha a private employee.

Student associations strongly condemned the early admissions.

“Many corporate schools in the city completed 50 per cent of admissions in their schools. They were trying to attract parents by offering huge discounts. The education department should take necessary measures to stop the admission process before regulating the fee structure,” said K Ramesh state secretary of the Student Federation of India. Krishna district education officer Rajya Lakshmi speaking with TOI requested parents not to take up early admissions in corporate schools.

“We have noticed that many private schools in Krishna district are running against rules. They are collecting exorbitant amounts in fees. We have started inspections as per the guidance of APSERMC and schools violating norms will lose their recognition soon. Parents will suffer if they got admission to such schools,” she pointed out. I have directed deputy education officers across the district to identify schools taking early admissions and initiate stringent action against them, Rajyalakshmi added.

Title: Eyes on SC relief to resume work at NGT bench
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

NGT chairperson Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel had issued an office order transferring expert member Siddhanta Das ... Read More

PUNE: The NGT Western Zone Bar Association will seek a judicial order from the Supreme Court at the hearing of their writ petition on March 3 after the green tribunal’s administration in Delhi on Tuesday extended, for the second time, the date of resumption of functioning of the NGT western zone bench in Pune to April 1 for want of a judicial member.

“The Centre has finalized names of six judicial members for appointment, but the cabinet committee of ministers has not yet approved them, despite assurances to the SC at the previous hearings,” lawyer Saurabh Kulkarni , the association’s president told TOI. “We will raise this issue at the impending hearing to seek a judicial order from the Supreme Court (SC),” he added.

Since an SC order on January 1, 2018, an elaborate recruitment process is on for the appointment of judicial and expert members at the NGT benches. “The NGT’s Chennai bench, which has lesser matters compared to Pune, has already benefited from the recruitment process as it has resumed operation with a two-member bench from December 2, 2019,” Kulkarni said.

On January 2, NGT chairperson Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel had issued an office order transferring expert member Siddhanta Das from the green tribunal’s principal bench in New Delhi to the Pune bench. Following this, the NGT administration had issued a circular stating that the western zone bench will become functional from February 1, 2020, subject to joining of a judicial member.

The development gave hope to several environmental litigants from Maharashtra , Gujarat, Goa and the Union Territories (UTs) of Daman and Diu, Dadra and Nagar Haveli considering that after New Delhi, the green tribunal’s Pune bench draws maximum number of litigations concerning several key environmental issues in these states and UTs. “The pendency of cases at the Pune bench is around 600,” Kulkarni said.

The litigants have been waiting for over two years now after an SC order on January 1, 2018, (in the WZ bar association’s petition which remains pending) restrained NGT cases from being heard by one-member benches. Between February and August 2018, only filing of cases was allowed at the Pune bench. In case of urgent matters, the litigants were required to move the principal bench in New Delhi for relief. After August 2018, the matters filed at Pune bench are being heard via video conferencing on an average two days per week for two-hour session each.

However, in another circular on January 31, the NGT administration extended the date of resumption of work at NGT’s Pune bench to March 2, subject to joining of a judicial member. The latest circular on Tuesday, once again cited a similar reason and stated that the Pune bench will start from April 1.

Title: Narrow Yapral road leads to brawls
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: A narrow carriageway coupled with commuters travelling in the wrong direction have led to several heated arguments at Yapral junction . The most recent skirmish, involving a retired defence personnel, has left locals fuming.

Describing the incident, Col Krishna Mohan Poduri (retd), said, “A scooter rider coming from Hanuman temple had taken a wrong turn and almost hit a motorcycle-borne family coming from the Ammuguda side. Despite being in the wrong, the scooter driver got aggressive, and when I intervened, he began attacking me and even tried to choke me.” A FIR has been lodged in the case at the Jawaharnagar police station.

The assault is among many skirmishes being reported from the area as a result of a lack of planning at the junction, say locals. Though the junction appears small, the volume of traffic it caters to has been on the rise.

Speaking about the roundabout, Malcom Wolfe, a road safety expert who lives in the area, said, “Space restriction does not allow larger vehicles to travel around the roundabout, which means they are forced to break rules.” Besides a narrow carriageway, he says street vendors and shanties have eaten into the road, reducing its area.

Wolfe said persistent follow-ups with the GHMC about improvement works over three years have met a dead-end.

Responding to the issue, GHMC assistant city planner, Malkajgiri, Md Khaliluddin, said that the zonal commissioner along with the executive engineer and other officials had inspected the site.

“Notices were issued for a building that is suspected to be protruding on to the road. The electricity department has given an estimate to shift electric poles which are on the road. A junction improvement plan is under consideration.”

Besides the road itself, locals say the area faces several challenges. K M Rajesh, a resident, said, “We find a lot of youngsters hanging about the area and drinking. This has become a concern especially for women who travel through the area.”

Attributing the issues to the increasing population in the area, Air Vice Marshal Sagar Bharti (retd), said, “The influx of residents and commuters following the city’s expansion requires one to revisit planning. More awareness must also be created so that people follow the rules.”

Title: US firm’s bankruptcy to hit handicrafts exporters
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: The Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of the Texas-based Pier 1 Imports has rattled the handicraft exporters in Rajasthan leaving them wondering if they could recover collective dues of Rs 400 crore. Additionally, they are also confronted with the challenge of finding another buyer like Pier 1, on which some exporters depended fully.

The handicrafts industry estimates that over 70 companies from Jodhpur and Jaipur supplied home furnishings, decor, particularly furniture, table-top items and decorative accessories to the New York Stock Exchange listed Pier 1 and the dues pending with the company could be around Rs 400 crore.

But some exporters from the state said Chapter 11 bankruptcy allows the company to restructure or sell out and it is not that the pending dues will not be honoured.

“As part of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy, Pier 1 has already raised $260 million to revive its business. It is now closing down 450 loss making stores and has announced that the rest of the 1000-odd stores will conduct routine business. For the time being, the payments are stuck but the exporters will get back the money once the retailer comes out of the proceedings,” said an exporter in Jaipur who has been working with the retailer for close to a decade.

When TOI contacted the company to know its payment obligations to Indian exporters, the Pier 1 replied with a note that detailed about the Chapter 11 bankruptcy process which is yet to ascertain the liabilities of the company.

Exporters also take insurance for their exports so that they don’t lose out the entire receivables in the event of any mishap or the company failing to pay up. When TOI contacted the Jaipur branch of Export Credit Guarantee Corporation, which provides insurance against the shipments, an official said that they are yet to receive any claims.

“The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy only last week. It will take time to ascertain the liabilities. But once the exporters submit us the bills for which payments have not been received, we will start the process,” said the official.

Not every exporter is taking ECGC cover because it needs them to pay a premium. But the ECG official said that exporters can get back 80-90% of money if they submit the details of their policy.

Title: Maharashtra CM tells officials to continue with new airport work
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Shirdi airport

PUNE: Chief minister Uddhav Thackrey on Tuesday told the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited to go ahead with the proposed new Pune airport project while presiding over its board meeting for the first time after the new government was formed.

“We briefed him about the developments and the status of the new Pune airport project. He did not react and just instructed us to continue with the work which was started,” a source in the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) said.

Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar had earlier said he would take a decision on the project soon. Speculations are rife about the site of the project being shifted.

Sources in the MADC said Thackeray told the officials to focus on the Shirdi airport in the meeting and develop it aesthetically.

“We briefed Thackeray about the developments at Shirdi and he said that the new terminal building of the airport should have aspects of the Sai Baba temple and the temple town. He said the best practices should be followed for the construction,” another source said.

“The tender for the construction of the new terminal building would be floated next month. New flights to Delhi, Chennai and Indore have started from the Shirdi airport and IndiGo is operating an Airbus A-321, which can carry 222 passengers. There are 34 flight movements at Shirdi now. The status of Amravati airport was also discussed. We informed the chief minister that the airport would be re-developed and commissioned early next year for flights under UDAN,” the MADC official said.

Title: Pune: Restaurateurs claim losses due to police clamp down, approach commissioner
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Restaurants along Balewadi High Street

PUNE: Nearly 70 restaurateurs attended a meeting with the Pune Restaurants and Hoteliers Association (PRAHA) and the police commissioner on Tuesday to air their grievances over the police’s action on facilities against alleged flouting of noise norms in the last fortnight.

The owners said police personnel had entered multiple restaurants in Koregaon Park and the surrounding areas around 9.30pm on February 15 over flouting of noise regulations. “Resultantly, almost all the restaurants in Koregaon Park, Kalyaninagar and the surrounding areas had to be closed early on February 15,” a restaurateur said.

Another restaurant owner said, “We are being told there have been noise complaints. The police are confiscating the equipment without investigation. The noise levels were not even checked before the systems were confiscated. We have all the permits and are following the law.”

PRAHA president Ganesh Shetty said, “We received complaints from our members across the city. There were instances where the customers were told to leave while the staff members were taken to the police station. Why is the police doing this even when restaurants have all the permissions? The police say they have got orders from the top.”

He said all restaurants in Maharashtra were allowed to serve liquor till 1.30am. “According to the Supreme Court guidelines, establishments can play music outdoors till 10pm. Music can be played indoors till the late hours if it does not cause a nuisance,” a restaurant owner said.

Shetty said the police action was only leading to revenue loss for restaurants. “Customers will not visit restaurants if police are stationed outside from 9.30pm. We raised these issues with the police commissioner,” he said.

Another restaurateur said the meeting with the police commissioner remained inconclusive as they were still confused about the course of action for sound permissions.

When contacted, Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham said, “We have advised restaurateurs to put peer pressure on hoteliers not following rules. They stated that they were following rules. I told them if that was the case, we will deploy manpower elsewhere.”

Title: Making Delhi world-class government priority: LG Anil Baijal
Content:
Anil Baijal

NEW DELHI: Making Delhi a “world-class” city and a “classic example” of good governance will be the priority of the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) government in the next five years, lieutenant governor Anil Baijal said on Tuesday.Addressing the newly elected legislators on the second day of the seventh Delhi assembly’s first session, Baijal also appealed to people to maintain “peace, law and order, communal harmony” in view of the violence in north-east Delhi over the amended citizenship law and urged them to cooperate with security agencies.Outlining the government’s priorities, Baijal said the current dispensation would “focus on further consolidation of welfare activities” such as 200 units of free electricity, 20 kilolitres of free water, free bus ride for women, quality education and infrastructure, mohalla clinics, highest minimum wages in the country, doorstep delivery of services and the free pilgrimage scheme for senior citizens.The government’s commitment towards the welfare of people, Baijal pointed out, got reflected in the “10 guarantees” made in the run-up to February’s assembly elections. These include 24-hour electricity supply apart from undergrounding of cables; 24-hour clean piped water to every household; quality education to all till graduation; cheap, accessible and better healthcare; largest and cheapest transport system; pollution-free, clean and beautiful Delhi; women’s safety; basic infrastructure in unauthorised colonies; and pucca houses for slum dwellers. The government will also take “further action to make Delhi a world-class city”, he added.The government’s focus on getting “equal and fair” share in central taxes and funds for the municipal corporations as per the central finance commission’s recommendations also featured in the speech. The AAP government has repeatedly complained about Delhi’s share being stuck at Rs 325 crore since 2001 though the citizens of Delhi pay about Rs 1.5 lakh crore in taxes.“Equal and fair share for Delhi like other states in central taxes is essential for economic development. Prior to 2001, there was a system of sharing central taxes for the development of Delhi. To get it re-established and provide funds to the corporations... are among the priorities of my government,” the LG said.Baijal also sought cooperation of the newly elected members — a combination of veteran, experienced and first-timers — “to realise the dreams of the people of Delhi of living in a city, which is caring and productive, which embraces change and nurtures talent to make our life environmentally sustainable and prosperous”.The three-day session will conclude on Wednesday with the election of the deputy speaker and the motion of thanks on the LG’s address.

Title: 2 traffickers arrested, six kids rescued
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Ibrahimpatnam police arrested two persons for allegedly trafficking six minors from Jagdalpur in Chhattisgarh to Nagari in Chittoor district and Salem in Tamil Nadu after Bachapan NGO and representatives of Child Line alerted them.

Based on the information given by NGOs, police intercepted a bus carrying 20 people near Ibrahimpatnam. Upon checking the bus, police spotted six minors, including a girl, being taken to work in poultry farms and stone crushing units.

Ibrahimpatnam inspector K Sridhar Kumar said Kiran from Nagari hired them from Jagdalpur through Mitesh from Bihar. Mitesh supplied some people to Kiran to work in his poultry farms at Nagari and took the rest of them to Salem in Tamil Nadu to put them to work in the stone crusher industry.

The minors aged under 14 years have been sent to a rescue home for rehabilitation and the two persons have been arrested under relevant sections of Prevention of Human Trafficking Act. They were produced before court which sent them to judicial remand.

Title: United campaign should be launched against BJP: Activist
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Cooling heads: Safwan, a volunteer, sprays water on people sitting under the hot sun at the protest against CA... Read More

MANGALURU: A united political campaign should be launched against the BJP , which is trying to garner votes through divisive politics in the name of CAA , NRC and NPR , said activist B R Bhaskar Prasad .

In his keynote address at a protest rally organised by the Muslim Aikyatha Vedike at Kudroli on Tuesday, Prasad said the BJP has lost two major sources of their vote bank – Ayodhya and Gau Mata. Hence the BJP has devised CAA, NRC and NPR to divide people and thereby ensure their vote bank stays intact in the next Lok Sabha election, he said.

“For many years, the BJP used Ayodhya for their political mileage. However, they have lost it after the Supreme Court delivered a verdict. They were also playing politics in the name of cows, but their political motive behind it has already been exposed. They have been considering cows as gau mata, but they are silent about six major companies that are exporting 1.5 lakh tonnes of beef a day. None of those exporters are Muslims and Dalits. Now the BJP wants to create a burning issue to ensure their victory in future. Hence, they have devised CAA, NRC and NPR to divide people and ensure their victory in the next Lok Sabha election,” he said, and appealed to people to be cautious about the consequences of the implementation of it.

The proposed citizenship laws of the government will affect not only Muslims. It will have worse impact on Hindus, especially, Dalits, backward communities, tribals and all citizens, who are homeless, he said, adding, “Let Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah show their educational qualifications before asking us for our documents.”

The organisers had named the protest venue after Nauseen Kudroli and Jaleel Bengre, who died in the police firing during an anti-CAA protest in Mangaluru on December 19, 2019. On the police firing, Prasad said, “I apologise before the kin of Nauseen and Jaleel that our system killed them.”

Religious preacher H I Sufiyan Sakhafi said though India has many religions, castes and sub-castes, it was Dr B R Ambedkar who made the nation a sovereign socialist secular democratic republic. “We love the Constitution of India and we will protect it at any cost by dedicating our lives. In the history of India, we cannot find a government policy that offered citizenship to people on the basis of their religion. We will not allow this anti-constitutional rule,” he added. Former minister U T Khader spoke on the occasion.

Title: Uma Bharti praises V D Sharma, calls him grassroots leader
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Former Union minister Uma Bharti and BJP state chief VD Sharma

BHOPAL: Former Union minister Uma Bharti on Tuesday reached BJP state headquarters to meet newly-appointed BJP state chief V D Sharma .

“Promises made by the Congress-led state government to the people of Madhya Pradesh were not fulfilled. People feel betrayed and cheated. Law and order situation has also turned worse as crimes are being reported from places close to police stations. We have fought for the interests of the people without being in power for a long time, achieving the objectives and goals. We lost our government and pride after losing the last assembly election. We are not in power today, but will force the Congress government to fulfil promises it made to the people,” said Bharti.

A day before, Sharma had a close-door meeting with former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan and former Rajya Sabha member Kailash Sarang. However, he could not meet Uma Bharti at her official residence.

Uma is happy with changes made in the state organisation and extended support to Sharma, said sources.

“The organisation, which was nurtured and nourished by our ideologues —Kushabhau Thakre and Rajmata Vijayaraje Scindia —has made a right choice to preserve the culture and courage of the party. VD Sharma, being a capable grassroots worker, has all the qualities of a good leader and being a capable president. He won Lok Sabha election by a margin of 5 lakh votes. Under his leadership, we will see the BJP again in power,” Bharti said.

The BJP leader also added that she knew Sharma since 25 years and took the initiative for his marriage with Stuti (Sharma’s wife), who is daughter for her old friend. Sharma said that he was overwhelmed by Bharti’s gesture and always respected her as a senior party leader.

Title: MHA panel submits report to CM Sarbananda Sonowal
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

GUWAHATI: The panel set up by the ministry of home affairs ( MHA ) to recommend ways to implement Clause-6 of the Assam Accord to provide constitutional, legislative and administrative safeguards to the indigenous Assamese people submitted its report to chief minister Sarbananda Sonowal here on Tuesday.

Sonowal is expected to send the report to Union home minister Amit Shah soon but the recommendations, which are a result of the Assam Accord of 1985, will not be binding on the Centre without screening and ratification by the Assam Assembly.

For 34 years, Clause-6 of the Accord for protection of the identity of Assamese people has not been touched by any government in the absence of an official definition for ‘Assamese people’.

“MHA will examine and see if the recommendations are within the ambit of the Constitution or if there are any recommendations going against any judgment of the Supreme Court, which cannot be implemented. MHA also has to send back the recommended definition of the ‘Assamese people’ to the Assembly. The Assembly will then discuss the definition and give its approval before it can be implemented,” minister Himanta Biswa Sarma said.

Three leaders of All Assam Students’ Union (Aasu), who are members of the panel, did not attend the handing over function to register their protest against the report being submitted to the chief minister and not the Union home minister.

“The Union home minister had shown so much of interest when he announced the setting up of the panel, but now he has no time for the panel to accept its report,” Aasu chief advisor Samaujjal Bhattacharyya said.

Justice (retd) B K Sharma , who led the high-level committee, said: “The report was prepared in time, but as it has not been made public and is yet to be handed over to the Union home minister, it will not be prudent on my part to divulge anything.”

He said the panel deliberated on the various clauses of the Assam Accord, visited places in Assam, and received more than 1,200 representations and talked to various stakeholders for preparing the report.

Sharma said, “There were two things — to suggest ways for safeguards to Assamese people and give a definition of Assamese people, who will get the safeguards.”

He added, “We have also given a cut-off date for identifying an Assamese. Various suggestions were received… some wanted that it should be 1826, the year of the Treaty of Yandabo — when Burma agreed to cede to the British-Assam, Manipur, Rakhine (Arakan) and the Taninthayi (Tenasserim) coast south of the Salween River . Some others wanted it to be 1950 when India became a republic and some suggested 1971 (the cut-off date for determining an illegal migrant as per the Assam Accord). We examined all suggestions and arrived at a date we thought was right.”

Title: Revamp of Monda Market delayed as vendors protest against eviction notices
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Plans to revamp the historic Monda Market have hit a roadblock. In spite of eviction notices being served to vendors multiple times, even in September last year, the vendors have stood their ground.

The Monda Market is a heritage structure which was constructed in 1880. All the shops, stalls were allotted during 1954 to persons on a lease basis for one year, subject to certain lease terms and conditions. In 2011, rents were enhanced for 384 units of the market.

Citing high court orders in 2009, officials state that, “No renewal of lease is permitted even with the sanction of government for a period beyond twenty-five years without conducting public auction.”

Terming the vendors as “unauthorized tenants”, the government directed that eviction notices be issued, but with the stall owners standing firm, the revamp of the market will take longer.

Yadagiri Rao, additional commissioner, estates, GHMC, however said, “Plans were going as per schedule and evictions will take another month.” He said engineers will be roped in for a design for the revamp once the eviction is completed.

Vendors however, have remained steadfast in their protest. Venkat Mohan, state president, Telangana Street Vendors and Hawkers Trade Union, said, “Section 3(3) of the Street Vendors (Protection Of Livelihood and Regulation Of Street Vending) Act 2014 clearly says that no street vendor can be evicted or relocated till two surveys are completed. An ID card and vending certificates have to be issued to them.”

He added that unless a suitable location is provided to the hawkers and benefits of various schemes are provided to them, any move would be illegal.

Title: High court orders CBI probe into illegal detention of 3 in Guntur
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Tuesday ordered Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to conduct an inquiry into the alleged illegal detention of three persons by Guntur urban police and submit a report by June 17.

The high court had earlier ordered a judicial inquiry into the issue.

The police, however, had opposed the judicial inquiry report alleging that it had not taken facts into account. With the police opposing the judicial inquiry report, the high court said it will order a CBI inquiry, which the police did not object to.

The high court directed the CBI to conduct an inquiry and asked them to submit the report by June 17.

The Guntur urban CCS police allegedly took N Adinarayana, R Srinivasa Rao and T Srinivasa Rao into custody on charges of cricket betting in October, last year. However, after they did not return home, their wives lodged a missing complaint with Pattabhipuram police station and later also met Guntur urban SP P H D Ramakrishna.

After the police failed to respond, the wives of the missing persons filed habeas corpus petitions in the high court seeking directions to the police to present their husbands before the court.

The high court heard the matter on October 31 and the government pleader sought time to submit details.

On the same day, Chebrole police produced the three missing persons before Guntur court. The three accused deposed before the court that they have been in police custody since October 14 and the same was recorded by the magistrate.

Nimmagadda Venkateswarlu, the advocate for the petitioners submitted the statements of the accused to the high court and said that the police have put them under illegal detention without producing them before the court.

Taking a serious note of the issue, the high court directed the Guntur principal senior civil judge to conduct an inquiry and submit a report on the role of police officers connected to the matter. The judicial inquiry report was submitted to the high court on Tuesday.

Title: 8 gang members arrested
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The Task Force South Zone team arrested two gangs, including a total of eight offenders, who were involved in three separate cases of extortion, dacoity and theft. Items worth Rs 2.75 lakh, including two motorcycles and five mobile phones, were seized from their possession. The first gang of five members were arrested for extortion and dacoity. The other gang of three persons was booked for theft. tnn
