Title: Quota above 50% in local bodies: HC to hold fresh hearing
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Tuesday reserved orders on a batch of petitions challenging implementation of reservations in panchayat elections over and above 50 per cent.

Earlier, the high court had reserved the orders after hearing both sides. The high court, however, decided to conduct fresh hearing as the applicability and power under section 202-A of Andhra Pradesh Panchayat Raj Act 1994 and three other judgments given by the high court in similar matter were not covered in earlier arguments and needs to be verified to come to a conclusion.

Earlier, the petitioners argued that providing reservations more than 50% was a violation of Supreme Court judgments. They argued that the providing reservations beyond the set limit would violate the rights of others and would deny them equal rights given under the Constitution. On Tuesday, the high court bench headed by the Chief Justice J K Maheswari and Ninala Jayasurya held a fresh hearing on the matters related to section 202-A of Panchayat Raj Act.

The bench asked about the basis for reaching at a little over 59% reservations in local bodies. The HC also asked about Section 202-A of Andhra Pradesh Panchayat Raj Act which says the reservations to backward castes should be provided based on socio economic survey by Andhra Pradesh Backward Classes Co-operative Finance Corporation Limited.

Replying to the bench, advocate general S Sriram said that the reservations were based on 2011 census and the population of backward classes in the state is more than what is being given by the state government. He argued that in special circumstances the state government can provide reservations over and above 50% for equal representation of all.

Title: Kerala: Arooja’s school functioned ignoring shutdown notice
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

KOCHI: Arooja’s Little Stars School (ALSS), Mattancherry, which landed in a controversy after 29 Class X students of the school missed the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) board exam this year due to lack of affiliation, has not met any of the requirements mentioned in the CBSE Affiliation Bye Law 2018, said district education officials.

The district education officer (DEO) has rejected the school’s application for government recognition and no objection certificate (NOC) multiple times citing the lack of basic infrastructure prescribed by the CBSE. The latest rejection letter was issued in May 2019. Moreover, the school had been reportedly operating illegally after ignoring a shutdown notice issued by the deputy director of education (DDE) in October 2017 due to the lack of recognition and affiliation.

According to the rejection order issued by the DEO Ernakulam, which was accessed by TOI, the school failed to meet 11 requirements considered mandatory for the affiliation. “ALSS is situated on less than seven cents whereas the CBSE affiliation requirement is two acres. Also, the school does not have its own road and is using the paths used by the nearby residents. Playground is necessary for CBSE affiliation and the school lacks one,” the order said.

The school authorities did not mention the dimensions of the classrooms while submitting the application and a few classes were conducted on the two floors of a residential building. There is no building plan submitted by the management. Also, it has not submitted the fire safety certificate from fire and rescue department.

“Above all, the teachers in the school must have to be qualified as per the National Council for Teacher Education standards and ALSS could not provide any proof for the same qualifications of teachers. Also, the teaching or non-teaching staff should have the same remuneration as those working in corresponding government schools. ALSS failed to submit proofs for this too,” said the order.

Title: Delhi most polluted capital globally, Ghaziabad worst city: Report
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

A traffic policeman wears a face mask to protect from pollution (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi topped the list of most polluted capital cities in the world in 2019, according to a new report, which also revealed that 21 of the world’s 30 most polluted cities were in India. Ghaziabad , meanwhile, had the dubious distinction of being the most polluted city in the world.

According to the World Air Quality Report 2019, compiled by IQAir Air Visual, Ghaziabad was followed by Hotan in China, and then Gujran-wala and Faisalabad in Pakistan. Delhi took the fifth place.

Track the pollution level in your city

The 21 Indian cities named in the list in the order of their ranking were Ghaziabad, Delhi, Noida, Gurugram, Greater Noida, Bandhwari, Lucknow, Bulandshahr, Muzaffarnagar, Baghpat, Jind, Faridabad, Coraut, Bhiwadi, Patna, Palwal, Muzaffarpur, Hisar, Kutail, Jodhpur and Moradabad.

As per the country-wise data, India ranked fifth in the world’s most polluted countries with Bangladesh taking the top spot, followed by Pakistan, Mongolia and Afghanistan.

The report, however, also mentions that Indian cities have shown improvement compared with last year. “Whilst cities in India, on average, exceed the World Health Organisation target for annual PM2.5 exposure by 500%, national air pollution decreased by 20% from 2018 to 2019 with 98% of the cities experiencing improvement,” the report stated.

Frank Hammes, IQAir CEO said, “While coronavirus is dominating international headlines, a silent killer is contributing to nearly seven million more deaths a year that is air pollution. The gap in air quality data in large parts of the world poses a serious problem, as what is not measured cannot be managed.”

Avinash Chanchal, senior campaigner at Greenpeace India, said the steps being taken to control pollution were not sufficient. “In Delhi, be it bypass roads, shutting down of Badarpur power plant, shifting industries to PNG and BS-VI mandate have had result in reduction of pollution levels on an annual average basis, but the latest World Air Quality Report is an indication that the steps taken are not sufficient,” he said.

Title: 2 Cong leaders expelled for 6 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The Congress on Tuesday expelled two leaders from the party for six years for indulging in activities that tarnished the image of the party. Nadwai block president Prashant Upadhaya and Ajmer lawyer Rajesh Tondon who had uploaded derogatory social media posts against women IAS officers posted in Ajmer were shown the door.

Title: State govt set to digitise wildlife and forest crimes
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: The forest department is in the process of digitizing all the wildlife and forest offences that were until now registered manually.

The digitization will be done only for the pending cases up to 2016, and from 2017 till now, all the cases irrespective of their status will be uploaded. The department will do the same for forest areas where there is encroachment.

G V Reddy, principal chief conservator of forest (PCCF) told TOI, “Till now, all the cases of forest and wildlife offences were maintained in a register manually at the district level. However, we are now in the process of digitizing them, in order to analyse the type of offences and the number which is pending along with the reasons for the same. With one click, we will be able to see all the cases, which was not possible till now. We are very serious about curbing such offences and this would help us in doing so,” Reddy said.

The matter was discussed during a video conference meeting of officials on forest protection held on Tuesday.

The data will be uploaded for the last ten years, though only the pending cases till 2016 will be digitised. “After 2016, all the cases whether the investigation has been completed or pending will be uploaded. This would help us in identifying the repeat offenders as well so that we can take the needful action,” added Reddy.

The department will also identify the areas where forest has been encroached upon, as well as have a digital record of the same. Elaborating further, the top forest official said, “Forest encroachment is also an offence and till now, the data was only on register. We will make it digital and also mark the encroached areas so they are visible on Google so that we can see them virtually. Up till now, they are not visible in this manner.”

Title: Photo evidence of snow leopard presence in and around valley of flowers, Pithoragarh's Gori valley
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

DEHRADUN: Images of more than a dozen snow leopards have been captured in the cameras installed in the hill areas of the state by the forest department last year. These pictures are of great significance, say forest officials, considering that the snow leopard is an extremely elusive animal.

“We have spotted around four snow leopards in Malari; two each in the valley of flowers, Gorso, and Alaknanda forest division; and around three outside valley of flowers. The movement of these snow leopards was captured in the cameras last year. The evidence of their presence in these areas had also been confirmed by our patrolling team this year,” said Kishan Chand, divisional forest officer (DFO) of Chamoli.

A World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) team, which had installed cameras in Pithoragarh’s Gori Valley, has also claimed to have found the presence of a few snow leopards in the area. Rishi Kumar Sharma, head of WWF’s Snow Leopard Conservation Programme, told TOI, “We sighted six snow leopards in a 150 square kilometre long area in Pithoragarh’s Gori valley. We are confident that their numbers are higher as only 10 camera traps were installed and that, too, in a small area. Our focus was on conservation planing and examining opportunities for continued co-existence between people and snow leopards in that region.”

He added that government of India has embarked on an ambitious national snow leopard population estimation program using camera traps and genetic surveys which are widely accepted scientific tools to reliably estimate snow leoaprd population. "The current natioanl estimates of snow leoaprd numbers are gudestimates and the curent thrust on sing accepted scientific methods will help us determine snow leopard numbers with confidence.” said Sharma.

Notably, Uttarakhand has already trained its DFOs in implementation of snow leopard estimation project in February and has become the first state in the country to spearhead the programme.

He added that estimating the number of snow leopards through camera traps is not really a scientific method. “Their population count, estimated on the basis of camera traps, is just guesswork,” said Sharma.

Notably, Uttarakhand has already trained its DFOs in implementation of snow leopard estimation project in February and has become the first state in the country to spearhead the programme. At Wildlife Institute of India , officials were recently given insights on camera estimation works. “We will be engaging local youths and non-government organisations for the estimation works. But we will first educate our officers so that they further dispense the knowledge,” said RK Mishra, chief conservator of forests, Uttarkhand forest department.

S Sathyakumar, senior scientist at Wildlife Institute of India, told TOI that Uttarakhand has a significant population of snow leopards. Kumar, who has been working in the snow-leopard belts of the country for several years, told TOI, “We estimate there are around 500-700 snow leopards in the country roughly. Out of this, about 85 would be in Uttarakhand. WII worked intensively for four years in areas above Bhagirathi and captured evidence of presence of snow leopards. A protocol for snow leopard number estimation has also been developed now.”

Title: Man killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: A 35-year-old man was killed in a road accident near Sri Convention, RC Puram, on Tuesday. He was riding a motorcycle when an unidentified vehicle crashed into his two-wheeler. The deceased was identified as Thotla Nagaraju, a worker at a vegetable market and resident of SN colony in RC Puram. The victim died on the spot. tnn

Title: Research gets a boost at NITK Surathkal with CRF
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Ramesh Pokhriyal, Union Minister of Human Resources Development inaugurating Central Research Facility at Nati... Read More

MANGALURU: Research activities at the National Institute of Technology, Karnataka (NIT-K) Surathkal received a shot in the arm, with the dedication of a top-notch Central Research Facility (CRF). It was inaugurated by Union minister of human resources development (HRD) Ramesh Pokhriyal , on Tuesday.

The CRF will have 45 high-end research equipment. These machines will be procured at a cost of Rs 80 crore. The newly inaugurated facility is already equipped with three facilities, and is open to all who want to do research.

Karanam Uma Maheshwar Rao, director , NITK Surathkal , explaining the purpose of the CRF, said that the centre facilitates research and research collaboration, and aims to disseminate research results through research conferences, meetings and various activities. It strengthens undergraduate and postgraduate education by providing students with training opportunities and access to facilities. It also helps to seek extramural research funds.

The centre will be a one-stop production facility with state-of-the-art manufacturing equipments, material characterisation facility and IPR cell. Technology transfer cell, office for industrial consultancy and sponsored research (ICSR) as well as technical business incubator and others.

The facility is a great help to more 700 research students who are in the campus. The equipment will be procured from abroad, but stress will also be given to Make in India products. “The research papers will have more weightage at the international journal when these equipment are used for the purpose,” said a faculty member.

The CRF is funded by the Higher Education Funding Agency (HEFA). It is a joint venture of MHRD, government of India and Canara Bank, for financing creation of capital assets in premier educational institutions in India, to enable premier institutions to excel and reach the top in global rankings by financing the building of world class infrastructure including R&D infrastructure. NITK Surathkal is the only one among 31 NITs chosen by HEFA.

The institution is also among six institutes (the only NIT) to get a loan from HEFA in the country.

Foundation stone for new facilities Ramesh Pokhriyal also laid the foundation stone for Laya and Shruti apartment for faculty and new girls and boys hostels.

The faculty apartment block will have green building features which include, energy-efficient design, use of fly ash based CC block for masonry with minimum 40 per cent fly ash content; use of industrial waste like GGBS as cement replacement; low VOC paints, LED-based energy efficient luminaries and 75 per cent of built up area lit with natural daylight.

Title: Can Kumbhalgarh be upgraded to a tiger reserve: NTCA to Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Kumbhalgarh fort.

JAIPUR: The National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) has written to the chief wildlife warden of Rajasthan to look into the possibility of upgrading Kumbhalgarh Wildlife Sanctuary into a tiger reserve. The letter dated February 10 asked the forest department to explore the possibility keeping in view the core buffer strategy and landscape approach towards tiger conservation. NTCA has sought a detailed report in this regard.

The letter read that in the 17th meeting of NTCA held on January 6, Dungarpur MP Harshvardhan Singh had expressed his opinion that the sanctuary be notified as tiger reserve to accommodate the rising population of the big cat in the state.

Rajasthan forest department had already initiated the process to upgrade the sanctuary in Rajsamand district into another tiger reserve.

A final proposal had been submitted to chief wildlife warden for the same. Following the state government’s direction, assessment report on the potential for relocation of the big cats at the sanctuary was prepared by the department. “We are already working on the possibility of upgrading the sanctuary and will reply to NTCA with the detailed report. A draft proposal has been ready for a while,” said Arindam Tomar, chief wildlife warden.

According to the draft, the name of the area is proposed to be Kumbhalgarh Tiger Reserve which will constitute Kumbhalgarh Wildlife Sanctuary, Todgarh-Raoli Wildlife Sanctuary and adjoining forest areas. The area of the proposed reserve is 1280.49 square km, out of which 355.25 square km will be the core area and 925 square km as buffer area in phase I.

The highlight of the proposed tiger reserve is that there are no revenue village in the core area. The proposed reserve lies in the districts of Pali, Rajsamand, Udaipur and Ajmer and is located in the oldest range of Aravallis spreading over the tract starting from Khulbrahora (Gujarat) and culminating on Delhi ridge. Once, tigers used to roam in the natural forests of Kumbhalgarh and Raoli-Todgarh. The habitat of both the sanctuaries is suitable to tigers, other predators and its prey base. Also, a corridor connects both the sanctuaries.

Title: City cops help transport heart
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Secunderabad: To facilitate the shifting of a live heart for transplant, the city traffic police created a green channel between Yashoda Hospital, Secunderabad and Care Hospital, Nampally on Tuesday.

The distance between Secunderabad and Nampally was covered in 10 minutes, said the Hyderabad traffic police, by providing non-stop movement to the ambulance carrying the organ. The medical team carrying the live organ (heart) left at 06.22 am from Yashoda Hospital, Secunderabad and reached Care Hospital, Nampally, Hyderabad at 06.32 am. TNN

Title: RBSE chief takes charge
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Professor Dharmpal Jalori on Tuesday took charge as chairman of Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education. The post was vacant since 2018.

On the first day, he told journalists that his priority would be to conduct the transparent upcoming board examinations which kick off from March 5. He said he would ensure evaluation of papers accurately and results on time.

Title: Call to restore Benz Circle service road
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Residents of Bharati Nagar and surrounding colonies have demanded that the district administration and National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) restore the service road adjacent to Benz Circle Flyover at its starting point near Vinayak Theatre junction. Locals urged the government to implement the high court’s order to restore the service road immediately.

Benz Circle Flyover reduces traffic on the busy ring road from Ramavarappadu junction to Skew Bridge. The flyover’s construction, however, congested the service road from Novotel Hotel to Gunrunanal College Centre. After a trial run was done on the flyover, officials built a wall blocking traffic through the congested service road. Officials who initially proposed to acquire land from around 25 building owners to expand the service road for a stretch of 800 meters, dropped the idea given the cost of land.

“We have lost direct connectivity with the road. We are travelling double the distance to reach a place which is just 500 meters away from our place. Officials were hesitating to come forward for the construction of the service road as the market value of land in the area is around Rs 1 lakh per square yard. But the government should solve our problem,” said K Narayana Kumar a local. Krishna administration clarified the court directed them to restore road within three months and the works would begin soon.

Title: Accident hits traffic on Katraj-Dehu Road bypass
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Pune: The traffic movement on Karaj-Dehu Road bypass was hit for at least three-and-a-half hours on Tuesday evening after a limestone-laden truck jumped the divider and tipped over on the opposite lane at Bavdhan, near Chandni Chowk.

The vehicle movement resumed around 7.30pm after the Hinjewadi traffic police shifted the truck with the help of two cranes. The truck driver suffered minor injuries. A resident of Bavdhan said the traffic on both sides of the bypass remained stranded since 4pm. “The by-lanes in the Bavdhan, too, suffered from its cascading effect,” he said.

An officer from the Hinjewadi traffic police said that truck was heading towards Dehu Road from Katraj. “Prima facie probe revealed that after crossing the Chandni Chowk, the driver lost control of the wheel following failure of brakes and the vehicle hit the divider.,” the officer said. TNN

Title: Panel to decide fate of Purushothapatnam
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) has constituted a committee with officials of Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF), Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) and Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Roorkee to examine whether there is a need for independent Environmental Clearance (EC) or an amendment to the Polavaram EC is to be obtained to construct Purushothapatnam Lift Irrigation Scheme.

The NGT had earlier asked to submit details about the project after two petitions were moved opposing the proposed lift irrigation project. While the state government argued that it is part of the Polavaram project to supply drinking water, the petitioners argued that the Detailed Project Report (DPR) says that it is an irrigation project.

The NGT had also directed all works of the project be halted following the show cause notice issued by MoEF for non-compliance of environmental norms. The NGT found fault with the state government for submiting a report with misleading facts.

The National Green Tribunal further stated in its order that as it was clear that the said project was an irrigation project, it needs to be examined whether an independent EC is required or an amendment to the earlier EC given to the Polavaram project has to be obtained. The Central Pollution Control Board will act as the nodal agency of the committee constituted to determine the same.

Title: Five red junglefowl adopted at Hyd Zoo
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Members of the Rotary Club of Hyderabad adopted five small birds (red junglefowl) at the Nehru Zoological Park, Hyderabad for a period of one year on Tuesday.

According to a press release issued by the zoo authorities, Shiva Narayana, district governor, Rotary Club of Hyderabad along with other members presented a cheque of Rs 20,000 to N Kshitija, curator at red junglefowl enclosure at the zoo.

Narayana thanked the members of the Rotary Club for showing a keen interest in adopting the birds. The zoo curator appealed to the citizens to come forward in more numbers towards the adoption of animals in the zoo. “I was impressed by the way the animals are taken care of because I have been to many zoos across the world,” said Narayana.

Title: 3 held for robbery at Jubilee Hills house
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Task force, west zone team, nabbed three men for committing a burglary at a house in Jubilee Hills. Police recovered gold ornaments worth Rs 10 lakh from them. The accused were identified as Syed Yousuf and Shaik Shahed, both relatives, and Syed Shahbaz, a friend of Shahad. All three are residents of Borabanda.

Yousuf was going through a financial crisis and hatched the burglary plan at the house of one Naseer Ali Khan, where he had previously worked as a driver. The accused brought a coconut cutter to threaten the inmates had they resisted. They also carried a fence cutter to enter the house.

On the intervening night of February 14 and 15, they went to the house on road no. 34. They entered through the back portion by cutting the fence. They stole the jewellery and other valuables while the inmates were sleeping. They were caught on Tuesday while they were on their way to sell the stolen items near Jubilee Hills and were booked for house burglary. Police seized the vehicles used to commit the offence, along with the stolen gold ornaments. tnn

Title: Riots in Delhi: Couldn’t have let anyone come in his way: Delhi cop who faced the barrel
Content:
Dahiya (inset) explained that in such situations, a cop is trained to put the lives of civilians above his own

NEW DELHI: “Agar mere saamne koi mar jaata, toh bahut dukh hota hamesha... (had anyone died in front of me, it would have hurt me forever),” head constable Deepak Dahiya (31) told TOI on Tuesday. A day earlier, Dahiya had come face to face with a rioter, who pointed a pistol at him even as he himself stood defiant with just a lathi in hand.Dahiya hails from Sonepat and was inducted into Delhi Police in 2010 as a constable. He cleared the exam for the post of head constable and is currently undergoing training at Wazirabad.Recalling the events of Monday that catapulted him to front page of newspapers, Dahiya said: “I was deployed at Maujpur Chowk. Things suddenly took an extremely violent turn and people started pelting stones at each other. As I moved towards the scene of violence, I heard a gunshot. I saw a man wearing a red sweatshirt... he was wielding a pistol. I immediately jumped to the other carriageway to divert his attention.”Live: Army should be called in, Kejriwal saysDahiya explained that in such situations, a cop is trained to put the lives of civilians above his own. “He was charging ahead... I walked up to him to divert his attention.. I could not have allowed anyone else to come in his way. My priority was to ensure that there was no casualty,” he said. Asked what was going in his mind at that particular moment, Dahiya said: “Kaam hain mera, karna hi hai... (it is my job and I have to do it).”Dahiya’s wife and two daughters reside in Sonepat, along with the rest of his family. Till Tuesday morning, they were unaware that he had come this close to death. “I did not tell them anything, but my photograph went viral on the social media. My wife called me up all worried. I tried to dodge her questions, but even though my face wasn’t visible in the photographs, she recognised me from the blue stripes on the jacket... I kept quiet as I know that she has full confidence in me,” he said.Dahiya hails from a family of men in uniform. His father retired from Indian Coast Guard. He has two younger brothers: one is with Delhi Police and the other is with the coast guard.

Title: Hushed up! Kidnapping cases in Kochi drop as parents cop out
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

KOCHI: Ernakulam Rural police has recorded a steady rise in the number of kidnappings and abductions over the past five years even as Kochi city police numbers show a decline.

According to the latest report of the District Crime Records Bureau, a total of 37 kidnapping cases were reported in rural areas of the district 2019. Of these, 27 involved a woman or girl victim. In 2016, the total number of cases stood at 11.

The city police registered 13 cases in 2015. This dropped to six in 2019, after rising to 19 in 2017.

According to police officials, the majority of such abductions involve sexual abuse. “We invoke IPC sections 370 (trafficking) and 363 (kidnapping) along with offences like rape and child abuse. This is actually a graver offence as the victim is not in a position to give consent or is tricked into being taken somewhere,” said M J Sojan, additional superintendent of police, Ernakulam.

Experts say the higher numbers in rural areas is because it is difficult to hush up such cases in such neighbourhoods. Fr Jenson Varyath, director of Ernakulam Childline, said city parents are less likely to come out and report such an offence than those in rural areas. “Now, due to various awareness drives, more cases of sexual abuse are getting reported in rural areas. It is difficult to keep things quiet in a rural neighbourhood as compared to the city where things can be kept under wraps. Also, parents are not that forthcoming in reporting such crimes in the city,” said Fr Varyath.

Police say most of the kidnapping cases in the district involve either minor girls cheated on the pretext of love or women given false promises, including of marriage, and are taken to various locations where they are sexually assaulted.

ASP Sojan added that officers realizing the need for adding the charge of abduction to sexual abuse cases due to the efforts of police wings like the anti-human trafficking unit is also another reason for the spike in rural areas. P S Muhammed Ashraf, a police official who works with the special juvenile police unit (SJPU), said there have been instances where child labourers were rescued, only to reveal a kidnapping or abduction angle.

“In many cases, follow-up investigations would suggest that the children were trafficked from other states or other districts. In such cases too, FIRs are registered for kidnapping and abduction,” said Ashraf.

Moreover, Bindu P A, special public prosecutor with the Ernakulam Pocso court, said that about 40% of abuse cases get settled due to various reasons, such as the victim refusing to go forward with the complaint.

“At least in Ernakulam, most cases with enough evidence lead to conviction. In fact, around six in 10 cases lead to conviction. However, due to the vast area that comes under the Ernakulam court, there are around 450 cases which are pending,” said Bindu.

Title: Bid on lives of siblings: Four held, hunt on for five others
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: A week after a bid was made on the lives of two siblings at Gandimaisamma in Quthbullapur , four persons were arrested on Tuesday. A manhunt is on to apprehend five other assailants in the attempt to murder case.

The arrested persons were K Shiva, S Rajkumar, K Srisailam and K Balaraj of Gandipet. Narsingi police said following the orders of Ashok Yadav , who lost in the recent municipal elections from ward No. 17 in Narsingi municipality, the four accused along with their associates — Gowtham, Srikanth, Sateesh Yadav and Mahesh Yadav — attacked K Anand and his brother Raj Kumar with an axe, beer bottles and sticks.

After losing the elections, Ashok met the winning TRS candidate Venkatesh Yadav. Venkatesh’s followers — Anand and Raj Kumar — roughed up Ashok and a case was registered at Komuravelli police station, Madhapur ACP N Shyam Prasad Rao said.

Ashok hatched a plan with his associates and attacked Anand when the latter was travelling from Gandimaisamma to Kokapet on February 18.

“Upon hearing from his brother about the attack, Raj came to his rescue. The assailants targeted Raj also. He fell unconscious. The attackers fled from the scene thinking that he had died. Anand and Raj are out of danger. Based on their complaint, we arrested the four accused,” the ACP said. A hunt is on to nab the other accused, including Ashok.

Title: T govt, Markfed at wits’ end over red gram procurement
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Even as the row over providing MSP for turmeric farmers is refusing to die down, procurement of red gram has become a headache for the state government and Markfed.

Currently, 24,000 metric tonnes of red gram procured by Markfed last year at a cost of Rs 200 crore is lying in the godowns. But the state government is yet to give permission to sell the produce in the market.

As 1.5 lakh MTs of red gram remained unsold by the farmers this year, the state government is worried about disposal of the produce. The Centre was ready to procure 47,000 MTs only.

“One lakh MTs of red gram will still be with farmers. We are already under pressure from the farmers to procure the produce,” a highly-placed official said. Farmers have been assured Rs 5,000 per qunital.

Markfed is also worried, with traders quoting only Rs 4,200 per quintal. It had purchased the produce from farmers at Rs 5,675 per quintal. Overall, Markfed spent Rs 7,000 on each quintal, factoring in the transport charges.

Though the state government has written to the Centre on additional purchase of red gram, there no response has been received yet.

This has left the farmers worried. “Private buyers quote much lesser price. The state government does not allow the traders to directly buy from us. We are caught between the devil and the deep sea,” A Srikanth Reddy, a farmer from Yadadri district said.

Irate farmers burnt several bags of red gram at Mothkuru market on Monday.

Title: Sindhu roped in to promote state govt’s anti-corruption initiative
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: The government has roped in badminton star PV Sindhu to spread awareness about its various initiatives to curb corruption. Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy released a promotional video on Tuesday featuring Sindhu, where she exhorts the public to lodge complaints against any form of corruption.

“Corruption-free Andhra Pradesh is the vision of our chief minister. If anybody seeks bribe or indulges in graft, please call toll-free number 14400,” she says in the video.

Jagan said the menace of corruption has to be rooted out completely. “Whether it is a small work or real-time insurance, only graft seems to be working. One has to pay bribe even to get a toilet sanctioned. This kind of situation has to change,” he said after releasing his government’s latest anti-corruption initiative .

Title: Kadavumbhagam synagogue: More funds sanctioned for restoration work
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Kadavumbhagam synagogue

KOCHI: A major hurdle for restoration of the 600-year-old Kadavumbhagam synagogue at Mattancherry, which collapsed partially during the rains in September 2019, has been overcome with the cultural affairs department sanctioning the additional amount required for acquiring 0.0351 hectares lying adjacent to the monument.

Though the state archaeology department had provided administrative sanction for Rs 91.45 lakh for land acquisition and credited the amount to the account of Ernakulam district collector, the process could not be completed because the total cost was estimated to be Rs 1,67,22,956 after adding five percentage contingency charge of Rs 7,96,331.

The cultural affairs department has now sanctioned Rs 75,77,956 after subtracting the Rs 91.45 lakh sanctioned earlier. The synagogue was the historical place of worship of Malabari Jews.

The ownership of the synagogue changed hands after Malabari Jews, who took care of the building, immigrated to Israel. The ownership of the monument was with Vanaja Traders, a coir trading company for a while. The property adjacent to the monument is currently owned by Regina Tharyan, but under the possession of Punjab National Bank as it was mortgaged for loan.

“We have already declared it as a monument but the final notification is yet to be made. We would be able to do the restoration work only after the final notification is made,” said archaeology department director K R Sona. The structure’s front portion collapsed in heavy rain on September 10, 2019. A portion of the synagogue was pulled down overnight by some unknown persons in 2015. Heritage conservationists had long been demanding that authorities take measures for the upkeep of the structure.

Title: Machines spearhead Chennai corporation’s Swachh Bharat mission
Content:
Proposals worth Rs 200 crore are in the pipeline to procure mini amphibians which clean smaller waterbodies.

CHENNAI: If you are a regular visitor to the Marina beach , you might have noticed that the sand has been levelled with a machine. In the northern part of the city, sanitary workers collecting garbage from homes in narrow streets feel more dignified because they are no longer ‘kuppa vandi’ drivers, but move around in battery-operated vehicles.Both are part of Greater Chennai Corporation big push towards mechanisation of its core activities of cleaning and maintaining hygiene.Proposals worth Rs 200 crore are in the pipeline to procure mini amphibians which clean smaller waterbodies, robotic excavators which will dig deep into canals and bring out waste buried for years, and high pressure jet-rodding machines which will de-silt choked drains. Funds have been obtained from the State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) and Swachh Bharat Mission (SBM), with a small contribution from the corporation’s own reserves.The work where machines will replace humans ranges from pruning of tree branches that are at a height of 30 feet to sweeping roads, picking up finer waste particles from the road and converting non-biodegradable waste into saleable items. The beach-cleaning machine, six of which are deployed at the Marina and two at Elliot’s Beach, can sweep three acres of wet and dry beach sand every hour and comes equipped with a tipper lorry to dump the collected waste.Officials said in three years, Chennai would see a marked improvement in nationwide cleanliness rankings, while markers on health and hygiene would also show a considerable improvement as machines will dig out dirt from places hitherto unexplored.“A human sweeper is paid Rs 300 to clean 500 metres of a road. A mechanical sweeper will do it in a more efficient manner and cover a larger area,” an official said.A robotic excavator will get into a canal and dig out garbage dumped many years ago. The earlier practice was to send men in catamarans.“Not only is this hazardous to the men, they would not be able to plumb the depths that an excavator can. Also, while desilting water bodies, we will be able to quantify the amount of silt that has been dug out,” said another official.Apart from safety of workers, some machines support recycling of waste. Vehicle-mounted suction-cum-jet-rodding machines, seven of which have been procured at a cost of Rs 5.2 crore each, recycles water and sludge removed from a drain. The earlier model of this vehicle uses 90,000 litres of water per hour to create the water jet that will pierce the sludge. The recyclable machine uses 2,000 litres of water.P Nakkeeran, treasurer of anti-corruption NGO Arappor Iyakkam, welcomed the move towards mechanisation. “But as far as cleanliness of waterbodies is concerned, officials should also focus on removal of encroachments and cutting down on illegal sewage inflow. There should be transparency in how much these machines can be used,” he said.

Title: Alliance against CAA tells Telangana CM K Chandrashekar Rao to junk NPR process
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Telangana CM KCR.

HYDERABAD: The Alliance against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) asked chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao to not to go ahead with the NPR process in the state.

In a meeting headed by Justice Chandra Kumar (retired), members of Alliance decided to undertake a ‘Boycott NPR’ drive across Hyderabad from March 1 to 15.

“The questions in the NPR form, used to gather information from the citizens, are objectionable,’’ said Justice Kumar at a press conference in the city.

Co-conveners of the Alliance Mohd Sadiq Ahmed, Vimala Morthala, Sara Mathew, Khalida Parveen strongly objected to the detention of protesters and said the Act was against the spirit of the Constitution.

They also insisted that CM explain the government’s decision to permit minsiter of Home Affair Amit Shah’s public meeting in the city.

“KCR must clear his stand by ensuring early passage of a resolution against CAA, NPR and NRC in the Assembly. We also demand that he roll back NPR process immediately,’’ said members.

Title: Garbage won’t be picked if it is not segregated: KT Rama Rao
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao said the government will soon issue orders to municipalities to stop collecting garbage if residents and house owners do not segregate waste.

Urging people to cooperate with the municipal authorities in keeping the towns clean, the minister said though the authorities had introduced a two-bin system for wet and dry waste and distributed bins, they are not being used by the residents.

The minister said the citizens will have to segregate waste so that sanitation workers could process the waste.

The minister, who took part in Pattana Pragathi programme at Devarakonda and Kalwakurthy towns on Tuesday, asked the officials to identify problems and address them immediately.

The minister had a word of advice for the local elected representatives. “There are no elections in the next four years. All we have to do is work hard to find a permanent place in the hearts of people,” he said and instructed councillors and ward committee members to identify the problems and start addressing them right away.

He asked the people to not pay bribes for getting building permissions from April 2 as the government is coming up with a new mechanism for building permissions.

“If you don’t get building permisssion within 21 days, the permission is deemed to be granted,” he said.

He laid the foundation stone for various development works in Devarakonda. These include construction of an underground drainage network, STP, roads and a park at a cost of Rs 48 crore.

The minister undertook a padayatra in the town. KTR later inaugurated a 32/11 KV sub-station in Kalwakurthy.

Meanwhile, finance minister Harish Rao also spoke about segregation of waste while interacting with councillors and residents in Sadasivpet in Sangareddy district. He asked the authorities to impose a fine of Rs 500 if people do not cooperate with the authorities in segregating waste.

He urged people to not dump garbage in open places and directed the officials to identify problems pertaining to electricity poles, roads and other civic issues in the town.

Title: World Bank fillip for health, education sectors
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Lynne Sherburne-Benz, regional director, Human Development, World Bank, with CM Jaganmohan Reddy at the secret... Read More

Vijayawada: World Bank has evinced interest in partnering with the state government in health and education sectors.

A team of officials from World Bank, led by Lynne Sherburne-Benz, regional director, Human Development, South Asia, held discussions with chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy on Tuesday, on the state government’s initiatives in various sectors besides administration decentralisation.

The team complimented the initiatives of the chief minister in health and education sector and showed interest in partnering with the government. The chief minister briefed them about the government’s plans in English medium education, skill development centers and renovation and strengthening of schools and hospitals under Naadu-Nedu scheme. He also told them that the government would soon start YSR Village Clinics across the state shortly where 24x7 medical and health services would be made available. He also told them that schools would get digital class rooms. The students would also get tabs with internet provision for e-learning, he said.

The chief minister briefed the team on village and ward secretariats and his plans to connect them with the state secretariat and the district collectorates. The village and ward secretariats would soon start registration activity so that people need not go to the offices of sub-registrars.

The skill development centers would come up in all Lok Sabha constituencies and they would be kept under one skill development university. These centers would upgrade the skills of the people according to the requirement of the industry, he told the team.

The CM explained to them the reasons to take up decentralisation of administration. He told them that the government would require at least Rs 2 crore to provide basic infrastructure of roads, drains, electricity and drinking water for every one acre of land in Amaravati. He said that this would mean concentration of development in one place, while the rest of the state is ignored. He had taken the decision to decentralise the administration to distribute the fruits of development to various places, he said.

The World Bank team was impressed with the initiatives of the government. The team members said that they were aware of the padayatra by Jaganmohan Reddy before the elections.

Title: A trip to Thailand proved that age is just a number
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

It was always my dream to take my parents on a trip abroad. However, my dad passed away years ago, when I was quite young, and my dream took a backseat as I got busy with the challenges of life. But it was always there at the back of my mind, and I was determined to take my mother and show her a slice of the world. After much deliberation, I decided on Thailand and surprised my mother. I will never forget the look on her face when we reached Pattaya and she saw the speed boats scattered near the sea shore and the multi-coloured hot air balloons dotting the azure blue sky. My mum has always been scared of boats, but she managed beautifully on the speed boat that took us to Coral Island, even though we had to change multiple boats.

The years lifted off my mum’s face as we giggled and licked ice-creams of exotic flavours as we made our way through the mind-boggling malls of Bangkok. My mom forgot her knee-pain and laughed like an excited school-girl as we soaked in the sights and smells of Bangkok. She pointed out Kashmiri shawl sellers and Sardarji’s excitedly as they brought forth the familiarity of home in a strange country. She looked in amazement at the sky-scrapers of Bangkok and the huge bill boards and sky-walks. We often tend to think of old people as fixed in their view-points and unwilling to experiment, but my mum proved all that wrong. She sportingly tried the local Thai cuisine and even managed to fold her arthritic leg into a Tuk-Tuk that went so fast that we literally had to cling on to for life, since we were almost slipping off.

My mum loved the Bangkok city trip in which we visited monasteries and saw the Grand Palace of the Thai monarch. She listened eagerly to everything our guide told us and looked left and right to view all that there was to see. She encouraged me to talk to the local people and know about their life and habits. She felt that there was a lot of similarity with India and yet it was as abroad as abroad can be. Our short and sweet trip to Thailand is one of my most memorable trips that brought us closer and proved to me that age is just a number.

(The writer works for an IT company)

Title: Andhra plans to emulate TN model to rehabilitate convicts after jail term
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state prisons department is set to adopt the Tamil Nadu model of reforms to prevent convicted criminals from committing crimes.

Director General of Prisons and Correctional Services, Md. Ahsan Reza said the department would take care of convicts who have finished their jail term and rehabilitate them in various trades they have acquired at the correctional service centre and with the support of their families.

“Our teams will visit prisons in Tamil Nadu to observe their model before implement it in Andhra Pradesh. We chalking out plans to allow the family members to interact with the convicts and to organize a mela at the central prisons premises on August 15 or January 26 and invite the family members to interact with inmates in all the central jails,” said Reza.

On the increasing number of remand prisoners in jails and they going back to old days after released on bails, Reza said the majority of the remand prisoners stay only for a short time in prisons and the department have little time to correct them.

“Our priority is to study the convicts for their reform and rehabilitation. We will monitor the released convicts with the support of a few other departments,” Reza said.

IG Prisons G Jayavardhan, DIG of Prisons, Coastal Andhra Range Dr Indla Sreenivasa Rao and Superintendent of Vizag Central Prison, S Rahul said the AP Prisons Department has been providing skill development training for convicts under Skill India programme to increase revenue. They said these measures ensure that the convicted get some money during their time in jails and are able to find employment once they are released.

Reza inaugurated the spices processing unit at Vizag Central Prison. The unit has been set up with a cost of Rs 38 lakh to produce quality red chilli powder and turmeric powder. Plans are on to produce cumin, coriander, pepper and a few other spice powders.

Some convicts have been trained to operate the unit. The red chilli and turmeric powders produced in Vizag Central Prison will be used in all the prisons in the state and the remaining will be sold in retail markets in Vizag and other parts of the state under the brand name of Sudhar, Reza added.

Title: Pvt schools disregard govt bar, make a killing in fees
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Even as the state government tries to introduce reforms in the education department to check the collection of exorbitant amounts of fees in private schools, many corporate institutions in the city expedited the 2020-21 admission process without permission in a bid to rake in large amounts in fees.

Chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy, who promised to create a stress-free pocket-friendly education system in the state, constituted Andhra Pradesh School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission (APSERMC) to implement education reforms.

The state government conducted inspections in private and corporate schools collecting unreasonably high fees and barred them from conducting admissions till they were given grades fixing the fee pattern.

But the majority of corporate schools in the city are conducting admissions ignoring the directions. Parents were busy gathering reference letters of ministers and other VIPs to get admissions for their kids in corporate schools. “Marketing teams of corporate school managements were repeatedly contacting us for the admission of my son in high school. They are offering huge discounts if we take admission before the completion of the academic year,” said J Lakshmi Narasimha a private employee.

Student associations strongly condemned the early admissions.

“Many corporate schools in the city completed 50 per cent of admissions in their schools. They were trying to attract parents by offering huge discounts. The education department should take necessary measures to stop the admission process before regulating the fee structure,” said K Ramesh state secretary of the Student Federation of India. Krishna district education officer Rajya Lakshmi speaking with TOI requested parents not to take up early admissions in corporate schools.

“We have noticed that many private schools in Krishna district are running against rules. They are collecting exorbitant amounts in fees. We have started inspections as per the guidance of APSERMC and schools violating norms will lose their recognition soon. Parents will suffer if they got admission to such schools,” she pointed out. I have directed deputy education officers across the district to identify schools taking early admissions and initiate stringent action against them, Rajyalakshmi added.

Title: Delhi: Over 150 swine flu cases in just two months
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The scare over swine flu isn’t limited to the Supreme Court, where five judges are said to be infected with the viral illness.Across Delhi, at least 152 positive cases of the influenza virus — which took to epidemic proportions in 2009 and has since become a part of seasonal influenza — have been reported in the last two months.There are no deaths reported though, as per the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) — a central health body.Dr Suranjit Chatterjee, senior consultant, internal medicine at Indraprastha Apollo hospital said the sudden upsurge in cases could be due to a mutation of the virus. “All viruses change or mutate to adapt. We don’t know for sure but it’s possible that the H1N1 influenza virus has mutated, leading to higher rates of transmission,” he said.In the last two weeks, Chatterjee added, the hospital has admitted at least four to five persons suffering from severe symptoms of swine flu. “Most patients have mild symptoms like running nose, sore throat and fever. Admission is required in case of breathlessness or persons in extremes of age who need regular monitoring,” the doctor said.According to Dr Anoop Misra, chairman, Fortis C-Doc, those with existing illnesses such as diabetes are being advised to take preventive vaccination.Another doctor said symptoms of swine flu are similar to common flu and even the novel coronavirus infection, increasing the fear in the public.Last year, Delhi had reported 3,627 cases of H1N1 of which 31 persons had died. The death toll across the country was 1,218 in 2019, the NCDC data revealed.The latest update on H1N1 situation in the country shows 884 people have been diagnosed positive for H1N1 over the last one-and-a-half-months in the country and there have been 14 deaths. Tamil Nadu reported the maximum cases (172), followed by Delhi (152), Karnataka (151) and Telangana (148).The union health ministry issued a statement in the wake of five SC judges testing positive for swine flu. It stated that the court roons and residences of the judges were being sanitised.The ministry said H1N1 is a seasonal infection, which usually occurs every year with two peaks: once in January to March and the other between July to September. It advised people to maintain hand hygiene and avoid crowded places.“The symptoms of swine flu are similar to common viral illnesses. Patients feel lethargic, have high-grade fever and sore throat, among other symptoms. The treatment is mostly symptomatic,” said a doctor. He added that maintaining hygiene was the most important. “People should wash their hands at regular intervals with disinfectants. If there is prolonged fever, one must see a doctor and not ignore symptoms such as difficulty in breathing,” he said

Title: Panel probes OU’s reservation rules
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Secunderabad: The Telangana State Commission of Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (SC/ST) has enquired about the rule of reservation followed during recruitment of teaching and non-teaching staff as well as admission into PhD programmes at the Osmania University .

During a review meeting on Tuesday, the commission enquired about the number of SC/ST faculty at the university in each department. The varsity informed that government has sanctioned 1,267 teaching posts of which 819 are lying vacant. Of these, 82 are SC posts and 56 are ST posts. Of the 1,267 sanctioned posts, 152 are professors, 514 associate professors and 601 assistant professors.

The commission also identified gaps in the recruitment roster of SC/ST faculty. It has instructed the university registrar to constitute a five-member committee to study the gaps and submit a report on it to the government within a month.

Apart from this, the commission also instructed the university to issue recruitment notification for all backlog non-teaching staff immediately and asked the it to write to the state government seeking permission for the same.

Title: Stir at UoH over action against CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The students of University of Hyderabad staged a protest on Tuesday against penalisation of three students who conducted an event in solidarity with Shaheen Bagh protesters.

Students raised issues such as restriction on public gatherings and arbitrary charges on auditorium. The university’s registrar P Sardar Singh had recently fined the three students.

UoH students union demanded that administration issue regulation certificate to PhD students among other reforms.

UoH asked the three students to submit a letter stating that they would not indulge in acts of indiscipline in the future. The university has constituted a committee to look into the students’ demands. The committee, to be led by Bipin P Varghese, deputy registrar will hold consultations with other members and submit a report to the vice-chancellor Appa Rao Podile before March 20. However, UoH was adamant that it would not change its stance on the public gathering issue.

Title: 4 held for trying to sell Durga idol for Rs 1 crore
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Task force, west zone team, on Tuesday arrested four persons who were allegedly trying to sell a Durga idol and Nagamani stone, valued at Rs 1 crore, at Jiyaguda, Karwan, by telling people that the idol and stone were auspicious and needed to be kept at home.

The accused were identified as B Devendar from Karwan, T John from Kukatpally, Mohammed Ashraf from Tappachabutra and Prem Chand Gupta from Ramkoti.

Three years ago, Devender had gone to Mumbai and bought the Nagamani stone from there. A few months ago, he met two other accused. He showed them the stone and said that they could earn a lot of money by selling it with the Durga idol.

They asked Ashraf and Prem Chand to get customers to buy the idol and stone for Rs 1 crore, promising them commission. While the accused were waiting for a customer, they were caught in Kulsumpura. They were booked for cheating and police seized the Durga idol and Nagamani stone from them. tnn

Title: How violence spread in Delhi as cops failed to stem riot
Content:
Demonstrators gather along a road scattered with stones following clashes between pro and anti-CAA protesters ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Though early on Tuesday, police forced back pro-CAA protesters from the temple on the main Maujpur-Jafrabad Road — the epicentre of the violence that has now engulfed entire northeast Delhi — the violence shifted to the inner lanes and across the Shahdara drain dividing the region both geographically and demographically.The situation remained tense through the day, with the confrontationists pelting stones at each other as early as 8am near the Maujpur-Babarpur metro station.When TOI reached the spot, it saw cops under attack from stone throwers on the rooftops in Kabir Nagar. While the bridge there was a no-man’s land, there were plumes of smoke above the houses on the inner lanes.TOI heard regular gunshots being fired. Dipak, his forehead bearing a vermillion tilak, had an injured hand wrapped up in a handkerchief. “They are shooting at us from the rooftops. Four people have been injured,” he claimed. Shantanu Mittal, who resides next to the metro station, was recording the scene from the terrace when the mob banged on his door. “I was scared and deleted all the videos,” he said.TOI saw another group preparing petrol bombs. They also used slings to attack those on the roofs. Journalists were warned not to film the scenes, and there was no security from the grossly inadequate police presence. Around 1.45pm, joint commissioner Alok Kumar arrived with four buses of personnel. Half an hour later, security personnel fired teargas shells at the pro-CAA protesters to push them back and relative calm prevailed for almost an hour.The road from Shani temple going to Ghonda was black with the ashes of goods looted from shops. Identifying himself as Gupta, one footwear seller, muttered, “They mistook my shop as belonging to the other community. I had only taken this on rent recently.” TOI saw elderly women guarding the shops while urging stick-wielding youngsters to spare them. “If we go away, we will lose our life savings,” remarked one of them.The rioters were targeting CCTV cameras to evade identification later. The owner of Shubham Collection store pleaded with them not to touch the shop as it belonged to “someone like you”. He, his wife and son chanted “Jai Shri Ram” to prove their credentials, but the cameras were nevertheless pulled down.Back near the temple, BJP functionary Jai Bhagwan Goyal arrived to placate the crowd. “People from the other community want to show us in poor light during President Trump’s visit. So let us have peace,” he implored, but the mob taunted him to come back and say such things when the other community was on the attack.Around 3.30pm Rapid Action Force contingents came, and used teargas to disperse the mob. A flag march from Kardampuri to Jafrabad followed amid reports of a quick-response team van set alight in Jafrabad. TOI also saw a Gramin Sewa vehicle and several motorcycles burning on the 100ft Road near Chhajupur.A senior police officer disclosed late at night that the arterial road, including the sit-in site of women at Jafrabad metro station, had been cleared and Section 144 of CrPC imposed in the area.

Title: Rice mills to be set up for inmates
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With prisoners in the state upset over the quality of the rice being served, the prisons department has decided to set up rice mills at two central prisons.

Mohammed Ahsan Reza, director general, prisons and correctional services, said they have sent a representation to the government to improve the quality of rice that is given to the convicts and remand prisoners in the state. “We hope the government will improve the quality of rice as home minister Mekatoti Sucharita has assured supply of quality rice,” said Reza.

M Vara Prasad, DIG, Prisons, Rayalaseema Region, said they would set up two rice mills within the prison premises. “We will procure quality paddy from farmers and the prisoners will operate the mills,” he said.

The state government has agreed to list all the convicts under Aarogyasri Health programme for better medical facility to the convicts, Reza said.

Prison officials from across the state are attending a two-day retreat in the city to chalk out new prison and correction policy. tnn

Title: Delhi clashes: Must face action if you provoke, says Gautam Gambhir
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Gautam Gambhir

NEW DELHI: As violence continued unabated in northeast Delhi on Tuesday, with the toll climbing steadily, BJP’s East Delhi lawmaker Gautam Gambhir demanded strict action against anyone who made “provocative” speeches. “Whoever, no matter which party he belongs to, whether he is Kapil Mishra or anyone else, who gives speeches to provoke people, should face action,” Gambhir told reporters after visiting injured policemen admitted at a private hospital in east Delhi.

Violence had erupted in parts of northeast Delhi soon after former MLA Kapil Mishra led a march near Maujpur on Sunday, protesting against blockage of two roads by anti-CAA (Citizenship Amendment Act) protesters since Saturday night. Mishra had given a three-day ultimatum to Delhi Police to get the Jafrabad and Chand Bagh roads cleared, adding that those favouring CAA would otherwise take to the streets.

There was a strong backlash against Mishra on social media and elsewhere with many blaming him for the violence.

Mishra said on Tuesday that he had been getting threat calls from abroad. “Friends, I have been getting constant calls from the country and abroad and people are threatening to kill me. Asking to open closed roads is not a crime, supporting CAA is not an offence, speaking truth is not a crime. I don’t fear this massive hate campaign against me,” he tweeted on Tuesday.

Mishra had unsuccessfully contested the recent assembly polls on a BJP ticket from Model Town. He was debarred by the Election Commission for three days for making incendiary statements.

Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari had said last week that those who make such hate speeches should lose their legal right to contest elections. Seeking strict action against rioters on Tuesday, Tiwari said no leader should do something that “causes confusion” and sends the wrong message among people. “Everyone should refrain from making inflammatory statements,” he said.

Rohini MLA Vijender Gupta, however, has come out in defence of Mishra, saying that those blaming his party colleague keep quiet when leaders of other parties make provocative statements. “Some media friends and so-called intellectuals are saying that @KapilMishra_IND is responsible for violence in Delhi but keep quiet on statements made by people like Waris Pathan (of AIMIM). These people do not want to stop the violence but try to run their agenda in its fire,” said Gupta.

The leader of the opposition in Delhi assembly, Ramvir Singh Bidhuri, however, said home minister Amit Shah had already asked party leaders not to make provocative statements. Without naming Mishra, Bidhuri said every leader of BJP will have to follow Shah’s directions. After Gambhir’s statement, the BJP leadership issued directions to party functionaries against making statements on violence or participate in TV debates on the subject.

A senior party functionary, however, said what Gambhir had said was “correct”. He added: “Whoever makes such inflammatory statements should face the music.”

Title: In 2 years, cost of Kochi corporation's RAY project goes up by Rs 21 crore
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

An under-construction building under the RAY project in Kochi

KOCHI: The apartment complex of 199 units being constructed for rehabilitating slum dwellers in the city is now estimated to cost Rs 21 crore more.

The original cost of the project, being implemented under Raji Awas Yojana (RAY), was Rs 14.73 crore. The work was awarded to a contractor in 2018 for Rs 18.6 crore.

With the latest revision the project cost has been pegged at Rs 39 crore. Now, the cost of an individual apartment with 300sq.ft built-up area would be around Rs 19.5 lakh. “We have revised the estimate to Rs 39 crore. We have sent the revised estimate to the government for its approval. The administrative sanction is also awiated,” an official with Kochi corporation said.

At the same time, works standing committee chairman P M Harris said officials with the local body are revising the estimates. “No project of the corporation has been initiated without a revised estimate. Officials keep revising estimates. We are laymen as far as the engineering side is concerned,” Harris said. “We designed the project so that many homeless families will have a roof over their heads. Kochi corporation authorities have approached Cochin Smart Mission Limited (CSML), the agency which is implementing the Smart City project in Kochi, for providing the additional funding of Rs 21 crore. But, CSML authorities said that they would allot the funds only if the state government approves the revised estimate.

The land where the project is coming up is owned by the corporation. “Average cost of construction excluding cost of land is around Rs 2,500 per sqft. Add to this Rs 500 per sqft for promotion,” an office-bearer of Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) said. Even then, the cost of 300sq.ft apartments comes to just Rs 7.5 lakh. When asked about the break-up, the official said, “The cost includes facilities like sewage treatment plant, escalator etc.”

Corporation authorities have already identified 194 families living in the slums of Thuruthi colony in Mattancherry as beneficiaries. There is also a plan for constructing another apartment complex with 199 units at Mehboob colony in Mattancherry. Cochin Smart Mission Ltd is expected to fund construction of the second complex from its slum alleviation scheme.

Title: Charred, beheaded body retrieved
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Salem: A day after they retrieved a mutilated body in Pasukkal area in the city, the Alagapuram police on Tuesday launched a probe to ascertain the identity of the deceased and the cause of murder.

According to deputy commissioner of police (crime and traffic) S Senthil, the murder came to light after a stray dog was found with a mutilated human arm that was in a decomposed state.

Local residents, who saw this, alerted the Alagapuram police, who retrieved a beheaded body. “The right arm was also chopped off. The person could have been murdered at least five days ago,” the officer said.

Police sent the body to the Salem government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital for postmortem and registered a case under Section 174 (unnatural death) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

Police are yet to trace the head and arm. “The body was found with a khaki shirt. We suspect that the victim could have been an auto or a heavy vehicle driver. The murderer beheaded the body, which was set on fire, with an intention not to identify the deceased,” the officer said.

The Alagapuram police on Tuesday inquired with auto drivers to see if any of their colleague has been missing.

Title: First cargo service from Vizag takes flight
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: An exclusive freighter cargo service operated by SpiceJet was flagged-off from Visakhapatnam international airport on Tuesday. The six-day service cargo flight will connect Chennai, Visakhapatnam and Surat on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays while it will connect Chennai, Visakhapatnam and Kolkata on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

On the first route, flight SG7051 will leave Chennai at 10:25am and reach Visakhapatnam at 11:50am. Subsequently, it will leave for Surat at 01:05pm and reach at 03:20pm. On the second route, the schedule will remain the same till Visakhapatnam, after which the flight will go to Kolkata.

The total capacity of the flight is around 21 tonnes. Following the launch, the flight left for Kolkata. Visakhapatnam MP MVV Satyanarayana, who was present at the launch, said that this will create opportunity to export pharmaceuticals, marine and agriculture products in the near future. K Vijayamohan, president of Tours and Travels Association of Andhra Pradesh said that the association will confer with airlines to prepare proposals for more services from Visakhapatnam.

Title: T Congress pushes Rahul Gandhi’s name to be AICC president
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Day’s after party leaders Shashi Tharoor and Sandeep Dikshit raised concerns over a leadership vaccum, senior Congress leaders in Telangana have expressed their loyalty with Rahul Gandhi and said that only he can arrest the grand old party’s political descent.

Party leaders from the state, under the banner of Congress Loyalists Forum, on Tuesday wrote a letter to party interim president Sonia Gandhi to hold an All India Congress Committee (AICC) meeting at the earliest and entrust party leadership to Rahul Gandhi.

“It is our sincere belief that the strengthening and revival of the party would only be possible under the leadership of Rahul Gandhi. A session of the AICC may be convened at the earliest to entrust the party leadership to Rahul Gandhi. We are writing this letter to echo the sentiments and views of the rank and file of the Congress party besides the people in general,” stated the loyalists in the letter.

The forum comprises of former ministers Marri Shashidhar Reddy and S Chandrasekhar, AICC secretary V Hanumanth Rao, All India Kisan Congress vice-president M Kodanda Reddy, AICC OBC cell vice-chairman P Vinay Kumar among others.

Rahul Gandhi had resigned as the AICC president after the party’s defeat in Lok Sabha elections of 2019. Sonia Gandhi was made interim president in August 2019.

NDMA former vice-chairman Marri Shashidhar Reddy told TOI that Nehru-Gandhi family members have pan India accessibility. Though the party has several good leaders, the charisma and acceptability of Gandhi family members is unparalleled, he said.

Title: Banker lodges plaint against DCP
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: A senior executive of Yes Bank lodged a complaint with Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar alleging that North Zone DCP , Kalmeshwar Shingenavar made her wait under the sun for a long time.

According to the commissioner, Yes Bank VP Syamala Kumari Ghantasala complained about the North Zone DCP through an e-mail.

“Due to protests by certain political parties at US Consulate, bandobust arrangements were put in place in nearby places. The complainant said that her vehicle was also stopped by police and she was made to wait for a long time by the police official,” the commissioner said, adding that he had ordered an inquiry into the matter. TNN

Title: Delhi: Fire engines shifted from riot-hit areas to another base
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

A protester holding a stick walks on a deserted road after clashes erupted in Delhi's Karawal Nagar

NEW DELHI: “If the firemen hadn’t fled, they would have been burnt alive along with their vehicles.” This startling revelation was made by a senior fire officer overseeing the firefighting operation at Gokulpuri market on Monday night.

Three fire tenders had been sent to douse several vehicles that had been set afire, but were stopped mid-way near Brahmpuri. The rioters not only set the tenders ablaze, but also attacked three firemen.

A fire officer was injured in the stone-pelting on Tuesday. Delhi Fire Service (DFS) teams responding to distress calls of arson were asked to abandon their vehicles in case of violence. Till Tuesday afternoon, the fire department had received 70 calls of vehicles or shops being set on fire across northeast Delhi.

DFS chief Atul Garg said more than 100 teams have been kept on standby. “The biggest challenge for us to reach the affected areas is violence. We have asked police to ensure the safety of our men before we send fire tenders,” he added.

Officials said they received the first call around 8.30pm on Monday about a fire at Gokulpuri tyre market . This was followed by several distress calls from Brahmpuri. “When our teams reached the road heading towards the market, they saw thick smoke billowing at many places. They were soon surrounded by a mob and dragged out of the fire engines. Some of them were thrashed,” said a fire officer managing the control room.

Through the night, DFS kept receiving calls about fires at Brahmpuri, Maujpur and Chand Bagh. “We informed police about our location, but at some places even they were outnumbered by the rioters,” said the officer.

The fire department has asked police to ensure that gas depots and fuel stations are made inaccessible to the rioters. “If any of them is set on fire, it will end in calamity as northeast Delhi is highly congested,” Garg said.

The fire stations in Bhajanpura, Karawal Nagar and adjoining areas have been shut down and the fire tenders shifted to another base.

Title: Alot 3,700 Swagruha flats to poor: Revanth
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The Congress has demanded that the 3,700 vacant Rajiv Swagruha flats at Bandlaguda and Pocharam should be allotted to the homeless after carrying out repair. Telangana Congress working president A Revanth Reddy on Tuesday visited the Swagruha township and interacted with the residents. “If there is no response from the government, I will not hesitate to go to the court,” he said.TNN

Title: Minor girl sexually assaulted by relative
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Eluru: An 11-year-old girl was raped in Undrajavaram mandal in West Godavari .

Though the incident took place about four days back, it came to light on Tuesday after the child related the incident to the parents.

The accused is a distant relative of the minor girl.

The police, which have booked the accused under the POCSO act, said 30-year-old Durga Prasad had lured the girl and sexually assaulted her four days back when there was no one at home. Her father is a rickshaw-puller and her mother works in a spinning mill. As both of her parents stay away from home for a considerable period of time, she spends about four hours alone in the house after returning from school.

The accused had taken advantage of that.

The incident came to light as Prasad started to call the girl’s father regularly on the phone. Suspecting that something might be up, the parents questioned the girl, who, in turn, revealed the ordeal. They immediately lodged a complaint with the police. tnn

Title: Hailstorm, showers lash Uttarakhand, mercury dips
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Weather in Dehradun witnessed a sudden change on Tuesday as intermittent rains and hailstorms

DEHRADUN: Weather in Dehradun witnessed a sudden change on Tuesday as intermittent rains and hailstorms lashed the state capital after overcast skies prevailed in the city post noon. Thunderstorm activity was also witnessed at isolated places in Tehri, Pauri, Uttarkashi and Pithoragarh districts.

Overcast conditions accompanied by lightning were witnessed in the city towards evening. This was followed by a heavy spell of rain accompanied by hailstorm which threw normal life out of gear at least for a couple of hours.

The sudden wet spell resulted in a dip in the mercury as the maximum temperature in Dehradun was recorded at 24.3 degrees Celsius, just one notch above normal, while the minimum settled at 9.9 degrees Celsius.

In Pantnagar, the maximum temperature remained at 23.9 degrees Celsius, one notch below normal, while the minimum hovered at 12 degrees Celsius. The maximum temperature in Mukteshwar, which also experienced thundershowers, was recorded at 9.3 degrees Celsius, five degrees below normal level.

Meanwhile, the Met office has predicted clear weather in Dehradun and other parts of Uttarakhand from February 26 onwards and dry conditions are likely to prevail at least till Friday.

“Another western disturbance is expected to hit Uttarakhand from February 29 morning onwards and a fresh spell of rain and thunder activity is going to lash parts of the state,” said Bikram Singh, director of regional meteorological centre.

Title: Poet held for ‘provocative’ speech
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Renowned poet Imran Pratapgarhi was booked by police on Tuesday for his alleged provocative speech at an anti- Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) poetry programme in the city.

The programme was organised by Congress leader Khaja Bilal and Mushaira Syed Saleem of Raza-E-Elahi Foundation at the Quli Qutub Shah Stadium.

Taking sou-moto action for defying police permit rules, S Guruswamy, sub-inspector, Charminar filed a complaint alleging that permission for the programme was given under conditions.

The police said that organizers were reluctant to end the programme and continued to host the show till 9:48pm past the 9 pm cut-off.

Imran who was the invited as chief guest allegedly made an anti-CAA comment that could affect the public tranquillity. Police have registered a case under IPC sections 188 and 505(1). TNN

Title: Visakhapatnam: 68-year-old biker on a mission to draw attention to organ donation
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

68-year-old Pramod Mahajan reached the city from Pune on Tuesday.

VISAKHAPATNAM: To spread awareness about the importance of organ donation, a 68-year-old farmer , who has already donated one of his kidneys , Pramod Mahajan has undertaken a solo motorbike ride across India, as part of Bharat Organ Yatra (BOY) - II.
