By May-end, Mahajan, who is from Dhavali village of Sangli district of Maharashtra, intends to cover 94 cities in 25 states — about 17,500 kms.

The biker and volunteer for Rebirth Foundation, who started from Pune on January 18, reached Visakhapatnam on Tuesday evening after covering over 4,000 kms across eight states.

In October 2000, he had donated his kidney to an army jawan in a Mumbai hospital. Speaking to TOI, Mahajan said, “Despite efforts of doctors and counsellors, people are still not aware about the necessity of donating organs. After I donated my kidney to an ailing ex-army man nearly 20 years ago, he became father of two children after 13 years of marriage. I realized I have not just saved his life, but two more beings got new life as well. That was a turning point in my life.”

During his first solo ride, Mahajan’s encouragement and awareness creation had resulted in around 250 police personnel in Bhopal pledging to donate organs in case of brain death. “In Indore, around 600 students had filled the form. I also record my journey through social media for more people to know. My tour featured in the Limca Book of Records,” said Mahajan.

Title: Give Cheriyal revenue div tag: Residents
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Residents of Cheriyal, led by Congress MP from Bhongir Constituency, Komatireddy Venkat Reddy, staged a demonstration at Pragnapur demanding the status of a revenue division to the mandal within 20 days.

Cheriyal is a mandal in Siddipet district. Earlier on Monday, former minister from Jangaon Ponnala Lakshmaiah submitted a memorandum to chief secretary Somesh Kumar on the issue. tnn

Title: State irrigation dept releases water report
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Compiling the data on availability of water resources and requirements of the state, the Telangana irrigation department has come up with a report which was released by chief secretary Somesh Kumar on Tuesday. The report compiled water resources such as the Godavari and Krishna rivers with an emphasis on inter-state issues and discussed water requirements of Telangana. TNN

Title: Salem: Two more held in gangrape of 16-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

Title: Puri temple administration has no control on over 25,000 acres of Lord’s land
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The Jagannath temple in Puri

BHUBANESWAR: Even as Puri is getting a makeover as part of the government’s heritage corridor project surrounding the Jagannath temple, the shrine administration seems to have failed to safeguard hundreds of acres of land that belongs to the sibling deities.

In a written reply, law minister Pratap Jena told the assembly on Tuesday that the Jagannath temple administration owns 60,426.943 acres of land in 24 districts in Odisha. However, the shrine body possessed ownership records of only 34,803.013 acres. According to the minister’s reply, the temple administration is yet to take control of 25,623 acres. Temple sources said the 25,623 acres have been encroached upon.

“We (temple administration) have so far registered a total of 864 encroachment cases in different tehsils under the Jagannath Temple Act-1955, Section 16-A (1). Steps are being taken to get the 25,623 acres of land back,” Jena said.

The minister said Jagannath temple owns 395.282 acres of land in six states (West Bengal, Andhra Pradesh , Madhya Pradesh , Maharashtra, Bihar and Chhattisgarh) with the bulk of the property (322.930 acres) located in West Bengal . The minister’s reply, however, has no mention about the status of the land use. According to Jena’s reply, the Jagannath temple has 17 acres in Andhra Pradesh, 28 acres in Maharashtra, 25 acres in Madhya Pradesh, 1.7 acres in Chhattisgarh and 0.274 acre in Bihar.

On November 4, 2019, the Supreme Court had sought information from the temple administration on the immovable property and quarries owned by the deities in Odisha and other states. The temple body had sought more time from the apex court to furnish the details.

Temple sources said land sharks in connivance with some corrupt temple officers had created forged documents and transferred hundreds of acres of land in their names in the state.

Title: Northeast Delhi violence: Karawal Nagar in distress, cries out for relief
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Motorcycles set ablaze as protestors throw brick-bats during clashes between pro and anti-CAA protestors at Ka... Read More

NEW DELHI: Amid thick plumes of smoke and shops being ransacked, people trapped in Karawal Nagar frantically started making distress calls on Tuesday. Those living in the internal parts of Karawal Nagar and Khajuri Khas had no escape route with the main road being “captured” by rioters and stone-pelters.

Vikram Pandey, a resident of Karawal Nagar, said, “A mob was outside my house and even policemen weren’t allowed entry. We were stuck at home for two days. I could hear firing. I gave first aid to a man who was hurt in stone-pelting.”

In fact, a family of four had packed its bags to leave for its hometown of Patna. “I don’t think the situation is going to change. I’m not going to put myself or my family in harm’s way. I have applied for leave and I’d rather give my resignation than remain here,” said the family head.

The situation was the same at Bhajanpura with locals standing outside protecting their shops. Delhi Police fired tear gas at the mob in Chand Bagh, which has been on the boil for the last two days.

A woman at Bhajanpura was seen carrying a stick to “simply protect herself and her family”. “Many of us are trapped here. We have to protect ourselves when we go out. Those who are not part of the riots have the most to lose,” she said, while calling police for help.

At Chand Bagh and Yamuna Vihar, the situation was worse. A convoy of at least 25 police vehicles reached Karawal Nagar at 3.40pm. The mob there kept hitting the ground with sticks while sloganeering. Within the next 15 minutes, the mob was contained and the protesters started running towards the narrow lanes of 3-Foota Road. A loud cheer of “Delhi Police Zindabad” was soon heard.

A flag march was conducted at Chand Bagh around 4.15pm. The condition seemed to get normal there, but as soon as security forces passed the mob went berserk. The protesters broke the barriers and pelted stones towards the other side of the road.

Nagma, a resident of Chand Bagh, couldn’t sleep through the night as her son hadn’t returned home. “I had told him to get some items from a shop nearby on Monday. Later, I heard about the clashes. People kept pelting stones in the lane and didn’t let anyone enter. I was awake the entire night worried for his safety. If I had stepped out, then I could have been hurt or killed. I breathed a sigh of relief when he returned in the morning,” she added.

The anger against media personnel was quite evident as the crowd started throwing stones at the journalists. The situation remained tense till late at night, but there was no letup in police cover.

Title: Lakshmi Parvathi visits Andhra varsity
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Chairperson of Telugu Academy N Lakshmi Parvathi visited Andhra University (AU) on Tuesday. Lakshmi said the academy will extend its services to all parts of the state and sought assistance of the varsity. AU vice-chancellor Prof PVGD Prasad Reddy said the departments of Telugu, Hindi and Sanskrit have historic significance and the varsity will take assistance of the academy to revive the glory of these departments. Prof Reddy also requested Lakshmi Parvathi to serve as an honorary professor at the varsity. tnn

Title: Two women robbed of gold chains in Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Two incidents of chain snatching were reported from the Ambad and Mhasrool areas of the city on Monday. Police have registered offences against unidentified suspects in this regard.

According to Mhasrool police, the incident took place at around 8.45 pm in the Sneha Nagar area along the Dindori road. The complainant told police that her aunt and her mother had been to the market for some purchases. While they were returning, an unidentified person approache them and snatched gold chain worth Rs 30,000 from her aunt’s neck, before fleeing from the spot.

In another incident, an unidentified person snatched a gold chain worth Rs 33,000 from a 40-year-old woman when she was walking near the gate of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ground in Ambad along with her daughter at around 9.30 am, police said.

Title: Will enforce CAA at all cost, says Kishan
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy on Tuesday said CAA would be implemented at all costs. He also faulted Asaduddin Owaisi for asking people in Old City to not cooperate with officials for taking details during the Census drive. TNN

Title: Nirav Modi assets to be auctioned tomorrow
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

MUMBAI: A collection of 112 lots of prized assets belonging to absconder diamantaire Nirav Modi shall be put up for live and online auctions starting here on February 27, officials said.

These assets were seized by the ED and the auction is an attempt to recover a part of the dues Modi owes to various banks. The lots going under the hammer in two separate auctions would include major artworks by top contemporary and modern Indian artists, coveted luxury watches , handbags and cars.

The first auction shall be conducted by Saffronart as the Spring Live Auction here on Thursday, followed by the Spring Online Auction on March 3 and 4. The first auction comprises around 40 lots including 15 artworks worth crores of rupees, and the rest will go for auction next week.

Leading the pack in the sale are works by M F Husain and Amrita Sher-Gil.

A Rolls-Royce Ghost with advanced features, technology and comforts will also be on auction (live) estimated at Rs75-95 lakhs, besides a 2010 Porsche Panamera for between Rs 10-15 lakhs (online).

Over two dozen luxury items including watches worth millions of rupees shall also be on auction. The auctions will feature several top brands of handbags like Birkin and Kelly from Hermes, in the range of Rs 3-6 lakhs. The other items will be expensive personal collectibles from Chanel, Piaget, Celine and Louis Vuitton, Cartier Asymmetric ‘Crash’ wristwatch, etc.

Title: Jeweller jumps to death in Nashik while being grilled by Cyberabad cops
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK/HYDERABAD: A jeweller from Nashik ended his life by jumping to death from the fourth floor of a government guesthouse where he was being questioned by Cyberabad police in relation to purchase of stolen gold on Tuesday.

A team of Cyberabad police along with their counterparts from Mahbubnagar of Telanagana and Guntur of Andhra Pradesh, went to Nashik on Monday to question jeweller, Vijay Birare, about allegedly purchasing stolen gold from a burglar Santosh alias Prakash Shinde Shinde.

Cyberabad police launched a man hunt for Shinde and Shamshabad police arrested him on 15, February after they found his finger prints at a crime scene.

“Shinde was involved in burglaries since late 1990s and was imprisoned also. However Shinde managed to procure a bogus death certificate to close all his pending cases in different cities,” a police official from Nashik said.

Cyberabad commissioner VC Sajjanar said that Shinde is an accused in 24 night burglary cases registered in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh.

“After his arrest, Shinde confessed that he disposed over two kilos of stolen gold with Vijay Birare and our team went to Nashik with Shinde to recover the stolen property from Vijay. When he was being questioned at a government guest house in Nashik, Vijay made an excuse saying that he had to drink water and committed suicide by jumping from the building,” Cyberabad commissioner said.

While the Cyberabad police told their Nashik counterparts that the jeweller ended his life, his family members accused that police excesses led to his death.

“We apprehend that the victim could have managed to give the Cyberabad police team a slip at the guest house and jumped from the fourth floor to end his life,” said Nashik police sources.

The bereaved family and relatives of the jeweller created a ruckus at Nashik Civil Hospital refusing the authorities to carry out the autopsy. They demanded that Cyberabad police should be booked for Vijay Birare’s death.

Nashik police commissioner, Vishwas Nangare Patil met the bereaved family and assured them of a fair probe into the death.

“The case has been handed over to the state Crime Investigation Department for investigation as victim had died under Cyberabad police detention,” the Nashik city police commissioner told TOI.

Title: Rural police warn petrol pump dealers against selling petrol in loose
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Rural police on Tuesday conducted a meeting with petrol pump dealers across the rural district to sensitise them about the illegal selling of petrol and diesel in loose on the backdrop of the recent incident in Lasalgaon where the woman accidentally caught fire and died.

Over 100 petrol pump dealers across the rural district were present for the meeting, where the superintendent of police Arti Singh warned the dealers of strict action if they are found selling petrol or fuel in bottles.

There are over 350 petrol pumps across the rural district. While it is legally not allowed to sell the petrol in loose, these rules are often neglected by a large number of petrol pumps.

A good section of motorists is in the habit of carrying additional petrol in bottles or cans so that when their vehicle runs out of petrol, they have the fuel in reserve in the bottle or can. According to police officials, petrol cannot be sold in bottles given the hazards involved while handling highly inflammable fuel.

A few days back, a woman carrying a petrol-filled bottle had an altercation with her paramour and threatened to kill herself by dousing petrol all over her body. The woman accidentally caught fire and got killed.

Title: Gujarat: Five flung into river as dumper hits tractor on bridge
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PALANPUR: Five youngsters were flung into Vatrak River from a bridge when a dumper hit the tractor near Malpur in Aravalli district late on Monday night.

The five were sitting on the edge of the tractor and were flung under the impact of the collision. While all five died of drowning, 24 others who were injured in the accident were admitted to hospitals in Modasa and Himmatnagar.

JP Bharwad, police sub-inspector of Malpur police station, said, “The accident took place on the bridge over Vatrak River when a dumper hit the tractor from behind. The five were sitting on the edge of the tractor.”

The tractor was ferrying around 32 persons, including women and children, who were returning from a wedding at Mahiyapur in Malpur taluka .

All the deceased belonged to Belu village of Megharaj taluka in Aravali district . They were identified as Simetbhai Chamar (14) Ankit Chamar (17) Meheshbhai Chamar(20), Rajdeep Chamar(17) and Jayesh Chamar.

Title: IT officials raid dairy firm premises in Erode, Tirupur
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Erode: Income tax sleuths conducted surprise raids at a dairy company owner’s house, units and offices in Erode and Tirupur districts on Tuesday to check for possible tax evasion. While the raids are likely to continue till Wednesday morning, officials have seized many documents from the company.

An income tax department official said four teams, each comprising five people, from Coimbatore office have been searching the premises of Gokulam milk diary private companies in Nambiyur near Gobichettipalayam in Erode district, and Udumalpet and Pollachi in Tirupur district since Tuesday morning.

“Two teams are conducting raids at the dairy production company, office and the owner’s house in Nambiyur, while the remaining teams are searching the milk production units in Pollachi and Udumalpet,” the officer said.

The dairy belongs to K Palanisamy, 70, of Nambiyur. In business for more than 20 years, his main market is Kerala.

The raid started around 7am on Tuesday. “We came to know that the company is doing brisk business. However, it has failed to produce proper accounts for us to verify the revenue it clocks. So, we conducted the raids. After detailed investigation, we will take further action on the dairy, if it is found guilty,” the official said.

Title: Leopards on prowl leave villagers on tenterhooks
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Erode: Fear gripped the residents of Pasakuttai village near KN Palayam forest after a leopard killed a calf in the early hours of Tuesday. Panicked, they, along with forest officials, combed the entire village for the leopard, but in vain.

According to C Gopal, 45, who reared the calf, the leopard came out of the Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve around 4am. “I had tied my cattle at the backyard of my house. Hearing the calf cry in distress, i went to check on it only to find the leopard pouncing on it and trying to drag it into the forest.”

As Gopal raised an alarm, fellow villagers rushed to the spot. Meanwhile, the leopard left the dead calf behind and disappeared in the forest.

The villagers alerted forest officials, who later joined them to trace the animal. S Bernard, forest ranger, Sathyamangalam forest range, said, “We have found pug marks of the leopard.”

The officer said they would chase away the leopard into deep forest. “We will set up a cage with a bait to trap the animal.”

The carcass of the calf was, meanwhile, buried after postmortem.

In another development, forest officials on Tuesday installed CCTV cameras in Ariyappampalayam Inur to monitor the movement of a leopard that has been roaming around the village for the past one week.

“We have fixed eight CCTV cameras to monitor its movement. We have also set up a cage with a got in it to trap the animal. We are hopeful of capturing the animal in a couple of days,” S Bernard said.

Title: Delhi high court lifts stay on Nauroji Nagar infra project
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The court had questioned the Centre on how a residential area could be converted into a commercial zone withou... Read More

NEW DELHI: Almost two years after it stayed further construction, Delhi high court on Tuesday gave its nod to the Nauroji Nagar redevelopment project in south Delhi.

The project envisages a commercial hub including a World Trade Centre and was challenged by activists for lacking crucial clearances.

A bench of justices G S Sistani and Jyoti Singh, in its decision, lifted the August 30, 2018 stay by which National Buildings Construction Corporation (NBCC) was restrained from any further construction at the project.

The court held that once the issues of water and traffic congestion have been dealt with and no objection certificates (NOCs) procured from departments concerned, it need not enforce the stay on completion of the redevelopment projects.

Earlier, the court had questioned the Centre on how a residential area could be converted into a commercial zone without change of land use. However, NBCC had maintained that the project was approved as a package by the government and had all clearances from relevant agencies.

“There is no violation of Delhi Preservation of Trees Act and there is adequate compensatory plantation in lieu of felling of trees at Nauroji Nagar,” the bench added, disposing of the petition filed by one Kaushal Kant Mishra, where he had challenged the environment clearance granted to Nauroji Nagar project claiming a large number of trees had to be cut.

“We have no hesitation in saying that the NOCs have been issued by the respective departments and they would have been issued only after a careful analysis of ground realities and provisions of law,” the bench further noted, while relying on an affidavit filed by the New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) that revealed final sanctions are still awaited from the authorities.

“While we see no violation of the Master Plan Delhi (MPD)-2021 and are also of the view that the environmental clearances (EC) have been correctly given for the Nauroji Nagar project, however, since the NDMC is still seized of the matter, we may only observe that while granting the final sanction, the concerns of the petitioner may be taken into account,” the bench said while disposing of the petition.

It clarified that in case the NDMC is of the opinion it needs to revisit any of the issues flagged by the petitioner in his plea, especially those relating to the grant of ECs, the civic body is free to seek clarifications or reports from the authorities.

Title: Four smugglers nabbed, 31 gold bars seized on Bengaluru-Hyderabad highway
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Gold seized by DRI officials

HYDERABAD: Four smugglers carrying 3-kg gold were arrested at a toll plaza on the Bengaluru-Hyderabad highway on Monday night. During interrogation, the four accused admitted that they were smuggling gold from Bengaluru to the city.

Acting on specific information, Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) officials intercepted a private travels bus at Raikal toll plaza near Shadnagar. They caught hold of a smuggler and recovered some gold. Based on his inputs, the DRI team intercepted a car coming from Bengaluru at the toll plaza and nabbed three others travelling in it.

“The accused were carrying 31 gold bars weighing three kilos. The seized gold is of foreign origin with Valcambi precious metals from Switzerland and 24-karat purity. Its market value is Rs 1.38 crore,” said a DRI official.

The accused were not carrying any ownership documents. “They confessed that the gold was supposed to be delivered to receivers in Hyderabad. We are trying to nab the other gang members,” said the DRI official. The four accused were arrested under Customs Act.

In another case, CISF sleuths intercepted two men at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport when they were taking a flight to Khartoum via Dubai and found 46 kilos of white sandalwood in their baggage. “The duo produced bills for only 20 kilos of white sandalwood. We handed them over to the customs officials for further probe,” said a CISF official.

Title: Government has proof of insider trading: Basha
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Deputy chief minister S B Amzath Basha said the government has proof of insider trading worth Rs 40,000 crore in Amaravati during the TDP rule.

Addressing the media here on Tuesday, he said the government was gathering all information required to bring the scams to light.

He further said that former chief minister and TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu would face the music soon over insider trading.

He said TDP was unable to tolerate positive developments in the state and was opposing the shifting of secretariat to Vizag out of heartburn. He also asked Naidu to explain the purpose of his Praja Chaitanya Yatra. tnn

Title: Morbi relieved after GCC holds back duty
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

RAJKOT: In a big respite to Morbi ceramic makers , the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), the political and economic union of six Gulf countries, has put in abeyance its interim order to impose anti-dumping duty on tiles imported from India.

GCC had proposed duty ranging between 40% and 106%. The final order was expected a month after the interim order was passed, which was during Diwali last year.

According to the sources, GCC may be reluctant to impose the duty on Indian tiles immediately due as ceramic production in China, the biggest exporter, has come to standstill due to the deadly coronavirus epidemic.

GCC consists of members from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Bahrain and United Arab Emirates (UAE). The countries had reduced its orders beginning August last year fearing the anti-dumping duty.

Talking to TOI, Nilesh Jetparia president of Morbi’s Ceramic Association said, “We expected GCC’s final order a month ago. But we are getting good orders from Saudi Arabia currently. It’s possible that the local government is not in position to take a final decision because of coronavirus crisis in China.”

Echoing Jetparia’s view, sources in Director General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) said, “Currently, there is no movement in GCC regarding the anti-dumping duty on Indian tiles. It seems it has been put in abeyance for now.”

According to the data, the export of tiles from Mundra port to the Saudi Arabia was Rs 161 crore in April 2019, which increased to Rs 329 crore in December and Rs 274 crore in January 2020.

Saudi Arabia was the biggest importer of Morbi’s ceramic products during the current financial year. The export is also increased in USA and Europe countries.

“The export orders increased by nearly 10% in the last one month. We are getting benefits in those countries who were importing tiles from India and China,” Jetparia added.

According to reports, Shandong province of China is the biggest ceramic production hub, but manufacturing has not resumed because of the epidemic. It is learnt that labourers have not turned up at the factories and there is lack of logistic and transportation for ceramic products. Sources in ceramic industry said Shandong is not in the position to restart normal production before the end of March.

The Foshan International Ceramic and Bathroom Fair (CeramBath) which was scheduled to be organized from April 18-21 in Gangdong province has also bee postponed.

Title: Hyderabad Metro News: Three new corridors in phase 2 of Hyderabad Metro
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

File photo of Hyderabad Metro train

HYDERABAD: Three new corridors are expected to launched in the second phase of the Metro Rail project. Of the three, two of them connect parts of the city with Rajiv Gandhi International Airport. NVR Reddy, managing director, Hyderabad Metro Rail Limited on Tuesday said that the DPR (detailed project report) for the three corridors- Lakdikapul to RGIA, Nagole to LB Nagar and Raidurg to RGIA – are ready and have been submitted to the state government.

“The DPR has been submitted and is currently under examination. It is being considered for the phase II,” he said.

Title: Northeast Delhi violence: Four securitymen suffer acid burns
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Shops set on fire during clashes between pro and anti-CAA protesters in Delhi's Karawal Nagar

NEW DELHI: Eight people injured in the riots in northeast Delhi on Tuesday were rushed to Lok Nayak Hospital. Among the injured were four security personnel, who were attacked with acid while they were controlling a mob in Karawal Nagar.

The security personnel suffered burns in the eye and face.

According to hospital sources, the victims of acid attack were aged between 24 years and 37 years. While one of the security personnel, who suffered acid burn in his eye, was referred to Guru Nanak Eye Centre, another acid injury victim was referred to the ENT department of the hospital.

Two others were referred to the burns department for further examination of the injury and treatment. Allegedly, some of the rioters poured acid on the security personnel from rooftops. “The acid burns weren’t severe among the cases referred to us. No one has been admitted to the hospital,” said a senior doctor at LNJP’s burns department.

There were four others who were hit by stones and referred to LNJP for treatment on Tuesday. At least two persons with gunshot wounds were also admitted to the hospital on Monday, sources said, adding that both are currently stable and undergoing treatment.

Delhi government sources said Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital in northeast Delhi’s Shahdara, where most people injured during Monday’s rioting were being sent to initially, is running at full capacity. “We are planning to shift the new cases to Lok Nayak Hospital for now,” a doctor said.

“Hospital authorities have been directed to make arrangements for manpower and infrastructure that may be required to treat mass casualty, if the situation arises,” a government official added.

Title: Director of Heritage Aviation gets bail
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Dehradun: The district court of Rudraprayag on Tuesday granted bail to the director of Heritage Aviation, Rohit Mathur, in the 2018 helicopter ticketing fraud case.

Mathur was sent to jail after his bail application was rejected by the local court in Rudraprayag on February 22. Later, Mathur was even taken to a hospital in Chamoli after he complained of chest pain.

He was lodged in Pursari prison in Chamoli district. On Tuesday, Mathur’s lawyers moved the bail application in the session court. After hearing the arguments of both sides, the court granted him bail. The court also asked Mathur to furnish two sureties of Rs1lakh each and personal bond of similar amount.

Title: Two-day tech fest begins
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Tachyon-2020, a two-day tech fest, was inaugurated at Anil Neerukonda Institute of Technology and Sciences (ANITS) on Tuesday.

The department of electronics and communication engineering of ANITS, in association with the ANITS Communication Engineers Society, is conducting the fest. Head of the department, ECE, Prof Rajya Lakhsmi, said Tachyon, which is conducted every year, provides a platform for the students to showcase their tech talent. “This year Tachyon has got more than 800 registrations, including 80 registrations from other colleges,” said Prof Lakshmi. tnn

Title: Flyovers won’t narrow down Mettupalayam Rd: Official
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: The highways department on Tuesday assured the commuters on Mettupalayam Road to restore the width of road after the construction of flyovers at Kavundampalayam and GN Mills. The officials said the flyover pillars would occupy only 2m of the 23m-22m wide road.

It would now take at least 15-18 minutes to cross the Sanganoor Canal-Vellakinar Pirivu stretch, where flyover construction is taking place, during peak hours. Kirubashankar, a resident of Periyanaickenpalayam, said, “The stretch, which is hardly 5km long, is nightmarish between 5pm and 7.30pm and again from 9am to 10.30pm. The road has become too narrow in Kavundampalayam Junction area and hardly a car and a two-wheeler could drive side by side.”

T Shankar, a driver, said the road was not only too narrow but also bumpy with potholes.

The highways department told TOI that the situation would improve once the flyover work was over. An official said the flyovers would occupy only 2m of road space at the centre, leaving 20m of the 22m to 23m wide road for vehicles.

Selvakumar, divisional engineer, national highways, said “It will be like the Gandhipuram flyovers, where cars can drive beneath them comfortably. With the flyover carrying a sizeable portion of the traffic, the road below can accommodate its traffic.”

A section of residents and activists in the area said the service road on either side of the upcoming flyover could be extended by at least 15ft. Mariappan, a resident of Kavundampalayam, said, “This will be beneficial. Even now it plays a major role in easing traffic congestion to a large extent. However, the space is being encroached by some shops.”

Title: Pune: Kin in net for sexually harassing 5 in family
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect their privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

PUNE: The Pimpri police on Tuesday arrested a 32-year-old man from Roha in Raigad district on the charges of sexually harassing five women, including four minors, of a family on the pretext of “nullifying the spell of black magic” and helping them trace treasure hidden in their house.The man, a distant kin of the family, claimed that one of their woman relatives had “cast the spell of black magic for which women in the family cannot give birth to sons”. The police said the man had told his targets that the life of one of the girls in the family was in danger.The said the man had told the women that there were seven boxes of treasure, including a gold utensil and a Ganesh idol — hidden in their house. He had taken Rs3.11 lakh from the family “to perform a puja to nullify the effect of black magic, save the girl’s life and trace the hidden treasure”.Milind Waghmare, senior inspector of the Pimpri police, told TOI, “On the pretext of performing the puja, he sexually harassed four minors and raped their elder sister. The minors and their elder sister remained silent, as the man had threatened them to kill their parents with the power of black magic.”He said, “One of the girls gathered courage after the man eloped with one of her sisters and shared the incident with her parents. The three other girls also told their parents what had happened.”The family subsequently approached the Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmoolan Samiti and its members helped them lodge a police complaint. On Monday, a 22-year-old woman from the family lodged an FIR with the Pimpri police.Milind Deshmukh of the Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmoolan Samiti told TOI, “The man had taken Rs3 lakh from them for the puja expenses and Rs11,000 as his charges. He is married twice and lured one of his targets to marry him.”Inspector Waghmare said the family members had sold their gold ornaments for Rs60,000 and borrowed Rs2.5 lakh from a private money lender to pay the man for the puja rituals.“Our investigation revealed that the crime branch had in 2018 arrested the man from Roha and found a firearm on him. We are probing if he is involved in any other crimes,” he said.The man has been charged under various sections of the Indian Penal Code and the relevant provisions of the Maharashtra Prevention and Eradication of Human Sacrifice and other Inhuman, Evil and Aghori Practices and Black Magic Act and also the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, Waghmare said.

Title: HC directs state to grant pension to centenarian who worked as Tamil pandit
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: Directing the state government to disburse pension to a centenarian who worked as a Tamil pandit in various government aided schools, the Madras high court has observed that the authorities concerned should bear in mind that he could enjoy the fruits of this order in his lifetime only based on their swift action in letter and spirit.

The petitioner, K Srinivasan was working between 1944 and 1964 for which he was paid salary by the government. Due to the abolition of the Tamil pandit post, he was relieved from service on December 31, 1964. Since the petitioner was eligible for pension he submitted several representations to the authorities concerned, but no steps were taken.

In 2012, Srinivasan moved the high court Madurai bench, which directed the authorities to pass orders in this regard within eight weeks. However, the director of elementary education passed an order on June 1, 2015, rejecting the petitioner’s claim of pension on the ground that the documents relating to his service was not available.

Hence, he moved the high court Madurai bench in 2015, seeking to quash the rejection order and sought to grant relaxation for not having the relieving order and disburse pension for his service for 15 years two months and three days.

R Subramanian, counsel for the petitioner submitted that an aided school at Rajapalayam in Virudhunagar district in which the petitioner worked lastly had certified that when the petitioner was relieved from service, he was receiving Rs 90 as pay, Rs 25.50 as dearness allowance from the government and Rs 5 as house rent allowance from the management. He stated that the authorities had erroneously rejected the petitioner’s claim.

The special government pleader N Shanmugaselvan submitted that an employee who is retired on attaining the age of superannuation or voluntarily are alone entitled for pension. He further submitted that the petitioner has not produced any documents to show the reason for which he was relieved from service and no document had been produced for his service particulars.

On perusal of the submissions, justice J Nisha Banu observed that the authorities concerned were not able to produce any documents to show that the petitioner was not paid salary by the government and there was no such abolition of posts of Tamil pandit during the relevant point of time. The judge noted that on contrary, the petitioner has produced an appointment order by the then Ramanathapuram district collector and had also produced certificates issued by the schools where he worked.

The judge the set aside the rejection order and directed the state to release pension to the petitioner by considering his case sympathetically and based on the documents produced by him.

Title: Farming practices in 4 blocks to be surveyed
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: The district’s agriculture technology management agency (ATMA) plans to survey four blocks—Pollachi, Karamadai, Annur and Periyanaickenpalayam, to understand the exact requirement of farmers and ensure their land and resources are optimally used.

The project to improve their livelihoods and revenue will be a five-year plan. Farmers will be advised on more suitable crops, cultivation practices, varieties and use of machines.

ATMA was launched by the Centre to achieve sustainable agriculture development. It plans to select specific areas, or a few villages, study their soil type, weather, rainfall pattern, labour availability among others and use this data to understand the gap in yield that farmers experience.

The areas selected for the study are Pollachi—which is primarily a coconut-based cropping system, Karamadai which like Thondamuthur is a vegetable cultivation belt, Annur which like Sulthanpet and S Kulam is a millet cultivation belt and Periyanaickenpalayam which is an integrated farming belt, said Tom P Silus, the deputy director in charge of central government schemes, agriculture department.

From mid-March till April-end, ATMA workers will be visiting the four villages and going door to door covering almost every farmer and getting them to fill four surveys. “The four surveys will basically assess the crops they cultivate, variety they cultivate, their water resources like tanks, bores etc., irrigation method, availability of labour, cost of labour, revenue, fertilizers being used, among others. With this, we will identify what they lack and what they need and try providing it for them, and advising them on better options like alternate crops, better varieties available or advising them to add a few milch cows etc.,” Sylus said.

ATMA consists of seven government agencies, including agriculture department, horticulture department, agriculture marketing and business department, agriculture business department, sericulture department, fisheries department and animal husbandry. “We believe that the data we get from these four villages, will be adequate for us to come up with a plan for the entire district, because all four villages have not only different cropping patterns but rainfall and water availability patterns too,” Sylus said.

ATMA conducted a two-day orientation workshop including a few model farmers and panchayat presidents from the four blocks, to draft questions for the survey at TNAU on Monday and Tuesday. “Our plan is to get at least 100 farmers from each block to participate in our survey,” Sylus said.

Title: Counselling session for rowdy-sheeters
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Tirupati urban SP Avula Ramesh Reddy held a counselling session for rowdy-sheeters at the district police office on Tuesday where he urged them to mend their ways.

He also warned them that the police would not hesitate to take stern action if they resort to any kind of illegal practices. “The police department has opened the rowdy sheets only because of the continuous illegal acts of some persons who refuse to mend their ways. One must respect the law,” he said, while adding that the cops will continuously monitor their movements and will not hesitate to arrest them against if there is a threat to the city’s peace due to their illegal acts. tnn

Title: Violence in Delhi: Many dreams die a painful death in riot-hit Delhi
Content:
Protesters throw brick-bats during clashes at Chand Bagh in Bhajanpura area

NEW DELHI: Even as five families were grieving at the loss of their loved ones in the violence in northeast Delhi on Monday, there were many injured who had been admitted to various hospitals in a critical condition. On Tuesday, some of them breathed their last, raising the death toll to 13.Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital was swamped with relatives of the deceased. Among them were the inconsolable family members of Shahid Khan (22), who came in the line of fire while returning home along with his brother after offering prayers.While his brother managed to dodge the bullets, Khan collapsed in a pool of blood after being shot. He and his wife were planning to go on vacation next month. They had got married in September last year.“His wife is three months pregnant. Their future plans died along with him,” said Khan’s grieving elder brother, Imran.When Khan didn’t return on the fateful day, the family members started to panic. When they heard a knock on the door, they thought he had finally reached. “But it was a stranger who showed us a picture of Shahid lying in a pool of blood in Bhajanpura. We were told that two men had taken him to GTB Hospital. We rushed there and found him dead,” Imran said. Khan was the youngest of four brothers.Like Khan, 32-year-old Furqan was shot dead when he ventured out to buy food. Mohammad Imran, his elder brother, said that Furqan, who had a handicraft business, wanted to buy essential food items to store in the house. Mohammed said the street was relatively clear when he went outside. He had only walked a few hundred metres when a stray bullet hit him.“I was at work when a relative called me saying that Furqan had been shot. I rushed home and we took him to the hospital. He was bleeding profusely and succumbed to his injuries,” said Mohammed.Furqan got married in 2014 and had two children, a four-year-old girl and a two-year-old boy. Mohammed said his brother always kept his family first. “This is probably the reason why he went out. He only wanted us to be safe. Though things were tense in the area, we never expected this to happen,” he added. The autopsy was carried out at GTB Hospital.Another victim, Rahul Solanki (26), a civil engineer by profession, was at home till 5pm. He had assured his colleagues at 4.30pm that all was well and he would meet them the next day. However, within an hour, his colleagues received a call that Solanki had been shot dead by rioters. “We got to know about the riots and people from office had called him up immediately asking him to take care. He said everything was fine. An hour later, we came to know that he had been shot,” said Shweta Chauhan, a colleague.Solanki’s father was inconsolable. He said everyone in their family was excited about his daughter’s marriage due in early April. They had been busy with the preparations for the past couple of months. “He had taken leave from work because of the tense situation in the area. Now I think it would have been better if he had gone to work. At least he would have been alive today,” added the grieving father.

Title: One injured as parked PMPML bus rolls down slope in Katraj
Content:
Major accident averted when a parked and empty PMPML bus started rolling down the slope on the busy Katraj Cho... Read More

Commuters fume

PUNE: A major accident was averted on Tuesday morning when a parked and empty PMPML bus, purportedly operated by a private contractor, started rolling down the slope on the busy Katraj Chowk, injuring one person and hitting two autorickshaws.Sources in the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) said had a middle-aged man not gotten inside the bus and applied the brakes, more people could have been injured. The bus was to start its trip on the Katraj-Lohegaon route when the incident occurred.“The driver had parked the bus at the main bus stand in Katraj at 6.30pm. However, he did not apply the hand brake. When he was reporting to the controller at the bus stop as per the norm, the vehicle started rolling down a slope. The vehicle belongs to a private contractor and the driver was not directly employed with the PMPML,” a PMPML official said.He said as the bus started rolling down the slope, it gathered speed and hit two autorickshaws, injuring one auto driver, who was later identified as Javed Belge (29) of Katraj.“The bus did not have any passengers. Once it slowed down, a middle-aged man, ran towards the bus and somehow managed to get inside it before applying the brakes, bringing the vehicle to a halt. It is a minor incident and further investigations are on. The Bhartiya Vidyapeeth police are also investigating and a first information report (FIR) has been lodged against the driver,” the official added.When contacted, a PMPML spokesperson said, “An inquiry is still going on. Things will be clear by Wednesday.”Acting on the complaint lodged by the injured, Belge, the Bharati Vidyapeeth police booked the PMPML bus driver on the charge of neglecting safety of road users by keeping his bus engine on at the busy Katraj Chowk.Inspector Vishnu Tamhane of the Bharati Vidyapeeth police said the driver should have switched off the engine before leaving the bus cabin. “He also didn’t apply the hand brakes,” he said.The PMPML official terming the incident “minor” drew flak from commuters and activists alike.“How can this (incident) be termed minor? If the man not reacted on time, the bus could have hit more vehicles and people on the road. How can the PMPML be so casual about it? This again exposes the PMPML and shows that things are far from fine in the transport utility. This incident, like many others, would deter new commuters from using the service,” PMP Pravasi Manch activist Sanjay Shitole said.Questioning the “casual approach” of the PMPML, he said, “Have they (PMPML authorities) still not understood that all buses, whether owned by PMPML or private contractors, run under as PMPML vehicles?”Akshay Datre, a commuter, said, “This is so scary. If the bus had passengers, they would have panicked, leading to a major accident. The casual approach of the PMPML should end at once.”

Title: Housing society’s office raided, documents seized
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Kanadia police along with cooperative society officials on Tuesday raided office of central government officers grih nirman samiti at Vijay Nagar.

“We have seized documents related to the membership, elections. The president of the cooperation is absconding, so he has been removed from the post. An administrator Pradeep Chouhan, senior cooperative inspector has been appointed on the post by the administration and society,” said Kanadia police station in charge RD Kanwa.

He said that the lock was broken and documents were seized.

Meanwhile, during public hearing one Sunny Lashkari approached officials and claimed that he was also duped by Bobby Chhabra. His documents are being looked into, said the police.

Chhabra was arrested on February 14 under Indore police's Operation Clean-Up - a drive against land mafia in the city. Chhabra was on the top in the administration’s list of land sharks. He became chairman in around a dozen housing cooperative societies and sold plots meant for its members to someone else. He is currently on Kanadia police remand.

Title: Hyderabad Airport: RGIA to extend screening for coronavirus
Content:
File photo of Rajiv Gandhi International Airport

HYDERABAD: As per a fresh directive from the ministry of civil aviation, Rajiv Gandhi International Airport ( RGIA ) will start screening passengers arriving from Nepal, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia in wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

Title: Son of former Haryana transport commissioner kills mother, then shoots self in Doon
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: The 28-year-old son of former transport commissioner of Haryana shot dead his mother before killing himself in Sahaspur area of Dehradun on Tuesday morning.

Jai Pandit, son of late Subhash Sharma who was the former transport commissioner of Haryana, shot dead his 70-year-old mother, identified as Sushila Devi, inside his residence before committing suicide .

According to police , Jai, believed to be a drug addict, was running a dairy and a students' hostel at his farmhouse in Bhauwala area of Sahaspur, on the outskirts of Dehradun.

“Around 8.30am on Tuesday, Jai asked his servant to go out of the house saying that he wanted to talk to his mother. Within minutes, according to the eyewitnesses, sounds of multiple gunshots were heard. On entering the room, the servant saw both son and mother lying in a pool of blood,” said inspector Rajiv Rauthan, in charge of Sahaspur police station.

Jai, who originally hailed from Rewari district of Haryana, was supposed to take his mother to Chandigarh on Tuesday to check the issue of non-disbursement of family pension for the past four months. He had even booked a taxi for Chandigarh, police said.

One of his friends, identified as Ankit Srivastav, who had come from Varanasi and was staying on the first floor of the house, was also supposed to accompany the mother-son duo to Chandigarh.

Jai’s father had retired from service in 2009, after which he made a farmhouse in Bhauwala area of Dehradun. He died in 2012 and since then his son has been looking after the property.

Rauthan added, “The neighbours told police that Jai was addicted to drugs and had an erratic behaviour. Preliminary investigation didn’t point towards any property or family feud.”

Title: Gujarat: Lesser flamingo electorcuted
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

RAJKOT: A lesser flamingo died after it hit a high tension power cable near Hamirpar village of Kutch on Tuesday.

The pictures of the dead flamingo hanging on high tension wire had gone viral on the social media. According to locals, there have been incidents in the past where birds including the great India bustard have after hitting high tension power cables during flight. The locals have demanded that all high tension cables be insulated or be laid underground to save the birds.

Title: Hyderabad: Daughter died on birthday, mother unaware of tragedy
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: At around 8 pm on Tuesday, as neighbours started to trickle into Gautham Buddha’s house , he chose to meet them outside instead of inviting them inside. His youngest daughter and son-in-law were killed in a car crash in Frisco and his wife is still unaware of the deaths. Gautham’s daughter Divya Avula , died on her birthday.

“She died on her birthday. They went to see their under-construction house and were on their way back . My grand-daughter, Riya, was attending dance class ,” he said.

Gautham, has not been able to muster courage to inform his wife about the tragedy. “Bhabi doesn't know about the deaths. She is aware of the accident and is worried,” said a family friend.

Divya had met her elder sister in Columbia a few days ago and came back to Frisco only a day before the accident occurred. “She visits us once every two years. Last year she came here," said the father, who broke down while showing his daughter's pictures.

The father found out on Tuesday that Divya, her husband Raja Gavini and husband's friend, Premnath Ramanatham were killed in the accident. “The driver who hit their car was a juvenile. That's all I know. My elder daughter will come here with my granddaughter,” he said

Title: Northeast Delhi violence: Journalists face bullets, sticks in quest for facts
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Demonstrators gather along a road scattered with stones following clashes in Maujpur area (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Journalists are being attacked by both sides involved in the Citizenship Amendment Act-related violence in northeast Delhi, with six of them roughed up on Tuesday at the riot sites. Akash Napa, a correspondent for JK24*7 news channel, was shot while reporting from Maujpur in the afternoon and had to be admitted to Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital, where, according to the latest medical report, his condition was serious.

Three NDTV reporters and cameraperson were beaten by the mob. In the assault, Arvind Gunasekar lost three teeth. Saurabh Shukla was hit on his back with lathis when he intervened to save Gunasekar. At a separate location, Mariyam Alvi was hit on her back. NDTV claimed there were no police personnel present in the areas where its journalists were attacked.

Parvina Purkayastha, a reporter for Times Now, tweeted about being cornered by a group armed with sticks and bricks. “I pleaded with them and ran for my life,” she said on Twitter. The mobile phone of another Times Now journalist was snatched and reformatted. Incidents of phones of journalists filming arson and violence being grabbed and broken are becoming common now.

On Monday, TOI reported on how two of its journalists were heckled by rioters in Maujpur-Jafrabad while a photojournalist was even threatened with the removal of his trousers to ascertain his religion.

Both Press Club of India and Indian Women’s Press Corps expressed serious concern at journalists coming under attack in northeast Delhi since Sunday. The statement issued by the journalists’ bodies reads: “Several journalists have been hospitalised. They have been punched and attacked by communal mobs, and police were either absent or did not come to help. Shockingly, the mobs were checking the religious credentials of journalists.”

The statement of the two bodies said, “We have little doubt the attackers actively sought to prevent videography or photography that may lead to them being identified.” Condemning both police and politicians, the statement added, “A lethargic police and politicians instigating communal violence cannot escape blame for the attacks on the media… We expect the authorities, particularly police and the Union home ministry, to be alive to democratic sensibilities and ensure that the media are not brought under physical assault.”

Title: Get approvals by May or face action, CEO tells unrecognised schools
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: Making it clear that unrecognised schools will be dealt with legally, if they did not get approvals, chief education officer (CEO) P Usha, who took charge last week, said the district school education department will be strict in dealing with them.

The CEO said the department has already sent two show-cause notices to unrecognised schools. “We are in the process of sending the third show-cause notices.

The schools have been clearly told that they have to get necessary approvals or else have to face legal action. If they don’t comply, as per the directions of the district collector, we will proceed with action,” she said, adding that schools should submit their proposal documents within this month and should get approvals within May.

To help parents who want to join their wards in schools, the department will come up with the list of recognised schools before the upcoming academic year in June. “We will prepare the final list of recognised schools and publicise it,” she said.

According to data released by the school education department in July 2019, 205 private play schools and 40 private nursery and primary schools in the district were functioning without recognition.

Block education officers have been inspecting the schools and serving them with show-cause notices.

Title: Jafrabad Protest: Jafrabad women move sit-in protest to Seelampur
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nearly 300 women shifted to Seelampur, a kilometre away from Jafrabad metro station (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The stretch below Jafrabad Metro Station, which was occupied by women protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act, was vacated around 7.30pm on Tuesday. As surrounding areas went up in flames and mobs unleashed fury on common people just a few hundred metres away, a call for clearing the place went out.

“Local leaders, clerics and activists appealed to us to move for our own safety. A similar call was made from the mosque before the evening prayer in the neighbourhood,” said one of the protesters. Police, too, asked the people to vacate the site.

The dialogue between the community elders and the women concluded around 7pm with everyone reaching a consensus that it was “in the interest of the movement” to shift to another site. “The movement against CAA/NRC/NPR will continue. But we have to send the message across that this is not a communal issue. Therefore, for larger good, we have decided to move,” said Sania.

Nearly 300 women shifted to Seelampur , a kilometre away from Jafrabad metro station, and joined the sit-in there. By 8.30pm, several men from the neighbourhood joined to ensure nothing went amiss.

One of the volunteers, Amir, told TOI that the issue was to ensure people’s safety as they navigated between the two sites. “There was violence everywhere. Teargas shells were being fired. Some volunteers were seriously injured. To ensure women reach the other site safely was a challenge,” he said.

Amidst smoke-filled air, stones and glass shards littered on the road, the volunteers, forming human chains around the women, managed to cover the distance between the two sites.

“The area leading to Maujpur has to be monitored constantly to ensure no anti-social elements attack women. This night will be very long,” said Sania, assuring that the spirit of the movement will prevail.

At Shaheen Bagh, which became the inspiration behind the Jafrabad protest site, things were calm. The protesters in the neighbourhood said they heard that the women at Jafrabad were asked to “leave” and condemned the violence. “Our protests have been peaceful and so has theirs,” one of the women told TOI.

Title: Rs 16 lakh looted from ceramic trader in broad daylight
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Bike-borne robbers looted Rs15.8 lakh from a ceramic trader in broad daylight by throwing chilli powder in his eyes at Vavdi road on Tuesday. The robbers first hit Hitesh Saradva from the backside when he alighted from his SUV near his office car and then threw chilli powder in his eyes before snatched the bag containing cash from his hand. This is the second robbery in Morbi town in last one week.

In his complaint Saradva said he had come to his office with the bag containing the money as he had to make payment to his staff. Cops have checked recordings of nearby CCTV cameras which showed the two robbers came on a bike, one wearing a helmet, another in mask. Cops have blocked all exit routes from Morbi and also alerted police of neighbouring districts.

Title: HC directive on establishing homes for destitute women
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: The state government has been directed to look into the issue of establishing homes for destitute women and victims of heinous crimes above 18 years.

Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana of the Madras high court passed the order while allowing the pregnancy termination of a 17-year-old girl who was sexually assaulted in Tuticorin district.

Observing that there is no rehabilitation home for women above the age of 18 years in the state, the judge directed the secretary of the social welfare department to formulate policies in consultation with the other secretaries concerned, to address this issue within a period of eight weeks.

Since the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, which seeks to extend the termination of pregnancy period from 20 to 24 weeks is pending before the Parliament for approval, the judge reiterated that there should be a permanent committee constituted for setting up a protocol procedure or permanent mechanism for expediting the termination of pregnancy involving rape victims and abnormal foetus. The judge also directed the principal secretary of the health and family welfare department to look in this issue and take appropriate action.

“Even though the victim is a minor under the care and protection of her mother, this kind of unfortunate event happened. Therefore, there is no guarantee that even after this medical termination of pregnancy is performed, she will get relieved of such kind of risk in the future,” observed the judge.

Hence, the judge observed that the minor girl is admitted in a home and the mother and the family are suffering in penury and hence, post-natal care is to be extended to this girl. The judge directed the Tuticorin principal district judge to follow up the matter right till the complete recovery of the girl. The judge further directed the principal district judge to submit a report to this court once in two weeks in this regard and adjourned the case to the first week of March.

The judge allowed the pregnancy termination of the girl after taking note of the report submitted by the team of medical experts. The judge also directed to preserve the DNA of the foetus for criminal trial and further directed the police to expedite the process of criminal trial at the earliest as the victim’s mother who moved court is awaiting compensation.

Title: 14-year-old blind Godhra girl’s mellifluous voice stuns Motera
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Happy Desai

Vadodara: She may not have seen Prime Minister Narendra Modi or US President Donald Trump or even the mammoth gathering for the ‘Namaste Trump’ event at Motera Stadium in Ahmedabad, but what she experienced at the event will be memories for life for this 14-year-old blind girl from Godhra.

Happy Desai sang the famous song ‘Teri laadki main’ with celebrated folk music icon Kirtidan Gadhavi on the stage at the Namaste Trump event ahead of the arrival of Modi and Trump at the stadium. Happy was roped in for the performance only on Saturday.

Happy, who is blind from birth, had started learning music as a five-year-old. She sang at a major event for the first time earlier this year at the Panchmahotsav in Pavagadh here she performed with Parthiv Gohil where she had rendered ‘Teri laadki main’.

Happy’s father Vinod Kumar said that he got a call in the early hours on Saturday asking him if his daughter would perform at Motera Stadium. “I agreed and at around 8.30am, I was asked to reach Ahmedabad by 3pm on Saturday itself,” said Vinod who is a teacher at a government primary school. He added that a rehearsal took place on the same day in the night.

The girl said that she did feel nervous while performing at the event. “I could feel the crowd. I had never expected to sing at such an event. It seemed as if I was having a dream,” said Happy.

Seeing her interest in music, her father is planning to support her and encourage her. “I wish she does a PhD in vocal music,” he said.

Title: Chhota Udepur DPEO faces music for lethargy
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Dr Vinod Rao (centre) made a surprise visit on Monday

Vadodara: The district primary education officer (DPEO) of Chhota Udepur has come under fire after a surprise visit by primary and secondary education secretary Dr Vinod Rao on Monday.

During Rao’s visit it came to light that DPEO B D Bariya was reportedly absent without taking prior permission of senior officers and also ignorant of Rao’s instructions. Rao had also visited schools and went through books during which he reportedly learned that as a class I supervising and monitoring officer, Bariya was completely negligent.

Due to Bariya’s lethargic work, the education department served him a show-cause notice on Monday evening asking him to respond within three days about why action should not be initiated against him.

The show-cause notice also mentioned that the education department has taken several initiatives in the past one year to bring changes in quality of primary and secondary education in the state.

However, during Rao’s visit, it came to light that Bariya was unaware of any of these initiatives, sources said.

Chhota Udepur district has consistently remained at the bottom in performance during class X and class XII examinations in the past few years.

Title: NAAC team to visit Govt Arts College
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: A team of experts delegated by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) would visit the Coimbatore Government Arts College on Wednesday and Thursday to verify the facilities and infrastructure as part of the fourth NAAC cycle of the college.

Principal K Chitra said the college was accredited with ‘A Grade’ by the NAAC in the past two cycles. She said they had uploaded all details about the college in their ‘self-study report’. “The team would visit the campus to verify the details we have uploaded,” she said.

The team would comprise three members and an observer, she said. The team would inspect the college’s facilities, departments, labs, and would interact with students and alumni, she said. After the visit, the team would evaluate and prepare a report on the college’s performance and after discussions with the officials of the University Grants Commission (UGC) the grade of the college would be decided, she said. tnn

Title: Uttrakhand: Upset at state govt taking over Char Dham shrines, priests warn pilgrims of ‘2013-like floods’
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

DEHRADUN/NAINITAL: Angry at the Char Dham Devsthanam Management Act that the state assembly recently passed and which gives control of around 50 temples including the four Char Dham shrines to the Uttarakhand government , priests of Kedarnath, Badrinath, Gangotri and Yamunotri have warned pilgrims not to visit the holy sites as they “might witness something worse than the 2013 tragedy”. Seven years ago, massive floods had ravaged the hill state.

The priests' warning came during the annual practice of Char Dham priests travelling across the country to visit devotees when portals of the temples are closed during winter.

The priests have alleged that the state government is playing with people’s faith. On Tuesday, Shiv Prakash, chief priest (rawal) of the Gangotri temple in Uttarkashi, told TOI, “By taking over the temples through this law, the state government is playing with religion and people’s faith. If they don’t quash the law, something worse than the 2013 floods will happen.” He has already visited Gujarat, Rajasthan, and Delhi to persuade people to not visit Char Dham shrines this year in protest against the shrine board law. He will be travelling to Assam next.

Rajesh Semwal, another priest from the Gangotri shrine, told TOI that if the state government doesn’t retract the law, the priests will boycott temple rituals this year and pilgrims won’t be able to offer prayers. “If the priests boycott rituals, the yatra of pilgrims will remain incomplete,” he said, adding that the government’s move doesn’t send a positive message to pilgrims.

This came even as senior BJP leader and Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy moved the Uttarakhand high court on Tuesday against the newly passed Act. Following this, the HC has given the state government three weeks’ time to respond to Swamy’s PIL.

“The division bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma heard arguments from both sides and directed the government to file their responses within three weeks,” Swamy said. He also demanded that the court put a stay on the Act.

Lawyers appearing for the government, including advocate general SN Babulkar and chief standing counsel Paresh Tripathi, have defended the Act and said it has been passed following the country’s Constitution and that the petition is based on a "political stunt" and therefore should be quashed.

The Char Dham Yatra this year will start from the last week of April with the portals of Gangotri and Yamunotri opening on April 26, followed by those of Kedarnath and Badrinath subsequently.

Title: ‘Renewed’ status for only 9 out of 65 leased Cantonment properties
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

PUNE: The Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) continues to grapple with the renewal of long-term lease of properties under its jurisdiction two months after the lapse of the December 2019 deadline set by the ministry of defence (MoD).

As of now, barely nine of the total 65 leased properties in the PCB limits, for which renewal proposals were under process, have got their renewals.

“Of the remaining 56, five lease holders neither applied for lease renewal nor did they respond to our correspondence. We have since recommended to the Principal Director of Defence Estates (PDDE) for termination of their lease,” said Amit Kumar , the PCB’s chief executive officer.

The proposals of 51 properties are pending at various stages. Kumar said, “Almost 90% of the leased properties are residential in nature. The rest are either commercial or residential-cum-commercial units.”

The lease holder normally applies to the PCB for (lease) renewal at the end of the earlier (lease) term. The PCB does an on-site verification of the property, including instances of any violation of the lease terms and conditions, and prepares a report with its recommendation.

The report is then sent to the office of the PDDE, which has certain powers to act on the PCB’s recommendations. In cases where the matter is beyond its power, it is referred to the Director General of Defence Estate and the MoD in Delhi. Action is taken as per the MoD’s final word.

Kumar said, “The lease renewal is a time-consuming process and this should explain why we have got nine renewal proposals sanctioned so far. We will wait for the MoD’s further directives on the issue. In cases where there is clear recommendation from the higher authorities and as per the procedure, we will send legal notices to the lease holders seeking their explanation for not having a valid lease agreement.”

He said, “If someone misuses a leased property, like using a residential unit for commercial purpose, the board is authorized to take legal action against such person under the Cantonment Act, 2006.”

A property owner said requesting anonymity, “Despite submitting relevant documents, the authorities take months to complete the procedure. We had to wait for two years to get the renewal for the property.”

A senior Director General Defence Estates (DGDE) official in New Delhi told TOI over the phone that over 40 cantonments across the country have not finished their lease renewal process within the deadline. “Considering the situation, the MoD may extend the deadline once again,” he said.

Another senior DGDE official said, “The MoD has delegated administrative power to the PDDE and, hence, many of the cases have been processed and renewed across the cantonments.”

Title: Market yard threatens to suspend licences of traders
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Traders clashed with police on the first day of the protest in Rajkot

RAJKOT: The ongoing traders’ strike of Rajkot market yard entered the 9th day on Tuesday without any solution emerging to end the stalemate between the traders and the police.

Meanwhile, after the directors failed to solve the impasse, a board meeting of the market yard was called on Tuesday where the traders, commission agents and the directors met to resolve the ongoing issue. The meet decided to suspend licenses of traders and commission agents if the strike isn’t called off within three days.

The BJP-ruled market yard board has come under the pressure from both farmers ’ body as well as the state government to end the strike at the earliest.

The traders and commission agents of the market yard went on strike over the issue of mosquito menace, demanding a permanent solution to the age-old problem. The mosquito breeding is rampant in the backside of the market as the city’s sewage gets accumulated in the Aji riverbed.

On Tuesday, the farmers too protested at the market yard demanding resumption of auction. When contacted, the president of commission agents, Atul Kamani said, “We are also exploring options to challenge the order in the high court if the authorities suspend our licenses.”

Protesting traders last week clashed with the police who detained the traders and also booked 32 other people along with traders, a few farmers, and labourers on charges of rioting. Looking at the grievousness of the matter, the chief minister’s office has issued order to immediately solve the problem.

According to rough estimate the daily turn over of the yard is Rs 7-8 crore. Rajkot market yard is Saurashtra ’s biggest market yard. The traders are demanding chief minister’s intervention to solve this stalemate.

Talking to TOI, chairman of Rajkot market yard, D K Sakhia said, “We cannot allow them to take the market yard into their hands. The farmers are facing massive trouble for the past nine days. We have decided to suspend licenses if the strike isn’t called off within three days.”

Title: Dairy raided, 50 litre spurious milk destroyed
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: The food safety department on Tuesday carried out search at a dairy in Sanwer on suspicion of adulteration and destroyed 50 litre milk . The department team sent samples for laboratory test.

Senior food safety officer Manish Swami said that they carried out a search at Maa Bageshwari Dairy in Hatunia village after receiving a complaint against owner Vijay Jaat that he was using soya oil, milk powder and water to prepare milk. “The team found some packets of soyabean oil and milk powder. Sample of milk was collected and sent for lab test,” Swami said.

He said that the officials also destroyed around 50 litre milk on the spot. “Based on report of the lab test, action will be taken against the shopkeeper,” he said.

Title: Topper among 25 new CSs eyes corporate sector
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

(Clockwise from top) Students who cleared CS; Divykumar Surti; Gunjan Bhagtani

Vadodara: The Institute of Company Secretaries of India (ICSI) declared the results of CS exams on Tuesday with 25 students from the city successfully completing the professional programme. ICSI declared results of CS executive and professional programs, examination of which were held in December last year.

Gunjan Bhagtani, a fourth-year student of BA LLB at M S University’s Faculty of Law, topped the list of successful candidates from the city. Gunjan, whose father Parshottam Bhagtani is a UK-based businessman, plans to take up a career in corporate sector.

“After completing Class XII in commerce, my parents wanted me to pursue chartered accountancy but I found accounts difficult. So, I started pursuing CS professional programme (new syllabus),” said Gunjan, who had bagged All India Rank (AIR) 22 at the foundation-level and city rank second in executive level of CS course.

“I just wanted to clear the professional programme. Getting a city rank was a pleasant surprise,” she said.

Divykumar Surti, whose father Sanjay is a tailor and mother a homemaker, bagged the second rank in the city. Divykumar, who has completed his BCom from MSU’s Faculty of Commerce, too, wants to join the corporate sector. He had earlier bagged AIR 24 at the foundation level. His sister Vruti is also pursuing the CS course.

Interestingly, though Divykumar hails from reserved category, he has not availed any of quota benefit while pursuing his graduation studies. Soniya Thakkar, who bagged city rank three, had bagged AIR 20 in foundation level and city rank first in executive level. “I too would be joining the corporate sector,” Soniya, a third year student at MSU’s Faculty of Commerce and daughter of businessman Dhanraj Thakkar said.

Title: Hyd police on alert, appeal for peace
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Keeping in view the violence in Delhi, city police force are on high alert . Patrolling has been intensified in various parts of the city. “Appeal to all citizens of Hyderabad. We have to remain united to see that no mischief maker tries to take advantage of the disturbing news from Delhi....Take pride in our beautiful city ,” Hyderabad commissioner Anjani Kumar tweeted. TNN

Title: It will be a peaceful sit-in, assure brains behind Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: In the backdrop of violence and arson over CAA protests in New Delhi, top police officials of the city met with representatives of Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh at Aathupalam Junction and asked them to conduct the sit-in without causing inconvenience to traffic and the public and cooperate with police for safety and security reasons.

Representatives assured police officials that such incidents would not happen in the city. K Raja Hussain, district president of Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) and the organiser of the federation of all Jamaaths and Muslim organisations, said people of all faiths are living in harmony in the city. “People from other faiths are also taking part in the protest,” he said.

The sit-in against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), the National Registry of Citizens (NRC) and the National People’s register (NPR) entered seventh day on Tuesday.

Protesters said they were careful to conduct the protest peacefully and not allow even a small untoward incident to take place till CAA is repealed. Meanwhile, central committee member of CPM U Vasuki addressed the protesters.

Many of the protesters were working and businesspeople. They have given up their pay and have been taking part in what many of them term the ‘second struggle for Indian Independence’.

Ibrahim, an organiser at the protest site, said he had two readymade garment retail outlets in the city and had not visited them in seven days. “I went to the shops for half an hour to see accounts. I would head back to the protest site soon.”

Considering security reasons, women protesters are sent home at night and they come back to the protest site after they finish their household chores and sending their children to schools and colleges in the morning. Shameema Habeeb, a protester, said women were ready to sit in protest in night. “But considering security, we come home. We are strong in our idea that we would not allow even a small untoward incident to happen,” she said.

There were also views among protesters that the sit-in was getting monotonous and they were looking to engage in other forms of civil protests. Mujibur Rahman, an organiser, said they would not let go the Shaheen Bagh protest, but simultaneously look for other means of protests too.

Title: CM to lay foundation stone for govt med college in Virudhunagar
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

edited
