Madurai: Minister for milk and dairy development K T Rajendra Bhalaji said that chief minister Eddapadi K Palaniswami would be given a grand welcome in Virudhunagar where he is scheduled to lay the foundation stone for a government medical college on March 1. He was speaking at the preparatory meet held in the district for the chief minister’s proposed visit to the district. The medical college is the first in the district and is being built at a cost of Rs380 crore. After laying of the foundation stone, welfare benefits will be distributed to over 25000 beneficiaries at a grand function on the same day. The minister said that all basic amenities should be provided to the public who come for the function. Police and the fire service were asked to ensure safety of people at the meeting venue.

Title: Business hit: Delhi shops vandalised, workers pack their bags
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Many workers have left the area as the riots have left behind a trail of destruction in northeast Delhi

NEW DELHI: With northeast Delhi in the grip of violence for close to three days, local residents are a worried lot.

The area is a hub of migrant labourers who have come to the capital to earn a livelihood from Bihar and various parts of Uttar Pradesh and mostly work in local factories.

Around Seelampur, eight of them were waiting on a footpath for stone-pelting to stop. Most of them were even scared to talk, but one of them said, “We work here as artisans. But since Monday night, the roads are on fire. I do not want to die as I am not part of any protest. We have come here to work and earn money. I am now going back to Muzaffarngar.” Another interrupted him, saying his family had called and asked him to return to Moradabad.

In Bhajanpura, the situation is not much different. Raj Kumar, the owner of a liquor shop, said, “People broke my store open and took beer and wine bottles in the wee hours. Over 100 cartons of alcohol worth around Rs 80 lakh are missing. I have informed police.”

A footwear shop was vandalised in Ghonda and the shoes and other items were distributed among rioters. But as the owner rushed in to save whatever was left, the rioters realised that they had mistakenly attacked the shop of a “known” person and asked people to return the looted items.

With the situation remaining tense, many families are moving out of Karawal Nagar for now. A family of four has decided to return to Patna. “I am not going to put myself or my family in harm’s way. I have applied for leave from my office and I’d rather submit my resignation if the situation does not get better,” said one of them.

The man pointed out that hundreds of others were also living in fear. Recalling Monday night, he said they had never experienced anything as scary when they felt they could be attacked any time. “We do not want to live in constant fear. It’s better to be away till the situation normalises.”

Anand, who stays on 66 Foota Road where violence has been going on, was looking for a way to reach a metro station along with two women and three children. With bags on his shoulder, Anand said he was trying to reach a relative’s home in Faridabad.

Title: Tension in Arilova area over use of loudspeaker during rally
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Tension flared between two groups during a religious procession at Visalakshi Nagar under Arilova police station limits in the city on Tuesday. The tiff reportedly started over the use of loudspeakers by the organisers of the procession near a college in the area, but nearly spiralled into a violent fight before the timely intervention of police brought things under control.

A community elder said a group of youngsters came on bikes and shouted at them to stop the procession and disperse from the locality. “It was a peaceful rally which is held regularly. The group also attacked our woman members,” he alleged.

Dismissing the claims, the other group said they only asked to reduce the volume of the loudspeaker during the rally as it was passing close to a college and classes were on. “When they ignored our plea, we asked them to produce the permission letter from the police for using the loudspeaker. We neither chased nor attacked them, we only asked them to not use loudspeakers,” a member of the other group said.

MVP Colony police station inspector Ch Shanmukha Rao said loudspeakers were being used in the rally without obtaining police permission. “When some youngsters asked the organisers not to use loudspeakers near a college, there was some argument between the two groups. We prevented a possible clash by reaching the spot and pacified both the groups. We also told them to obtain prior permission before holding any rally in future,” Rao said, adding that they didn’t register any case as there were no clashes or attacks as is being claimed by one group.

Title: Woman seeks SP’s help to release hubby jailed in AP
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Coimbatore: A 29-year-old woman from Ondipudur on Tuesday submitted a petition with the superintendent of police office claiming that her husband was charged with a false case and arrested by Andhra Pradesh police about a week ago. She sought the SP’s intervention in releasing her husband from prison.

In her complaint, Vaneeshwari said the Rajahmundry police charged her husband Ravichandran, who is in transport business, with stealing bags of rice that had to be delivered to a customer in Kollam. An FIR was registered against him under sections 407 (criminal breach of trust) and 420 (cheating) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and was arrested.

Vaneeshwari said her husband had leased a lorry on November 1 and was transporting goods within the state. “On February 4, the Rajahmundry police called him and questioned him about whereabouts of sacks of rice that went missing within their limit on January 29,” she said, adding, “We did not have a clue. The last trip the lorry had was on January 27. We parked the lorry in front of our house at Ondipudur for the next couple of days and then it was left in a private parking lot.”

The Rajahmundry police visited us on February 11 and told my husband to accompany them to Andhra Pradesh for inquiry purpose and drove away the lorry too, she said. “We submitted toll gate tickets and parking lot tickets to prove that the lorry was in Coimbatore. However, they arrested my husband and lodged him in prison,” she said.

She alleged that police were thrashing her husband to make him admit to the crime that he did not commit. Instead of arresting the culprits who stole the rice using a vehicle with fake registration plate, the police had arrested my husband, she said.

Receiving the petition, police officials assured to look into it.

Title: Work on ramp at Alwarpuram to be over by March
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: Construction of a permanent structure at Alwarpuram to enable the grand entry of Lord Kallalagar into the river Vaigai during the Chithirai festival, which was taken up recently will be completed in a month’s time, officials from the Madurai Corporation have said.

In the absence of a permanent structure, the corporation used to construct a temporary ramp. The civic body used to shell out more than Rs 40 lakh for construction the ramp alone, officials said.

An official from the engineering wing said the permanent concrete structure taken up under the Smart City scheme is taking shape rapidly. It is a part of the Vaigai River Front development work and construction is expected to be completed by the end of March. The Chithirai festival takes place in April or May, he said.“Unlike the temporary ramp, the proposed structure will have bigger hollow beneath, which will allow water to pass freely. In the past, a boy, who was washed away got stuck in a smaller pipe. The new structure will be safer,” he said.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan visited the construction area and instructed the contractor to finish the work at the earliest.

Title: 72-yr-old admitted in isolation ward in Kanyakumari
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Cleared/175 Words

Madurai: A 72-year-old man from Kayalpattinam in Tuticorin district was admitted in the isolation ward of the government medical college and hospital at Asaripallam near Nagercoil in Kanyakumari district after he complained of severe stomach pain. Though the man did not have any symptoms of COVID-19 he was admitted in the isolation ward as he had recently returned from Hong Kong.

It is learnt that the man working in Hong Kong came to his native a few days ago and had gone to Kanyakumari district to visit a relative on Monday. The same day he headed to the Thiruvananthapuram airport to board a flight to Hong Kong, when he complained of acute stomach pain. He was rushed to a private hospital and referred to the government hospital in Asaripallam considering his recent travel history.

He was admitted to the isolation ward for COVID-19 suspects and samples were collected from him for testing. While results are expected in a day or two the doctors learnt that his stomach pain could have been due to his suspected addiction to alcohol.

Title: Gujarat: Businessman held for Rs 15 crore input tax credit scam
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The goods and services tax (GST) department on Tuesday arrested a businessman for fraudulently availing input tax credit and duping the government of Rs 15 crore.

Manoj Agrawal, who is into scrap business, was nabbed after CGST, Vadodara II commissionerate investigated his firm’s transactions over last few months.

GST officials said that Agrawal had been issuing fake invoices without the actual movement of goods to generate fraudulent input tax credit. “Investigations revealed that the accused had created eight firms located in Vadodara, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Bangalore. They were receiving fake invoices from other firms and, in turn, were passing on the input tax credit using their firms,” GST officials said.

“The investigation further revealed that the fake firms utilized the input tax credit in tax payment of goods purchased from registered/unregistered tax payers. Further, to validate the receipt and supply, they had generated e-way bills using seven trucks which were stationed at a single place and had not moved,” GST officials added.

Investigation has so far revealed that the accused issued and received fake invoices to the tune of Rs 100 crore and fraudulently availed input tax credit worth Rs 15 crore.

GST officials said that the accused has been sent to judicial custody. “He (Agarwal) began availing input tax credit fraudulently soon after GST was introduced,” a GST official said.

Title: Delhi Violence: Teenager shot at on way home from school among scores injured
Content:
People participate in a candlelight march at India Gate (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Among the more than 200 victims of stone-pelting and shooting in northeast Delhi is a 13-year-old boy. He was shot in his back. Victims like him include two men who were returning home when they were attacked by a mob. Police also confirmed four acid attack cases.Faizi Hussain, 13, was on his way home from school on Monday when he learnt about riots breaking out in his neighbourhood of Vijay Park near Maujpur. He reached home safely, but the curious youngster ventured out for a look at what was happening. A few minutes later, a bullet fired from somewhere on the main road hit him in his lower back and he collapsed.Doctors have told the family it’s wiser not to remove the bullet lodged in his lower spine — so the boy will have to live with it for the rest of his life. At Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital, where Hussain is undergoing treatment, his family recalled how saving the teenager’s proved difficult. “It would have been almost impossible to get him to hospital if our family hadn’t owned an autorickshaw,” Hussain’s father, Munna, said.“We were pelted with stones on the way. He was bleeding profusely. I feared that I was going to lose him,” Munna said. “The doctors have told us the bullet is lodged deep inside near the spinal cord. They said surgery poses a risk to his life.” The father also worries that his son, who is an enthusiastic sports lover, will now be unable to fulfil his wish of becoming a national sportsperson with a bullet lodged in his body for life.On Tuesday evening, hospitals in east and northeast Delhi were taking in more victims. More than 150 people had been admitted to GTB Hospital, around 20 at Jag Pravesh Hospital, 10 in Max Patparganj and 15 in Lok Nayak Hospital.Shah Alam, 45, is one of them. The tailor was hurrying back home in the Mustafabad area, when he saw a group of rioters marching down the road towards him with lathis, stones and other weapons. From behind him, a couple of stones flew in his direction. A jittery Alam took cover against the wall, but a stone hit him on the right side of his neck, opening up a deep gash. Alam, who has since undergone surgery, disclosed that he might have to remain in the hospital for at least a week to recover.Shahir, 25, found himself in a similar situation barely a few hundred metres from where Alam was targeted. “I was returning home from work when I heard gun shots ring out close to me. I was scared and started looking for cover, but before I could find a safe spot, I was shot twice on my upper thigh,” Shahir said. “I fell unconscious and when I regained my senses, I found myself in the hospital. I am so grateful to God that I am alive. In riots like these, what can people like me do? I had nothing to do with the protest yet am facing the brunt of it.”Among those who have been hospitalised with injuries sustained in the mob attacks is Aakash, a journalist was in Maujpur to report on the riots.

Title: No religion in India produces terrorists, says CM Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CM Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath on Tuesday said none of the communities and religions in India produce terrorists . Those involved in terrorist activities in Kashmir are not Indians, but outsiders, he said.

“Has any regional terrorism been born in India? There is regional terrorism in Holland, in America. We, people of every society and every religion (in India) do not produce terrorists. Those in Kashmir are not Indian terrorists, they are outsiders. We cannot say that terrorists in Kashmir are Indians,” Nath said at the inauguration of a new building of Masajid Committee near Taj-ul-Masajid in Bhopal .

India’s strength is in its multiculturalism and the times call for the elderly to “advise” youngsters, the CM said. “Our country’s culture is brotherhood. For thousands of years, from the times of (Emperor) Chandragupta and Ashoka, what a culture (of peace and unity)! Our civilization is the biggest strength of India. The thought of today’s youth is different. Sometimes, they become excited but it is the responsibility of the elders to provide the right direction and vision to future generations,” said Nath.

The chief minister also praised harmony and unity being propagated by all religions, and said, “Our country, our culture is great because it has the characteristic of being united with a sense of honour and respect for each other. This culture of unity in diversity is intact because people of the old generation were dedicated to protecting it. The biggest challenge before us today is that we should bring the origin, civilization and diversity of our great culture closer to the younger generation and they should imbibe it, so that our country always remains safe and united.”

The CM okayed minority welfare minister Arif Aqueel’s proposal to hike the honorarium of Imams from Rs 2,200 to Rs 5,000 per month and that of their deputies, moijjans, from Rs 1,900 to Rs 4,500 a month. This will benefit 4,534 persons and cost the exchequer Rs 43.52 crore a year, said Aqueel.

Title: Oppn seeks relief for kin of farmers who died in fields
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: The Opposition on Tuesday created ruckus in the House during Question Hour demanding compensation for kin of farmers who died while working in agriculture field.

Minister Shanti Dhariwal, while replying to a question by Madan Dilawar on the number of farmers who died from October 2019 to February 2020 during agriculture work in Kota division and the compensation paid, said the number of farmers died is eight but only five were given compensation of Rs 2 lakh as others died due to non-agriculture reasons like extreme cold.

The minister said the compensation was paid from the Rajiv Gandhi Krushak Sathi Yogana. “As per the provisions of the scheme, only those farmers who had met with some accidents while working in the field were eligible for compensation. Three of the farmers’ families could not be given compensation as one of them died due to biting cold and others have neither conducted post-mortem nor applied for compensation.”

He said if someone dies of cold while working in the field is not accident. The person should have covered well before venturing out to the field. This led to ruckus in the House as the Opposition demanded that compensation be paid to all farmers.

Title: VMRDA begins work on ‘realistic’ budget
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) has begun preparing the budget for the 2020-21 fiscal. VMRDA officials are keen on creating a realistic budget in tandem with the urban development authority’s financial position, instead of inflating proposals.

Even though the VMRDA wanted to limit the budget to around Rs 1,100 crore, it was learnt that budgetary proposals would be around Rs 1,200 to Rs 1,300 crore in tune with its priorities.

A major chunk of the expenditure is expected to go towards preparation of the master plan, NAD Flyover project, master plan roads , development of pooled land and the development of Yarada Hills.

Over the last few months, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy laid foundation stones for nearly Rs 380 crore worth of works of the VMRDA. All these works will feature in this year’s budget with allocations worth Rs 200 crore devoted to the works over two fiscals.

Some of these works include: Kailasagiri Hill-top Park development which has been allocated Rs 56.5 crore, planetarium of Kailasagiri Hill-top Park allocated Rs 37 crore, integrated museum allocated Rs 40 crore, multi-level car parking allocated Rs 80 crore, commercial complex at Ram Nagar allocated Rs 13.5 crore, master plan road at APSEZ entrance in Pudimadaka allocated Rs 27.13 crore.

According to a source in VMRDA, final touches are being made right now. “The budget is likely to be ready in the next two weeks,” the source said.

In 2019-20, the VMRDA had pegged its budget at Rs 1,286.5 crore. The budget had earmarked Rs 100 crore for the development of an ‘information technology city’ in Madhurawada. However, the project did not make any headway over the last one year.

Now, VMRDA officials are mulling over how to work on the project by getting rental assurance from IT giants as it involves nearly 20 acres prime land and investment of nearly Rs 100 crore.

Meanwhile, the VMRDA might also drop some projects proposed in the earlier budget like the construction of a cycling and jogging tract from Kailasagiri to Bheemili (allocated Rs 2 crore), Masala Bazaar and Vuda Park (allocated Rs 5 crore). VMRDA is expected to allocate some money to civil and greenery works in Vizianagaram district.

Title: SMC’s three urban health centres get NQAS certificates
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Surat: Three urban health centres (UHCs) of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) have received National Quality Assurance Standards (NQAS) certificates for their public health services.

The quality certification programme for the public health facilities has been launched with the aim of recognizing the good performing facilities as well as improving the credibility of public hospitals in the community.

The SMC’s urban health centres at Adajan, New Dindoli and Umara have been given NQAS certificates.

The certification is provided for being able to meet the standards set by the NQAS.

The quality urban health focuses on assessment, improvement and certification of urban health facilities and urban outreach under National Quality Framework.

“The NQAS are currently available for district hospitals, CHCs, PHCs and urban PHCs. Standards are primarily meant for providers to assess their own quality for improvement through predefined standards and to bring up their facilities for the certification. The National Quality Assurance Standards include service provision, patient’s rights, inputs, support services, clinical care, infection control, quality management and outcome,’’ said an SMC official.

“During the next round of inspection of the NQAS, the SMC’s Lakhpati and Palanpore health Centres will be covered under this programme. We aim to cover all our urban health centres to get accredited with this certifications,’’ added the official.

Title: CRPF officer moved in to control Delhi riots
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

SN Shrivastava was the anti-terror chief in Delhi Police till 2015 (File photo)

NEW DELHI: In a surprise move, the ministry of home affairs on Tuesday evening posted 1985-batch IPS officer SN Shrivastava as the chief of law & order in Delhi. He was serving as special director general in Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF).

Shrivastava was repatriated to his parent AGMUT-cadre around noon after which lieutenant governor Anil Baijal posted him as special commissioner (law & order) with clear directives to restore order and security in the capital. Shrivastava is also the senior-most person in line for Delhi Police commissioner.

Known for his integrity and no-nonsense attitude, Shrivastava was the anti-terror chief in Delhi Police till 2015. He was also handling terror operations in Kashmir during his stint in CRPF. Officers who worked with him said he was a hard taskmaster with an eye for detail. He had headed several departments in Delhi Police before being sent on deputation to CRPF.

Sources said Shrivastava assumed charge immediately and took stock of the situation in the capital. He was also reportedly part of a two-hour meeting held by Union home minister Amit Shah late in the evening. In another meeting held around midnight, Shrivastava and other Delhi Police officers chalked out a strategy to bring down violence in the riot-hit areas.

During Shrivastava’s tenure in Delhi Police, Special Cell had wiped out the Indian Mujahideen and Lashkar-e-Taiba network from the capital. Brought in the aftermath of the Delhi high court blasts in 2011, he played a crucial role in strengthening Special Cell. While preventing terror attacks for over three years, the cell went on to arrest 37 terrorists, including 22 from IM and 7 from LeT.

“IM’s deputy chief Tehsin Akhtar, Pak bomb-maker Waqas, Abdul Qarim Tunda and IM’s shadow techie Ajaj Shaikh landed behind bars due to his team’s efforts. His team also solved the 2012 Pune serial blasts and the Jama Masjid blast,” said a senior officer.

The post of law & order chief was last held by well-known IPS officer Deepak Mishra. After Mishra, the post was divided into two parts with an objective to achieve better security and order in the capital. However, the move backfired with law and order hitting rock bottom in the last four years during which Delhi Police had two commissioners, Alok Verma and Amulya Patnaik.

Title: Jobless man booked for attacking constable in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A jobless man was booked on Monday for attacking a 31-year-old constable outside Kasewadi police chowkey on Sunday night following a dispute over registering the complaint of a handcart operator accusing him of vandalising vehicles at Kasewadi slums.

The constable, Amol Uttam Patekar from the Khadak police, lodged an FIR under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code after he was discharged from the Sassoon General Hospital.

Police said the handcart operator, Imran Shaikh from Kasewadi slums, called the city police control room stating that the suspect had barged into his house, attacked him and vandalised vehicles. After the control room relayed the message to the Kasewadi police chowkey, a police team reached the spot. The police personnel brought Shaikh and the suspect to the chowkey and started questioning them before lodging Shaikh’s FIR.

The suspect picked up a dispute with constable Patekar for questioning him in the presence of his 10-15 supporters. He then abused Patekar and instructed a woman to tear her clothes for teaching the policeman a lesson, police said.

A police officer said, “Patekar called a superior officer and gave the information of the incident, following which he was instructed to escort Shaikh and the suspect to the police station.”

The officer said, “The suspect sat on a policeman’s bike after he was requested to go to the police station, but he later alighted fearing that a case would be registered against him and again abused Patekar. In a fit of anger, he pushed the constable down.”

The other policeman tried to overpower the suspect, but he created ruckus and fled. A police team has been fanned for arresting him, the officer added.

Title: Justin Beiber breaks Elvis Presley's six-decade-old record
Content: Pop sensation Justin Beiber has now become the youngest musician of all time to score seven Number 1 albums on the Billboard Hot 200 list.According to a report, Beiber broke the long-standing record of the pop legend Elvis Presley by earning this honour at a young age of 25, thanks to his latest album 'Changes'.This is one year less than Presley who achieved this feat with his 1961 album 'Blue Hawaii' at the age of 26.Beiber recently took to Twitter in order to express his gratefulness for this milestone. Beiber dropped the album 'Changes' this Valentine's Day, which is his first since the year 2015.Nearly 231,000 copies of the album have been sold as of now. This comes as his fifth studio album to hit the number one spot, apart from two remix albums.

Title: Pune civic body to set up isolation wards in 12 private hospitals amid coronavirus fears
Content:
Travellers from Nepal, Vietnam, Indonesia and Malaysia will now also be screened to avoid spread of novel coro... Read More

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) will set up isolation wards at 12 private hospitals in a week as a precautionary measure against novel coronavirus COVID-19 ).Civic officials said the isolation wards will be set up on the lines of the PMC-run Naidu hospital. “A total of 36 travellers were screened for the novel coronavirus infection and all tested negative. However, we have decided to scale up the monitoring, for which private hospitals have been roped in for setting up isolation wards,” Sanjeev Wavare, head of the insect control department, PMC, said.He said the new isolation wards in private hospitals will be ready in a week. “These hospitals have given in-principal approval to start the facility. Such additional measures were also taken during the spread of H1N1 virus in the city a few years ago and showed good results,” Wavare said.The civic body also plans to join hands with doctors’ associations to create awareness about the contagion, for which training programmes will be held for medical practitioners.According to Wavare, 35 ventilators, 40 isolation wards and 25 ICUs will be available once the isolation wards in private hospitals are ready.“There is no need to panic. The training will emphasis educating the doctors, who will further guide the patients in their hospitals,” Rajendra Jagtap of the Society of Emergency Medical Services said.Travellers from Nepal, Vietnam, Indonesia and Malaysia will now also be screened to avoid spread of novel coronavirus. The screening is already being held for travellers arriving from China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Singapore.

Title: Corpn saves Rs 60L a month in water supply
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: The measures taken by the Madurai Corporation to prevent misuse and pilferage of water meant for distribution to residents through vehicles has helped the civic body save around Rs 60 lakh a month. The money can be used for various other public amenities by fund started Madurai corporation.

Last year, the corporation installed global positioning System (GPS) and pressure sensors in all the 34 trucks and 33 tractors used for water supply. GPS tracking helps locate vehicles real time and to ensure they are reaching the assigned locations. Whereas, pressure sensors help officials to check remaining water in each vehicle and to make sure that vehicles reach filling station only after entire water gets emptied. Earlier, trucks make a beeline at the filling station without supplying entire water to show that they have made more trips in a shorter time, thus burning a hole in the corporation’s coffers. GPS has also brought in greater transparency and accountability in water supply as a vehicle cannot be diverted as per whims and fancies of certain influential people. Corporation commissioner S Visakan said, “Earlier corporation spending used to be around Rs 1.5 crore. It has come down to Rs 90 lakh. Apart from curbing water diversion and theft, accountability has also been brought in. Even if a load of water is required for commissioner’s bungalow, I have to make a request to the assistant engineer concerned, who will approve through the system.”

Title: 5 bars raided for selling liquor bottles
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Officials of the prohibition and excise department raided five bars in Visakhapatnam on Tuesday for allegedly selling liquor bottles which are supposed to be sold only from government-run liquor stores. The bars were allegedly selling the liquor bottles at a higher price that in government outlets.

Speaking to TOI, T Srinivasa Rao, deputy commissioner of police Vizag, said that teams of the prohibition and excise department raided bars in Gajuwaka and other places in the city after receiving concrete information. The officials have sealed the five bars and issued notices to the managements.

An official of the excise department said that the bars were selling liquor at around Rs 70-Rs 100 more than the price in government-run outlets. While government-run liquor stores close at 8pm, these bars were running till 11pm.

Title: Second leopard cage installed in Phursungi
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The forest department installed a second cage at Phursungi village in Pune after a female leopard and her cubs were sighted there.

MJ Sanas, range forest officer (RFO), Punecisaid, “We installed a cage near DSK Dream City a week ago, where a leopard sighting was reported. We cannot confirm the number of cubs but the pugmarks found here are different from the one found at the earlier spot, so this is a different leopard, which is now on the move.”

RB Raskar, round officer, Loni Kalbhor, said a shepherd spotted a leopard with her cubs near Sonar bridge on Monday. “No leopard has been sighted near DSK Dream City for 5 to 6 days so we shifted the cage to Koyatevasti. Another cage has been installed near Sonar bridge,” he said.

Title: CM Kamal Nath should decentralise power to get good results in Madhya Pradesh: Laxman Singh
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CM Kamal Nath

INDORE: Congress MLA from Chachoda assembly seat Laxman Singh on Tuesday said that chief minister Kamal Nath should decentralise power to get good results in government as well as in the organisation.

“When Digvijaya Singhji was chief minister, he had taken a big decision of decentralisation of power to empower civic bodies, gram panchayats…..and it had yielded good results,” Laxman told mediapersons.

Urging Nath for decentralisation of power, Laxman, who is brother of Digvijaya said, “Kamal Nathji is a good administrator and has years of political experience. He has served in as minister in UPA rule at the Centre and knows how to run a government. He asks MLAs and party workers for problems and tells them that he is capable of resolving them…. But somewhere, you need to decentralize the power.”

Nath is probably waiting for panchayat and civic body elections to get over before taking a step in this regard, he added.

When asked about appointment of MPCC chief Laxman said, “There are many capable party leaders, including women, who can be assigned the post of MPCC chief. But he/she should visit across the state , stay at nights in villages and take required steps to strengthen the party’s base.”

Responding to a query on much-hyped meeting of senior Congress leaders Jyotiraditya Scindia and Digvijaya Singh ending in few minutes, Laxman said, “Both the leaders happened to meet. It was a courtesy meeting but media made it as much-hyped one.”

Speaking about Burhanpur MLA Surendra Singh Shera accusing Congress of showing apathy towards the party workers, Laxman said, “Shera is an independent MLA and has given support to the state government. If he is concerned about Congress workers, he should first join the party”.

Title: SMC’s three urban health centres get NQAS certificates
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Adajan, New Dindoli and Umra health centres get certifications

Surat: Three urban health centres (UHCs) of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) have received National Quality Assurance Standards (NQAS) certificates for their public health services.

The quality certification programme for the public health facilities has been launched with the aim of recognizing the good performing facilities as well as improving the credibility of public hospitals in the community.

The SMC’s urban health centres at Adajan, New Dindoli and Umara have been given NQAS certificates.

The certification is provided for being able to meet the standards set by the NQAS.

The quality urban health focuses on assessment, improvement and certification of urban health facilities and urban outreach under National Quality Framework.

“The NQAS are currently available for district hospitals, CHCs, PHCs and urban PHCs. Standards are primarily meant for providers to assess their own quality for improvement through predefined standards and to bring up their facilities for the certification. The National Quality Assurance Standards include service provision, patient’s rights, inputs, support services, clinical care, infection control, quality management and outcome,’’ said an SMC official.

“During the next round of inspection of the NQAS, the SMC’s Lakhpati and Palanpore health Centres will be covered under this programme. We aim to cover all our urban health centres to get accredited with this certifications,’’ added the official.

Title: ‘17,453 govt employees benefitted under NFSA’
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: Food and civil supplies minister Ramesh Chand Meena on Tuesday said 17,453 government employees availed benefits under the National Food Security Scheme (NFSS) and recovery action was being initiated against them under Rajasthan Public Demands Recovery Act 1952.

The minister was replying to supplementary questions by legislators during the Question Hour. He said ineligible persons availing the NFSS have been served notice and recovery action was being initiated as per the prevailing rate in the market. He said the selected beneficiaries was being reviewed through biometric verification.

The minister said so far action has been taken against 5,963 government employees. Meena informed that 3,68,354 people who were not eligible under the scheme have been removed from the list from December 2018 to December 2019 and during this period 31,53 720 eligible people were also added to the beneficiary list. Earlier, in response to the original question of Rajendra Rathore, the minister said under the scheme, action have been taken against the government employee for obtaining ration at concessional rates. He informed that after investigation of these ineligible beneficiaries, the process of speedy recovery at the market rate as per the rules is under process.

Title: Detailed protocol for representatives of people announced
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: The House on Tuesday witnessed acrimonious scenes when parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal announced that protocol must be followed on inviting people’s representatives at government functions.

The opposition MLAs complained that despite several directions, the protocol was not being followed. Opposition leader Kataria said Jahazpur MLA was heckled and manhandled during a function and demanded detailed inquiry into the violation as well as action against guilty officials.

Rajendra Pareek, who was in the chair, directed the members to give their account of violations to the Speaker who will decide on the issue.

Dhariwal said, “It is mandatory to invite public representatives of the area at foundation laying ceremonies and state government programmes.” The minister said there were only two points in the circular issued on April 5, 2018, while 8-10 points were added in the new circular.

He said it had been ensured that whenever any state programme is held, prior information should be given to the local people's representatives. Along with this, it must also be ensured that information is obtained and arrangements were made for public representatives to sit in the dais.

Dhariwal said information related to the government should be sent through faster communication means so that they are received on time.

It should also be ensured that the receipt of information by the public representative has been confirmed by the officer concerned. The minister said the foundation stones/inaugurations should be done by only public representatives. Officers should not lay foundation stones/inaugurations and should not inscribe their names.

Title: He was always passionate about job: Slain cop’s kin
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Head constable Ratan Lal

NEW DELHI: Outside the Burari home of Ratan Lal , the Delhi Police head constable who got killed on Monday in the violence that has engulfed parts of the capital, locals have put up a poster saluting him.

It features photos of Lal and Indian Air Force pilot Abhinandan Varthaman, who was captured by Pakistan last year, both sporting handlebar moustaches. Locals at Amrit Vihar rued while Abhinandan could return alive from Pakistan, Lal died on duty.

A relative described Lal as a quiet man who was always kind to his family and friends. Originally from Rajasthan’s Sikar, Lal came to Delhi in 1998 when “he got a job here. He had always wanted to join the police force and was passionate about it”, said his cousin, Dalip Bari, who lives in Sarai Rohilla and runs a small socks manufacturing unit.

The 42-year-old has left behind his wife and three children aged 13, 11 and 6 years. “He never even raised his voice against anyone. He liked to stay at home during his off days and watch television,” said Nitin Bari, his brother-in-law who reached Delhi on Monday night after getting the news through TV and social media.

On Tuesday afternoon, several hundred people stood outside the house to pay their last respect. The family said his body would be kept at the Amrit Vihar residence for some time so that “people can pay homage to him”. On Wednesday, it will be taken to his village “where his mother is awaiting him”, said Dalip.

Prakash Nirankari, a local contractor, slammed Delhi government for “supporting” the anti-citizenship Act protests. “I am asking Delhi government how will they pay for this.”

Meanwhile. Union home minister Amit Shah on Tuesday wrote to Lal’s wife, conveying his condolences, and said the country was with the family in the hour of its grief. Senior officers also paid tribute to Lal at the new Police Lines in Kingsway Camp.

Title: Spanish tourists raise alarm over noisy boats at Omkareshwar
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The tourist urged the authorities to introduce battery-operated boats and take pro-active steps in regulating ... Read More

INDORE: Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board has found sound pollution due to boats operating on Narmada water in Omkareshwar .

A two-member team visiting the pilgrimage found that boats were generating 75-80 decibel noise. The team’s visit was prompted after a Spanish tourist on a visit to Omkareshwar filed a complaint with the Central Pollution Control Board about noise and water pollution caused by diesel engine boats in the water body.

The tourist urged the authorities to introduce battery-operated boats and take pro-active steps in regulating noise pollution.

Taking cognizance of the complaint, Central Pollution Control Board, Delhi directed officials in the state board to introduce battery-operated boats at Omkareshwar to eliminate noise and water pollution.

Dr DK Wagela, chief chemist and lab head at regional PCB said, “Acting on a complaint from a Spanish tourist in Omkareshwar, we inspected the ghat and found that boats were generating high noise. We have suggested preventive measures to curb noise and water pollution as battery-driven boats are not workable here looking at high flow of the water.”

Around 350 diesel engine boats operate at Omkareshwar, of which just 169 are registered with the municipal council.

PCB suggested boat operators to use silencers and upgrade outdated models to minimize noise and water pollution.

Title: SPV formed to start work on Trichy trade centre
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) here have launched a special purpose vehicle (SPV) to mobilise fund and launch the construction work for the trade centre. City-based entrepreneurs part of the SPV have approached the National Institute of Technology (NIT) Trichy seeking suggestions to design the trade centre.

The SPV with 15 members will float Trichy trade centre private limited under the Companies Act, 2013. Trichy District Tiny and Small Scale Industries Association (Tiditssia), one of the stakeholders, said that Trichy trade centre private limited was incorporated by the union ministry of corporate affairs on February 21.

The state government in 2017 had announced a trade centre in Trichy and 9.42 acres was identified in Panchapur. As the total cost of the project is estimated to be Rs 12 crore, the SPV will have to mobilise Rs 7 crore as their contribution. The state government has provided Rs 5 crore as a grant.

“We have to add new members to the SPV for mobilising the required funds. Trichy trade convention centre is just a step away from becoming a reality,” said N Kanagasabapathy, former president, Tiditssia. The SPV members have approached NIT Trichy seeking architectural support for designing the convention centre.

The convention centre at Panchapur is likely to accommodate at least 2,500 people at a time. Construction work for Trichy trade centre can be launched in the next six months, according to SPV members. Once the proposed design is approved by Tamil Nadu Small Industries Development Corporation (Sidco), sources said that civil work will complete in a year.

Title: Khambhat on boil again; DSP, deputy shunted out
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Fresh violence erupted on Tuesday after a public gathering was organized near Tower Bazaar

Vadodara/ Anand: Fresh violence broke out in coastal town of Khambhat in Anand district on Tuesday as a mob set a house and a shop ablaze in Mochiwad area of the town. There were however no reports of any person getting hurt due to the riots.

Following the rioting, state home department transferred Anand superintendent of police Makrand Chauhan and Khambhat’s deputy SP Reema Munshi. Three police inspectors were also shunted with immediate effect by the state DGP’s office.

Theviolence broke out after a public gathering organised by the ‘Hindu Samaj’ near Tower Bazaar in the heart of Khambhat. The ‘Hindu samaj’ had given a bandh call on Monday following which shops and businesses in all markets of the town remained closed during the day. The public gathering however witnessed a massive presence.

“The public gathering was not called by any social or political organisation. Residents of Bhavsarwad area, where rioters from the minority community had looted around 25 households apart from damaging their vehicles, had appealed their community members to express solidarity and support them. We did that,” said Khambhat’s former BJP MLA Sanjay Patel, who along with Khambhat’s city unit head of BJP, Pinakin Brahmbhatt, was among those who addressed the gathering at Tower Bazaar.

The political leaders later submitted a memorandum to Anand district collector demanding action against those responsible for the riots.

“The bandh was voluntary. Nobody has enforced the bandh. It was successful as the shops, whether owned by Muslims or Hindus, remained close during the day,” Patel said.

The town has been on the boil since Sunday following communal clash between members of minority and Chunara community in Akbarpura area. As violence that started in Akbarpura spread to other parts of the town, around 30 houses and shops were set ablaze and dozen-odd vehicles were damaged by rioters.

Late on Monday evening toom the town witnessed violence when a police party had raided Lal Darwaja area to arrest residents wanted for Sunday’s communal clash. Around 15 cops were injured after a mob attacked them. One of the constables fractured his hand.

Police have arrested 86 people in connection with the Sunday’s rioting which had left 13 persons injured. The rioters had also damaged a masjid and a temple.

The police has registered four offences at Khambhat police station in which 95 persons along with a mob of 1,000 persons belonging to both the communities were booked for rioting and arson.

Ahmedabad Range IG A K Jadeja told TOI, “The situation was under control and investigation into the riots is on.” On Tuesday, Gujarat DGP Shivanand Jha visited Khambat town to take stock of the situation in the town that has been on edge since past few months.

Title: Local residents raise voice against digging borewell for water scheme
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: A peace talk held at the Srirangam tahsildar’s office on Tuesday to persuade residents to allow digging a borewell in the Cauvery for Thiruverumbur Water Supply Improvement Scheme ended without any consensus as residents vehemently opposed it.

The water project aims to provide piped water supply to residents in the added areas of wards 61 to 65 in Thiruverumbur. To pump water, the local body has proposed digging a borewell in the Cauvery at Settithoppu near Melur in Srirangam.

While the pipeline installation is complete, the corporation has not launched work on the borewell owing to opposition from Srirangam residents, as they say it would lower the groundwater table in their locality and adjoining cultivations. To appease the residents, a peace talk was held by the district administration on Tuesday.

“The groundwater table has already declined due to the presence of numerous borewells in the Cauvery. Further, the corporation is planning to source 27 MLD of water, it will be a disaster for us if implemented,” said B Hemanathan, a Srirangam resident at the meeting.

Residents urged the local body to dig the borewell near the Grand Anicut by stating that the venue is closer to Thiruverumbur. But the civic body officials said that 95% of the water project work is already accomplished, and the project cannot be shifted to another location.

The explanations put forward by the civic body failed to convince the residents. Officials said that they are interested to implement the project only with the support of locals. “We will discuss with the district administration further to take a decision on implementing Thiruverumbur water project,” an official source said.

Title: RWA publishes booklet on rainwater harvesting
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The residents’ welfare association of Jagannadharaju Nagar (JR Nagar) near Old Venkojipalem has brought out a booklet on the role of RWAs in rainwater conservation and harvesting. The 30-page booklet describes the different approaches followed by JR Nagar to augment the colony’s water resources.

“It consists of details pertaining to the creation of rainwater harvesting structures, the technicalities involved, and the quantum of water that can be saved by following the guidelines,” KSR Murthy, president of JR Nagar RWA , said. JR Nagar was adjudged the third best resident welfare association in the country in the 2018 National Water Awards. The awards, instituted by the ministry of water resources, carries a cash prize of Rs 1 lakh and a citation.

JR Nagar also won an award for its rainwater harvesting system at the seventh national conference of RWAs in November last year. It is considered a model colony due to its greenery, garbage segregation and solid waste management initiatives and use of solar energy.

The colony has taken up several initiatives, such as systematic pruning of trees, which served two purposes — the trees did not suffer any major damage, and second, there was no power interruption due to overgrown trees criss-crossing power lines in the colony.

Title: ‘Cheating’ priest remanded in police custody for four days
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Dr Prashant Upadhyay

Vadodara: A local court remanded Dr Prashant Upadhyay, accused in a fraud case, in police custody for four days on Tuesday. Upadhyay had been on the run for the past 12 days after a police complaint of cheating was registered against him at Warasia police station.

Later, another FIR of threatening a woman too was registered against Upadhyay whose activities and lifestyle had become a subject of discussion on social media. “We sought his remand for recovering the money that he has been accused of siphoning off by the complainant apart from gathering other evidences,” said S Anand, police sub-inspector, Waghodia.

Upadhyay was nabbed from a restaurant on the highway at Chikhli in south Gujarat. Police said they tracked down Upadhyay from information received from his followers as well as their intelligence. Upadhyay was nabbed when he stopped at a restaurant on NH-48 near Chikhli on Monday.

Upadhyay is accused of cheating Devraj Pandya of Rs21.8 lakh. Pandya had approached Upadhyay as his business was suffering losses and he needed some solution. Upadhyay took Rs15 lakh from Pandya for some rituals and later Rs6.8 lakh over a period of time for some or the other reasons. When Pandya’s business did not recover, he asked for refund of his money. Upadhyay didn’t give the money back so Pandya lodged a complaint at Warasia police station.

Police had made several efforts to arrest him, but he managed to keep them at bay. Upadhyay had also sought anticipatory bail which a sessions court here denied.

Title: Man falls to death, mom dies of shock
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaisalmer: A 27-year-old youth, who was sitting on the terrace of his house at Khatrion Ka Vas in Chauhatan town of Barmer district, died falling off it on Monday night. When his mother got the news, she died of shock an hour later.

According to police, Manoj Khatri was sitting at terrace of his house when he slipped and fell down and sustained fatal head wounds. When the incident happened, his sister-in-law was at home while others were away.

On hearing cries, people from nearby houses rushed to the spot. A compounder reached and declared Manoj dead. When his mother Kamla Devi (57) reached the house, she became unconscious on seeing the body of her son in a pool of blood. an hour later, she died of shock. Manoj’s father who had gone to a marriage party was shocked on hearing two deaths in his family.

Sources said a week ago Manoj’s friend Ashok was injured in an accident and was admitted to hospital before succumbing to death. Ashok’s death disturbed him. TNN

Title: Two gangs of northeast Delhi, their UP-based aides under lens
Content:
Security personnel stand guard during clashes between pro and anti-CAA protesters in northeast Delhi

NEW DELHI: Two gangs of northeast Delhi and their UP-based associates have come under the scanner for their alleged role in the northeast Delhi riots , a source said on Tuesday.At least a dozen people, who were either spotted by the cops or caught on camera opening fire, throwing stones and setting vehicles on fire, have been found to be associates of the Nasir gang and the one led by his rival, Irfan Chhenu, said an official. Multiple sources confirmed that over 500 rounds had been fired by rioters in the past three days, indicating availability of a large cache of arms and ammunition.The probe hints at a bigger conspiracy wherein these gangs may have been hired by bigger entities to fan violence, claimed a source. “This also can’t be achieved without the support of local gangs,” said a source, adding that a manhunt would be launched as soon as the situation was under control. The cops are already investigating over a dozen robberies reported in these areas.Over a dozen WhatsApp groups, allegedly used by the rioters to strategise and coordinate, are also being scanned. A source in an intelligence establishment said many groups were deleted and new ones were being created regularly to avoid surveillance.A source alleged it seemed stones and Molotov cocktails had been stocked at strategic locations like houses, rooftops, balconies and corners of inner lanes since the past few days.Delhi Police spokesperson Mandeep Randhawa claimed on Tuesday that the situation in northeast Delhi had come under control. “We are responding to stray incidents of violence. Sufficient force, including Rapid Action Force, Sashastra Seema Bal and Central Reserve Police Force, has been deployed. The Union home ministry has given us additional force and we are deploying it,” he said.Randhawa also said police would use drones to monitor activities. “Incidents were reported despite prohibitory orders being in place and we took swift action. We are taking strong action. All miscreants and anti-social elements will be dealt with strictly. Video footage and CCTV feeds are also being analysed,” he added.Delhi Police on Tuesday sent a report to the home ministry detailing the sequence of events and the action taken during the riots.

Title: Now, trade FSI heritage for repairs in new plan
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Bhopal has hundreds of heritage structures that need conservation

BHOPAL: The draft 2031 masterplan for Bhopal could give a nod to transfer of development rights (TDR) or tradable floor space index (FSI) available to more than 500 private heritage structures in Bhopal, said sources.

Trading FSI aims to help heritage properties owners carry out much needed repair and restoration works. The cumulative net value of TDR and FSI of these properties is pegged at Rs 2,000 crore.

“TDR and FSI have spurted heritage restoration in many other cities. The move lays the foundation for heritage protection and incentivising it,” said a senior urban development official.

According to Indian National Trust for Art and Culture Heritage (INTACH) listing of heritage in Bhopal, there are 374 structures of importance which are under immediate threat and need conservation. The issue of TDR would be for private property owners who undertake restoration of their heritage. In turn, the private owners would be issued TDR, a certificate to give FSI as compensation or benefit. Heritage property owner can encash the certificate that will allow him or a third party to construct additional built-up area anywhere else in the city.

Bhopal has hundreds of heritage structures that need conservation. Most of these properties are in the walled city. The owners do not have the money to undertake restoration. TDR allows for heritage conservation and at the same time incentivises the heritage owner, according to experts. Similar interventions have taken place in Ahmedabad, which became India’s first world heritage city in 2018.

“Issue of TDR certificates is going to be a complicated deal. The property ownership is not a single ownership in many instances. Government needs to find direct ways to fund and support heritage restoration,” said author and conservationist, Rizwanuddin Ansari.

The TDR policy will reduce the burden on the civic body, besides reducing the project’s cost. It includes interventions like road widening and acquiring of land.

Private builders could also be roped in for development of proper housing along 700 plus slums in the state capital. A similar draft has been proposed for Indore , said sources.

Title: Govt plans to expand coffee cultivation area by another 58,000 acres in next 5 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) and Coffee Board are planning to increase coffee cultivation in the agency areas of Visakhapatnam district. Coffee cultivation was increased by roughly 42,000 acres in the last five years and the government now wants to add another 58,000 acres by 2025-26.

Coffee cultivation in the state is mainly done in Visakha agency area, which is known for its very own Araku coffee brand. The weather conditions in the high-altitude tribal belt is suitable for coffee plantation.

The focus now is to increase the area under cultivation and facilitate the export of Araku coffee.

ITDA project officer DK Balaji said their focus is to bring more area under coffee cultivation. “AP today stands third in the country in coffee cultivation behind Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. By 2025, we expect to become second in the country in terms of coffee cultivation. The branding of Araku coffee has helped us gain a foothold in the export market, which was not there earlier,” he said.

ITDA and Coffee Board officials said coffee has become the main driving force of the agency area’s economy and is the single largest employer, with over 1.34 lakh families directly dependent on coffee cultivation, which accounts to nearly 80% of their income source.

“Coffee cultivation has changed the economy of the agency areas. Today, the tribals are able to live with dignity and have financial security. We welcome the state government’s move to increase coffee cultivation area further,” G Rama Gopal, state president of Indian Confederation of Indigenous and Tribal People, said.

Title: Rajasthan: Rights body asks govt to table accountability bill
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Activists Aruna Roy and Nikhil Dey marched with hundreds of activists from Shaheed Smarak to the Civil Lines i... Read More

JAIPUR: The Mazdoor Kisan Shakti Sangathan (MKSS) has asked chief minister Ashok Gehlot to table the accountability bill in the ongoing assembly session.

Activists Aruna Roy and Nikhil Dey marched with hundreds of activists from Shaheed Smarak to the Civil Lines in Jaipur on Tuesday demanding the enactment of the Act which fixes accountability of government employees from the level of chief secretary to the sarpanch. They activists also asked the government to slot a space for protests and demonstrations in Jaipur and district headquarters.

Taking on the government, Roy reminded Gehlot that enactment of the accountability Act had been listed by the Congress in its manifesto before the assembly elections in 2018. “By not introducing the Act, the government is not doing good with the people,” said Roy, who said till the Act is introduced, the protest will continue across the state.

The activist headed to the assembly to meet Gehlot but the meet was cancelled due to unavailability of the CM. The present assembly session will end on March 14 and the draft is not listed in the business.

The activists has been demanding the tabling of the Act since the government came to power in December 2018. Gehlot had assured them of bringing the Act soon while accepting its draft prepared by the MKSS in early 2019.

Thereafter, the state constituted a committee headed by IAS officer Ram Lubhaya to prepare a draft within three months and hinted to table it in mid-2019. However, the committee submitted the draft in January 2020.

Title: Mahila court SPP booked for colluding with Pocso accused
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Sivaganga: A special public prosecutor (SPP) of the Sivaganga mahila court has been booked by the Sivaganga district police on charges of colluding with a Pocso (Protection of Children from Sexual Offence) Act case accused to make the victims turn hostile in the case during its trial in 2016.

The special public prosecutor has been identified as V Indra Gandhi. Apart from the SPP, the accused in the Pocso case identified as Murugan, headmaster of a primary school in Sivaganga district, was also booked under IPC Section – 195 A (threatening any person to give false evidence) based on a complaint from one of the victims.

Initially, only Murugan’s name was mentioned in the February 8 first information report (FIR). Sivaganga district superintendent of police Rohit Nathan, however, told TOI that the SPP’s name has been added in the case through further statement.

The incident came to light when the SP Nathan reviewed pending cases in 2019. He had written to the district collector in November, to replace the SPP stating that the accused will escape from the clutches of law if she continued in the post. It was forwarded to the additional chief secretary of the state government.

Meanwhile, the victim, who is 13 years now, lodged a complaint with the Sivaganga all women police station stating that Murugan visited her and her grandmother during the course of trial in 2016 and pleaded with them to turn hostile. He told them that he was ready to offer money also.

Murugan took her to the woman public prosecutor, who tutored her to say that the headmaster did not involve in the sexual assault case. Two more victims have also made complaints to the police stating that the public prosecutor tutored them to turn hostile. Meanwhile, Indra Gandhi on Thursday moved the Madurai bench of Madras high court, seeking anticipatory bail.

It maybe recalled that Murugan sexually abused six girl students studying in Class IV in 2015. The incident came to light when one of the students, who was staying in the hostel, narrated the incident to her grandmother in July 2015 when she had gone to her place. Noticing something wrong with the child, the grandmother inquired with her. The girl then told her that she was sexually assaulted by Murugan inside the school bathroom.

When she came to know about the shocking incident, the grandmother took the girl to the police station to lodge a complaint. The case came up for trial in 2016.

Title: Cong, BJP gears for Rajya Sabha polls
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madhya Pradesh, September 18 (ANI): Congress General Secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia with Madhya Pradesh Chief ... Read More

Bhopal: Intense lobby has begun in ruling Congress and opposition BJP after announcement of schedule for Rajya Sabha elections. Three seats of the Upper House from Madhya Pradesh are falling vacant and the Congress and BJP are eyeing a clean sweep. Given the strength of parties in MP Assembly the Congress with a strength of 114 MLAs and support of 2 BSP members and a Samajwadi Party MLA must comfortably win two seats.

However, BJP is eyeing two seats and is making all-out efforts to win two seats. The seats falling vacant include those of Digvijaya Singh (Congrees), Prabhat Jha and Satyanarayan Jatia (BJP). Govind Singh Rajput, a minister in Kamal Nath cabinet has raked up the issue of RS ticket and demanded that party must field Jyotiraditya Scindia.

If BJP sources are to be believed party is unlikely to field two-time MP Prabhat Jha as he is a brahmin. Party has already appointed a brahmin, VD Sharma, as state chief while the leader of Opposition in MP Gopal Bhargava and chief whip in assembly Narottam Mishra also both are brahmins. Likewise, Jatia, a senior leader, will have to make way for a young leader.

State Congress leaders claim that Digvijaya Singh being a senior leader could get a second term in the Upper House as he has also been active and vocal during his first tenure. Singh was fielded from Bhopal Parliamentary seat in 2019 by lost against BJP’s Pragya Singh Thakur. If Digvijaya Singh gets repeated, there will be just one seat with many leaders vying for the same.

In the race are former Union ministers Jyotiraditya Scindia who lost Guna, Arun Yadav who lost Khandwa to BJP’s Nandkumar Singh Chouhan, former LOP Ajay Singh who was defeated from Sidhi, former deputy speaker of the assembly Rajendra Singh defeated from Satna and veteran leader Ram Niwas Rawat who also faced defeat from Morena Parliamentary constituency.

Minister Govind Singh Rajput on Tuesday said, “Jyotiraditya Scindia is a capable candidate for both post of state Congress president and the Rajya Sabha.” Rajput is considered close to Scindia and argued that both the positions should be given to the former Union minister of state. “This is my personal opinion and demand from the entire state,” the minister said.

Title: Quarantined ship: Special flight to bring back Indians today
Content:
The 138 Indians who were on board Diamond Princess included 132 crew members and six passengers. (AP)

MADURAI: The Indian embassy in Japan on Tuesday asked Indian crew members on board Diamond Princess, a cruise ship quarantined at Yokohama port after some patients had tested positive for coronavirus infection (COVID-19), to be ready to be airlifted in a chartered aircraft on Wednesday. The Indian crew members were sent mails in this regard along with terms and conditions for the evacuation eight days after they were given forms asking them to express interest for premature evacuation from the ship.A copy of the advisory available with TOI added that the flight was tentatively scheduled for February 26 evening. Pre-disembarkation process is expected to start around 2pm. The crew members have been advised to pay attention to the announcements made on board Diamond Princess. The advisory states that only those who have not tested positive in the PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test, conducted by Japanese authorities, would be evacuated.Individuals should also have given consent by filling in the forms that were sent by the embassy to them on February 17 for leaving the ship and returning to India before the expiry of the mandatory Japanese quarantine period. Those who have not filled in the forms should fill them before 10am on Wednesday.Repatriation is subject to clearing the mandatory medical check-up by an Indian medical team, the advisory said. It added that individuals should also follow instructions from officials of the Indian government, aircraft crew and medical personnel on board the flight and are requested to wear face mask.They should undergo a mandatory 14 days quarantine on arrival in India. Stating that transportation from Yokohama port to Haneda airport would be by road, the embassy added that the vehicle would not be allowed to stop anywhere during the around 20km journey.Crew on board, who did not want to be named, expressed concern over 14 more days of quarantine they would have to undergo in India. “We have been quarantined in the ship from February 4. On February 17, we were given forms for leaving the ship with the condition that we would have to undergo 14 days quarantine on reading India,” he said. “But Wednesday will be nine days after we submitted the forms. So an additional 14 days from Thursday will make it a total quarantine of 37 days. The government should consider this and reduce the quarantine period in India as only those who have tested negative for COVID-19 and certified by the Japanese health authorities will be brought to India,” he added.The 138 Indians who were on board Diamond Princess included 132 crew members and six passengers. The embassy tweeted on Tuesday evening that PCR test results for all Indian nationals have been declared and two more tested positive, taking the total to 16.

Title: Should tax rates be hiked for commercial properties located on main roads?
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

With SCB looking to hike commercial property tax , TOI asked readers what the criteria should be to set a tax slab.

While revising the property tax for commercial buildings on the main road will be a wise decision by the authorities, along with it, they must also ensure that adequate facilities are provided in these establishments. Numerous commercial complexes near the main road lack a parking space, washrooms and drinking water facilities. In this case, it becomes immensely difficult for people to enjoy these spaces. With summer already setting in, the situation will only worsen. Hence, the authorities should see to it that these facilities are provided as the tax is hiked. There will be no point in collecting more tax without it being used sincerely. The cause will be lost.

- G. Vijay Kumar

The commercial establishments on main roads should be taxed higher in comparison to the ones in by-lanes as rates of all properties are subjected to their location. A slab system for taxation of the buildings based on their location would generate higher revenues, that can consequently be used to develop and maintain other areas, like the cantonment. It is sort of a domino effect. The government gets more revenue and the people, better facilities. Having said that, the civic authorities should also relax the laws governing the construction of buildings. The main reason that people cite to move out of the cantonment are the medieval rules that still apply there and do not deem fit for the current times. Hence, the areas of main roads should be examined by the authorities and the dwellers should be informed beforehand about the hike in the tax so that the move does not come as a shock to them. This would only help better the procedure of governance in the area.

- Deepesh Surana

Property tax should be based on a variety of factors such as the location, value and area of the property in question. The parameters should dictate the tax contribution being made by citizens. In this context, it makes more sense for the owner of land in a prime area to pay more than her counterpart who lives in interior areas. This is based on the logic that the person living in the prime area has more access to various facilities being provided by the government through the taxpayers money, when compared to someone living in a interior location. To make this system really work, the government should conduct regular surveys to access the land values and the appreciation or depreciation of assets.

- Sai Charan

There are several factors that must be taken into account in setting the property tax. For instance, in the Cantonment areas, there are several restrictions on the kind of construction that one can indulge in. Are these restrictions being taken into account when deciding a tax amount? Moreover, there are several ‘commercial’ areas that have been for long ignored by the civic body. When the government cannot do its bit, it is not fair to charge exorbitant amounts just by virtue of the location of the property.

- Amal R

Title: Rajinikanth fails to appear before panel probing Tuticorin violence
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: Actor Rajinikanth, who was summoned by the retired Justice Aruna Jagadeesan Commission probing the anti-Sterlite protest and police firing in Tuticorin, failed to appear before it on Tuesday, and sought exemption citing possible inconvenience to the public due to his visit and prior commitments. However, the commission refused to accept the first reason and said that fresh summons will be served based on the actor’s convenience.

The commission summoned Rajinikanth on February 4, to appear for questioning in Tuticorin at 10am on February 25 for the 19th sitting into the May 22, 2018, incident. He was summoned for his remarks to journalists in Tuticorin on May 30, 2018, that ‘intrusion of anti-social elements’ was the reason for the mob turning violent and eventually ended with the police resorting to firing at them.

On Tuesday morning, the actor’s counsel Ilambarathi appeared before the commission and submitted an affidavit that Rajinikanth could not appear for the above mentioned reasons. On the actor’s request, the commission sent a sealed cover with the possible questions he will be asked. “He will answer them and submit a written affidavit. If summoned, he will appear,” the counsel told reporters.

Counsel for the commission, Vadivel Murugan told reporters that the panel had not accepted Rajinikanth’s reason citing inconvenience to public. “Many political leaders and cine personalities have testified before the commission. Police made proper security measures and there were no inconveniences to the public,” he said.

However, the commission accepted the second reason cited by Rajinikanth that he has shooting commitments and exempted him from appearing on Tuesday. Stating that many witnesses in the past have asked exemption for a particular date, following which they were summoned on a later date, he added that the commission may ask his convenience for the next date and serve fresh summons.

“We have not summoned everyone. His testimony is important in the probe as some of his remarks are of utmost importance for the commission. So we summoned him and asked him to appear,” he said. Murugan added that the commission is confident that he will appear because he is in a responsible position in the society and a law-abiding citizen.

He recalled that the actor on February 4 told reporters that he will extend full cooperation to the commission.

Title: 25-yr-old held for sharing lewd videos
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: A 25-year-old engineering graduate from Tamil Nadu was arrested at Secunderabad railway station for sending obscene videos to a woman from Malkajgiri.

A week ago, a case was filed following the woman’s complaint. The accused confessed to his crime and was sent to judicial remand.TNN

Title: Delhi high court to hear plea for a judicial probe, arrest of politicians
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court said it would examine on Wednesday a plea demanding an independent judicial inquiry, compensation for deceased and arrest of political leaders for inciting violence in Delhi’s northeast area.

The plea was mentioned before a bench of Justices G S Sistani and A J Bhambhani for an urgent hearing on Tuesday but the court posted it for next day.

Filed by human rights activist Harsh Mander and activist Farah Naqvi, the petition sought setting up of an SIT to inquire into the incident prosecution of individuals who were inciting masses and making hate speeches.

It also urged the court to direct the Centre to deploy Army for maintaining law and order in the national capital and areas where the “communal attack on people are most ferocious.” The plea said that on February 22, around 500 people reached Jafrabad metro station where women were holding peaceful protests against Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

The plea also sought directions to the authorities to register an FIR against Kapil Mishra, Union minister Anurag Thakur and BJP MP Parvesh Verma and others who were allegedly “engaged in criminal activities, including rioting and inciting hatred among classes.”

Arguing that the authorities must declare on their website the full list with names of persons who were detained by police and paramilitary forces, the plea asked high court to intervene so that detained persons were provided access to their family members and legal counsel.

A key to ensuing that a proper probe was carried out was that police preserve evidence and CCTV footage of all cameras in and around the protest sites. The plea said the authorities should be directed to ensure the safety and protection of all the protest sites, especially women and children.

“After provocative speech were given by the three prominent politicians liked by the assailants, the assailants carried out multiple brutal attacks against unarmed persons who were protesting against CAA,” the plea claimed.

Title: ‘Kasturba Gandhi helped steer path of her husband’
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Tushar Gandhi, great grandson of Mahatma Gandhi, spoke on ‘Kasturba: A remarkable life’ during SGR Knowledge o... Read More

Nagpur: Kasturba Gandhi put in a lot of efforts to steer her husband’s path, right from his career to freedom struggle. But the biggest injustice towards Kasturba is that she is always seen through the lens of a wife, mother and grandmother and not as a solitary person, said Tushar Gandhi, a thinker and great grandson of the Mahatma, on Monday.

He was delivering a lecture in the 26th edition of knowledge series organized by SGR Knowledge Foundation and Chitnavis Centre on ‘Kasturba: A remarkable life’, at Banyan Hall.

Gandhi brought to light Kasturba’s essence which is often lost in her husband’s shadow. He said, “Like others, even I made the mistake of not recognizing Kastur’s contribution. It is time to take corrective measures and take notice of her role in Mohandas’s life so that future generations know about her real personality.”

Speaking about the earlier days of their life, Gandhi said, “Kastur and Mohandas shared a long journey. Married at the age of 13, they got to know each other from a tender age. They grew up in neighbouring societies and it is possible that they even played together as kids.”

“According to tradition, she had to leave her parents’ home in Porbandar and settle with her husband’s family in Rajkot after marriage. She learnt how to be a wife while living in the confines of the house. On the other hand, Mohandas bought a manual that had instructions on how to be a husband,” he said.

“He used to read a chapter everyday and implement the tenets on Kastur. One lesson in the manual taught him that a wife cannot do anything without seeking permission from her husband. He told Kastur to not step out of the house unless he permitted her for the same. This order bore no fruit as Kastur resisted and walked out anyway,” he added.

“There were a number of failed attempts of controlling her by asking her to seek permission relentlessly and directing her to return to her parents’ home, as instructed by the manual, since she stood her ground,” Gandhi said.

He said, “In his autobiography, Mohandas hails Kastur as his role model for non-violence principles.”

Gandhi said his life goal is to break away Mohandas from the grasp of the Mahatma title and portray him as a common man in the public eye. “When we think of Mahatma, it entails a sense of devotion and we detach ourselves from the thought that his ideologies can be inculcated by common man,” he said.

He held back tears while narrating about what Kasturba might have gone through when Mohandas was in Johannesburg prison.

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: It was started in 1942 to tap young talent
Content:
