Title: Government rail police help pregnant woman stranded at station
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The woman delivered a baby girl near the gate of the rural hospital

NASHIK: When a pregnant woman — stranded at the Nandgaon railway station along with her family members — went into labour early on Saturday morning, an assistant sub-inspector (ASI) of the Government Railway Police ( GRP ) came to her aid.

Along with his 23-year-old son Chetan, ASI Shivaji Ighe helped look for an available vehicle to shift the woman to a hospital. The patrolling team of the Nandgaon police came forward to transport the woman, who eventually delivered in the police van itself. However, within minutes, the woman was handed over to the Nandgaon rural hospital for further treatment.

Ighe also revalidated the train tickets of the woman and her family so that they don’t have to spend again on tickets to Gonda in UP.

Shivaji and Chetan have received praise from all quarters.

Adityaprasad Jaiswal, his pregnant wife Sumitadevi and their 7-year-old daughter had taken the Kushinagar Express (11015) for Gonda on Friday. Sumitadevi went into labour during the journey. When the labour pains became unbearable, the Jaiswal family got off the train at the Nandgaon railway station at 3.45 am.

Running from one place to another seeking help, Adityaprasad met the personnel of the Railway Protection Force (RPF). The doctor available at the railway station could not help as he did not have the necessary equipment for the delivery. Subsequently, the RPF personnel called up ASI Ighe on his cellphone at 4 pm. Ighe, who was patrolling around the railway station, got there within a couple of minutes. Seeing the condition of the woman, he started checking for an ambulance.

The GRP police said that there were no ambulances around. They even called up the 108 ambulance, but the one in Nandgaon was not available. Officials of the 108 ambulance said that they were rushing an ambulance from Manmad. However, it would have taken more than an hour to reach Nandgaon.

Ighe then called up his son Chetan and asked him to scout for a vehicle to take the woman to the Nandgaon rural hospital. The woman had already started bleeding at the railway station. Chetan came across a patrolling van of the Nandgaon police. The patrolling team rushed to the railway station. The police personnel and the railway doctor arranged for four bedsheets and made the woman lie down in the police van.

While the woman, her husband and daughter, two police personnel and Chetan were in the police van, Ighe said he and the railway doctor followed the van on his two-wheeler. The woman delivered a baby girl near the gate of the rural hospital. Ighe said the family left for Gonda on Monday.

Rohan Borse, the medical superintendent of the Nandgaon rural hospital, said, “Ighe did a great job. Had the police not made haste in rushing the woman to the hospital, the bleeding after the delivery could have been more profuse and that could have put the woman’s life at risk.”

Title: Vadodara Municipal Corporation spent Rs 76 lakh on drainage lines
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) had to spend Rs 76 lakh on the repair of four major breaches in drainage lines in the city. The roads had developed cave-ins due to breaches in the western parts of the city.

The cave-ins had taken place near Vasna Jakat Naka on Vasna Road, Malhar Point on Old Padra Road, ABS Towers on Old Padra Road and Shivam Apartment on the Subhanpura-Gorwa Road in the same period. It is believed that settlement of earth below the drainage lines due to the heavy rains this year may have led to the situation. The area has witnessed similar issues in the past too, due to the nature of the soil.

The VMC spent Rs 11.28 lakh to repair the drainage line near Vasna Jakatnaka, Rs 4.63 lakh on the line near Malhar Point, Rs 42.9 lakh for the leakage near ABS Towers and Rs 17.19 lakh on the line near Shivam Apartment.

The expenses had to be done using the provisions to take up works without the standing committee’s nod in wake of the emergency situation. While the expenses have already been made, the works have been put before the standing committee for its formal approval.

Title: Surat student shines in CS executive exams
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

SURAT: City student Mayuri Jain secured 24th rank in company secretary executive programme of The Institute of Company Secretaries of India (ICSI), the results of which were announced along with that of its professional programme on Tuesday. These examinations were conducted by the ICSI in December 2019.

Mayuri, daughter of a Goods and Services Tax officer, is currently in fourth year of five-year integrated LLB course at Veer Narmad South Gujarat University . She is interested in working in corporate sector and hence chose a combination of law and company secretary courses to make her career.

"I used to attend classes regularly and also spent five hours daily on my studies. This has helped me to perform well in the examinations," Mayuri said.

She scored 482 marks out of 800 in the examinations. Jain expected good marks but never expected to be among top 25 in the country.

"One has to be consistent in studies and should regularly revise whatever has been taught in the classes. This will help anyone to perform well during the examinations," she added.

Many students in the Diamond City pursue chartered accountancy and company secretary courses together. "Those doing CA find CS comparatively easy. A lot of students study CS for better career options," said a tutor from the city.

Title: Demand to release draft on action plan to tackle climate change in Tamil
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: As the last date to give public opinion and suggestions on the draft prepared by the state on action plan to tackle climate change (TN-SAPCC) got over on Sunday (February 23), environmentalists have sought extension apart from releasing the draft in Tamil.

The state had released its previous action plan in 2013, which the union government has asked to update. While the revised draft was prepared by the state department of environment, it was released a couple of weeks back.

While the union government had given a format on preparing the revised draft, G Sundarrajan of NGO Poovulagin Nanbargal said the state government should have consulted every stake holder including farmers, activists, water experts and local bodies. “It should have been released in Tamil and English, but it was not done and the draft was released in English,” he said.

Nanbargal, who has carried deliberations on the draft, said that apart from identifying vulnerable places in the coastal region, the action plan is silent on many of vital details that should have been part of the draft. “For instance, there was no mention about data on basic carbon emission in the state. Also, dividing the state into seven agro-climatic zones is a flawed concept,” he said.

Stressing on the need to release the draft in Tamil so that it reaches more people, Thaneer – a Trichy based environmental organisation - said the time given to give opinion was very less. “The draft needs to reach farmers who are major stakeholders. Not many people have come to know about the draft as there wasn’t much efforts on publicising the action plan,” said K C Neelamegam, Thaneer secretary.

C Ravichandran, associate professor from Bishop Heber College, said that the draft could have been shared with the academia for opinion. It would have ensured that the state government got varied opinions.

Asked on the demand to release the draft in Tamil, he said not many are aware of climatic changes and the science behind it, which could have limited the state to release the draft in English.

Title: Naval band’s performance at National College casts a spell
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: A 29-member musical troop of Indian Naval Band from Eastern Naval Command left the audience at National College Trichy ( NCT ) spellbound with its performance on Friday.

The programme, first time in a city college, was organised by the chief inspector of Naval Armament, Trichy, to inspire students.

Considered one of the finest in Asia, Indian Naval band played some diverse music starting with the theme music of ‘Captain America: The First Avenger’.

The troop led by commander Sathish K Champion also played Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’ and ‘Cornfield Rock’ before enthralling the crowd with ‘Marana Mass’ song from Rajnikanth-starrer ‘Petta’.

The band also played Ilayaraja’s ‘Ooru vittu ooru vanthu’ from Tamil film ‘Karagattakaran’.

Lauding their performance, chief guest of the event and film composer Karthik Raja held them on a par with Jazz ambassadors – a group of leading musicians which helped the US improve its public image.

He requested the band to perform popular Captain America’s theme once again after asking the children in the last row to come close to the stage so that they can experience music direct from the instruments.

Commander Anup Thomas of Naval Armament, Trichy, said that the event was to inspire youngsters towards armed forces. This was a platform to make youngsters have a glimpse of Indian Navy and the way of the life of the people in the service so that they aspire to take up jobs in armed forces, he said.

Title: ‘Last Lecture’ at SIOM by Deepa Malik
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nashik: International Para-athlete Deepa Malik has called upon the student fraternity to never stop learning no matter what obstacles come their way.

She was invited by the Symbiosis Institute of Operations Management ( SIOM ) in the city to deliver the ‘last lecture’ which is a custom of the college to invite a personality to deliver the last lecture for the passing out students as part of their farewell programme — Adyant 2020.

A number of 136 students from the 2018-2020 batch attended the lecture. “Learning should never stop. There are ample of things that you can learn all your life. I had started with a small restaurant in Ahmednagar despite my disability. The journey of a restaurateur to a sportsperson achieving multiple awards was only due to my quest of learning,” she said.

Mother of two daughters, Malik said that she never felt that her life is dull and boring. “My daughters always said, Mom! Your life is so cool. One should never be afraid to fail and keep learning new things in life. Getting the president’s awards four times, making three Limca world records, getting Arjuna Award, Khel Ratna and Padmashri, achieving two honorary doctorates, etc. are all due to my quest of learning,” said Malik.

During the session, Deepa also introduced the other guest of the event. International swimmer and Eklavya awardee, Hansraj Patil, who is also the Naib Tehsildar in Nashik collector office, sang a song despite suffering from cerebral palsy.

The college awarded the top scorers of last three semesters with certificates and announced the name of the best student of the batch.

Sana Rai, who was declared the best student, told TOI “I did not see this coming. I hail from Bengaluru and I have spent the best time in past two years. I have got the job offer from a multinational company in Bengaluru and I am going to miss college.”

Vinay Tawani, another final year student, said “The two hardest things to say in life are hello for the first time and goodbye for the last. It was a beautiful gesture by the college to give us the last lecture.”

The day for the students had much more to follow. They unveiled their year book and the college graffiti wall, enjoyed dance, drama, poetry and band performance, distributed committee certificates and had the last dance.

Title: Ahmedabad: US President Donald Trump gone, cattle and dogs return to streets
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: The high profile visit of US President Donald Trump had the cattle nuisance department running from pillar to post to impound stray cattle and dogs. The exercise will not mean much the long run, as these impounded animals will be back on the roads.

In the last week, AMC workers caught 48 cows and buffaloes and 55 dogs from the area around Motera and the airport. Officials said that according to policy, the dogs will be sterilized and released from wherever they were caught.

“We have a policy that the owner has to pay a fine and to get their cattle back and this will be done,” said deputy municipal commissioner Mukesh Gadhvi.

Officials at the zone-level said that the AMC has in many cases lodged police complaints against such cattle owners, but in this case no complaints have been registered. The officer said that it was also noticed that not all dogs had been caught but most of the cattle on the roads were caught.

The Gujarat high court had last May directed that “the concerned authorities enforce appropriate laws in connection with stray animals. Appropriate preventive as well as curative measures will be taken by the concerned authorities to prevent this problem more effectively during the monsoon period. It is also directed that appropriate authorities shall take appropriate action against the owners or persons leaving their cattle to stray on the roads so that such persons are not tempted to repeat the same again.”

The officer said that it has been noted in many cases that the cattle impounded are caught again and again and in each time the owner gets them released after paying the fine.

Title: Illegal liquor unit busted in Pudukottai
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: Prohibition and Enforcement Wing (PEW) busted an illegal liquor manufacturing unit operating in a house in Alangudi of Pudukottai district on Tuesday.

While two people, including owner of the house fled, Dharamlingam, 38, from Puducherry, who was helping the duo to set up the unit was arrested.

Dharmalingam was helping Raja, 40, from Andakottai village in Alangudi to set up illegal liquor manufacturing unit in his house in the middle of a farmland. On Monday night, Raja went to Puducherry along with his friend Balu, 35, to meet Dharmalingam. The trio were returning with spirit and other raw materials for making liquor from Puducherry when PEW Pudukottai chased them based on a tip-off. While Raja and Balu managed to escape, Dharmalingam was caught along with the material. Two cars were also recovered from the spot. The police took the duo to Raja’s house and recovered bottles and stickers to pack the liquor. A case has been booked in this regard in Alangudi police station, further investigation is on.

Title: Gujarat: Farmer’s son, tailor’s daughter top in CS exams
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

At least four students from Ahmedabad made it to the national ranking

AHMEDABAD: The son of a farmer and the daughter of a tailor have made it to the top of the professional programme of the Company Secretaries of India. Vipul Parmar, whose father is a farmer, ranked second in the centre and eighth in the country on the old syllabus, while Mitushi Darji ranked first in the centre and 21st in the country on the new syllabus.

The Company Secretaries of India on Tuesday declared the results for the executive and professional programme examinations held in December 2019. At least four students from Ahmedabad made it to the national ranking. One student from the executive programme and three from the professional programme made it to the Top 25 in the country.In the executive programme (Module-I) the success rate was 22.10% while in Module II the rate was 18.81%. In Module III it was 25.81%. In the professional programme (new syllabus) it was 30.77% while in Module II it was 13.33%, and in Module III it was 30.77%.

Vipul Parmar ranked eighth in the professional course (old syllabus). Parmar said that the key to his success was his father, who was a farmer. “I saw him working hard in the fields and this hard work left an impression on me. As I grew up I realised that hard work is required,” he said. Parmar has already completed his Chartered Accountancy course.

“In my village, Dhelana in Mangrol taluka of Junagadh, I am the only CA and CS and my father today walks proudly in the village,” he said. Vipul has also completed his Bachelor of Commerce course and is now doing his master’s in commerce as an external student.

Mitushi Darji, the topper in Ahmedabad, ranked 21 in the country in the new syllabus of the professsional programme. Mitushi lives in the Jivraj Park area and is the daughter of a tailor. Mitushi says that her father works from their home. “I was inspired by a cousin who completed her CS course. I decided to join the course and was aware that it was hard to crack. I decided to work hard and I was surprised to find that I topped the new syllabus course.” Darji now wants to do her articleship and work in the the corporate world and help her father out.

Title: Nashik: Civic body to open 10 mohalla clinics in slums
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) has decided to replicate Delhi government’s mohalla clinic project in the city and has proposed 10 such clinics that will provide OPD facilities and generic medicines in slum areas.

In order to make this project a reality the civic administration has increased the outlay in the health sector from Rs 21.45 crore in the current fiscal to over Rs 51 crore for the financial year 2020-21.

While presenting the budget municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game said 10 mohalla clinics have been proposed in the budget. These clinics are to be started particularly in slum areas in order to provide medical facilities to the slum dwellers.

“Retired medical officers are to be deployed at these clinics to provide medical facilities to the patients,” he said.

Game added that as many as 25 medical officers are working in various NMC-run hospitals on honorarium basis and the civic body is the process to appoint 23 medical officers and 5 physicians on honorarium basis for its hospitals.

The civic administration has also proposed setting up of sanitary napkin vending machines for girl students in 90 civic-run schools.

“The NMC is making efforts to provide maximum facilities to school students and maintain the strength of students. We have made a provision of Rs 40 lakh to provide sanitary napkin vending machines and disposal machines in each civic school,” Game said.

“Apart from backward category students, two school uniforms are also to be provided to poor students from open category and necessary financial provision has been made for the purpose in the budget for the FY 2020-21,” he said.

The NMC has also made financial provision to provide shoes and pair of socks to students from municipal schools. The civic body has increased the provision for education department by Rs 37.48 crore to Rs 97.37 crore for the FY 2020-21 against the provision of Rs 59.89 crore for FY 2020-21.

The civic body has also taken several measures for municipal schools like setting up of water purification system, installing fire safety provisions and providing sports equipment.

Title: Former Daman district panchayat president nabbed in Mohali
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Accused in police custody

SURAT: Daman police nabbed former Daman District Panchayat president and BJP leader Suresh Jagu Patel alias Sukho in Mohali in Punjab on Monday. He will be soon brought to Daman on a transfer warrant, police said. Cops were in search of Patel, who was on the run for several months after his name cropped up during investigation in a double murder case.

Police arrested Patel and his aide Sajidali alias Salim Chaudhary from Mohali on the basis of specific information. The accused tried to snatch gun from a cop leading to one round being fired accidentally. The bullet hit one person who was accompanying the accused.

A separate offence of firing has been registered in Mohali. "Patel and his associate have been arrested by police in Mohali. The local police are investigating yesterday's incident. Daman police will take custody of the accused on transfer warrant once their custody with local police ends," said a police officer of Nani Daman police station.

In April 2018, Ajay Raman Patel and Dhirendra alias Dhiru alias Dhiriya Durlabh Patel were shot dead by some assailants and an offence was registered at Nani Daman police station. The complaint in this connection was lodged by Chhotu Patel. Police have so far nabbed Noon Majam, Mohammad Hasan Abdul Aziz Siddiqui, Rashid Murtaza and a couple of other accused in the case.

"Our investigation revealed that Patel was the mastermind of the murders and his name was later added in the complaint. Police went to register his statement on October 21, 2019 at his office, but he managed to escape. He has been on the run since then,” police said.

His elder brother Ramesh Patel alias Michael is a bootlegging kingpin. Michael had earlier been arrested in multiple cases by cops of different police stations of south Gujarat . Ramesh was controlling the entire bootlegging network of IMFL that was being pumped into Gujarat. Enforcement directorate had initiated action against Ramesh under Prevention of Money Laundering Act and seized his properties and cash worth several crores.

Patel and his wife were also booked in the past in a few offences of bootlegging after seizure of liquor by Valsad police.

Title: State stays appointment of 8 new standing panel members
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nashik: The state government on Tuesday stayed the appointment of eight new members of the Nashik Municipal Corporation’s ( NMC ) standing committee following complaints by Shiv Sena group leader Vilas Shinde.

Mayor Satish Kulkarni had on Monday declared the names of eight new members of the standing committee — four from BJP, two from Shiv Sena and one each from Congress and NCP — after the term of eight former standing committee members came to an end.

In the 16-member standing committee, the BJP has got nine seats, while Sena has four and Congress, NCP and MNS have one member each. The quota of standing committee members to the political parties is decided on the basis of their strength of corporators .

During the 2017 civic elections, the BJP had won 66 seats and Shiv Sena got 34. Accordingly, the comparative strength of both BJP and Shiv Sena was 8.65 and 4.45, respectively. Hence, BJP had got a quota of nine members, while Sena had got a quota of four members.

The total number of BJP corporators later reduced from 66 to 64 and Sena’s number increased to 35. Owing to this the comparative strength of BJP reduced from previous 8.65 to 8.39, while Sena’s increased from 4.45 to 4.59.

After the drop in comparative strength of BJP, Sena had demanded the mayor to reduce the BJP’s quota to eight members and increase Sena’s quota from four to five members. The proposal, however, was rejected by the mayor.

Vilas Shinde, hence, complained to the urban development department of state government. Accordingly, the urban development department stayed the appointments of new eight members on standing committee. The stay will continue until the municipal commissioner takes decision on the issue.

Title: Man’s body found with head severed in Pudukottai
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: The body of a 21-year-old man with his head cut off was found at an isolated location in Pudukottai district on Tuesday.

Six people have been arrested in connection with the murder.

The deceased has been identified as T Sambath Kumar, from Kamarajapuram. The accused have been identified as Subramanian 29, Vinoth 22, Vijay 19, Karthik, 22, Sridhar, 22, and Srikanth, 19.

The body with injury marks was spotted in in a piece of land with eucalyptus plantations near Sambath’s house.

Sambath has two cases pending against him at the Ganesh Nagar police station for engaging in fights.

Last week too, he was involved in a violent clash with a group of youngsters from his village. Police suspect that the murder could have been a fallout of that fight.

Police have sent the body to the Pudukottai government hospital for postmortem.

Title: Technical snag delays 2 international flights
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: Nearly 200 passengers were stranded at the Trichy Internation Airport after two outbound international flights developed technical snags early on Tuesday. Following the issue, the Kuala Lumpur-bound Air Asia and Dubai bound Air India Express were grounded at the airport.

The scheduled arrival time for Air Asia flight from Kuala Lumpur is 11.40 and it will return at 12.10 am. When the flight was about to take off as per the schedule with 127 passengers, the flight developed a technical snag .

After intimating the air traffic control room, a technical team started to rectify the snag. Though the team took hours to fix it, the problem remained unsolved. Then the service was cancelled and the passengers waiting at the airport were shifted to a private hotel. Later a technical team was called in from Kuala Lumpur and engaged in rectifying the fault.

Though it was declared that the plane would depart at 10.30 am on Tuesday, technical team kept resolving the issue, forcing passengers to remain at the hotel till the evening.

Airport sources said that the terminal officials have been intimated that the flight would take off at 4 pm. However, that too did not happen. According to officials, the flight may leave Trichy probably at 9 in the night, adding some passengers were accommodated with 8.55-morning flight while others were waiting.

In another development, the Air India Express from Dubai, which was supposed to arrive at Trichy at 12.10 am on Tuesday landed at Trichy airport at 4.10 am a 4 hours delay. The flight should have departed from here at 1 am. However, it took off at 5.20 am, airport sources said.

Title: Rail users forward suggestion ahead of meet
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: The Thanjavur District Rail Users Association has submitted a charter of suggestions to the Southern Railway in the forthcoming railway timetable for the benefits of commuters in Trichy railway division. A two-day All India Railway Time Table conference, to be held on February 27 and 28 in Bengaluru, will discuss changes in the new railway timetable.

One of the suggestions include diverting train 16231/16232 Mayiladuthurai – Mysore express, which is operated with a full capacity between Trichy and KSR Bengaluru, via Namakkal to save running time and eliminating an engine train reversal at Erode.

As there is a huge demand for the train service to Bengaluru and Hubli from delta districts, a new daily express train service between Belagavi and Kumbakonam, Thanjavur via Hubli, KR Puram, Banaswadi, Salem may be introduced.

There exist a long-pending demand for a direct train between Thanjavur and Mumbai CST. Hence a new bi-weekly express train service between Thanjavur and Mumbai CST via Kumbakonam, Villupuram, Arakkonam, Renigunda, Mantralayam Road, Pune may be introduced.

Frequency of the well-patronised trains 16779/16780 Rameswaram – Tirupathi Express may be increased to daily. This will be the restoration of erstwhile daily express train operated during the meter gauge era. Arrival time at Tirupathi may be advanced to reach around 7am.

Timings of train 56113 Mayiladuthurai-Trichy passenger may be suitably changed to connect train 76833 Trichy-Salem DEMU at Trichy.

A new daily day express train to connect Mayiladuthurai, Kumbakonam and Thanjavur with Palani, Pollachi may also be introduced.

Title: One more leopard rescued in Niphad
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The forest department on Monday night rescued a four-year old female leopard at Niphad taluka. This is the third incident of rescuing leopards in last 12 days.

A few days back, the forest department had put up a cage at the farm of Vinayak Gholap near Vadali village in Niphad taluka of Nashik district. On Sunday night, 1.5 year old male leopard was trapped and released next day following medical check-up and procedure.

As villagers had complained that they had spotted three-four leopards in the area, the forest department had replaced the cage with new one there.

Forest officials said the four-year-old female leopard was trapped in the cage on Monday night. “We are in the process of conducting medical check-up of the animal. The leopard is to be released after the medical check-up and following necessary formalities,” the official said.

On February 14, the forest department had rescued a one-and-a-half year old female leopard from the cane farm in Kasbe-Sukhene village in Niphad taluka of the district.

Recently, three cubs of leopards were found in a cane farm in near Shinde-Palse village, near Nashik Road area of the city. While a female leopard had taken two cubs, but had left the third cub there in the farm.

The forest department tried for reunion of mother leopard and her male cub, but mother leopard did not come. Finally, the forest department had sent a cub leopard to Sanjay Gandhi National Park near Mumbai.

Title: Ahmedabad Youth hangs self on lockup bars in presence of cops
Content:
Family members of the victim protesting at Kagdapith

AHMEDABAD: A teenage boy, who put in the lockup at Kagdapith police station, fashioned a noose from his shawl and hanged himself from the top bars of the lockup gate. CCTV footage shows it took nearly 10 minutes till he finally succumbed, at 10.20pm on Monday. Surprisingly, his action did not draw the attention of a single cop in the police station at a relatively busy hour, 10.20pm.The family of the deceased said their son was just 17, but the cops insisted that he was an adult.The suicide has raised serious questions about the functioning and attitude of the police. The foremost question is why was he locked up despite the boy and his family insisting that he was a minor.He was detained under Section 151 of the CrPC after allegedly getting into a scuffle with a resident of Hiralal Chawl in the Raipur area of city.Section 151 allows a police officer to arrest, without orders from a magistrate and without a warrant, a person, if it appears that the commission of an offence cannot be otherwise prevented.“The youth was sitting in an autorickshaw and talking on his phone late on Monday night when the auto-owner objected and they got into a heated argument. The two, then, allegedly assaulted each other but as the auto driver called the police, the cops caught the boy and took him to the police station,” said a police official.Sources in the police said that the cops did not make a station diary entry about his arrest and put him in the lockup. They reportedly threatened to book him under grave charges, which scared him, after which he took the extreme step.As the youth’s family staged angry protests, police suspended the police station officer (PSO) of Kagdapith. “The youth committed suicide by hanging himself from the top bar of the lockup gate. He tore a shawl, which he was allowed for the night, to make a noose and hanged himself,” said Inspector U D Jadeja of Kagdapith police.Jadeja said the deceased was “19 or 20 years” and had been caught for first time, after he fought a neighbour. “We have CCTV footage of the lockup which shows him committing suicide,” said Jadeja.Prakash Jhala, a distant relative of the deceased, said that the youth was born on May 20, 2002.“Even as the youth and his family told the police he was a minor, four cops had first thrashed him near his home. He was again beaten up inside the police station. The cops also threatened to book him under serious charges. The young boy could not bear such humiliation and committed suicide,” said Jhala.The family was informed of the incident half an hour after the youth had hanged himself. The deceased’s family and relatives protested at Kagdapith police station for a day and later at VS Hospital, where the postmortem was conducted.

Title: VCK chief, Jothimani booked
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: The Trichy rural police booked around 3,000 people including VCK MP Thol Thirumavalavan and Congress MP S Jothimani for taking out an anti-CAA (Citizenship Amendment Act) rally without permission at Puthanatham here on Monday.

Acting on a complaint from the village administrative officer, the Puthanatham police registered a case against 18 identified people and 2,982 including 700 women on charges of unlawful assembly, procession, road blockade and demonstration in front of a petrol bunk on Elamanam road.

The protest was organised by the Jamath Nattamai Rahamathullah of Puthanatham, although police had denied permission. They also staged a demonstration where Thirumavalavan and others addressed the gathering. No arrests have been made.tnn

Title: Higher allocation for Godavari cleaning
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nashik: The civic body, in order to effectively deal with pollution of river Godavari and other environment issues, has increased the budget allocation from Rs 1.20 crore allocated for financial year (FY) 2019-20 to over Rs 8 crore for the FY 2020-21.

Bulk of the amount would be used for cleaning Godavari and making it pollution free. The NMC has already set up Godavari conservation cell to deal with river pollution. The civic administration has also proposed monetary fines on erring residents found throwing garbage, washing clothes and vehicles, dumping nirmalya (puja waste) into the river.

While presenting the budget, municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game said special attention is being given on cleaning the river on the stretch between Holkar bridge and Talkuteshwar bridge.

The NMC has also proposed robotic excavator to clean the river and remove silt. The monetary provision has been made in the budget under the Godavari conservation cell. A trash skimmer machine has already been deployed by the civic body for cleaning the river.

Apart from this, another robotic excavator is to be procured to clean Godavari and its three tributaries — Nandini, Waldevei and Wagahdi.

Earlier, the civic administration would clean Godavari manually through a contractor who would remove water hyacinth, filth and other waste from the river.

The one-year term of the contractor is ending on February 29 and the civic administration is not willing to continue with him after the contract ends. Now, mechanical cleaning of Godavari and its tributaries will be carried out.

The NMC has also proposed buying new machines to clean the drainage lines. For this necessary financial provision has been made in the budget.

Title: Councillor’s abuses on SMC staff goes viral
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Surat: Dinesh Kachadiya , Congress councillor from Fulpada has embroiled in a controversy for allegedly abusing a civic body worker over the phone for releasing stray cattle captured by the Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) cattle squad from Varachha.

An audio clip of the Congress councillor went viral on the social media platform on Tuesday. Kachadiya is heard speaking with an female officer of the cattle squad of the SMC in an authoritative language. He uses abusive words demanding immediate release of the stray cow caught by his staff.

When contacted, Kachadiya said, “This audio is about one-and-a-half month old. Those who made it viral have trimmed the conservation and used the portion where I used abusive language with the officer.”

According to Kachadiya, the incident was reported at Kasturbaug Nagar society at Baroda Pristage in Varachha. The cattle squad picked up a stray cow from outside the residential society at about 10 pm. The cow had delivered a calf 15-days-old back. The cattle owner had sought Kachadiya to help release the cow.

“I called the officer to release the cow as it had a 15-days-old calf. Despite of repeated calls, the officers did not released the cow. In the last call, I was so frustrated that I used abusive language,” admitted Kachadiya.

A senior officer of the cattle squad of SMC told TOI, “We have been getting complaints from Varachha and many parts of the city regarding stray cattle. It was a routine work of the squad members. But the councillor used abusive language with our staff member. He did not know about the calf.”

Title: Roadshow diplomacy with world leaders is new trend
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

On Monday, Ahmedabad wore a festive look to host a massive rally in honour of US President Donald Trump

AHMEDABAD: Roadshows by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to honour foreign counterparts has emerged as a new trend in political diplomacy. On Monday, Ahmedabad wore a festive look, its streets all decked with up lights and posters of ‘Namaste Trump’, to host a massive rally in honour of US President Donald Trump .

“The roadshow diplomacy is something new. It speaks of the showmanship of both Trump and Modi. Both believe in hype,” said Ghanshyam Shah, a political expert. The 22km roadshow on Monday by Trump and Modi from Ahmedabad airport to the Motera stadium saw people flocking in large numbers to catch a glimpse of the two world leaders.

Dance groups and singers from several states of India performed on stages dotting the route. Soon after the roadshow, Trump announced that the two countries will soon enter into a $3 billion deal in the defence sector. He said this at the Namaste Trump event at the Motera stadium.

This is not the first time that a world leader has accompanied Modi in a roadshow. In September 2017, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was with Modi on a roadshow that showcased the culture of Indian states.

They had travelled 8.5km to the Sabarmati Ashram in an open vehicle decorated with garlands. Soon after the roadshow, the two prime ministers set the foundation stone for the multi-billion dollar bullet train project, to be undertaken with the financial assistance of Japan.

In January 2018, Modi along with his Israeli counterpart Benjamin Netanyahu embarked on a roadshow from the airport to the Sabarmati Ashram. The Israeli prime minister’s six-day visit has boosted trade ties between the two countries. All the three roadshows by Modi with world leaders were held in Ahmedabad in his home state. Also, two of them were held in an election year. While US goes to polls this year with Trump’s re-election a possibility, the 2017 roadshow with Abe was held in the assembly election year for Gujarat. Also, Japan was up for elections, and Abe won the polls.

Title: MVA govt orders probe into BJP-ruled NMC’s project
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nagpur: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government on Tuesday ordered inquiry into BJP-ruled Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s garbage-to-compost project at Bhandewadi dumping yard. Urban development department minister Eknath Shinde assured action against NMC office-bearers and officials, if found guilty.

On the second day of budget session of the state legislature in Mumbai on Tuesday, West Nagpur MLA and Congress city president Vikas Thakre raised the issue and alleged Rs250 crore loan scam by the project operator Hanjer Biotech Energies Private Ltd and various irregularities by NMC office-bearers and officials.

BJP MLA from Central Nagpur Vikas Kumbhare and six others have also signed the question raised by Thakre.

Replying to the query, Shinde said, “Inquiry will be conducted at the level of divisional commissioner and responsibility will be fixed. Those found guilty will be brought to book, be it office-bearers or officials.”

Thakre claimed that Hanjer has duped Punjab National Bank of Rs250 crore and CBI has already started an inquiry. The project operator availed loans citing garbage projects in Nagpur and other cities. However, it utilized most of the loan amount for other purposes, he claimed.

“Hanjer took a loan of Rs50 crore for Nagpur project though the value of the existing plant at Bhandewadi dumping yard is less than Rs50 lakh. NMC had paid Rs18.89 crore to Hanjer ignoring the fact that the operator could not process even 200 metric tonne (MT) garbage of the total capacity of 600 MT,” he said.

Thakre also said that NMC was supposed to get entire plant free of cost in March this year, but Hanjer, in nexus with NMC officials, removed all machineries from the yard.

“NMC has deposited its share of compensation with the NGT, but Hanjer has not,” he pointed out.

In written reply to the query, Shinde said, “Hanjer had submitted fraud bills of Rs18.89 crore to the NMC and received money. The Nagpur municipal commissioner has informed that the operator has even dismantled the plant and took away all machineries without the permission of the civic body and sold the scrap.”

Shinde also revealed that Hanjer did not operate the plant for 544 days between October 29, 2013 and June 21, 2018, for which the NMC levied a fine of Rs2.11 crore on the operator. “NMC has stopped paying tipping charges of Rs330 per MT to the operator from October 2016 and the civic body has not disbursed Rs1.10 crore to Hanjer,” Shinde said.

Thakre pointed out that NMC general body had constituted a committee to probe the matter. “Even after five months, the committee has not submitted the report. Action including suspension and registration of FIR should be taken against the then mayor, office-bearers and officials,” he demanded.

Title: Wooden box washes ashore near Velankanni, causes flutter
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nagapattinam: A wooden box which washed ashore near Velankanni created a flutter among fishermen on Sunday evening.

The Coastal Security Group (CSG) authorities received information from fishermen that a wooden box had washed ashore at the Seruthur coast.

A team rushed to the spot and retrieved it. They suspected it to contain heroin and informed customs officials in Nagapattinam.

A team from the customs department headed by superintendent S Prem Babu took custody of the box which was partially burned. The powder was sent to Anna University in Nagapattinam for lab test. However, the tests turned negative, officials said. The box contained seashell powder.

Seashell powder costs Rs 4,000 per kilogram and can be used for medicinal purposes, said Prem Babu.

“The powder may have been used to cheat smugglers,” he said.

“This wooden box looks like a hoax. It may have been used to cheat a gang which then threw it away,” another official said.

Smuggling narcotics, particularly ganja to Sri Lanka via Kodiyakarai near Vedaranyam, is not uncommon, official sources said.

Narcotic Control Bureau officials have foiled several bids to smuggle narcotics in and around Kodiyakarai and have detained Sri Lankan nationals.

Title: Civic chief presents draft budget of Rs 2,161.79 crore for FY 2020-21
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) has increased its annual budget for the financial year 2020-21 by Rs 75.43 crore.

Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game on Tuesday submitted a draft budget of Rs 2,161.79 crore to the standing committee of the NMC for approval.

The standing committee will now discuss the proposal during a special meeting to be held on Wednesday. The annual budget of the NMC for the financial year 2019-20 was Rs 2,086.36 crore, and it has been increased by 3.5% for the upcoming fiscal.

“There was a total demand of Rs 3,000 crore from various departments. But we have finalised the budget considering our revenue generation and liabilities. We have projected income of Rs 2,161.79 crore and outlay of Rs 2,160.48 crore, with surplus amount of Rs 1.31 crore during the financial year 2020-21,” Game said.

The major thrust for revenue generation would be on property tax collection and the target has been raised to Rs 148.86 crore. Moreover, the NMC has also increased the water tax collection target to Rs 65 crore.

The draft budget has also increased the outlay for the city bus service by making an allocation of Rs 70 crore — an increase of Rs 48 crore as compared to the present fiscal.

The NMC has planned to deploy 400 CNG, electric and diesel buses in phases and the service is expected to begin from April. The civic body has also formed a special purpose vehicle, Nashik Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Ltd, to monitor the operations of the city bus service.

Presenting the budget, Game said that the budget for the financial year 2020-21 has been prepared based on the necessity of the works, availability of funds and technical approval. “The liabilities of the works already undertaken and expected revenue generation have been considered while preparing the outlay budget,” he said.

“Focus has been given to improve city’s road connectivity. The missing links on ring roads and major roads are to be developed. Moreover, tarring of macadamised roads is to be done,” he added.

The budget also includes necessary provisions for constructing bridges on nullahs and canals in 22 villages falling under the jurisdiction of the municipal corporation. These villages were included in NMC’s development plan for the city over two decade ago.

The budget includes provision of buying two road sweeping machines, developing new bus depot at Adgaon Naka and Tapovan at a cost of Rs 40 crore, provision of Rs 135.33 crore to improve sewage treatment network and build new sewer lines, Rs 35 crore to develop new sports grounds in all six divisions along with other sports-related activities.

The budget also includes provision of Rs 24.23 crore for the garden department. The civic body has also proposed renovation of projects like Dadasaheb Phalke Smarak.

Title: NMC begins razing Ambekar’s famed ‘Rs10 crore bungalow’
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nagpur: The sprawling 10,000 square feet land at Darodkar chowk on which tea boy-turned-don Santosh Ambekar’s constructed a mansion valued at Rs10 crore was partially demolished by the enforcement wing of the Nagpur municipal corporation (NMC) on Tuesday.

The demolition of the remaining part of the structure will continue on Wednesday. Nearly 8,640 sq feet of the don’s den was constructed illegally.

This is round two of the demolition process carried out by NMC.

In the first leg that took place on December 4 last year, the top storey and a shop on the ground floor of Ambekar’s another four-storeyed property, ‘Athawan’, also at Darodkar chowk, were demolished.

Ambekar and his close aides were arrested in October last year for duping and threatening a Gujarat-based businessman. At least 13 offences were registered against Ambekar following various complaints since October last year. He was also booked for the fifth time under Maharashtra control of organized crime Act (MCOCA).

NMC sources told TOI that Ambekar constructed the bungalow on the lines of Rajput-style architecture. He illegally amalgamated three plots and also took unauthorized possession of a part of a garden as well as a portion of the land meant for a gymnasium.

As per the records, Ambekar had clubbed the plots owned by him, his wife Neha and one Amarchand Mehta to construct the bungalow. The don had carried out illegal construction on 7,766 sq feet land owned by Mehta, 651 sq feet of construction on Neha’s plot and more than 226 sq feet construction on the plot owned by him. The three plots were earmarked for demolition.

Asst municipal commissioner of NMC’s enforcement department, Ashok Patil, stated that a notice was served to Ambekar on December 16 last year under relevant sections of the Maharashtra Slum Areas (Improvement, Clearance And Redevelopment) Act, 1971. “The notice of demolition was challenged and an appeal was filed but it was subsequently vacated on February 24 this year. The occupants had claimed that there was a second appeal but no documents were produced,” he said.

Earlier in the day, Ambekar’s family feebly tried to convince Patil that there was an appeal filed by their advocate. Ambekar’s son Sanchit, who is in his early 20s, showed Patil some documents but had to relent later as the NMC officer said they lacked substance to halt action. Patil was accompanied by enforcement inspector Sanjay Kamble and other staffers from NMC’s Gandhibagh Zone.

Senior PI Narendra Hiware of Lakadganj police station, API Pankaj Dharge of crime branch and other officials were present with sizeable manpower. Women cops had to be deployed as Ambekar’s wife Neha and other relatives were present.

Hiware said that adequate time was given to the Ambekar family to produce documents to stop the NMC action but nothing concrete was produced.

Two JCB excavators and a poclaine machine were pressed into action after a delay of around one-and-half hours. Till sunset, a substantial portion of the bungalow was demolished from the northern side.

Title: Duo held after 2 yrs for killing couple
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Trichy: A probe into the double murder of a couple brought to light the role of two youngsters in the murder for gain incident nearly two years ago. The duo was also involved in the murder of one of their younger brothers in 2017.

A special team from the Siruganur police station attached to the Trichy district police arrested S Kishanth, 21, an engineering graduate from Chathiramanai in Perambalur district and K Palaniasamy, 21, from Vaalaiyur in Trichy district for murdering A Ramesh, 37, and his wife R Latha, 38 on April 23, 2018. A two-wheeler, a gold chain, ring and Rs 3,000 cash were stolen from the house.

Though six police teams carried out the probe, the case remained untraceable for nearly two years. Deputy inspector general of police, Trichy range V Balakrishnan and superintendent of police, Trichy Zia Ul Haq insisted the investigation officers on cracking the case at the earliest.

Accordingly, deputy superintendent of police (DSP), Samayapuram A Rajasekar, Siruganur inspector Manivannan and their team took up the probe. A three-member team visited police stations in several districts to check if there was any trace of Ramesh’s stolen bike. A probe by a constable of the special team at Veppur police station in Cuddalore district found that a bike involved in a road accident was seized there. The constable found the number plate mentioned in Tamil and he checked the chassis and engine numbers with that of Ramesh’s stolen bike. Further inquiry revealed that Kishanth and his friend P Manikandan, 21 of Sengunam in Perambalur had met with the accident when they were travelling from Puducherry to Perambalur few months after murdering the couple.

The special team picked up Kishanth and inquired with him. During inquiry, Kishanth revealed that his craving for a new bike prompted him to conspire with Palanisamy to steal Ramesh’s new vehicle. As planned, the duo went to Ramesh’s house and attempted to enter the house. Ramesh and Latha woke up but the duo clobbered them on their head with a steel rod. They took the valuables and the bike.

“Their intention was to just lift the bike and not to murder them. The accused were under the impression that couple were unconscious. They came to know about their deaths later and absconded after changing the number plate in Tamil. The police teams probed from several angles but there was no headway until the bike was identified,” DSP Rajasekar told TOI.

While Palanisamy enrolled in a degree course, Kishanth was working in Puducherry. Inquiry with Palanisamy revealed that he had also murdered his younger brother K Perumal, 18, in 2017. Kishanth had aided Palanisamy in the murder. The Siruganur police had closed the case as suspicious death as his decomposed body was found floating in a water body and the postmortem also could not establish anything. Now, police arrested the duo in this case also.

Police produced the accused in the Lalgudi court on Tuesday, which remanded them in judicial custody. The stolen valuables were recovered.

Title: Plea to complete smart city work before Chittirai fest
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: Expedite the ongoing smart city works or put it on hold till the Chithirai festival concludes, urge city merchants and traders to the Madurai corporation.

Secretary of the Tamil Nadu Textile Merchants Association, Ashraf Yusuf said that the four Masi Streets, and Mahal Vadampokki Streets near the Meenakshi temple had been dug up for various works. “The unplanned and slow pace at which the work is undertaken is causing heavy loss to the traders, especially the textile traders,” he said.

The pits and holes dug up are so deep in the Masi Streets that the people are afraid of walking on those streets. “A fall in these roads could prove fatal for elderly people,” said Kumaran S a resident of Vadampokki Street. It was also because UGD, rainwater harvesting systems and road laying works are being carried out simultaneously.

Yusuf said that the dust particles are settling on their goods, making it difficult for the traders to even showcase their goods. “The four Masi Streets is the go-to place for the denizens for all their needs be it grocery, notebooks, electrical gadgets, electronics, hardware, paints, textiles, garments and jewellery. Now all these shops are facing a loss due to the ongoing works.

The four Masi Streets around Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple, frequented by tourists is now full of iron rods and cement slabs, posing danger especially in the evenings. Thousands of hawkers and roadside vendors are also affected by the dust from these works and their livelihood has been badly affected for the past 75 days, he said.

Traders say that the corporation should take steps to complete at least the road works before the Chittirai festival which will begin in the month of April. Lakhs of people come to the temple during these 15 to 20 days and they would be inconvenienced. Also, the car festival would also be held on these streets. TNN

Title: Laughter yoga for NMC school teachers
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: In a bid to release the stress of teachers and students of the Nashik Municipal (NMC) schools, mayor Satish Kulkarni came up with a laughter yoga initiative. The NMC organised a laughter yoga workshop for its school teachers at the Kalidas Kala Mandir and it was attended by nearly 300 teachers.

In the two-hour workshop, the teachers were told about the importance of laughing and how it can make them free of stress, which, in turn, can improve teacher-student interaction.

“Teacher-student relationship has a life-long impact on a child. We want this relationship to be healthy. If the teachers are stress-free, they will be able to help the students better. Laughing plays a vital role. A happy teacher will make a happy student,” said Devidas Mahajan, the NMC education officer.

The civic body is planning to hold more such workshops. A plan to gather 10,000 students in a big school ground and conduct a laughter yoga workshop with them is also afoot, said Mahajan.

After learning laughter yoga at the workshop, the teachers will be able to squeeze in a 10-minute session for the students in their daily school schedule.

Nitin Nandkar, a teacher at NMC School No. 49, said, “The students cannot sit down and listen even for 15 minutes. We learnt today that if they laugh out the carbon dioxide, their minds will be able to concentrate effectively and their capacity to be attentive in the class will increase.”

Manisha Chaudhary, a teacher from NMC School No. 10, said, “We are always in some or the other sort of stress. If we laugh, our body releases happy hormones (endorphins). We need to tell this to our students also that laughter is the best medicines.”

Title: CJ lauds seven advocates who emerged as pioneers
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Madurai: Lauding seven advocates who have completed 50 years in the profession, Chief Justice of the Madras high court, A P Sahi said that they have emerged as pioneers and have shown the path to others.

The Chief Justice felicitated the seven advocates - R Janakiramalu, M Patturajan, K Sree Kumaran Nair, V K Vijayaraghavan, K Srinivasan, M S Balasubramania Iyer and N Balakrishnan at an event organised by the Madurai Bench of Madras High Court Bar Associations (MMBA) on the court premises here on Tuesday evening.

In his felicitation address, Chief Justice Sahi said the members of the bar are fortunate to have people with such accomplishments. He said the lesson which other advocates should take is the dedication, experience and vision of these people who have emerged as pioneers despite the difficulties they faced. He stated that the service of these advocates to the society have been rightly rewarded today.

Earlier, the Chief Justice unveiled and garlanded a portrait of former President of India A P J Abdul Kalam at MMBA hall.

The administrative judge of the high court Madurai bench justice M Duraiswamy and other sitting judges were present during the event. President of MMBA N Krishnaveni welcomed the gathering and general secretary of MMBA N Ilango proposed the vote of thanks.

Title: Dozens of trees chopped off to widen approach to bridge
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

SMC officials said that transplantation of the trees was not possible

SURAT: Dozens of trees were chopped off by the Surat Municipal Corporation ’s (SMC) town planning department for the widening of the main road connecting the upcoming Pal-Umara river bridge in Umara on Tuesday.

The road alignment work was taken up a week back. The road is being widened to 80-feet till the approach end of the bridge in Umara.

On Tuesday, dozens of full-grown trees lined up on both the side of the main road opposite Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT) were chopped off by SMC workers for road widening.

Sources said there are more than 150 trees that would be chopped off under the road widening project.

Talking with TOI, garden superintendent, Dr S J Gautam said, “There is no other alternative but to chop the trees. We will be removing all the trees falling under the road alignment.”

Dr Gautam added, “The transplantation of the trees is not possible as there are lot of underground utility lines including water, natural gas, electricity etc. We will be taking up massive tree plantation drive on both the sides of the road once the widening project is completed.”

An environment activist asking anonymity said, “The civic body is doing work hastily to take up the construction of the Pal-Umara bridge at the cost of hundreds of trees.”

Title: Letter threatens to burn Kerala HC judge alive if church is given to Orthodox faction
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Kerala high court (File Photo)

KOCHI: A high court judge, on Tuesday, said he had received a letter, threatening to burn him alive if he ordered to hand over the Kothamangalam church to the Orthodox faction.

Justice P B Suresh Kumar revealed the receipt of the threat while pulling up Ernakulam district collector for not implementing the court’s order.

Justice Kumar said he won’t mind being burnt alive, but the court’s order should be implemented. The court registry has handed over the letter to the police.

Earlier, the court summoned district collector S Suhas and criticized him for not implementing its order to take over Kothamangalam church and hand it over to the Orthodox faction.

Justice Kumar criticized the collector after noticing his absence despite a directive on a contempt of court case filed by the Orthodox faction. The contempt case was filed by Orthodox priest Thomas Paul Ramban through advocate Roshen D Alexander.

During the morning session, the contempt of court case was listed as the first one to be heard. On noticing the collector’s absence, the judge directed that he must be present within five minutes.

The collector reached the court after around 15 minutes, and explained that earnest efforts were taken to implement the order but it failed as one of the factions opposed and some of them threatened to commit suicide if it was implemented. He also sought two more months to implement the order.

Pointing out that there was no stay on the order, the court said it could not allow the time the collector had sought.

The court also criticized that even though the collector was liable to implement the order, he was not viewing the matter seriously. Delaying the implementation of the court’s order by referring to suicide threats was equal to showing disrespect to the court. Though many days had passed since the order was issued, the state government had not done anything to implement it, the court said.

Further, the court said physical strength of some had become successful now and the inability to implement the court’s order was a shame for the state police. It shows the breakdown of law and order machinery.

Non-implementation of the court’s orders would result in people losing faith in the judiciary and would lead to collapse of the justice-delivery system, the court said. As the state government and the police had failed to implement the order, the court could direct central forces to carry out the order. It could also jail the collector as part of contempt of court proceedings, the judge said, while reserving the contempt of court case for pronouncing orders.

Title: Four of a family get life term for twin murders
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: District and sessions judge SA Ali on Tuesday sentenced four of a family to life imprisonment for the murder of Imrat Rana and his brother Puranlal in Samta Nagar in June 2016.

The murder had triggered a law and order problem in North Nagpur , including crowd chaos at Jaripatka police station. Police had to resort to lathicharge to disperse the dissenters.

The foursome convicted for the murders under section 302 and rioting under section 149 of the Indian penal code (IPC) were identified as Prashant Chamke, Zanak Tomaskar, his son Ankush and son-in-law Shivmohan Malik. They will also face an additional one year of imprisonment if they fail to pay the Rs2,000 fine.

The court also convicted them under section 304 (II) for culpable homicide not amounting to murder and also 149 sentencing them to imprisonment for up to five years and also a fine of Rs1,000. In case of a default, they would face an additional jail term.

Under section 143 of the IPC for unlawful assembly, the four have been slapped with three months of imprisonment and a fine of Rs500. Another one year of imprisonment and a fine of Rs100 was slapped on the foursome under section 148 of the IPC for rioting armed with deadly weapons.

Zanak’s wife Meena and her aide, Vandana Jais, too have been convicted under section 323 of the IPC for simple assault with an imprisonment of one month and fine Rs500.

Additional public prosecutor Nitin Telgote, who is also the government pleader, said there were 18 witnesses in the case who were examined during the trial. “A seven-year-old girl from the neighbourhood and Imrat’s wife Sunita were the prime witnesses who deposed before the court. These eyewitnesses proved to be the turning points in the case,” he said.

Telgote added that the case had plenty of evidence which led to the conviction.

The court also stated that the period of the life imprisonment would be adjusted against the span of time which the convicts have already spent in prison following the method of set-off under criminal procedure code (CrPC). The convicts were arrested by Jaripatka police immediately after the murder.

Vandana and Sunita had been asked by the court to surrender their bail bonds.

Title: Vidarbha loan waiver bill may be over Rs 6,300 crore
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: As the exercise begins to implement loan waiver scheme of the MVA government, the initial data shows that defaults in Vidarbha may easily exceed Rs 6300 crore. This relates to over 9 lakh loan accounts that have turned NPAs.

The MVA waiver scheme, named after social reformer Jyotiba Phule, covers loans that have been granted between April 2015 and March 31, 2019, and are overdue as on September 30, 2019.

A compilation of figures from banks shows that farm loans to the tune of Rs5,520 crore have been defaulted in the six districts that have been declared as farm crisis hit. On account of high farmers’ suicides, the districts of Akola, Amravati , Yavatmal, Buldhana, Washim, and Wardha are under special watch and have the crisis-hit tag.

The number of defaults in terms of amount is highest in Buldhana which has even surpassed Yavatmal — the district that has otherwise topped farm crisis list. In Buldhana, over 1.98 lakh farmers’ accounts have turned NPAs for loans worth more than Rs1,412 crore. The number of accounts and farmers can vary because each farmer can have more than one farm account.

This is followed by Amravati where 1.39 lakh farmers’ accounts are under defaulters’ list for loans to the tune of Rs1,250 crore. Yavatmal ranks fourth in the list with 1.08 lakh farmers’ accounts and Rs754 crore of defaults.

Gadchiroli has the lowest number with defaults worth Rs81 crore from over 16,600 loan accounts. Nagpur, on the other hand, has 4,900 NPA accounts having loans to the tune of over Rs300 crore.

The numbers will vary as the amounts will have to be confirmed by the farmers. In case of a dispute, the case will be referred to a committee.

The first list from two villages from each district of the state was released on Monday. These villages have been taken on pilot basis. “If no hassles are found in the initial list, then work would start on a full-scale bass by this month end,” said sources.

The current waiver scheme covers loans till an upper limit of Rs2 lakh. The scheme, named after Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and launched during BJP-led government, had covered loans up to Rs1.50 lakh. For a higher amount, a one-time settlement (OTS) scheme was put in place. Under this, the farmer had to pay an additional amount and get a waiver for up to Rs1.5 lakh.

A number of farmers with loans more than Rs1.5 lakh could not avail of the OTS. Some of those farmers can now directly avail the new waiver scheme.

While the current scheme covers loans granted from April 2015 to March 2019, the earlier scheme covered loans from 2002 till March 2016 that have been overdue as on June 2017.

“The farmers who had availed loans from 2015 to 2019 but could not avail the OTS can now be directly covered under the fresh waiver plan if their loans are within Rs2 lakh,” said a source..

Title: 32,000 students to get degrees at VNSGU’s 51st convocation
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Highest number of students who will be receive the degrees are from commerce faculty

SURAT: Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) will award degrees to over 32,000 students at its 51st annual convocation to be held here on Wednesday. Kapil Dev , former captain of Indian cricket team, will be the chief guest at the convocation to be presided over by Acharya Devvrat, governor of Gujarat and chancellor of the university. Poet Rajesh Reddy will be the guest of honour.

About 150 students will be awarded gold medals by Kapil Dev for securing highest marks in different subjects at the event to be held in VNSGU convention hall.

Highest number of students who will be receive the degrees are from commerce faculty. Their number is around 9,181 and they are pursuing 11 different courses in the commerce faculty. About 8,892 students of 23 courses of arts faculty will also receive their degrees along with 568 students of 32 courses of medicine faculty and 6,619 from faculty of science.

Only one student from the faculty of engineering will be awarded degree since majority of engineering students have migrated to Gujarat Technological University .

"The convocation address by Kapil Dev is main attraction. He will inspire the fresh graduates to achieve their goals in life," said a university official.

"Students are advised to take their seats before 10.30am in the convention hall. They will have to complete the formalities before arriving in the convention hall. The office staff will start work from early morning in the administrative block," the official added.

Title: Nagpur: Released convicts to soon get help setting up industries
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

NAGPUR: In a small beginning towards rehabilitating convicts who have served their jail terms, the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Institute (MSME-DI), Nagpur, is planning a scheme to help such persons set up industries after being released from jails.

The MSME-DI, which comes under the Union ministry of MSMEs, has written to the director general (DG) prisons in the state to share data of inmates who have been released in last one year and are living in Nagpur and nearby places.

“Usually, it is very difficult for former prisoners to get back into the main stream after they complete the sentence. The stigma means they cannot get jobs, and they are also susceptible to commit crimes again due to that. Self-employment can be the best option in such cases,” said MM Parlewar, director of MSME-DI. This would be the first ever scheme from an industry related department purely for rehabilitation of former prisoners.

“The idea was conceived in Nagpur and simultaneously I have also registered for PhD research on the subject — rehabilitating inmates by helping them set up industries. There are plans to start the initiative in Nagpur as a pilot project. Once it succeeds, the model may be put forward for implementation in other parts of the country too,” said Parlewar.

Parlewar plans to put up the research thesis itself as a proposal document before the ministry for adopting the model elsewhere in the country once it succeeds in Nagpur.

MSME-DI will select potential candidates from lists provided by the prisons department. Initially, it may be a limited number of inmates, but that number would increase eventually, he said.

There are some prisoners who may have taken up work involving specific skills during the sentence. For them, the process can start immediately. Others would be imparted skill development training too, he said.

Funds may be arranged through banks or other government schemes. In case the promoter has to bring in some initial capital, there are plans to arrange it through sponsors, he said.

The idea is to begin with cottage industries for inmates, as it would not require much capital investment. Moreover, the skills acquired during the prison term can also be utilized in such industries, he said.

Title: Tamil Nadu's Q branch joins cartridge case probe
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Pakistan-made live cartridges were found at Muppathadi bridge in Kulathupuzha

KOLLAM: The anti-terror squad ( ATS ) probing the incident involving the finding of Pakistan-made cartridges at Muppathadi bridge, Kulathupuzha, have questioned a Tamil Nadu-based Malayali poultry farm owner who is residing at Kulathupuzha on Tuesday.

The ATS team led by DIG Anoop Kuruvilla John interrogated the poultry farm owner in view of finding a Tamil Nadu state electricity board’s consumer bill from near the abandoned cartridges. The poultry farm owner told investigators that the bill might have fallen there when he came out of his vehicle to take a break. After a detailed interrogation, he was let go.

Police have collected several CCTV footages of the road where the bullets were found and several other places on the Thiruvananthapuram-Shenkottai road.

The TN Q branch is also investigating the incident in view of the murder of Wilson, a sub-inspector of TN police on the Kerala border near Kaliyikkavila by terror elements on January 9. The investigators have come to the conclusion that the cartridges must have been dropped at Muppathadi after February 4.

The investigating team has decided to collect information on ex-servicemen to ascertain whether they have links with terrorist organizations. The investigators held an evaluation meeting at Kulathupuzha. Senior officers who attended the meeting expressed confidence that they could zero in on the culprits soon.
