Title: Official docs to use the word, differently-abled
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

T’puram: The government has directed all department heads and officials to avoid using handicapped/disabled in government documents, brochures, websites and programmes. Instead, it has been directed to use words like differently abled or persons with disabilities in all official documents.

The directive came from the state commissionerate for persons with disabilities. The commissionerate is a statutory body constituted under the Persons with Disabilities Act, 1995 .

The main function of the commissionerate is monitoring the implementation of the Act in the state. The commissionerate is a semi-judicial body that can exercise the power of a civil court under Section 63 of the Act for the redressal of the grievances of the persons with disabilities.

Title: Coastal zone plan: State to map all bunds, sluice gates
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Panaji: The state government has directed the department of settlement and land records (DSLR) to map all bunds and sluice gates across the state and furnish the details to the National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management (NCSCM) to prepare the draft coastal zone management plan (CZMP).

The environment department issued the direction to the DSLR, after the National Coastal Zone Management Authority (NCZMA) recently accepted the state government’s request to demarcate the high tide line (HTL) along bunds and not around mangroves in khazan lands for the coastal plan.

A senior officer said that though a time limit has not been set to complete the work, mapping of bunds will be done soon.

The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed NCSCM, the Chennai-based agency entrusted with drawing up the plan, to submit the final draft to the Union environment ministry by March 31 after a public hearing. It added that the final notification must be issued before April 30, an official said.

The senior officer said that the environment department has written to the agriculture department’s soil division and to the water resources department to support DSLR with maps and other documents required to map bunds and sluice gates. The officer said the suggestions made by village panchayats and municipalities have been forwarded to NCSCM, but as the government has convinced the NCZMA to demarcate the high tide line (HTL) along bunds, these suggestions become null and void.

Title: Centre approves new tax tribunal bench in Uttarakhand
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CM Rawat to inaugurate bench

DEHRADUN: Union ministry of law and justice has approved to set up a circuit bench of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) in Uttarakhand . The body is scheduled to be inaugurated on February 27 by chief minister Trivendra Rawat .

Officials said that the bench will settle/clear income tax appeals pending in the hill state. The bench will also help tax professionals, lawyers, and chartered accountants as it will open new job opportunities for them.

As per official sources, the circuit bench will have jurisdiction on all appeals and application in the field of direct taxes from Uttarakhand.

City-based finance and taxation professionals welcomed the move of starting the bench. “The circuit bench will go a long way in helping litigants to settle their cases right here in the city instead of traveling far,” said Shishir Gupta, a city-based charted accountant.

Traders and businesspersons also termed the initiative as one which was long pending.

“The setting up of ITAT will help traders and also benefit the students of accountancy and finances as they will be able to get more job opportunities. People would not need to hire Delhi-based CAs anymore,” said Dinesh Semwal, a city-based trader.

Title: Five swine flu cases confirmed in Uttrakhand
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: The state health department confirmed eight swine flu cases on Tuesday. Among these cases, three patients are from the neighboring districts of Uttar Pradesh (UP) and the rest are from Haridwar and Dehradun districts in Uttarakhand.

Dr Pankaj Singh, who works in the office of director general (DG) health, told TOI that the state had sent 44 samples for diagnosis of swine flu to a laboratory in New Delhi. "We have received the reports of 26 patients. Among these, eight patients were diagnosed with the disease. Five of them are from Uttarakhand and the other three are from UP. These cases were reported from January first week to February second week," he said while adding that an advisory for the hospitals was already sent by the DG health which includes formation of isolation wards and ensuring proper stock of medicines.

Talking about preventive measures to check the spread of the disease, Dr Singh said that people must cover their nose as the H1N1 virus spreads by droplet infection. “Swine flu is a form of influenza which is curable but the virus can prove fatal in case of diabetics, children and the elderly. We advise people to opt for early treatment and avoid contact with people when its symptoms are detected. One should immediately consult a doctor in case of consistent fever and breathlessness,” he added.

Title: UP: Aligarh turns into fortress, 13 companies of RAF and PAC deployed
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nine companies of PAC and four companies of RAF along with three additional SPs, eight deputy SPs and eight st... Read More

AGRA: Mobile Internet services remained suspended in Aligarh on second day running on Tuesday and parts of the city were manned by a large number of security personnel in the wake of Sunday’s clash, and violence in Delhi. Sunday night’s clashes between anti-CAA protesters and policemen had left eight injured.

Superintendent of police (crime) Arvind Kumar said, “Nine companies of PAC and four companies of RAF along with three additional SPs, eight deputy SPs and eight station house officers (SHO) of neighbouring districts have been deployed in the city as a precautionary measure.”

Internet services are shut in the city since Sunday night and will remain suspended till the situation improves. However, administrative officials said that it may be restored by Wednesday morning, if all goes well.

Nearly 2,000 women sat on ‘dharna’ in Aligarh’s Kawarsi bypass and blocked the traffic to protest against CAA and NRC on Tuesday. Anti-CAA protesters at Shahjamal, Jamalpur area and Chungi Gate of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) have already been protesting for the past many days.

The protesting women threatened to continue their protest till the CAA is withdrawn by the government.

In view of tense situation in the city, ADG (Agra zone) Ajay Anand is camping in the city. Anand told TOI that in view of the violent incidents in Delhi and Aligarh, he will be monitoring the situation and will hold a dialogue with leaders of both the communities to develop confidence and restore normalcy in the city.

“Miscreants are being identified and legal action will be taken against them. Besides, flag marches were conducted by police in the sensitive areas of the city. We will also dispel fear about CAA and educate them,” he added.

Most shops in the minority-dominated localities, including Upper Kot and Jiwangarh, remained closed on Tuesday. But, shops in other parts of the city reopened. Police have booked more than 350 people in connection with the arson and group clashes that took place in the city on Sunday evening.

FIRs were registered under various sections of IPC including section 153 A (Promoting enmity between different groups on ground of religion), 307 (attempt to murder). About 100 people have been identified and 40 of them are named in the FIRs, said police.

Title: Angry Char Dham priests issue ‘apocalypse’ warning
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Priests of Kedarnath (above), Badrinath, Gangotri and Yamunotri shrines have warned pilgrims not to visit the ... Read More

DEHRADUN/NANITAL: Angry at the Char Dham Devsthanam Management Act that the state assembly recently passed and which gives control of around 50 temples including the four Char Dham shrines to the Uttarakhand government, priests of Kedarnath, Badrinath, Gangotri and Yamunotri have warned pilgrims not to visit the holy sites as they “might witness something worse than the 2013 tragedy”. Seven years ago, massive floods had ravaged the hill state.

The priests' warning came during the annual practice of Char Dham priests travelling across the country to visit devotees when portals of the temples are closed during winter.

The priests have alleged that the state government is playing with people’s faith. On Tuesday, Shiv Prakash, chief priest (rawal) of the Gangotri temple in Uttarkashi , told TOI, “By taking over the temples through this law, the state government is playing with religion and people’s faith. If they don’t quash the law, something worse than the 2013 floods will happen.” He has already visited Gujarat, Rajasthan, and Delhi to persuade people to not visit Char Dham shrines this year in protest against the shrine board law. He will be travelling to Assam next.

Rajesh Semwal, another priest from the Gangotri shrine, told TOI that if the state government doesn’t retract the law, the priests will boycott temple rituals this year and pilgrims won’t be able to offer prayers. “If the priests boycott rituals, the yatra of pilgrims will remain incomplete,” he said, adding that the government’s move doesn’t send a positive message to pilgrims.

This came even as senior BJP leader and Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy moved the Uttarakhand high court on Tuesday against the newly passed Act. Following this, the HC has given the state government three weeks’ time to respond to Swamy’s PIL.

“The division bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma heard arguments from both sides and directed the government to file their responses within three weeks,” Swamy said. He also demanded that the court put a stay on the Act.

Lawyers appearing for the government, including advocate general SN Babulkar and chief standing counsel Paresh Tripathi, have defended the Act and said it has been passed following the country’s Constitution and that the petition is based on a "political stunt" and therefore should be quashed.

The Char Dham Yatra this year will start from the last week of April with the portals of Gangotri and Yamunotri opening on April 26, followed by those of Kedarnath and Badrinath subsequently.

Title: Stern line on Islamabad: Ensure no terror activity in territory
Content:
President Trump (L) shakes hands with PM Modi during a joint press conference at Hyderabad House. (AFP photo)

NEW DELHI: While the India-US joint statement seemed to carry an abridged version of the condemnation of cross-border terrorism when the leaders met in 2017, it was unequivocal in condemning the menace as PM Narendra Modi and President Donald Trump denounced any use of terrorist proxies and called on Pakistan to ensure no territory under its control is used to launch terror attacks.While the statement slammed “cross-border terrorism’’ in all its forms and also named terror groups like Jaish-e- Mohammed and Lashkar-e-Toiba supported by Pakistan against India, it also noted concerns regarding China. India and the US spoke of efforts towards a meaningful Code of Conduct in the South China Sea and “solemnly urged that it not prejudice the legitimate rights and interests of all nations according to international law’’.Soon after Modi assumed office in 2014, after his first summit with then president Barack Obama, India for the first time mentioned the South China Sea dispute in a bilateral document with the US. This happened again after Obama’s visit to India in early 2015. In 2017 though, the countries dropped the mention even though they reiterated the importance of respecting freedom of navigation, overflight and commerce throughout the region.The joint statement called on Pakistan to ensure that no territory under its control is used to launch terrorist attacks and to expeditiously bring to justice the perpetrators of such attacks, including 26/11 and Pathankot. It also called for concerted action against all terrorist groups including al-Qaida, IS, Jaish-e-Mohammad, Lashkar-e-Toiba, Hizb-ul Mujahideen, the Haqqani Network , TTP, D-Company and all their affiliates.This is significant for India as it has sought similar condemnation from all world leaders, particularly the mention of cross-border terrorism, after high-level talks. Trump had in his speech in Ahmedabad on Monday and again at Hyderabad House on Tuesday said the US is working with Pakistan to confront terrorists and their ideology. He also added that his country enjoyed a very good relationship with Pakistan.Unlike last time though, the leaders did not affirm their support for a UN Comprehensive Convention on International Terrorism that, as they said in 2017, will advance and strengthen the framework for global cooperation and reinforce the message that no cause or grievance justifies terrorism.Also missing was the pledge as was done last time to work together to prevent proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems and to deny access to such weapons to terrorists and non-state actors.In his speech at the Hyderabad House, where he hosted Trump, Modi said cooperation between India and the US at the global level was founded on democratic values and objectives, especially in the Indo-Pacific region and other global commons. In a dig at China, he also said India and the US agreed on the importance of “sustainable and transparent financing’’ in the development of connectivity infrastructure across the world.

Title: Six impersonators caught taking UP Board exam
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Agra: Just two days after deputy CM Dinesh Sharma, who also holds the education portfolio, had visited Firozabad and claimed that UP is now free from rigged board examination, six impersonators were caught on Tuesday while writing the mathematics paper.

Three of them were caught at DSSM Inter College, Jajumai, one at Garg Inter College, Itaura, and two were caught at Mahraja Singh Baghel Inter College by SDM Ekta Singh. According to education department sources, all the six were booked under IPC 420 (cheating) and provisions of the examination Act.

“Out of the six, one impersonator was writing the exam for his younger brother,” said police.

Ritu Goyal, district inspector of school, said, “The invigilators appointed for the board examination have been given clear instructions to verify the admit card with available photo and Aadhaar card of the student. If there is any discrepancy, the student won’t be allowed to write the examination. The impersonators caught have to be booked and handed over to the police.”

Earlier, on February 22, 17 impersonators were caught while writing the English paper. Till date, 25,686 students have appeared in the examination in Firozabad district out of 29,583 candidates. A total of 3,897 have remained absent.

Title: Dual meter for 15,000 Ghaziabad factories
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

GHAZIABAD: Pashchimanchal Vidyut Vitaran Nigam Limited (PVVNL) plans to install double power meters for 15,000 small factories across Ghaziabad in an attempt to track irregularities.

Apart from the existing meter, another one would be installed at an electric pole where a factory’s supply feeder is set up. The readings of both would be tallied every month. An agency has been hired to monitor the meters.

PVVNL chief engineer Rakesh Kumar said: “We’ve implemented the system in 5,000 factories having load of over 25 kW. Now, we’re going to focus on 15,000 factories with load between 10 and 25 kW.” He said the step was taken after several cases of power theft came. “Detecting thefts manually or through surprise raids is a cumbersome process. So, the scheme of double metering has been introduced,” he said.

Title: On HC order, cops involved in violence on AMU campus to be identified
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University (File Photo)

AGRA: Complying with Allahabad high court directive, the ADG ( Agra zone) held a meeting of senior police officers in Aligarh on Tuesday and started the process of identifying the policemen who had allegedly smashed motorcycles and caned apprehended students on Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) campus on the night of December 15 last year.

Talking with TOI, ADG (Agra zone) Ajay Anand said a meeting of senior officials in Aligarh, including DIG and SSP, was conducted on Tuesday to decide on action to be taken against policemen involved in campus violence.

Welcoming the court’s directions, AMU students said finally it has been proved that students were subjected to brutal violence. The court directed the UP government to compensate students.

“It is time for police to accept the responsibility and take stringent action against those policemen who brutalized AMU students,” said Salman Imtiaz, former president of the AMU Students’ Union. He said, now, UP Police and RAF officers must be taken to task in accordance with the law.

“The court’s directive has proved that UP police behaved in an unprofessional manner and must be trained for good policing. It is now clear that police have abused the law, therefore all charges against AMU students in multiple farcical FIRs must be immediately withdrawn,” said Imtiaz.

The former student leader said the court’s verdict has exposed the lies of UP chief minister who recently accused students of violence on the campus. He alleged, “It was not students but the Yogi’s forces who vandalized the properties and injured innocent students. His statement in the assembly must be expunged from the records and he must apologize for misleading the nation and lying from a constitutional post.”

Demanding the resignations of AMU vice-chancellor and registrar, the students, who are protesting against CAA/NRC/NPR on the campus, said they two should take responsibility and quit immediately. They said they would intensify their stir in case the two did not resign on their own.

AMU spokesperson Rahat Abrar said the varsity welcomes the court’s order and added all evidence, including CCTV footage, will be provided to the high court and the compliance report will be submitted in the court.

A day earlier, the court had directed all concerned to adhere to the recommendations of the National Human Right Commission (NHRC). On January 8, 2020, the high court had asked NHRC to conduct an inquiry into the matter. Thereafter, a six-member team conducted a probe and the commission accepted the report. Later, a copy of the report was sent to the high court.

The bench asked the NHRC to ensure that its recommendations were followed by the Uttar Pradesh and central governments. The high court has sought a compliance report and listed the the next hearing on March 25.

Title: Man loses Rs 61,330 to claim free shoes in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An employee of the Central Ordnance Depot in Dehu Road lost Rs61,330 to online fraudsters on January 8 when he tried to avail a free pair of shoes as promised in an offer on an e-commerce website.

The Dehu Road police on Monday registered an offence under Section 420 (cheating and dishonestly, inducing delivery of property) of the Indian Penal Code and he relevant sections of the Information and Technology Act.

An officer from the Dehu Road police said the complainant came across an advertisement on an e-commerce website in December, which offered a free pair of shoes on the purchase of a pair.

“After placing the order, the complainant got the delivery of one pair of shoes on January 7,” the officer said.

He said the complainant contacted the customer care number of the website the next day as he did not get the delivery of the free pair of shoes. “The caller told the complainant that the latter had to transfer Rs10 from his Unified Payments Interface (UPI) application to receive the free shoes . The person on the other end of the call sent him a link to transfer the amount,” the officer said.

He said the complainant filled up his UPI details on the link and even provided his PIN. “Rs61,330 was immediately debited from two of the complainant’s bank accounts. Both the accounts were linked to his UPI,” the officer said.

The officer said the probe of the cybercrime cell revealed that the amount had been transferred to two different bank accounts. One was an account with a public sector bank and the other was with a private bank. The money had also been transferred to two e-wallets. “Our probe is on,” the officer added.

Title: Uttarkashi: Two-day workshop shares info on adventure sports, disaster management
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

UTTARKASHI: A two-day “Mountaineering Summit” workshop , organised by Uttarkashi district administration at the Nehru Institute of Mountaineering (NIM) ended on Tuesday.

On the last day of the event, officials from the departments of tourism, disaster management and others shared insights on various aspects of adventure tourism. Subjects including government schemes, impact of tourism on society and environment and risk factors in high altitude regions were discussed.

NIM officials spoke about fundamentals of mountaineering and trekking sports and safety measures that need to be followed while taking part in adventure activities.

During the event, the administration also felicitated several mountaineers of the district including Padma Shri Chandraprabha Aitwal, Kushal Singh Rana, Dashrath Rawat, Vishnu Semwal, Vinod Gusain and Ravi Chauhan.

Addressing the gathering, Gangotri MLA Gopal Rawat said, “After two days of brainstorming, we have received several good suggestions regarding the tourism industry. To make the event fruitful, we will present all these points to the chief minister and try to take positive steps on it, so that we can provide better facilities to tourists and boost the business of local tour operators.”

Title: Doc’s abduction: Wanted criminal arrested in Mathura
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Agra: Mathura police on Tuesday arrested a wanted criminal carrying a reward of Rs 1 lakh in connection with the abduction of a local doctor more than two months ago.

Nitesh, who hails from Madhya Pradesh, was arrested from Naujheel area in Mathura on a tip-off given by an informer. Police recovered Rs 50,000 cash along with a mobile phone from him. Three others, Sani Malik, Mahesh and Anoop, allegedly involved in the abduction are still absconding. A reward of Rs 1 lakh each has been announced for any information leading to the arrest of the three accused.

Earlier this month, Mathura police had suspended station incharge of the Highway police station, Jagdamba Singh and removed circle officer (refinery) Jagveer Singh from his post on charges of dereliction of duty and for letting off one of the four abductors without registering a case against them. The doctor was abducted on December 10 last year.

Police registered a formal case against the four suspects under section 364 A (kidnapping for ransom) of IPC at Highway police station on Feb 11.

According to police, Orthopedician Dr Nirvikalp Agarwal was allegedly abducted by a group of four persons on December 10 and was released after a ransom amount of Rs 52 lakh was given to them. On January 19, Agarwal again received a call by the abductors demanding another Rs 50 lakh.

Agarwal, who had initially refused to lodge a complaint, called the police and informed them about the extortion call. Highway police worked out the case and nabbed one of the abductors from Meerut. They also recovered of Rs 15 lakh from him which they reportedly handed over to the doctor.

However, police released the abductor after three days of detention without showing his arrest or registering an FIR. Senior officials inquired the matter and during the course of inquiry, action was taken against the cops who allowed the kidnapper to go scot-free.

Title: 17 proposals for Shivbhojan thalis
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The district administration has received 17 proposals for the Shivbhojan scheme under which meal is available at Rs 10. The government has announced to start four additional Shivbhojan counters for citizens of Kolhapur . New counters will be started at busy public places such as ST stand, government offices and hospitals.

State govt offices to have 5-day week

All state government offices in the district will operate from 9.45 am to 6.16 pm from Monday following state government’s decision to keep offices open for five days a week. The government has increased the duration of work by 45 minutes due to the decision. Emergency services like hospitals, fire brigade and milk have been excluded from the list.

208 farmers to get benefit from loan waiver scheme

Two villages in the district –— Asurle in Panhala taluka and Herle in Hatkanangale taluka –— are listed in the first list of farmers loan waiver scheme, the state government announced. As many as 208 farmers from the said villages will get the benefit of the scheme. A total of 116 farmers from Asurle will get benefit while 92 farmers from Herle village will be beneficiaries of the scheme. District collector Daulat Desai said that the official process of the scheme will begin on Monday. An official communication says that 50,884 farmers in Kolhapur district are eligible for loan waiver scheme. The list of farmers will be published on February 28.

SUK employees form action committee

Employees of the Shivaji University, Kolhapur, have formed an action committee for their long pending demand of implementation of seventh pay commission.

Title: Meerut: Youth gets fractured bones in attack by six, video shared widely
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative Image

MEERUT: At least six men allegedly thrashed a college student brutally, leaving him with a fractured arm and dislocated fingers after he refused to pay extortion money to them. The alleged incident took place in Hapur about 10 days ago, and was brought to the fore due a video recorded by the accused.

Police on Tuesday filed an FIR and booked the accused for attempt to murder. The youth , Lucky, 20 , has now threatened suicide if “police doesn’t take swift action against attackers”.

“These goons used to demand money from me. When I refused, they kidnapped me while I was returning from college. They took me to a secluded field and brutally attacked me with rods. I am now left with a fractured arm, leg and dislocated finger bones. I don’t know for how long I was lying unconscious there. I was saved when a passerby spotted me and informed my relatives. Now I have filed a police complaint. If police does not act against my tormentors, I will commit suicide,” he said.

The video, made by one of the attackers, purportedly shows the brutality of the attackers as they thrashed the youth, who lay half naked in the field.

Additional superintendent of police (ASP) of Hapur Sarvesh Mishra said, “We have filed FIR under IPC section 307 (attempt to murder), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon) and 149 (unlawful assembly). Efforts are on to arrest the culprits.”

Title: Dehradun: Winners of wall painting competition announced
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

DEHRADUN: The wall painting competition organized by Dehradun Smart City Limited (DSCL) came to an end on Tuesday after two and a half months of efforts of as many as 142 artists. Out of the 27 teams that participated, three were declared winners.

The first prize went to Anuj Kumar and team, for the detailed painting of a shrine. The second place was clinched by Dev Bharti and team, for a painting with religious symbolism. The third place went to Nikita Rawat and team for the painting of a deity.

The competition’s theme was “Art, Culture and Heritage of Uttarakhand”. Winners of the first prize received Rs 75,000, the second prize was Rs 50,000 and the third Rs 25,000.

Title: UP gets Delhi jitters, leaves of cops cancelled
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Flag march was carried out in several sensitive cities of Uttar Pradesh

AGRA: Leaves of all policemen were cancelled and flag march was carried out in several sensitive cities of Uttar Pradesh as the state government tried to pre-empt any attempt to disturb peace after parts of neighbouring Delhi erupted in violence leaving at least 13 dead.

Aligarh, which witnessed clashes on Sunday leaving at least 10 injured, was virtually turned into a fortress with the deployment of 13 companies of RAF and PAC. In Meerut zone’s Hapur district, the administration invoked section 144 of Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), barring assembly of five or more persons.

In Bareilly, additional director general of police (ADG) Avinash Chandra went a step further and warned of use of force against unauthorised protests. “I will not let the mistake of Delhi be repeated in the UP,” the police officer warned.

Sachindra Patel, superintendent of police (SP) of Firozabad, conducted a flag march with heavy police force in sensitive parts of the district.

“After violence in the national capital, we are on high alert. The district is divided into several zones and sectors. We are carrying out flag march in sensitive parts to send a message to locals that, at no cost, peace will be allowed to be compromised. Police presence is clear warning to anti-social elements,” SP Patel said.

Police are also keeping a close eye on social media platforms. Cyber cells of every district are scanning social media sites like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and WhatsApp groups.

“Any post which can trigger violence will be removed immediately and action will be taken against person sharing provocative content,” added SP Firozabad.

In December last year, at least seven residents of Firozabad were killed in violence which occurred during anti-CAA protest. Most of the victims died of bullet wounds. Police maintained that not a single bullet was fired by them.

Like Firozabad, flag marches by the security personnel were carried out in Bulandshahr, Sambhal and Baghpat also.

IG of Agra range, Satish Ganesh, who was on leave after overseeing security during US President Donal Trump’s visit to city, was asked to join immediately. ADG of Agra zone, Ajay Anand said, “DGP has asked everyone to remain alert at highest level.”

ADG of Bareilly zone, Chandra held a meeting with senior policemen. During the meeting, he said, “Any protest without permission will be dealt with immediate baton-charge. Rubber bullets and tear gas could be used if required.”

The ADG further said that he won’t let “mistake like Delhi to be repeated in the state and anybody trying to stage protest inside a police station will straightaway be charged by police.”

Chandra told TOI, “I would like send a message to the protesters. Irrespective of their religion, there will be zero tolerance for unapproved protests and especially people entering the police station for staging protest like Delhi. Police will welcome them with batons.”

After intelligence inputs from security agencies, home department has instructed ADGP-rank officials to stay in sensitive area like Rampur, Moradabad, Bijnor and Sambhal and keep a close eye on law and order situation. According to sources, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath is monitoring the situation and is in continuous contact with the ADGP-ranked officials across the state.

Title: Pune: Co-passengers help woman deliver baby on train
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Some women co-passengers in a general compartment of Solapur-Gondia Maharashtra Express on Sunday helped a woman deliver a baby after the train arrived at the Pune station around 11.40pm.

“Four personnel of the Railway Protection Force (RPF) were escorting the train. After it reached Pune, they got information that Rani Suresh Sonavane (20), a resident of Palshi, had gone into labour,” a senior RPF officer said.

The RPF personnel requested some women co-passengers to help her. “After all the male passengers disembarked from the coach, the women told Sonavane to lie on one of the seats and she delivered a baby before the doctors could arrive,” the officer said.

‘All norms followed’

The Pune rail division on Tuesday iterated all norms were followed to install the hoarding at Shahir Amar Shaikh Chowk, after a group protested against it. “CoEP approved its design,” Manoj Jhawar, PRO of Pune rail division, said.

Title: Kolhapur: Work at jack-well site likely to begin in March
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The water level of the dam needs to come down to resume the work halted since a year

KOLHAPUR: The water resources department (WRD) on Tuesday claimed that water level at the site of jack-well and pumping station in Kalammawadi dam will recede in the first week of March.

The area has been under water from last monsoon. The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC), through a private contractor, is carrying out the work of the jack-well to bring in the dam water to the pumping station. The total cost of the project is around Rs 488 crore and it was supposed to be completed two years ago.

MLA Chandrakant Jadhav met WRD minister Jayant Patil on Monday and demanded to direct the divisional office of the WRD to release water from the dam to get the site cleared for resuming the construction work.

A WRD official claimed that they are releasing water at the rate of 1,300 cusec whenever there is demand from the farmers. The farmers also have their electric pumps along the banks of the river from where the water is pumped for irrigation.

Rohit Bandivdekar, executive engineer of WRD, said, “Based on demand, water is released from Kalammawadi and Radhanagari dams. We have to ensure that adequate water level is maintained in the dams for supply during season. We expect that the water level at the site where the works of pipeline project has been stalled will reduce by the first week of March.”

Currently, the water level at Kalammawadi dam is at 639.75 feet. A civic official said that water level needs to be reduced further by 10 feet. “When the work resumes the contractor will get just three months to complete the work which is impossible with the current strength of the workers,” he said.

A senior KMC official said, “Most of the works related to laying the pipelines and setting up of water treatment plant have been completed. We have asked the contractor to increase the number of workers to complete the work at the dam site in the three months that we have. Once the monsoon arrives, it will be not possible to carry out the work.”

Title: Poultry biz hit as coronavirus misinformation goes viral
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nashik: The Poultry Farmers and Breeders Association (PFBA) has said that the poultry and egg business in Maharashtra has witnessed a Rs 600-crore loss in the past one month due to panic among consumers sparked by misinformation on social media about the coronavirus.

Uddhav Ahire, a senior office-bearer of PFBA, on Monday claimed that the poultry and egg industry in the state had incurred heavy losses due to fear-mongering on social media. “Misinformation has gone viral and the poultry and egg businesses have been badly hit since the outbreak,” said Uddhav Ahire.

The annual turnover of the poultry industry in Maharashtra is estimated to be around Rs 14,000 crore. Of which, the annual turnover of the poultry industry in Nashik district alone is Rs 2,000 crore. But the industry has been badly affected in the past month.

In a bid to create awareness and remove false information, the association has organised a two-day chicken festival in Nashik, beginning from Tuesday. The festival is to be held at Dongre Hostel grounds, along the Gangapur Road, between 4 pm and 10 pm.

Various dishes like chicken biryani, boiled eggs and other delicacies are will be available at 50 stalls at marginal rates, said Ahire. The association has appealed to the people to visit and taste various dishes at the chicken festival.

Title: 16 years on, 250 flat owners in Vyankatesh Nagar await mutation
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Nagpur: Over 250 flats owners in Vyankatesh Nagar, one of the biggest residential colonies in East Nagpur, are running from pillar to post for mutation of their flats in City Survey records despite no fault of theirs.

According to secretary of Vyankatesh Nagar Owners Association Suraj Singh Thakur, who is also BJP city vice-president, “Over 250 families are facing several hardships because of “irregularities” by the developer and red-tapism on part of concerned government departments.”

Thakur said the state government had acquired over 38 acres land in Nandanwan under ULC Act, but the same as returned to land owners under Talegaon Dabhade scheme. A developer decided to construct a housing scheme there with 26 towers comprising 416 flats and 110 twin-house bungalows in 2003 on the basis of power of attorney from all 29 land owners.

The Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) sanctioned layout and building plan of the scheme in 2003. Several citizens booked flats/ bungalows after verifying the sanctioned plan and inked agreement to sale with the developer which was duly registered with the registrar’s office. Most of the flat buyers availed home loan from banks, which verified the documents through their surveyors and legal experts before sanctioning the amount. The buyers were handed over the possession by 2004.

In the meanwhile, the land was brought under the Nagpur Municipal Corporation jurisdiction, which sanctioned the revised plan in 2006.

By 2009, nearly 50% of the buyers got their sale deeds executed followed by mutation. After some delay, sale deed of the remaining properties were also executed.

However, in 2017, one of the land owners lodged a complaint with the authorities alleging forgery in power of attorney documents. Following the complaint, City Survey department refused to execute mutations citing the objection from one of land owners.

In March 2017, crime branch’s special investigation team (SIT) registered a case against the developer on charges of forgery.

“The NIT or NMC are duty-bound to verify each and every document before sanctioning a layout and building plan,” said Thakur, who is also one of the aggrieved buyers. “The buyers are unnecessarily facing the brunt of the “misdeeds” of a developer and government departments,” he alleged.

As the mutation proceedings were halted, aggrieved buyers approached revenue minister in Devendra Fadnavis cabinet Chandrakant Patil in August 2018 and apprised him of their plight. Accordingly, state’s revenue department on September 25, 2018, directed collector’s office to investigate the matter and submit a report. However, the collector’s office has not submitted the report even after 17 months.

As nothing has moved since then, over 250 buyers are unable to mortgage the property for availing loan nor they are able to sell it in the absence of mutation. They, however, have to repay the home loan and also pay property tax to the civic body.

Superintendent of land records GB Daberao, under whom the City Survey offices comes, told TOI that he was not aware of the case. “I will go through the details and do the needful,” he said.

Collector Ravindra Thakre did not respond to TOI’s call and message.

Title: Meerut man to finally return from Diamond Princess; says will never forget 30 days on water
Content:
Diamond Princess (AP)

MEERUT: Piyush Vashist, the 29-year-old who boarded the coronavirus-infected Diamond Princess cruise on January 25, will finally be returning to India in a chartered flight arranged by the Indian government to bring back all the Indians on board on Wednesday.Vashist along with other Indians on board have been given instructions to wear a mask all the time so as to prevent any spread of the infection. They will then be kept at the coronavirus health facility in Haryana’s Manesar for a 14-day quarantine period and then would be allowed to go home.Piyush’s family is ecstatic and awaits his safe and quick return.“This was an extraordinary situation. I was worried and frustrated. All I wanted to do was to return home and it is finally happening,” said Piyush Vashist, who hails from Meerut and works as a software engineer.“The most important thing I learnt on the ship is to survive with limited resources,” said Piyush.He had boarded the Diamond Princess on January 25 from Hong Kong. Little did he know that his experience on the cruise will be a harrowing one. The Diamond Princess cruise ship was quarantined in Japan’s Yokohama on February 3, after the crew got to know that one of the passengers who disembarked the ship on January 25 was detected with coronavirus a few days later.“For at least 23 days, I survived on packed food to ensure that I do not catch any infection whatsoever from the food being cooked here – which, too, might have infection. I have been dependent on cup noodles, biscuits, chocolates and other similar items for 23 days now. I will finally be able to eat proper food once I am back,” he told TOI over the phone.Vashist and many other Indians on board got to know about their evacuation after they got an email from the Indian embassy in Tokyo. The flight will evacuate the Indian nationals by picking them up from Haneda airport in Japan.

Title: Coronavirus effect: Pipeline works delayed to peak summer
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NAGPUR: The coronavirus outbreak in China has delayed Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s ( NMC ) plan to install seven full-bore electromagnetic flow meters on the pipeline bringing raw drinking water from Pench dam to the city in February. Now, the civic body is purchasing the meters from Aurangabad , but they can be installed only by May. The procedure will require shut down of water supply for a few days for 70% areas of the city in peak summer time, when water demand is huge.Chairman of NMC water works consultative committee Vijay Zalke told TOI all efforts will be taken to minimize the impact in May. NMC had issued work order to a private company for purchase and installation of flow meters last year. The contractor placed the order with a China-based company. But the meters will not be available this month since the company cited disruptions due to coronavirus.“Now, the contractor has placed order with a company in Aurangabad. We have given a deadline of May. Earlier, we have taken shut down in May for crucial works. We will take shut down of 1-2 days in intervals to minimize the impact,” he said.To put an end to carriage of raw water through open canals, NMC had laid 31km giant-sized pipeline of 2,300mm diameter between Pench dam and Mahadula pumping station in 2015. Leakages were noticed in the pipeline due to some natural causes and also due to sabotage by unidentified persons. Over 30 million litres per day (MLD) water, sufficient for around two lakh people, was going waste for over one year due to the leaks.NMC repaired some leaks on temporary basis and reduced loss. Also, it planned to shut water supply from pipeline and bring water through canal. During shut down, NMC planned repairs of leaks and installation of flow meters. NMC will then be able to know exact point and cause of leakage.All this activity was planned in July last year. There would have been no effect to people had works been completed in the winter, as water demand is low. But NMC delayed the works for various reasons.NMC was confident of executing the works in February, which is pre-summer days. Now, people will have to suffer due to NMC’s delays. The demand for water is high during summer, especially in May. Also, NMC cannot bring water through open canal in May as losses will be high and there are chances of breach in canal.Zalke said works to repair leaks on the pipeline have started. “NMC took shut down for two days on February 13 and 14 for electric work. On these two days, some leaks were repaired. Remaining leaks will be repaired with shut down on March 1 and some more days,” he said.

Title: KMC taking ‘unnecessary’ action, claims traders body
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Traders further claimed that they were being harassed by the employees of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation

Title: Dehradun: Former students of Matri Sadan chief protest for Ashram’s security cover
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: The former students of Shivanand Saraswati , chief of Matri Sadan , are up in arms against Haridwar district adminstration and police for removing his and ashram’s security cover. Seer Saraswati was earlier a chemistry teacher at an intermediate college in Kolkata.

On February 19th, Saraswati’s security cover which included two gunners was withdrawn by Haridwar SSP . This angered the seers of Matri Sadan. Now, students from various parts of country are reaching Matri Sadan to oppose the move.

On Tuesday, one of his students interacted with media persons and urged the state government to reinstate the security cover of Matri Sadan and its head. “We are all former students of Shivanand Saraswati. So far, we haven’t joined protest for clean Ganga but now, his security has been removed. We all urge you to kindly help him get back the security cover so that he is safe from mining mafias,” said Yogendera Singh, one of his former students from Uttar Pradesh, who is currently at Matri Sadan.

Notably, Haridwar SSP Senthil Avoodai K Raj has already told the seers to approach the state government for security cover as their duration to avail the privilege was exhausted long back.

Meanwhile, seers Padmavati and Aatmabodhanand are undergoing treatment in AIIMS-Delhi. Padamavati has been kept on ventilator and Aatmabodhanand is being given intravenous fluid.

Title: Kalshetti issues notice to systems manager, prescribes fine
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti on Tuesday issued a show-cause notice to system manager Yashpal Rajput for finding several technical glitches in the system of citizen felicitation centre (CFC) at Tarani Market.

The CFC’s are meant for the citizens to pay taxes and avail various other civic services. The systems department handles the digital network of the CFC’s.

Kalshetti on Tuesday visited the Tararani Market CFC and found that the system was down due to several technical glitches and power supply issues. Unhappy with the developments, the civic chief gave a show-cause notice which read, “There is no back-up mechanism functioning at the CFC. In the case of a power cut, the data of the citizens may be lost and further pose a challenge in accounting. Since such things amount to negligence, I prescribe a fine of Rs 2000 which you have to pay if I did not get the reply to the show-cause notice within three days.”

Kalshetti stated in the notice that the system manager position holds importance as the e-governance system is operated through the respective department.

Every day, the staff has to ensure that the tax collection system applied for various civic services through the digital systems run efficiently. Kalshetti said that he observed that the battery back-up system located at another CFC located at Gandhi Maidan ward office is also not functioning properly and the required repair works have not been taken for the last some days. “The dire negligence towards the systems has been reported prima facie. The negligence amounts to a violation of service rules,” stated the notice.

Title: Kerala: LSGD clears buildings for permit renewal despite violations
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The special committee, under local self-government department ( LSGD ), has recommended renewal of permits beyond 10 years for a few commercial and residential highrises in state disregarding the grave violations reported against these constructions.

A meeting of the committee was chaired by former additional chief secretary (LSGD) T K Jose on February 12, the day cabinet decided to shift him.

Sources confirmed that officials were forced to prepare a draft of the minutes of the meeting, clearing the buildings for renewal of permits, that night itself. On February 14, the government issued an order transferring Jose to PWD . The minutes of the meeting carry the signature of additional chief secretary dated February 17.

It is also learnt that the agenda for the meeting was revised to insert an item regarding extension of permit of a building, reportedly at the behest of another top official. The five-member committee, which includes LSGD principal secretary, director of urban affairs, chief town planner, district officer of town planning department and secretary of civic body concerned, considered applications for renewal of permits beyond 10 years. The secretary of a civic body grants extension for a period less than 10 years.

The minutes of the meeting showed that a commercial-cum-residential building (7,471.24 sq m) in Kozhikode corporation, a residential flat (3,832.75 sq m) in Tripunithura municipality, a residential-cum-apartment building in Thrikkakara municipality (1,21,049.18 sq m), a commercial building (869.54 sq m) in Perumbavoor municipality and a special residential and commercial building in Irinjalakuda municipality (3,373.17 sq m) were cleared for renewal of permits. This was cleared though district town planner and chief town planner enlisted major violations from approved plan for each construction. The rule says that any deviation from approved permit should lead to revocation of permit, following a hearing process.

For the building in Thrikkakara, senior town planner recommended against extension of building permit, citing rule violations regarding access, height, environmental clearance and violation of Kochi structure plan. The chief town planner remarked that NOC issued to the building was regularized in 2015 despite major rule and scheme violations and it was a major fault by the officials concerned. The government was also ordered to stop construction activities and to take action after investigation by LSGD (vigilance wing).

The minutes also showed that the construction was not even permissible as the site came under agriculture zone as per the structure plan for the city. Despite these remarks, LSG recommended renewal of permit, forcing the committee to recommend extension of permit for two years for two towers and the municipality was asked to issue permit extension immediately.

Jose did not respond to request for comment via call and message. The officials with town planning department refused to comment on the decisions.

Title: Van rams bike, killing woman, son in Muzaffarnagar
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Represenatative Image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: A woman (65) and her son (35) were killed when a heavy vehicle rammed their motorcycle in Jansath area here on Tuesday morning.

Identified as Subodh and Pushpa Devi, residents of Behda Sadat village in Muzaffarnagar , the duo was on way to Meerut to attend a marriage ceremony. When they reached Jansath area of Muzaffarnagar, a speeding van hit their bike and fled the spot.

Someone alerted police. They rushed the duo to hospital, where doctors declared them brought dead.

Yogesh Sharma, station house officer of Jansath police station, said, “The bodies were sent for a post-mortem and the victims’ family was informed.” A case has been filed against the unidentified van driver and attempts are on to trace him.

In October last year, a UP roadways bus hit a mother-son duo on a bike in Shamli. While the woman died on the spot, her son, who was driving the bike, sustained severe injuries. The duo was going from Kairana to Jhinjana when the accident took place. The deceased were identified as Sukka and his mother, Shammema.
