Title: Schools shut during previous BJP govt to be reopened: Min
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan education department has issued orders to open government schools which were closed during previous government’s tenure due to Right to Education (RTE) violations and school mergers.

About 495 primary schools were closed due to merger of schools and 483 secondary schools were closed due to RTE violations have been identified. School education minister Govind Singh Dotasra on Tuesday announced it in assembly session that all the mergers were done at the time of BJP government’s tenure were against the rules which is being rectified now. These schools will start functioning from this session.

Dotasra said, “BJP government closed and merged 22,200 schools due to which 19,754 school buildings are lying empty. As per the RTE rules, we have decided to open schools with more than 15 students and a distance of more than one km from this session. If the empty school building is now being used for some other purpose, then it will be again allotted to the school. If further budget is required for the schools, we will provide that as well.”

The merger of these schools in 2014 had an adverse effect on the enrolment as well. A research report by an advocacy group, Accountability Initiate (AI), says 22,200 schools were merged for better governance and transparency. Later, 2,500 consolidated schools were reopened due to decline in enrolments by the same government.

The merger of schools in 2014-16 by the previous BJP government has reduced enrolments across social groups (ST, SC and OBC) by around 6 per cent. The decline was higher than the average decline of 1.4% registered across the state during the same period in non-merged schools.

The report says overall enrolment of students with disability declined by 4% between 2015-16 and 2016-17. “The rate of decline was much higher among consolidated schools at 22%,” reads the report.

Title: Kuttanad to get Cong candidate
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Congress will take the Kuttanad seat from Kerala Congress (Mani) as there is a lack of consensus between PJ Joseph and Jose K Mani factions within the party. This was communicated to both leaders by Congress and IUML leadership at the UDF meet on Tuesday.

IUML and Congress leaders met both leaders separately and said that UDF cannot afford to lose the seat and hence there is no point in having a difference of opinion or internal bickering. Pala result must not reflect in Kuttanad, they said. “We informed them about the seriousness of the issue and stressed on the need to win the seat at any cost,” said opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala after the meeting.

Congress will have a final talk with Joseph and Jose on Saturday in Kochi before taking a final decision. IUML leader PK Kunhalikutty, who was part of the discussion, said no decision was taken and discussions were going on.

It is also learnt that Joseph has almost made up his mind to give Kuttanad seat to Congress. However, Congress leadership is adamant that both factions in the party will not be allowed to select separate candidates. Instead, Congress will declare the candidate by the second week of March.

Meanwhile at the meeting, IUML leaders wanted to settle the differences that had erupted within Congress which they said is affecting the unity of the front. Congress and IUML leaders also met Anoop Jacob and Johnny Nellore separately and urged them to settle their differences.

However, Jacob urged to remove Nellore from the secretary post of UDF since the post was given to Kerala Congress (Jacob) and he has left the party.

Title: Lucknow: Harassed by colleague, girl quits her job
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A young woman who worked as an accountant at a luxury hotel on Rana Pratap Marg allegedly had to quit her job because she was routinely stalked and harassed by another employee. Although the incident took place in August last year, the mother of the woman lodged an FIR at Ghazipur police station on Sunday. A sexual harassment case has been lodged against the accused who is a front desk employee.

According to the FIR, the accused sent the woman smut texts and when she protested, he allegedly threatened to morph her pictures and upload them on social media. “He (the accused) had secretly taken pictures of my daughter while she was at work and had also been stalking her,” the mother said in her complaint. The young woman apparently went into depression after quitting her job and hadn’t confided in her family members until recently. “My daughter shared her ordeal after much persuasion. When we heard why she had left her job, we decided to approach police,” the complainant said.

Ghazipur SHO Brijesh Singh confirmed the FIR. “The accused has been charged with sexual harassment and we are probing the case,” he said.

Title: Bhopal: AIIMS doctor held on molestation charge
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

Title: HC notice to Telangana, revenue staff over land encroachment
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

Hyderabad: The Telangana high court on Monday issued notices to the state and its revenue officials in Medchal district, asking them to explain their stand on a petition. The petition, filed by M Naveen Kumar , charged them with inaction even in the face of encroachment of lake bed area in survey number 221 of Gajularamaram village.

In his plea, Naveen Kumar said that the encroachers have not spared even the full tank level area and the buffer zone area of a lake in the village and the officials are maintaining stoic silence.

This is government land but the land grabbers have converted this into a layout, made the land into plots and are selling them away, the petitioner complained.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy sought counters from the state and the revenue officials within four weeks.

Title: National meet to focus on reducing malnutrition
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As part of Kerala State Nutrition Mission (Sampushta Keralam) project, launched by the department of women and child development (WCD), a two-day national meet will be organized at Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology from February 27. Health minister K K Shailaja said the meet will focus on Hidden Hunger: Challenges and way forward. Governor Arif Mohammed Khan will inaugurate the two-day event that will see the participation of experts within and outside the state.

Though Kerala has made advances in the health sector, it should view the issue of nutrition deficiency among infants and pregnant women as this is causing health problems among children. The event will find a solution to the issue, she said, adding that state’s nutrition policy will be reviewed and a new action plan will be formulated.

The government is trying to implement new and better indices in the sector and Sampushta Keralam was launched for this purpose. The objectives of the mission include reducing stunting (impaired growth and development) among children aged till 6 years, reducing low birth weight, reducing anemia among kids aged between six months to 5 years, reducing anemia among women and adolescent girls and reducing malnutrition among children.

Title: MSP, farm yield up in 3 yrs: Min
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Lucknow: Accusing the government of not responding to pointed questions on its promise to double farmers’ incomes in five years, Congress MLC Deepak Singh walked out of the legislative council on Tuesday.

Replying to a query by Singh, agriculture minister Surya Pratap Shahi said both minimum support price and yield per acre had gone up over last three years but there was no department in the state which had data on farmers’ incomes. “There is no scientific system with the agriculture department to collect this information. The union statistics department collects the data. We know how much is being produced in the state,” Shahi said.

Title: RD, Laxmi-Pyare music magic casts a spell on audience
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Isha Ranade regales in the musical programme ‘Dosti Suron Ki’, organized by Dande Foundation, at Bhat Hall, Re... Read More

Nagpur: RD Burman and Laxmikant Pyarelal made a lot of experiments while scoring music for films. The magic of their creations was on full display at a programme titled ‘Dosti Suron Ki’, organized by Dande Foundation at Suresh Bhat Sabhagruh, on Tuesday.

The programme, presented by Awesome Musical Group, kept the audience glued to seats as singers excelled in their performances.

The programme started with ‘Kya yehi pyar hai’, sung by Sagar Madhumatke, who specializes in Kishore Kumar’s songs. Vijay Chiwande was the next who sang ‘Gulabi aankhen’.

Isha Ranade was at her best singing ‘Aaj tal paon zameen par nahi rehte mere’, a rather slow song, difficult to sing. Duet ‘Lekar hum deewana dil’, a duet by Sagar Madhumatke and Shruti Choudhari warmed up many a heart.

‘Ek din bik jaayega mati ke mol’, made immortal by Raj Kapoor, was presented by Arvind Patil. Chiwande then came up with ‘Mehbooba’,

Racy song ‘Jaane ja dhoondta phir raha’ by Madhumatke and Shruti Choudhary was greeted with repeated applause.

Shruti’s romantic songs “Kya janu sajan’ and ‘Aao na gale laga lo na’ were a hit.

It was Prashant Khandare whose saxophone did all the talking when he presented ‘Tum aa gaye ho noor aa gaya hai’ and made the atmosphere electrifying.

Isha rendered ‘Sheesha ho ya dil ho’ while Mukul Pande came up with ‘Chahunga main tujhe saanjh savere’.

Sagar took the audience to the heydays of Rajesh Khanna with evergreen ‘Mere dil mein aaj kya hai tu kahe to main’.

Mukul’s qawwali ‘Parda hai parda’ while Isha and Akansha’s rendition of folk song ‘Choli ke pichhe kya hai’ added a dash of colour to the programme.

‘Taro me saj ke’ by Arvind and ‘Bhor bhaye pan ghatpe’ by Isha were nice. ‘Ek pyar ka nagma hai’ by Arvind and Vina Ukunde impressed.

Jyoti Bhagat shared many tid-bits about the origin of songs and singers during the course of the musical.

The programme was conceptualized by Prashant and Prakash Khandare.

The accompanying artistes were Prashant Khandare (saxophone), Prakash (brass), Mahendra Dhole and Raja Rathod (keyboard), Prakash Chauhan (guitar) and Rakesh Wankhede (base guitar).

Quotes

* All the songs were presented well. Besides anchoring, the orchestration was up to the mark. I liked the performance of Sagar Madhumatke

Sudhir Jaunjal | IT employee

* I enjoyed ‘Main aaya hoon’, sung by Sagar Madhumatke. Combination of romantic and folk songs was good. New singers too performed well

Shubham Bhoyar | Businessman

* The atmosphere in the auditorium was enthusiastic as the audience responded to the songs of performers. The programme was good

Priyanka Gavai | Private job

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod; Interviews by Kanishka Rawlekar)

Title: Hyderabad ready to face cyber threats with new facility
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: National Cyber Research, Innovation, and Capacity Centre was inaugurated at Central Detective Training Institute (CDTI) at Ramanthapur on Monday with an aim to face cyber threats .

“There is no doubt that such a centre is the need of the hour as with proliferation of information technology life has become easier. But technology itself is a double-edged weapon and therefore criminals misuse it for ulterior purposes,” said Union minister of state for home affairs, G Kishan Reddy, who inaugurated the centre.

“The world in general and India in particular has witnessed a rise in cyber crimes during the last decade and fighting cyber menace is increasingly becoming a global challenge. Our dependence on technology coupled with the government’s intention for digitalisation has created a demand for cyberspace,” he added.

He also informed that ministry of home affairs was also working on setting up regional cyber crime coordination centres (R4Cs) in states. It would be in collaboration with the Indian Cyber Crime Coordination Centre (I4C) to further strengthen the cyber combat capabilities of the nation, he said.

Talking about CDTI, he said: “It will prove to be central hub for entire south India.”

Title: Water supply disrupted as AMC fails to mend pipeline
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The water supply from Cidco N-5 elevated storage reservoir (ESR) to Cidco N-5, N-6 and N-8 areas was delayed by 16 hours after the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation ’s (AMC) water works department failed to repair a broken pipeline on time.

Activists and residents met municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey on Tuesday requesting SMS alerts regarding water supply timings.

The fault in pipeline was detected on Tuesday after the residents of the Cidco N-8 area waited for water supply at 6 am. The residents were getting water after a long wait of five days. However, the taps remained dry until 7 am. The agitated residents then made several calls to the staff at the water works department as well as local corporators. It was only after making several calls did they realise that a pipeline at Avishkar Chowk was damaged and repairs had to be initiated.

At first, the water works department said that water will be supplied at 5 or 6 pm depending on the completion of repair work. When the supply did not resume even after 6 pm, the staff said that the repair work was underway and that the supply will only be restored by 10 pm. Homemakers, especially working couples, faced a lot of problems due to the ineptness of the civic administration.

The repair works had not completed until late on Tuesday evening. Meanwhile, the disruption in supply compelled the residents to buy drinking water from private suppliers.

In Cidco N-3, N-4 and Jai Bhawani Nagar, which are also supplied water from the Cidco N-5 ESR, the disruption in water timings is a common affair. The civic body does not have any mechanism to inform residents about the changes in water supply timings.

Subsequently, on Tuesday, a delegation of residents met municipal commissioner and reiterated the demand for issuing SMS or Whatsapp alerts about water timings. According to Rahul Ingle of Shahar Parivartan Aghadi, the residents pay whopping Rs 4,050 towards water tax annually and that too they get water once in 6 to 7 days.

Title: Want old NPR, no NRC, says Bihar House in one voice
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Bihar became the first NDA-ruled state on Tuesday to unanimously adopt a resolution to implement the National Population Register (NPR) in the state in its 2010 format, including only the transgender column from the new format. The assembly also adopted a resolution that the “National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) is not needed in Bihar”.

The resolution on the NPR and the NRC, put up by Speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary with the consent of the ruling and opposition parties, was adopted unanimously much to the discomfiture of the BJP members, who failed to oppose it.

“It was essential for the smooth functioning of the House. If a resolution is adopted unanimously that means it’s the common view of all the members and this situation is always desirable,” Choudhary later told TOI.

Speaking on the resolution, CM Nitish Kumar clarified in the assembly that the Centre had sought the opinion on NPR from all states and his government had sent a letter communicating its position on both NPR and NRC. It was this letter that was adopted as the resolution in the assembly.

“The Bihar government has already communicated to the Centre that NPR format should be the same as it was in 2010 and only the transgender column should be added to it. The state government’s letter should be considered as the resolution,” Nitish told the House and added: “We have also communicated that NRC is not needed in Bihar.”

Earlier in the day, the assembly witnessed an ugly scene after RJD leader Tejashwi Prasad Yadav moved an adjournment notice on NPR and CPI-ML MLA Mehboob Alam on CAA, NPR and NRC. Some BJP and RJD members almost came to blows when Tejashwi dubbed CAA as a “black law”.

Defending his party’s support to CAA in Parliament, Nitish cited statements of former PM Manmohan Singh and other Congress leaders in Parliament demanding Indian citizenship for the persecuted minorities in the neighbouring countries.

The “unanimous” resolution, however, was used as a tool of political one-upmanship as Tejashwi claimed that the government bowed to RJD pressure and JD (U) ally BJP, which failed to oppose the resolution, denied that the government bowed to RJD pressure.

BJP state vice-president and Baikunthpur MLA Mithilesh Tiwari told TOI, “PM has himself clarified that there has been no discussion on NRC, as of now. So, discussing the issue is like celebrating the ‘mundan’ of a baby before birth. Tejashwi should not feel elated as BJP never deviates from its principles and it is the party which has forced a country like Pakistan to kneel down.”

Political observers feel that the opposition fell in the government’s trap over the resolution, which suits Nitish, who was under pressure from the minority community to re-establish his secular credentials after joining hands with BJP again.

It is also seen as a masterstroke to blunt the sharp attack from RJD-led opposition and the likes of CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar, who is on a state-wide yatra against NRC, were trying to make NPR and NRC major issues in the coming assembly election.

Title: Hyderabad couple has a story for every child
Content:
Sinivas Rao and Shefali Rao

Students of MMPS Chitkul, a school in Medak, browse through their new books

HYDERABAD: The children of Dogra Nagar in Jammu often wake up to sounds of shelling. On days like these, they gingerly find their way to the house of an elderly couple because it means escape in more ways than one.The house, which doubles as a community library , is stacked with books that tell stories about children like them in lands away from theirs. And the books had been brought from homes of children their age, living over 2,000 kilometers away in Hyderabad.The books made the journey from Hyderabad to Jammu thanks to the efforts of city based couple, Srinivas Rao and Shefali Rao.The duo that run a consultancy firm in Banjara Hills, are book-lovers who wanted to revive the dying art of reading. In less than four years, the couple and their team of volunteers have managed to spread the reading bug to villages and semi-urban areas in 22 states. With 303 libraries, Food4Thought Foundation has reached prisons, schools and hospitals across India.“Stories deserve to be heard more than once. We source books through donations or buy them, segregate them into genres and identify locations that need books but have no access to them,” says Srinivas, founder of Food4Thought.Shefali says that they work like a corporate, with pie-charts to record their progress, a tracker to gauge the reception of books by readers and an extended network of volunteers who are committed to story-telling.“There are areas such as Nongshken Village in Meghalaya that courier companies refuse to deliver packages to. So we have volunteers who carry books on their backs and scale hilly terrains to deliver books,” Shefali says, stressing that the spine of the foundation is its well-connected bunch of volunteers.The curation of each library by founders and volunteers takes into account the age of the reader, the setting of the library and readers’ exposure to the language.The foundation also receives monthly feedback from all 303 libraries to assess progress being made by readers. Strategies are developed for libraries that record lesser footfall.“For instance, in a school in Khammam, children were scared to touch the new books. So the principal hung the books on a clothesline, to make books less intimidating,” says Madhavi Sharma, co-founder of Food4Thought.The economics of running the foundation has been a constant challenge, says the team. The foundation sends books to five libraries every week, costing them close to half a lakh per month in courier charges alone. Established four years ago, the organization only recently qualified for CSR status. But over 70% of funds come from the founders’ pockets. The rest is collected through donations.“Team members, including co-founders, draw almost no salary. The money we make through our firm is routed to meet the foundation’s demand,” says Srinivas.To the proverbial ‘what next’ question, the team says, “We hope to set up 500 libraries by December. We want to create a network to connect book-lovers across the country. We also plan to develop Braille and audio books to make storytelling more inclusive.”Rushing to pack the next bundle of books, Shefali says, “We want the country to know that for every child there is a story waiting to be discovered, enjoyed and retold.”

Title: Nanital: CAA will not affect any Indian Muslim, don’t know why people are protesting
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Subramanium Swamy (File Image)

NAINITAL: Senior BJP leader and Rajya Sabha MP, Subramanian Swamy said on Tuesday that the Citizenship Amendment Act will not affect any Indian Muslim.

Swamy who was in Nainital was responding to questions when he was asked about the clashes between the pro and anti-CAA protesters in Northeast Delhi. Swamy said that the CAA will not affect any Muslim in the country and that since there have been no discussions on the National Register of Citizens, the people are protesting against something that hasn’t even been proposed yet. “The protesters are protesting for something that hasn’t even happened yet. The CAA will not affect Muslims and the NRC hasn’t even come into effect, therefore, there is no need to protest,” Swamy said.

When asked what effect the protests will have on the visit of the US President Donald Trump, Swamy said, “Trump came to India with good intent. Therefore the protests will not have any impact on his visit,” he said.

Title: Bhopal secured 13th rank in country in CS exam
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Muskan Sahu

BHOPAL: Results of the executive and professional exam of the Company Secretaries of India which was held in December 2019 was declared on Tuesday. Making Bhopal proud, Muskan Sahu from the city of lakes secured the 13th rank all over India in the CSI executive exams.

“I had not expected that I will secure an all India rank this time too as the syllabus is very difficult. But I guess my hard work paid off. I used to study for 15 hours a day and gave equal time to all the subjects and revised the whole course thoroughly a lot of times”, said Sahu.

To all the students preparing for CS she said, “You have to very consistent and hard working. Study well now and enjoy later and be determined that you have to cross the exam.”

A total of 10 students, namely Deepanshi Agarwal, Vartika yadav, Rakshanda Singh Thakur , Kiran Andani, Itisha Agarwakl, Abhiraj Rana , Ayush Sharma, Princu Asati, Utkarsh Jain and Deepika Gurjar completed the CS course from Bhopal this year.

Students who have successfully qualified the executive exam can register for the professional exam for all modules by May 31 and for 1 module by July 31.

Title: College students, experts discuss climate change
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Hyderabad: British Deputy High Commission, Hyderabad, hosted a roundtable for 30 college students on the theme of climate change at St Joseph’s Degree & PG College on Monday. The participating students focused on three areas — energy, groundwater depletion and transportation, their impacts on climate change and proposed counter actions.

Speaking to TOI, Chevening alumni Thilotham Reddy Kolanu, an energy consultant, said: “Sustainable solutions need to be found at every level. How you eat, travel and how you engage with the poor all fall under this gamut. We need to question our actions at personal level.”

This event called ‘Chevening Conversations’ provided a platform for younger generation to engage with experts.

Andrew Fleming, British Deputy High Commissioner to Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, said, “I’m delighted that this event brought together our vibrant Chevening alumni to engage with young people on an issue that is truly the need of the hour. Leading up to the critical COP26 summit in the UK we will host events across both Telugu states on the theme of climate change bringing together a diverse mix of stakeholders.”

Students made presentations and team from St Ann’s College for Women won.

Title: Padmakumar gets charge of coir industries
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The cabinet on Tuesday brought about a minor bureaucratic reshuffle . Rural development commissioner N Padmakumar has been given the additional charge of special secretary (industries-coir). He would continue to the hold the charge of rural development commissioner as well.

The government appointed secretary (personnel and administrative reforms) Gopalakrishna Bhat as secretary (industries-cashew). He will continue to hold the other charges.

Director (fisheries) S Venkitesapathy has been given the additional charge of joint managing director of Kerala Water Authority. At present, secretary (water resources) B Ashok is holding the additional charge of managing director of KWA, after former managing director A Kowsigan was transferred from the post.

The cabinet on Tuesday posted incumbent director of sports and youth affairs Geromic George as the chief executive officer of Kerala Maritime Board. Deputy secretary (general administration department) Renu Raj will now hold the additional charge of director of sports and youth affairs.

Aid from CMDRF

The cabinet decided to provide a financial relief of Rs 3.22 lakh from the chief minister’s distress relief fund to a family in Kollam who are victims of an accident in which a drinking water storage tank fell on a house and a child was killed. The mother of the child had suffered serious injuries in the accident. tnn

Title: Guards to be deployed to keep Aurangabad markets free of illegal hawkers
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

The AMC is yet to work upon its hawkers'zone policy

AURANGABAD: After local businessmen raised concerns about the hawker menace in the market areas of Paithan Gate, Gulmandi and Tilak Path, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey agreed to deploy guards to ensure that the markets are free of illegal hawkers .

The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) is yet to work upon its hawkers’ zone policy.

A delegation of businessmen representing Aurangabad Jilha Vyapari Mahasangh and Paithan Gate-Tilak Path Vyapari Association met the municipal commissioner on Tuesday against the backdrop of parking policy and hawkers’ zone policy approved by the general body of the AMC recently.

According to the hawkers’ zone policy, the AMC had said that it would issue licences to street vendors in market areas of Paithan Gate, Gulmandi and Tilak Path. The AMC had planned to charge the vendors on a daily basis for plying their business in the market areas. However, the businessmen who have their shops in these areas, said that they are already facing inconvenience due to hawkers as they occupy space in front of their shops and prevent customers from parking or entering the shops.

They also said that the new policy of the civic body would authorise the hawkers further increasing the problems of the shopkeepers.

Pandey told the businessmen that the municipal corporation is in process of identifying spaces for specifying hawkers’ zones in the city. However, the hawkers are not allowed to conduct business in the ‘no hawkers’ zone.’

Jagannath Kale, president of Aurangabad Jilha Vyapari Mahasangh, said that after insistence of the delegation, the municipal commissioner said that the AMC would put up ‘no hawker zone’ signboards in market areas. The businessmen also demanded that AMC’s vigilance squad must be deployed in market areas to ensure that hawkers comply with the directive.

Title: Two grooms-to-be among three killed in accidents
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Bareilly: A 22-year-old man and his brother-in-law-to-be were run over by a speeding truck in Bithri Chenpur area of Bareilly district on Tuesday morning.

According to police, victim Pankh Dev Maurya was scheduled to marry another victim Devendra Pal’s younger sister on May 25 in Bithri Chenpur.

Maurya and Pal, both friends, were on their way to Bisalpur town in Pilibhit district to attend a wedding when their bike was hit by a speeding truck near Nagaria village, said police, adding that both died on the spot.

The bodies were sent for autopsy.

Maurya, a resident of Kalari village in Izzatnagar, was working at a brick kiln, while Pal was a resident of Delhi. Their families boarded a bus to reach the wedding venue, while both friends decided to go on the bike.

Bithri Chenpur SHO Ashok Kumar said an FIR would be registered after they received the autopsy report.

In another incident, a police constable, who was scheduled to marry on March 5, was killed after a speeding truck hit his bike on the Delhi-Lucknow national highway in Fatehganj (East) area on Monday night.

Victim Fareed Khan, a resident of Shahjahanpur district, was a computer operator at Shahzadnagar police station in Rampur district.

Police said Fareed was on his way to Shahjahanpur when the accident took place. He was rushed to a private hospital, but given his critical condition, he was referred to the district hospital. Fareed, however, died on his way to the district hospital. The body was handed over to his father Sohail Ali after the autopsy, said police.

An FIR was registered at Fatehganj (East) police station under IPC sections 304a (causing death by negligence) and 279 (rash driving) against the unidentified truck driver.”

Title: Services of Nizam VII never highlighted by governments: Family
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

CHARMINAR: On the 53rd death anniversary of the last Nizam of Hyderabad, Nawab Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur , on Monday, his family rued that his compassionate services and achievements were never highlighted by any of the governments.

The Nizam’s family members and followers paid floral tributes to the Nizam VII at his grave in Hyderabad. Najaf Ali Khan , grandson of the last Nizam, told TOI Nawab Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur’s contributions to the Deccan region are unparalleled till date.

“My grandfather Nawab Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur was the prime example and epitome of a religiously tolerant and benevolent ruler. Most of the services developed under his guidance and rule are still in use and remembered by the common people. His compassionate services and achievements have not been highlighted by any of the governments, which hurts our sentiments,” Najaf Ali Khan said.

He added that the tradition of secularism followed by the Asaf Jahi rulers was maintained by Nizam VII during his reign. “There are scores of examples of the secular nature of the Nizam VII. One such example is that he always extended financial help equally to Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Sikhs for religious and educational institutions and did not discriminate,” Najaf Ali Khan added.

Title: No stray menace in UP as government built cow shelters: Minister Suresh Khanna
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Suresh Khanna

LUCKNOW: A day after cabinet minister Suresh Khanna said that MP and Rajasthan were pushing stray cattle into UP to defame the government, another minister said there was no stray cattle in UP as the government had built cow shelters everywhere.

On Tuesday, jal shakti minister Mahendra Singh remarked there was no stray cattle here as the Yogi government had built cow shelters all over the state.The comment drew criticism from the Opposition.

“The jal shakti minister’s claim that there are no stray cattle in the state is ridiculous. It also contradicts the answer by Suresh Khanna, who had informed the House that the adjoining states were pushing their animals into UP,” said Leader of Opposition Ram Govind Chaudhary as leader of Congress legislature party Aradhana Mishra joined him.

Title: Rights panel finally functional, issuance of notices begins
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

Commission To Be Fully Staffed After Four Years

PANAJI: The Goa State Human Rights Commission, which has been non-functional for the past six months, began functioning again on Wednesday after former high court judge U V Bakre took over as chairperson.

“Notices have been sent to parties and regular hearings will commence in March,” an official told TOI.

For the first time in almost four years, the commission will function at full strength, with former principal district judge Desmon D’Costa and former law secretary and judge Pramod Kamat as members.

There are over 300 cases pending before the commission. Besides, there are 100 complaints that were inwarded over the past six months but could not be registered as the commission was memberless. Former judge A D Salkar completed his term in July last year.

“The procedure has now started. The commission has begun checking the complaints and where it finds there is a violation of human rights, it has been directing that these be registered and that reports called for,” an official told TOI.

The rights panel never had a full-fledged commission after 2016, when former Patna high court chief justice P K Mishra completed his term as the commission’s first chairperson. The commission has been headless for almost four years, and, since member J A Keny died in September 2018, functioned with only Salkar as member.

Among the first cases the commission will hear, on directions of the high court, is the complaint of unhygienic food allegedly provided to police personnel during the the BRICS summit in 2016.

The hearing will commence on March 2.

The high court last week quashed the April 2019 inquiry report/order of the commission which had recommended that the director general of police impose appropriate penalty on the caterer, and the subsequent show cause notice issued by the police, and directed the commission to decide the matter afresh after offering opportunity to both advocate Aires Rodrigues and Amoncar classic caterers.

Complaints of human rights violations ranging from police assault, and denial of pension and salaries to pollution of waterbodies and poor condition of roads and bridges, have been filed before the commission.

Title: Polling to 55 Rajya Sabha seats to be held on March 26
Content:
This story is from February 26, 2020

A general view of Rajya Sabha (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Elections to 55 Rajya Sabha seats falling vacant in April will be held on March 26, the Election Commission announced on Tuesday.

Fifty-one of these 55 seats from 17 states are falling vacant on different dates in April due to retirement of sitting members, while four other seats are already vacant due to resignation of members. The terms of the members who had resigned in the recent past were also ending in April.

Prominent among those retiring are Rajya Sabha Deputy Chairman Harivansh (JD-U), Union minister Ramdas Athawale (RPI), Congress veteran Motilal Vora , former union ministers Vijay Goel ( BJP ) and Kumari Selja (Cong), and former Madhya Pradesh chief minister Digvijay Singh .

The Rajya Sabha seats that have fallen vacant include those of Home Minister Amit Shah , who resigned after his election to the lower House from Gandhinagar, and Arun Jailtley who passed away.

While seven vacancies are from Maharashtra, six are from Tamil Nadu, followed by five from West Bengal and Bihar, four each from Odisha, Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh, three each from Assam, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan, two each from Telangana, Chhattisgarh, Haryana and Jharkhand, one each from Himachal Pradesh, Manipur and Meghalaya.

While notification for the elections will be issued on March 6, the last date of filing nominations will be March 13. Counting will be held on the evening of March 26, an hour after conclusion of polls.

The ruling BJP and opposition Congress are expected to win most of the seats in the elections but the two will also see their strength diminished marginally.

Trinamool Congress and YSR Congress Party are expected to make significant gains in the 245-member Upper House.

Strength of the NDA is 106, including BJP's 82 members, well-short of the half-way mark in the House.
